PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Elector-Initiated Referenda
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. the right of the people of a country to make law independent of politicians should be a basic and independent right;
2. consequently there is an urgent need for constitutional reforms.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, should:
support the Constitutional Alteration (Electors Initiative) 1987 Bill to alter the constitution so as to vest in the electors power to propose laws and to approve or disapprove such proposed laws.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation: Commercial Sponsorship
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate of the Commonwealth in Parliament assembled.
The petition of these residents of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth:
that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation provides the citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia with the only nation-wide independent radio and television service;
that the independence of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation must be preserved in the interests of the citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia;
that the introduction of commercial sponsorship or any form of advertising material from commercial sources would destroy the independence of the Corporation.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the honourable senators will oppose the introduction of any form of sponsorship or advertising material from commercial sources into the programmes of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Casino: Australian Capital Territory
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
(1) That we are totally opposed to the proposal for the establishment of a gambling casino in Canberra or the Australian Capital Territory.
(2) That a casino in Canberra would detract from the unique character and status of our National Capital.

Your petitioners therefore most humbly request the Senate and the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to reject any proposal or legislation which would permit the establishment of a casino in the Australian Capital Territory.
And your humble petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Schools: South Belconnen Region, Australian Capital Territory
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Canberra respectfully shows:

The ACT Schools Authority has acted in an unfair and improper manner in rejecting, without notice or justification, the Planning Criteria of its Draft Plan ``Community Schools for Canberra 1989-2000'', in which context it had invited communities to respond and in reaching decisions that conflict completely with those criteria.

The ACT Schools Authority by acting in this way, has set a precedent for arbitrary school reorganization throughout the whole of Canberra, in which schools can be closed at any time without prior notice or consultation, and without effective justification.

The Page Community has been denied natural justice by the decision to close its neighbourhood school, because that decision was made without warning, without consultation, and without right of appeal.
The Page Community is the only one in Canberra that has been given no opportunity to respond to a specific draft proposal for closure of its school.
Your petitioners therefore pray that:
The Senate note our strong and united protest at the ACT Schools Authority's decision to close Page Primary School.

Noting that, the ACT Schools Authority identified only two options for school reorganization in the South Belconnen area, and that it has chosen to implement neither, and that the people of the ACT are shortly to be given the possibility of self government; the Senate resolve that no South Belconnen schools be closed until the ACT Schools Authority has:
(a) developed a complete and integrated plan for the educational needs of the South Belconnen area;
(b) developed and publicized educational and social criteria for maintaining, relocating, reorganizing or closing schools;
(c) assessed all schools against these criteria;
(d) presented these results for public review, with a full range of options; and
(e) allowed reasonable time for community consultation prior to decisions being taken and implemented.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Jenkins (from 503 citizens) and Reid (from 4,070 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Food Irradiation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the House assembled.
The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That we most strongly oppose the process of `food irradiation' by Cobalt 60, Caesium-137, Caesium-134 or any machine sources.
That we oppose the introduction of regulations that will facilitate the food irradiation process being permitted by State Governments.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the Federal Government ban the importation of any radioactive substances or machinery for the purpose of food irradiation, disallow regulations permitting the irradiation of food in Australia and ban the irradiation of food in this country.
We also call upon the Federal Government to withdraw from the Asian Regional Co-operative Project on Food Irradiation and the International Consultative Group on Food Irradiation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Food Irradiation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That there is widespread community concern about the proposal to irradiate food in Australia.
Your petitioners, most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, should:
(1) Block the introduction of food irradiation into Australia, and
(2) Ban the import of cobalt-60 and caesium-137 and caesium-134 to be used to irradiate food products,
And your petitioners as is duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pine Gap Defence Space Research Facility
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
1. The Agreement between the United States of America and Australia concerning the Joint Defence Space Research Facility at Pine Gap terminates on 19 October 1986.
2. In the event of war between the United States and the Soviet Union, access by the United States to Pine Gap's facilities makes it a probable nuclear target.
3. Access by all nations to Pine Gap's capacity to monitor and verify compliance with existing and future nuclear limitations treaties could contribute to world peace and security.
4. The people of Australia are entitled to be consulted, through their representatives in Parliament, on any extension or modification of the Agreement affecting their lives, security and welfare.
Your petitioners, most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, should decide that-
1. The Agreement between the United States and Australia concerning the Joint Defence Space Research Facility at Pine Gap not be extended beyond October 1986.

2. Public discussion and inquiry be instituted into the feasibility of negotiating a new agreement with the United Nations during the International Year of Peace offering the verification facilities of the Pine Gap base to all nations.
3. Any agreement concerning the future use of Pine Gap be referred to Parliament for ratification.
And your petitioners as is duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: X-Rated Video Material
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
We the undersigned,

note that a majority of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material has strongly opposed the proposition that a new NVE category will contain that material as defined in the current `X' classification

call upon the Senate to request the Government immediately to implement the recommendation of the majority of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material by introducing substantive legislation to ensure that X rated video material (and its R rated equivalent) is refused classification for the purpose of Commonwealth laws.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Fees
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament
The petition of the undersigned shows:
That:
The Australian Democrats were the only party to vote against tertiary fees in the Federal Parliament in 1986;

The Students' Association at the Canberra College of Advanced Education resolved on 11 November 1986 to encourage students to vote against candidates from parties which have voted for fees (unless they give a commitment to vote against tertiary fees), and for candidates from parties which have voted against fees in the next Federal election; and
That at present candidates from the Australian Democrats could be universally supported in accordance with this motion, unlike those from the ALP, Liberal, and National parties.
Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should:
Note that many students will vote against candidates who support tertiary fees, and request any legislation imposing fees on tertiary students be rescinded.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Human Embryo Experimentation Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled-

The petition of the undersigned expresses concern that some scientists in Australia are intent on undertaking destructive experimentation on human embryos. This subject was examined exhaustively by the 1985-1986 Senate Select Committee on Senator Harradine's Human Embryo Experimentation Bill which received 270 submissions and more than 2,000 pages of evidence. The report of the Senate Committee recommended in October 1986 that the Commonwealth Government make unlawful any destructive experiment which frustrated the development of the human embryo.
Your petitioners therefore request the Senate and the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to:
Implement without delay the major recommendation of the Senate Select Committee to outlaw destructive experiments on human embryos.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Constitutional Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
Every citizen should have-
1. A constitutional guarantee of the right to vote and
2. A constitutional guarantee of the equality of votes.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, should-
Support the Constitution Alteration (Democratic Elections) 1985 Bill
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom: Metered Calls
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the introduction of time-charging for local telephone calls by Telecom Australia would seriously disadvantage thousands of elderly and disabled people and families, and would add a further burden to the already prohibitive cost of living borne by every Australian.
That accordingly the Senate and Parliament should reject any plans by Telecom to time-charge local telephone calls.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Committee of Inquiry into Folklife in Australia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:

That hitherto the Government of Australia has neglected to accord the areas of Folklife in Australia the recognition, appreciation and support we consider to be due; and which are needed to safeguard the existing, prevent the loss of, and promote the development of the Australian Cultural Heritage.
Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament Assembled, should:
Support the recommendations of the Executive Summary of the Committee of Inquiry into Folklife in Australia; namely the establishment of:
an Australian Folklife Centre
an Australian Folklife Grants Scheme to be administered by the Australian Folklife Centre
a National Collection of Australian Folklife
a Folk Arts Committee within the Australia Council
a Folk Arts Grants Program under the control of the Folk Arts Committee.

PETITION.TITLE: Relocation of Cappuccino Machine in the New Parliament House
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament.

The petition of the undersigned shows that we have it on good authority that there is no intention of relocating the Cappuccino machine from the existing cafeteria to the new Staff cafeteria in the New and Permanent Parliament House.
Your petitioners ask that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should direct that said Cappuccino machine should be carefully restored to its former glory in the New and Permanent Parliament House.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to have the Government's response to the Senate Standing Committee on Science, Technology and the Environment report on technology assessment in Australia incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The response read as follows-
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE TO THE SENATE STANDING COMMITTEE ON SCIENCE, TECHNOLOGY AND THE ENVIRONMENT RECOMMENDATIONS-TECHNOLOGY ASSESSMENT IN AUSTRALIA

The Government has examined the seven Recommendations put forward by the Senate Standing Committee on Science, Technology and the Environment in its Report `Technology Assessment in Australia', tabled in this House on 29 April 1987.

The Government commends the Committee on its detailed consideration of issues so pertinent to Australia's future. Changes in the emphasis in community and labour movement concerns, and the success of other measures introduced in recent years by the Government, have however to a large extent overtaken the specific recommendations for action given in the report. Technological change is not a single issue. Rather, it covers a number of issues including wealth generation, employment and job security, working and physical environment, investment, labour relations, education and equal opportunity issues. The Government has developed policies in each of these areas which are in accordance with the social aspirations of the community. Implementation of these policies has led, or is leading, to resolution of some of the concerns raised in the report, and to changes in the priorities of the Australian community.
The Government's response to this report therefore has been framed within the following context:
across all sectors technology is providing new challenges and opportunities; whether through improved management methods and ways of doing things, or through new products and inputs;
technological change is essential if Australia is to increase its international competitiveness;

there have been significant changes in the concept of technology assessment from a focus on `impacts', and thus a concept of technological change as a problem, to one of negotiated outcomes, where technology is seen as but one of many items of negotiation between employers and employees;

finally, technological change is an important element in achieving a more productive culture-this will involve changes in many inter related areas such as education, training, industry award structures and general attitudes towards technology within the community.

The major conclusions of the report fall into three areas. Firstly, the necessity to stimulate greater consultation in the workplace on the broader effects on the labour force of technological change. Elements of this include the timely provision of information on the effects of specific innovation, and consultation on the innovation which will enable those who are affected by the innovation to influence its introduction. In this way social costs are not borne by one sector of the community, and broader social costs and benefits are not overlooked by narrower private interests. The report recommends substantial new legislation of workplace consultation.

The second area concerns the establishment of a data-bank on the implementation of technology and the resulting social effects, including possible alternatives that may better suit community needs. This data-bank would be available to the community, especially to those groups faced with extensive and rapid change, and would provide resources for a more balanced community educational program on technological change and its effects, and alternatives in implementing this innovation.

The third area is the establishment of a body dedicated to undertaking assessments of particular technological changes and research into the social consequences of technological change. This would include studies at levels closer to specific industries and enterprises than previously, and ties in closely with the two areas outlined previously.

Sections of the union movement, and its peak body the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU), have on several occasions expressed concerns over the introduction of technology without consultation with the workforce. These concerns have to do with job loss, work design, health and safety, deskilling and training, and career structure. They are also associated with the unions' recognition that technological change is essential and that, given the opportunity, employees can make a very positive contribution. ACTU policy, expressed through its biennial congress, is to increase the level of consultation and effective participation of employee organisations in the process of technological change.

Change often entails stress for those involved. Concern over the process of change, and the level of participation in decision making of those affected by that process, is understandable, particularly where there may be alternatives.

Contemporary technological change is characterised by two major factors. Firstly, the change is pervasive, that is, it is affecting all sectors of the community to a greater or lesser extent. The nature of the change, largely through microelectronics and communications technology, is such that national economies can no longer effectively isolate themselves from international pressures for change.

Secondly, the rate of change is rapid and increasing. Decision making must be equally rapid if opportunities are not to be lost. A lost opportunity, in the international context, may well represent a firm, if not, an industry which will not survive.

The Government is aware of the benefits that may flow from legislation to regulate and increase the level of consultation which should take place prior to technological change, but is also mindful of the cost penalties which may be involved, both in direct costs and in time lost, which can result in lost opportunity. The Government encourages improved consultation and participative employment practices and would prefer to see these processes progressed on a voluntary basis, guided by agreement between the industrial parties. In this context legislation may become appropriate if such agreement has proved insufficient.

The Government would not wish to be precipitate about introducing further regulation of the business sector, where a clear need has not been established and alternative means to achieve the purposes of the proposed legislation are available. Indeed, a major emphasis of Government policy throughout its last two terms has been to deregulation, an emphasis accepted and largely approved by the labour movement and the business community.

An alternative approach, which has the marked advantage that it can be tailored to specific labour skills and, to a large extent, to specific industry conditions, is through establishment of Award conditions outlining the information, timing and consultation required in cases of technological change. It has the added advantage that these standards are agreed between employers and employee representatives, and can accordingly be varied as appropriate. The potential for conflict is thereby reduced as both parties have had input to the agreed standards. The ACTU, in its evidence to the Committee, expressed satisfaction with this approach to technological change consultation. The later report to the ACTU, `Australia Reconstructed', by the members of the ACTU/Trade Development Council Mission to Western Europe, expresses greater concern over the issue of promoting investment (including technological investment) by industry than with the issue of controlling the process of technological change.

As indicated before, the nature of the debate has to some extent changed since the Committee took evidence and developed its findings. The necessity for technological change in order to enhance Australia's internationally competitive capability is more widely appreciated in the community, and the effects of technological change are becoming more clearly understood. Technology is seen as one of a range of factors in the strategy to achieve socially desirable outcomes from Australia's integration on a wider base than before in the world economy.

The development of industry plans for appropriate sectors of the economy, with technological change as an integral part of these plans, has assisted in establishing the role of technology in the broader perspective. The plans are to provide more stable planning horizons for selected major industries, and to encourage employer/employee consultations to become more routine in these industries. Models have been developed for businesses to plan rational strategies for survival and growth-not least of these being the World Competitive Manufacturing program developed by the Commonwealth-State cooperative National Industry Extension Service (NIES). In parallel with this program is the Contribution of Labour Program, a strategic product being developed by NIES in recognition of the importance of human resources to the development of world class Australian firms. Encouraging employee consultations and participation are essential parts of these models.

The debate over technological change has in fact largely shifted to the measures necessary to educate the community in the skills required to facilitate technological change and to make best use of technology. Concentration is now on the technologies which will provide the industry base of the future. The recent Government initiatives in the area of technical education are a part of the response to community perceptions of the role of technology in Australia's future.

The data base on both the implementation of technology and its larger effects is expanding, although there is not at present a central repository of this information. The field is, however, so wide that it is sensible to look at coordinating those sources of information rather than attempting to gather them into one pool. They result from the activities of a diverse and growing range of bodies, which emphasise different aspects of technological change, undertaking studies on their own accounts. To centralise this process in a single body would risk the loss of the diverse perspective which is at present emerging.

The Committee expressed the view that social impact assessment of technologies should be separate from technology innovation studies, which have as their aim facilitating technological change. On this basis it recommends the creation of a separate Technological Change Council from the Technological Change Committee of the Australian Science and Technology Council (ASTEC).

The Government perceives technology assessment as an integral part of technology promotion. The effective integration of new technologies requires a full understanding of their impact on those immediately concerned and the wider community. It is not convinced that the creation of a separate Council, further distancing technology assessment and promotion, is the appropriate means to facilitate necessary technological change.

The Government recognises that the Technological Change Committee (TCC) of ASTEC has in its reports concentrated more on technology promotion than on the assessment of social impacts of change. Discussions will be pursued with ASTEC and the TCC to ensure their responsibilities are discharged with a broader viewpoint incorporating technology assessment.

The Government believes that both ASTEC and the Commission for the Future should have continuing responsibilities in technological change. As set out in its latest annual report, the Commission for the Future was established to encourage Australians to become involved in the economic and social opportunities made possible by scientific and technological developments. By explaining the social impacts of science and technology and fostering the development of an innovative, productive culture the Commission demonstrates that all Australians can influence the future through informed choice.

The Commission has successfully demonstrated its ability to undertake social assessment of specific technologies and of effects of technologies on disadvantaged groups. The impact of research into effects of technologies includes development of options for planning the introduction of technology into education and the workplace in order to avoid disadvantage. Further the Commission has already established a Clearing House on Future Issues which contains selected information on technological assessment issues from national and international sources.

The Senate Standing Committee has also developed recommendations on the external evaluation of the Grants for Industry Research and Development (GIRD) Scheme and the National Industry Extension Service (NIES), and on expanding the role of women in the ASTEC and TCC structure.

Evaluation of GIRD and NIES plays an important role in Government development of these measures. Careful consideration has indicated the minimum time which each will require for its effectiveness or otherwise to become apparent. Accordingly, it is intended to evaluate GIRD four years after its introduction (a year before its legislated life ends) and to evaluate NIES after three and a half years (1990).

The role of women in the workforce, and particularly in areas where they can influence decisions which affect the whole community, has long been a concern of this Government. Indeed the Commission for the Future has undertaken some significant work in the areas of technological change and the impact on women. Affirmative action, equal opportunity policies and anti-discrimination legislation have all been directed towards ensuring that not only women but all groups in the community who are under-represented in the decision-making areas of the community achieve a more balanced representation. The Government has been particularly active in this concern in its own organisations and administrative structures. Accordingly the Government supports the Committee's recommendation to increase the representation of women on ASTEC, and will be acting to implement the recommendations when circumstances permit.

The Report has highlighted many of the concerns of Government and the community in relation to technological change. Technological change is a diverse and dynamic field integral to many of the fundamental issues facing our society. Many of these issues are already being addressed or are achieving a consensus in the community. The Government believes that the Committee has identified many of the crucial issues facing the Government and the community, and will take account of the findings outlined in the report in further developing Government policy and the measures which effect them.
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE TO RECOMMENDATIONS

Recommendation 1: That the Senate review the operation of the Grants for Industrial Research and Development (GIRD) and the National Industry Extension Service (NIES) within two years of its commencing operations.

Response: The enabling legislation for GIRD established the scheme for a five-year period only. Similarly, the Agreements with the States which established NIES are for five years, though with provision for extension, and require a review of NIES to commence after three and a half years operation. There are provisions that GIRD and NIES be reviewed for effectiveness and the programs will continue to exist only if their effectiveness can be demonstrated. To commence reviews of GIRD and NIES after two years of operation would, however, provide insufficient time for either to demonstrate its effectiveness, and to assess the strengths and weaknesses of each. Further, a principal element of Government industry strategy is to provide a stable, predictable environment within which enterprises can develop effective business plans. To introduce further reviews at an earlier stage would introduce an element of uncertainty which would itself be likely to prove more costly to Australia than the benefits to be gained by the reviews. Consequently the Government does not intend to change the established and agreed arrangements for reviews of GIRD and NIES.

Recommendation 2: That priority be given to establishing within, or in association with NIES, a Clearing House for Information Material on the potential of new technological applications, and on the various problems that are faced in ensuring rapid adoption of these technologies.

Response: NIES is not, of itself, a single organisation, but rather an arrangement between the Commonwealth and States to rationalise and coordinate the delivery of services to industry. While NIES provides a general information service to industry, establishing an effective Clearing House for Information Material is not seen by the Commonwealth or States as a high priority at this point. Furthermore, it would require considerable additional resources, at a time when Commonwealth and State, staff and financial resources are constrained. The NIES network may, however, prove suitable for the dissemination of social impact information generated by organisations active in that area. The Government does not, therefore propose to establish such a function for the NIES network, but in association with the States will continue to monitor and guide the evolution of NIES, particularly with respect to its Contribution of Labour Pilot Program and the development of its National Database of Advanced Manufacturing Technologies. The Government also notes the efforts of the Commission for the Future in establishing a Clearing House on Futures Issues.

Recommendation 3: That a Technological Change (Sharing of Information) Act be introduced, requiring the provision of specific categories of information to employees and their unions in the course of consultation over technological change, and that such information also be lodged with a restructured `technological change council'.

Response: The question of legislating to require the sharing of information to employees and their unions has been under consideration in the context of Government measures to facilitate participative practices. It should be noted that the Confederation of Australian Industry (CAI) and ACTU have recently released a joint statement on participative practices which will operate as a framework within which participation can be progressed on a largely voluntary basis. Guidelines and principles for information sharing on such matters as technological change are presented in that statement. The need for legislative intervention in this area will now be assessed by the Government against the experience over the next year or so of voluntary adherence to the principles of the Joint Statement.
Recommendation 4: That the Government urgently implement the following recommendations made by the ASTEC/Technological Change Committee as a part of an educational campaign on consultation:

That the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations consult with the union movement, employees and employers, to produce detailed proposals for the implementation of a voluntary scheme of firm-based consultation between management and workers on the introduction of new and improved technologies, to serve as a model from which other firms in fact develop more effective consultation mechanisms.
The Committee adds the proviso that it believes that the information to be shared during consultations should be defined in legislation, and that the term `workers' should include their unions.

Response: The main thrust of the recommendation is already being addressed by a number of agencies, including the Department of Industrial Relations (eg through the industrial democracy programs funded by the Work Organisation Branch of that Department) and the Commonwealth/State NIES Contribution of Labour Program, but also through detailed guidelines on information sharing issued by the National Labour Consultative Council, and through the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission determinations in 1984 in the Termination, Change and Redundancy Case which opened the way for insertion of consultation provisions in Awards. The Metal Trades Federation of Unions has developed a broad model for employer-employee agreement on introducing technological change, based in part on the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission decision of May 1987. As outlined in the response to recommendation 3, the question of legislating on such issues as information sharing as a means of further supporting the development of consultative processes will be kept under review.
Recommendation 5: That a feasibility study into the establishment of an industry data bank be carried out as a matter of urgency.

Response: In establishing NIES, the Commonwealth Government has moved away from the direct delivery of programs and services to industry (leaving this primarily to the State Governments). The policy is intended to coordinate and rationalise the separately developed programs and technology strategies of the States, each established in the light of specific conditions and considerations in that State. In the first instance, the establishment of data banks on industry are the responsibility of the State governments, based on their perceived priorities. However, the NIES structure is an appropriate mechanism for coordination and this includes the development of data bases pertinent to industry. Accordingly, the Government does not intend to establish a separate industry data base and will not, therefore, commission a feasibility study.

Recommendation 6: That a Technological Change Council be established by restructuring the current ASTEC/Technological Change Committee to (a) carry out specifically impact-oriented assessments; and (b) manage a system of funding assistance to non-government organisations wishing to carry out technology assessments as a part of improving consultation in Australia. The Council should be provided with adequate resources.

Response: The Government notes the Committee's finding that the Technological Change Committee has not been able to discharge its full responsibilities in the area of technology assessment. The Government intends to pursue with ASTEC and the TCC the most appropriate means to ensure that a broader viewpoint which incorporates technology assessment is brought to ASTEC/TCC studies.
Recommendation 7: The membership of such a Council should ensure the representation of women's interests by women.

Response: The Government strongly supports this recommendation and notes the measures already taken by Government in the area of equal opportunity, and positive measures to increase the representation of women in all areas, particularly those of vital concern to women.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.10 a.m., pursuant to order the Senate will now proceed to Government Bills.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 10 May, on motion by Senator Tate:
That the Bill be now read a second time.
upon which Senator Vanstone had moved by way of amendment:
At end of motion, add: ``, but the Senate deplores the fact that:
(a) the Hawke Government's economic and social policies continue to cause a fall in living standards for Australian families, and
(b) the Prime Minister has refused to meet his 1987 election pledge that by 1990 no Australian child will be living in poverty''.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-By making a short statement at the start of the debate on the Social Security Amendment Bill, I may help facilitate some understandings people have about the Bill. I refer specifically to two amendments that have been circulated-one in the name of Senator Vanstone and one in the name of Senator Powell-concerning German restitution payments for the purpose of the pension income test. The Government sees that it has the same objectives in achieving a final outcome in this matter. However, given the fact that there has been a lot of confusion and probably there still will be unless a very clear outcome is achieved, we are prepared to adopt and support the amendment of Senator Powell on behalf of the Australian Democrats. We do so on the basis, firstly, that it would achieve the same objective that the Government requires; secondly, that it does not involve the administrative problems that the other amendment would; and, thirdly, that it would clear up the matter once and for all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shortness of time requires each of us to confine our comments to the most important sections of each measure before the Senate today. The important section of the Social Security Amendment Bill which attracts me relates to restitution payments made by the Federal Republic of Germany. I am grateful for the statement just made by the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Senator Bolkus). I am just disappointed that he has not chosen to adopt Senator Vanstone's amendment-but, again, we are seeking a common objective.

SPEECH.PARA: Victims of nazi persecution receive payments from the West German Government, and those payments are compensation for imprisonment, wrongful arrest, torture, loss of families and loss of livelihood. The problem here is that there has been continuing argument over the years as to whether those payments are income for the purposes of various income tests applied by the Department of Social Security in assessing entitlements to Australian pensions.

There are theoretically three ways in which this matter could be fixed. The first would be by some executive action or by administrative instructions from the Department of Social Security. This has been tried and has not worked. I will set out the reasons for that in a moment. The second way is by subordinate legislation, by a regulation, and the third is by amendment to the statute. We believe as a result of long and bitter experience in this matter that only the last option will do the job. Only a statutory amendment will provide the protection to these people.

The problem does not involve the stated intention of this Government or of governments that have preceded it. Governments have said that they want to ensure freedom of these payments from the income test. The trouble is that the Department of Social Security either has not been able or has not been willing to administer the rules to produce that effect.

The history of the matter is as follows: Many people who suffered under the nazi regime in Germany in the 1930s and 1940s fled to Australia. After the war the West German Parliament passed the Federal Restitution Act to provide the victims of nazi persecutions with a pension in recognition of the grave injustices that had been perpetrated on them and their families. The pension is also payable to persons living abroad in countries with which West Germany has diplomatic relations. In the 1950s the Australian Federal Government wanted all those restitution moneys to be subject to income tax. The German Government threatened to stop paying restitution to Australian recipients on the grounds that the moneys paid were not intended and should not be used by the Australian Government for revenue raising purposes.

In 1959 the Australian Government exempted restitution payments from income tax assessment by amending the definition of `income' in the various Acts and by introducing a new paragraph (kc) into the Income Tax Assessment Act. The exemption was further clarified in 1982 when a further paragraph (kca) was inserted in section 23 of the Act. But when the means and assets tests were introduced for the age pension in 1983 the situation altered. Problems arose as to whether the restitution moneys should be included in the assessments. It is quite apparent from the previous amendments that that was not the intention of governments.

Originally the Department of Social Security wished to include all restitution payments in assessments of income for the old age pension. People objected and a number of applicants appealed to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. The watershed case was Artwinska v. Department of Social Security. In that case, mounted by Mrs Edwarda Artwinska, the Administrative Appeals Tribunal held that a pension paid to an applicant under the Federal Restitution Act should not be taken into account as income in determining her entitlement to benefits under the Social Security Act. That decision was supported later in the Administrative Appeals Tribunal in the case of Kolodziej v. Secretary of the Department of Social Security. However, the situation did not end there. Although Mrs Artwinska won her case, and although the later case was won, the Department of Social Security again decided to appeal and won a subsequent appeal. In Mrs Artwinska's case the Tribunal found:

In short, the definition of `income' under S.6 of the Social Security Act 1947 does not comprehend or encompass restitution payments. The purpose of such payments is totally distinguishable from any other type of payments answering the description of `income'.

The Tribunal determined that the Department of Social Security should pay the costs. On 9 October 1985 Senator Janine Haines of the Australian Democrats introduced a private senator's Bill to seek to exempt all restitution moneys from assessment. To the best of my knowledge that Bill has never been determined. Senator Powell says this amendment will determine the matter. So would our amendment have determined the matter, but we are grateful that some amendment will determine it.

The Government's response at the time was to say that it would encompass the exemptions in a ministerial directive. In fact, there was a ministerial directive added to the departmental manual on 23 December 1985, in paragraph 5.295 and subsequent paragraphs. Problems arose within the Department as to how different branches handled applicants, and even how individual applicants were handled in a single branch. Further representations were made to the Minister because the departmental manual was not sufficient to ensure that all the people receiving restitution payments were treated in a similar fashion or that they were treated equitably. Some applicants were asked to bring all documents to be translated, which could have entailed suitcases of German documents, taking ages to translate. Others were asked to get specified information from the West German Government on the breakup of their payments, and the West German Government has refused to provide such details.

In 1987 the situation was complicated still further because the Department of Social Security appealed against the principle of the Artwinska decision, and in fact the Department won that appeal. It was held in that judgment:

. . . such payments to the applicant will continue to be regarded as `income' unless exemption is made in the Act in equivalent terms to that contained in Subs. 23(kc) inserted by the Income Tax and Social Services Contribution Assessment Act (No. 2) (1959) and Subs. 23(kca) inserted by the Income Tax Assessment Amendment (No. 4) Act (1982).

In other words, the appeal judgment said that if we want to resolve the situation we have to insert in the Social Security Act the same provisions as we had in previous Acts. That is now what we wish to do. Since then the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) has introduced an amendment to the Social Security Amendment Bill, now before the Senate. The Government has done this to try to honour a promise to find an effective solution to the restitution payments problem. But the amendment the Government has introduced does not do what it purports to do. It does not resolve the problem. The Government's amendment goes round in a circle. It purports to add a new definition of `exempt income' with the proposed new subparagraph (ka), but it then adds a rider to that definition to exclude what it calls `an amount expressed to be paid for lost income'. In other words, this will put the matter right back into the Department for departmental interpretation, leading to the same unsatisfactory process we had before.

Those who are in receipt of compensation for being incarcerated either in concentration camps or ghettos, or both, are assessed using a very complicated formula. This is why the Government's formula will not work. They are assessed on a percentage basis for loss of health, and a component of loss of health may be described nominally as a loss of earning capacity. The Government's proposed amendment could be interpreted by the Department, and on past experience might be interpreted by the Department, in such a way as to put this restitution payment back under the rubric of income. In other words, the purpose of the Government's amendment would then be defeated.

There is a group of people who come under the Reichversicherung rules; that is, they would have been working in Germany between the years 1933 and 1939 and automatically under the then German legislation would have had sums deducted from their salaries, similar to compulsory superannuation payments. As a result of the nazi restitution laws in 1949, some of these people qualify for entitlements. Under the Government's proposed amendment these entitlements could still be interpreted as income for the purposes of the income test. Besides all this, I am not at all sure it is wise to have an interpretation built in, as the Government's amendment seeks to do, which again limits the application of the exemption by any amount defined as being income. For that reason it is necessary for us to proceed to look for another solution.

We are grateful that the Government has produced some amendment: that at least is a token of its good faith in this matter. It is doing no more than seeking to put into the Social Security Act what already existed under income tax assessment procedures. It is a proper amendment but the amendment which the Government has introduced is not sufficient to achieve the purpose it set out to achieve; it is a defective amendment. Both the Opposition and the Australian Democrats have recognised that. Senator Vanstone has proposed an amendment which we believe would have put the matter beyond doubt. Senator Powell has produced an amendment, and we now learn from Senator Bolkus that it is the Government's intention to support the amendment produced by Senator Powell and the Australian Democrats. I must say that I am sorry that Senator Vanstone's amendment has not been chosen, but I do not really mind. At the end of the day I want the matter fixed. It is my hope that we will adopt an amendment-it looks as if it will be Senator Powell's amendment-acceptable to all parts of the Senate which will fix this matter once and for all and which will place beyond any doubt the status of restitution payments made to probably less than 1,000 old, sick people who were the victims of nazi persecution in a dark age almost half a century ago. I hope that the Government will accept the amendment which is being offered from the opposite side of the chamber in a spirit of compromise and in the pursuit of justice for the small group of aged people about whom we are speaking and for whom we are making these representations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in the second reading debate on the Social Security Amendment Bill 1988 with mixed feelings. The Australian Democrats are pleased to support this Bill, which is a straightforward machinery measure. It introduces amendments to the Social Security Act which in fact we sought from the Government last year. It also clears up some anomalies in the Social Security Act which, again, we identified during debate last year. The amendments which we had sought and which the Government is now introducing in this legislation include allowing sickness benefit recipients to receive benefit in arrears for a period in which they were too sick to lodge a claim for benefit. The previous time frame was impossible for some people, not necessarily a large number of people, and we are pleased to see that the Government is exercising some compassion in this area.

SPEECH.PARA: The moves in terms of the restitution payments which Senator Peter Baume has referred to in his contribution were, we believe, an attempt to straighten out some administrative problems. The Government's subsequent expression of support for the Democrats' amendment makes it clear that, as the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Senator Bolkus) said at the beginning of today's debate, the Government's intention has been to do the right thing by those people who are receiving German restitution payments. We certainly welcome that outcome. Last year we moved amendments to extend eligibility to recipients of supporting parent's benefit and in this Bill the Government is extending eligibility to those parents whose child is eligible for the child disability allowance. We certainly welcome that.

I have a further amendment along that line, which I will refer to in a moment, to extend further the eligibility for supporting parent's benefit to those supporting parents whose child is still in secondary education. As I said, the legislation also clears up some anomalies which we had been concerned about. They include the inconsistency in the application of assets testing of pensioners and beneficiaries, disadvantages caused to supporting parents unaware of their family allowance supplement entitlement until education payments were made and injustices caused to clients of the Department of Social Security by failure to allow for a large drop in income from a preceding period. The relevant dates are cleared up in this legislation, as are some anomalies caused by defining categories of the disabled in narrow and divisive ways.

It gives me pleasure to see the Government amending the Social Security Act to ensure that all categories of disabled are referred to specifically. Since the International Year of Disabled Persons the physically, intellectually and psychiatrically disabled have been seen within the disabled community and support groups as distinct groups. It is good to see that the Government is now introducing its own amendments, following a process of Democrat amendments to reinstate the psychiatrically disabled in the legislation. This was the case when former Senator Grimes was Minister for Community Services, and was something that was supported by the Opposition. Last year the Government itself supported a Democrat amendment to include the psychiatrically disabled in some social security legislation. The Government is now finally accepting that it is in the interests of those people to be included in legislation.

I would like to make some comments on the second reading speech and on general Government policy statements before I speak to my amendments. I find the Government's attitude to social justice, as expressed in its strong assertions, increasingly difficult to accept. The Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) assured us in his second reading speech that we can, on the one hand, continue to cut government spending and, on the other hand, meet the needs of Australians with income support. It was announced in the recent mini-Budget that measures would be taken to support and further advantage the business corporate sector. There was nothing in the mini-Budget of great significance, with the exception of the increase in the tax rebate for pensioners and beneficiaries. There is nothing of great significance for that large number of people in our community who are still dependent on the Government for income support and for services to reduce their dependency over time.

As the Australian Council of Social Service, the peak welfare body, has pointed out in its response to the mini-Budget, the Government needs to recognise that with the reduction in the rate of tax on business and the failure to introduce a gold tax at this point, it has forgone revenue. The low income people and the dependent groups in our community will have to pay for that. This means that many social justice measures are still necessary. That is not to say that the Government has not introduced measures over time. The problems the Democrats continue to have with the protestations of strong social justice orientation is that these measures are applied slowly, they are applied grudgingly and they are applied in a manner which is too piecemeal.

On the one hand, the Government's economic strategy seems to have a clear view-which is pushed on it by its corporate mates-of what business needs but, on the other hand, it does not seem to have a clear view of what is necessary for low income people. Two million Australians are still living in poverty. They are attempting to get out of that situation when the Government does not have an integrated approach to the problem. The business tax rate has been reduced from 49c to 39c, and personal income tax cuts are promised at the top level. It is significant that there is a difference of 10c in the dollar between business tax and the top personal tax. We will see what we have seen before-rorts. People will get into corporate setups and avoid their personal tax liabilities. Yet there has been no talk at all, not even a whisper, except from the Democrats in their mini-Budget proposals which were put the week before the mini-Budget, that the tax free threshold should rise for low income people.

Certainly, the pensioners' rebate has been increased so that pensions will not be taxable, as they would have been if that had not happened, but there are still very many low income earners and pensioners who can earn only $10 a week above their pension level before they fall into the tax bracket. This is happening at the hands of a government which is reducing the tax liability for the corporate sector, which on average last year paid only 28c in the dollar. The Australian Democrats have said quite often that we would be happy if the corporate sector actually paid something like its tax threshold. As a group, its contribution to the tax base, the government revenue base, has gone down significantly in the past decade or so and the pay as you earn taxpayer is paying more. While the top rates go down, obviously the lower income earners will pay more. That squeeze is hurting. While the Government has introduced new payments for children and has increased some of its rent allowances and so on, it is still a very piecemeal approach when the basics are not handled.

While we welcome many of the measures, we do not agree necessarily with the Minister when he claims in his second reading speech that social security policy is an area which shows a fundamental difference between the Government and the coalition. No-one should be fooled by this pretence that the Australian Labor Party and Liberal and National parties in the Parliament really have policies which are in fundamental opposition. The coalition continues to support Government legislation, particularly when it comes to Budget Bills, whatever happens. We heard Senator Stone in the mini-Budget Bills debate yesterday expressing considerable delight with the Government's moves and simply saying that perhaps the Government was not taking moves fast enough. What we have seen-and I am referring to the tax levels-is a move towards a much flatter tax base. Should the tax free threshold rise, obviously that will be the case even more so. The better off in the community are having their tax burden reduced significantly and the responsibility for the rest of the community has decreased.

While we are talking about tax liabilities, the Government has an extraordinary proposal, which it intends to impose on the Labor Party, if it can, at the upcoming Labor Party Conference, to put an additional tax burden on another group of people in the community simply because they have undertaken tertiary education at some stage. This is totally against two principles. The first is that anybody who earns a high income has a responsibility to make a more significant contribution to the general revenue base; in other words, a progressive income tax system. The second is that education should be freely available to all with totally open access regardless of income either at the time of undertaking the education or at any future time. Thus, the Government is creating enormous anomalies and potential barriers for people making decisions about their further education. One of those principles relates to our future economic development, which governments should have at the front of their minds. This country needs to take further steps in the area of science and technology because it is lagging behind. We have a government which says that it wants young people to stay in education longer--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Powell, you are getting rather a long way from the Bill before us. I can understand your remarks on the availability of resources. This is rather off the subject of the Bill.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy President. I am referring to remarks by the Minister in his second reading speech and to claims that his Party has a certain direction, which I think is called in question-and I will just conclude with this particular example-by the fact that one result will be that people will be less likely to become science teachers than history teachers since they will be paying more tax when the corporate sector is paying less.

SPEECH.PARA: Specifically on the amendments which I will be moving, I want to refer very briefly to the German reparation payments. To the Democrats' delight the Government has seen that administratively the most efficient way to ensure that restitution payments are exempted is to exempt them purely from any income testing, which is what the Democrats' amendment does. It was proposed in the early private member's Bill in 1985 by Senator Haines. We are delighted with it. This is an important group of people. As the German Government has said, they should not be used in any way as a revenue-raising exercise for the Australian Government. We welcome the Government's support for the amendment and the Opposition's support for the same principle, as expressed by Senator Baume.

Another one of my amendments seeks to reduce the difficulties which are experienced by people attempting to get the youth homeless allowance. The amendment reduces the qualifying period for eligibility and the administrative difficulties in assessing eligibility. I commend the amendment to the Senate. The efficiency and effectiveness of this allowance have been seriously undermined by unreasonably restrictive guidelines. A report by the Young Homeless Allowance Reform Group has shown that many young people are excluded from receiving the allowance because of the administrative problems and the strict criteria which apply. The Democrat amendment, to which I made a commitment in March, will make the allowance more accessible.

Youth homelessness is a major problem. Mr Brian Burdekin, the Human Rights Commissioner, said in March that, although no one knows exactly how many, there are thousands of homeless young people in our society. In Melbourne alone it is estimated that there are more than 2,000 young people without housing on any given night. Yet only a handful, a hundred or so, are able to prove eligibility for the youth homeless allowance. The Democrats, therefore, commend the amendment to the Senate.

The third amendment relates to increasing eligibility for the supporting parent's benefit, to make it available to all supporting parents whose children are still in secondary education. As I said, the Government has done something in this Bill for parents with disabled children. We commend to the Government the needs of supporting parents, particularly the needs of their children. The Government's proposals to have more young people stay at school and complete their secondary education are strongly supported by the Australian Democrats. The Government needs to realise that since the changes in eligibility for the supporting parent's benefit, evidence suggests that there has been considerable stress on many sole parent families whose older children want to stay in secondary education. Whilst the Government may say that other payments are available, the family dynamics-particularly the relationship between women and their teenage children-are often such that what the Government envisaged has not occurred. We believe that the best way to deal with this is to loosen eligibility for the benefit in line with the Government's policy to have children stay in secondary schooling. A good report by the Brotherhood of St Laurence entitled `Sole Parents and the 1987 Amendments to the Social Security Act', put together by Helen Morris and Jenny Threthewy, concludes:

The mismatch of this policy change, its stated objective, and the kinds of sole parents affected was also noted. Sole parents reported new hardships as a result of the change. Women who have been out of the work force caring for children for many years, who have few educational qualifications and little work experience, require time, secure income support, and opportunities for further education and training if they are to return to work successfully.

Sixteen years is too vulnerable an age for an adolescent child to be left unsupervised. It was thought more appropriate that the option of a supporting parent's pension remain open until the youngest child in the family had completed secondary school. . .

I move this amendment in the spirit of that report, although my amendment was drafted before the report came out. I commend my amendments to the Senate. I support the measures the Government has introduced in this legislation and urge the Government to take these issues into serious consideration.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sheil Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are moving right along in this debate on the Social Security Amendment Bill 1988 in the shadow of a guillotine which was supported by the Australian Democrats. Now the Democrats are monopolising the time available for debate.
—It is an absolute disgrace.

—Yes, it is a disgrace. The Social Security Amendment Bill 1988 is a very wide-ranging Bill, as undoubtedly it has to be, because social security consumes 28 per cent of our Budget-billions and billions of dollars. As such it needs this fine tuning adjustment as we move along. The amendments contained in this Bill make me think that the Department of Social Security is in the grip of a boa constrictor. When the Department gets the coils off one limb it then has to fight because it finds the coils around another limb. The aims and objects of the Bill, as mentioned in the second reading speech of the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe), are:

SPEECH.PARA: to ensure that every Australian resident obtains adequate income support as and when it is needed.
to protect the revenue by ensuring that payments are not directed to those who do not require them.

Those are very worthy goals which I am sure are shared by honourable senators on both sides of the House as well as by people in the Department of Social Security. However, the changes proposed in the Bill will hardly bring into effect the aims the Minister is talking about. I suppose that the whole problem results from the promising of huge welfare payments all the time. I think it is the old Confucian proverb gone wrong. Confucius said, `If you give a poor man a fish, he will eat for a day; but if you teach him to fish, he will eat forever'. The bleeding hearts of this world have changed that proverb to say, `That is no good. If you teach a man to fish, he will eat fish forever; you have to give him money so he can pick and choose what he eats'.

Throwing money at poverty really is subsidising poverty. If the Government subsidises poverty it will get more of it. That is what is happening in Australia today. We need look only at the reports of all the committees that have inquired into poverty to see the enormous increase in problems. I think there are 400,000 children in Australia today existing below the poverty level. We are 160,000 housing units behind in the housing program. The problem is not getting better because the Government has attacked with promises of welfare. There is no mention anywhere that welfare should be temporary to get people over a rough spot. Instead, that welfare goes on and on, thus creating a welfare industry. It is not remarkable that there are many political advocacy groups that are utilising taxes. They have sprung up because various groups realise they can get their noses in the public trough. They are not as representative as they should be. They claim to have a huge membership and democratically elected executives. However, they really have not. Their memberships are low; they are in the grip of the executive. They are professional lobby groups that can drag money out of the Government.

In regard to families, this legislation is supposed to be a family support package. It is not a family support package at all, it could be described more accurately as a family maintenance package. Ordinary families in Australia are starting off, as of today, $42 a week worse off than they were five years ago. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) made that grandiose promise that no child in Australia would go hungry by, I think, the turn of the century. However, we have to look only at the increasing numbers of children whose position is worsening as a result of the present policies to see that this is not so.

It is impossible to deal with every aspect of this Bill in the few minutes I have to speak. The restitution payments to the people who suffered under nazi Germany have had a checkered history. I am pleased to see that the problem is about to be fixed. I am also pleased that we have been able to come to some agreement on the amendments that have just been circulated. I know that the Opposition has one amendment and the Australian Democrats have two others. The Government has decided to accept the Democrats' amendment. We are reasonably happy about that because, generally, we are moving in the same direction. The Opposition is not opposed to the Bill, but I point out that if we keep subsidising poverty, we will get a lot more of it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe), in his second reading speech on the Social Security Amendment Bill 1988, stated very clearly-and I entirely agree with him-that no area more fundamentally shows the difference in approach between the Labor Government and the conservative Opposition than this area of social security. I agree with that statement wholeheartedly. The Opposition parties do not rely on the rhetoric of the Australian Labor Party. Let us look at some of the rhetoric that this Government has indulged in very recently, because it is important that people in the community understand exactly what that rhetoric is. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), prior to the last election, stated very clearly in a speech that no child will live in poverty by the year 1990. It was a ridiculous statement, and he has now backed away from that rhetoric. Indeed, none of the Government senators would agree with that rhetoric.
—Ha, ha!
—Senator McKiernan is laughing at the proposition.

—Indeed, as the Opposition Whip says, the Acting Government Whip is laughing at the proposition that the Prime Minister could possibly try to hoodwink the community into believing that he is capable of fulfilling that undertaking. Last weekend, we saw the same sort of stupid headlines in the Weekend Australian, that this Government thinks will be believed by the community. It will not work because the Government has lost touch with the grass roots. The Prime Minister said that the delays in personal tax cuts-the Government refused to introduce them in the mini-Budget-would immediately raise living standards. Again, it is unsubstantiated rhetoric and it cannot occur because the banks, in response to that message, immediately put up their interest rates for home buyers.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me turn to the problem that this socialist Government has. In the community there is a misconception that this is not a socialist government. Let people understand very clearly that this Government believes that it can spend public money, people's hard earned income, better than the families can. It has said, `We will take tax from you, we will not give you tax cuts, because we know that you may spend the money irresponsibly. We will give you back just as much as we think you should have'. Let me give the Senate a lovely example. The example I choose concerns legislation that was passed fairly recently, a few months ago, in regard to a family allowance supplement. In regard to this supplement the Government said, `There is a certain group of low income earners to whom we will give an additional amount of money'. That sounds very magnanimous, but let us look at what it is actually doing. For example, a single income earner with a dependent spouse and two children earning $330 a week gets $35 from the Government supplement. That is all very nice, but in point of fact he is taxed to the tune of $40.39. So this single income earner on $330 a week pays a tax of $40.39 and the Government gives him back $35 of it. It rips off the tax and then gives him back $35 of it because he is a low income earner. But what happens when that man decides that he wants to be responsible for his family and wants to earn a bit of overtime? If that man works 7 1/2 hours overtime, an extra day, he gets $90, but the Government takes off the handout, it takes off the $35 and taxes him in a higher bracket, and out of that $90 he gets $8.59. What man in Australia will work 7 1/2 hours to be given $8.59?

What this Government does is make sure that that family stays on the welfare. It makes sure that that man says, `I am not going to work overtime, I am not going to take on the responsibility of looking after my family. I will stay on welfare and put out my hand for the $35'. Why does the Government not say to that low income family, `You have not got to pay the tax; we will cut your tax'? But no, it rips off the tax and then hands back $35. This means that that man has no incentive to work to look after his family responsibly and he then refuses to do any overtime.

Let us look at the two different philosophies. The philosophy of this Government is, `We will keep people on social welfare. We will make them dependent on the Government'. Our philosophy is to introduce systems such as child endowment. Mr Menzies introduced that in 1941. When the Fraser Government realised that there were a number of families who were not entitled to the child endowment because it was given back as a tax rebate, it introduced a system whereby low income families did get their child endowment, and it was increased substantially, under the name of family allowance. So all the low income earners now get the family allowance. We did not tax them and give it back to them, but we gave it to them free of tax-a family allowance for all those low income families that did not earn enough to get a tax rebate.

That is the basic difference. I agree with the Minister that there is a fundamental difference between the two parties. Recently the Weekend Australian had an editorial on just that situation. As honourable senators realise, I have spoken about this many times in the Senate. I spoke about it yesterday and I spoke about it last year-

TALK.START.PARA: —You just go on and on and on.

—And as the Acting Government Whip says, I go on and on and on about this. It is so important that we not destroy the incentive of the people of Australia. I do go on and on and on, and I will continue to go on and on and on about this issue. The Weekend Australian gave a rather tidy example of just how this Government is destroying incentive. It said that, unfortunately, some welfare programs encouraged long term dependency on social welfare. There are in our community some disadvantaged groups-well defined groups such as homeless youth-which can never look after themselves, and the Government must look after them. That is the Australian way and I would hate to see that position ever deteriorate.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at an example that the Weekend Australian gave of how dependency can occur. Suppose a government decides that all people who smoke over 50 cigarettes a day put their lives unacceptably at risk. To combat this, that government decides to pay such people, who are duly certified by their doctor as cigarette addicts, $5,000 a year to quit smoking. Suppose a government said, `Everyone who smokes 50 cigarettes or more a day will be given $5,000 so long as they quit smoking'. Let us say that the program, in its first year, convinces 5,000 people to give up smoking. Its advocates can cite it as obviously very effective. However, the existence of the program has the unintended consequence of encouraging 10,000 more people to take up smoking 50 cigarettes a day to get $5,000 from the government to quit. Come the end of the day, those who had been smoking under 50 cigarettes a day are now smoking over 50 so they can get their $5,000 from the government, and we have 10,000 more people on welfare to get $5,000 by giving up smoking 50 cigarettes a day. The whole thing is just as simple example of how dependency can occur.

When I was on the former Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare, which looked into the illegal drug situation, we were given a very long term survey. Very few surveys of that nature have been done. The survey, which was taken over 30 years, was of two groups of delinquent children. One of the groups had had social welfare counselling for a number of years-I think for up to 10 years. Both groups were interviewed 30 years later. It was found that those in the group which had not had long term counselling by social workers had done very much better and were far happier with their lives than those in the group which had become dependent on long term counselling. I stress that the survey was done on two similar groups of youth and showed that those in the group that had had extensive long term counselling by social workers had become so dependent on social workers that they had not been able to cope as well when the counselling was taken away.

That is exactly what this Government is doing to the people of Australia. It is forcing people to become dependent. Why does the Government not take its hand out of people's taxes? Why does it not say to them, `You don't have to pay the $40 tax'? Why does it not say, `We believe you need the $35 that we are giving you; therefore we will not touch your tax', thus allowing them to earn money and be responsible for their families? I believe that the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) was 100 per cent correct in his second reading speech: there is very definitely a fundamental difference between the Government and the Opposition parties. Our whole philosophy is directed towards showing the people that they can be responsible for their families and towards creating incentive. The Government's socialist policy is to say to the people, `We'll tax you and we'll spend your money because we know how to do it a lot better than you do'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some people in the community are feeling great burdens of taxation and they feel left out by members of parliament and governments. Among those are the one-income earners with dependent spouses and children. As honourable senators will recall, in the 1970s I and a number of others developed a campaign on the question of families and family allowances. Some attempt was made to remedy the position, but it has now deteriorated to the extent that the overwhelming burden has been placed on those who earn wages and have a dependent spouse and some children. In particular, those in the middle income bracket, or the tradesman and above bracket, are feeling the pinch as has been indicated clearly by the taxation statistics which are available to honourable senators. In terms of average earnings the proportion paid in income taxation has increased significantly to an estimated level of three times that which existed in 1961-62. In other words, this year a taxpayer with a dependent spouse and two children is paying almost three times as much tax proportionately. The increase for single taxpayers has gone up by 60 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: What concerns me is that the Government has reduced corporate taxes but has ignored the most important business in Australia-that is, the business of bringing up families. Those with families are being discriminated against. They are being taxed blind and their family allowances have been frozen. That is a disgrace. Since 1976 these families have been robbed of more than $10 billion. They are the ones who will kick up at the next election. It is very important that the Government recognise that. The other day I spoke to somebody who is on a school board. He said that, whereas five or six years ago most of the requests for remission of fees were from low income earners, they are now from middle income earners; the middle income earners with families are suffering. It is very important-and I know some members of the Government are aware of the problem-for the policy makers in the Government to be aware of this because the reaction will come at the next election.
