DEBATE.TITLE: COMMUNITY SERVICES AND HEALTH LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 10 May, on motion by Senator Tate:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —This morning we are debating with limited time, because of the guillotine imposed on us by the Government and supported by the Australian Democrats, the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1988. This is a very important piece of legislation, a piece of legislation that in the coalition's view deserves a much more substantial debate than the guillotine will permit. But such is the management, or mismanagement, of Government business in this chamber and such is the fickle nature of the Australian Democrats, who frequently say one thing and do another. I am referring to their general pronouncements to the community that they want ordered debate in this chamber and in Parliament-although it does not concern them very much in the House of Representatives because they do not have any members there-they want sufficient time for debate and they want Bills to be considered properly. That is what they tell the community consistently. Yet, consistently, when it serves their own purpose they agree with the Government to gag debate.

SPEECH.PARA: In this instance they have agreed to a guillotine which, as you know, Mr Deputy President, has reduced the amount of time available for debate not only on this very important Bill but also on many others that are being jackbooted through this chamber as a consequence of two things. One is the Government's desire to get away to Tasmania and fix up the problems with its conference. We do not notice the Government saying that it is going to call off its conference, that it has important business to get through the Senate and that its responsibility is to the Parliament rather than to its own Party. No, instead the Government says, `Let's jackboot this all through and if we can do some cosy little deal with the Democrats we will'. The Democrats, being, as I have said, somewhat fickle and inconsistent, have agreed to that. I will not go on about that matter because it will cut down my own time to address some of the matters in the Bill before us.

As a nation we obviously seek to improve the opportunities for all, whatever their age and status in the community, but there are two groups who quite obviously deserve special care and attention. One group is the young, because the nation will be relying on them to build opportunities for everyone. That is a point at which we can make some real achievements in improving opportunities for people. The other group that deserves special attention is the aged. We should see care for the aged as a responsibility of the highest level. Indeed, we should see care for the aged as being a privilege in that they have made their contribution and we, who are capable of improving their lot and opportunities in the later years of their lives, should do so.

Aspects of a second reading amendment that I will move indicate the concern that we have for the ageing in the community, a concern that we do not believe is adequately shared by the Government. The matters that we are concerned with and that we believe are not appropriately addressed in this piece of legislation are as follows: We are concerned with the quality of care and the standards that are available to the ageing in our community. Obviously, it follows from that that we are concerned that there must be adequate staffing levels to care for the aged in our community in nursing homes and hostels. It follows from that that there must be adequate financial support for the aged care industry.

There are some in this community who believe that it is inappropriate to have an industry of aged care, that perhaps people ought not be able to make money out of looking after the aged. Of course, that is a ridiculous assumption. The aged need to be looked after. The Government is not going to do it, and we should be grateful that the private sector wants to fill that gap. We should be working with the private sector to give it every opportunity to care for the aged in the community at the level to which we believe they are entitled. Of course, if we are to have the appropriate quality of care and standards we have to have sufficient nursing home beds.

We are concerned about the practical consequences of this legislation. The Government does not seem to put much store on practical consequences. I use as an example of that its own legislation with respect to the referenda Bills, which was discovered last Friday to have a practical consequence that the Government did not want. As a result we have seen some very last minute changes, again jackbooted through this chamber with the support of the Democrats. That example shows that this Government does not pay sufficient attention to the practical consequences of the words that it puts in legislation before both chambers. That is quite obvious. But we are concerned with those consequences. Our reservations are shared by the industry, which has serious concerns with this legislation. It is no surprise that the Government has not taken industry views into account and does not give its views the same weight as we do. Consequently a portion of our second reading amendment requests the Government not only to consult closely with the industry but also to conduct a review of the standards for a classification incorporated in the residential classification instrument (RCI). It is typical of this Government to embark on a piece of legislation without adequate consultation and understanding, and that, as I say, is reflected in our second reading amendment.

Let me detail some of the concerns that have been expressed by the industry. On the one hand we have the Government, through its slick media machine, making much of extra staff care hours. Someone listening to the Government propaganda would undoubtedly endorse extra staff care hours and be pleased that the Government was doing that. They might think twice if they listened to what the industry had to say, because the industry says that the extra staff care hours add up to an extra 36 seconds per hour per day. Perhaps the Government should consider that; I hope Australians who are listening to this debate appreciate the point. The Government says it is giving extra staff care hours to the nursing home industry while the industry is saying, `Yes, that is true, but why doesn't the Government say it is only an extra 36 seconds per hour per day? You cannot give much extra care to a nursing home resident in 36 seconds'. Even if we put it all together and say it is another 12 or 13 minutes a day, it is not much. The Government makes much of its concern for quality care for the ageing in our community and yet the industry says that this legislation will force many people from nursing homes to hostels. Necessarily the level of care available to them will be lower. That has obvious implications for the standard of care that they will receive.

The major area of concern expressed by the industry surrounds the resident classification instrument. That is seen as being the means by which the Minister imposes on the community the standard of care that he will allow the industry to provide rather than what the industry may think is appropriate. As I understand it, the new proposals will be phased in. There is a reason for that phasing in. The Government does not want to face particularly Victoria and South Australia, Labor States which believe that nursing home standards in their States will suffer substantial reductions as a consequence of this legislation. It is because they are concerned that the Government is seeking to phase it in, to do it bit by bit and hope they do not notice. But any aged person in a nursing home is obviously going to notice. It does not matter whether it is done all in one lump or bit by bit, the Government will still in effect be reducing standards. People in all States, but particularly Victoria and South Australia are concerned with what they see as an impending reduction in nursing home standards.

One other matter the Government makes much of is an alleged $130m increase in funds. The industry says, `Why can't we get details of where that $130m is going to be spent?' It sounds very much like the Priority One: Young Australia promises. Honourable senators will remember them. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) promised three years ago that by our bicentennial year, this year, we would have 70,000 young people per annum entering traineeships. That was just a gigantic joke. It was a con job. When we asked for the details of the program we could not get them, and we realised that the details had not been sorted out. That was why we could not get them. I draw an analogy between the failed Priority One program that promised everything to young Australians and gave them nothing, because the detail had not been properly worked out, and the Government's claims of extra nursing home funding. The industry says it cannot find the details, and it does not think it is getting any extra money.

The Government, further, makes much of its fraud crackdown. All I want to say is that the powers are there; the Government can use them. It does not need to make a song and dance about a crackdown on fraud. No-one would suggest that we ought to allow fraud to continue in any area, least of all in the nursing home area. There is no need to politicise the nursing home area, but that is obviously what the Government is doing. It is playing politics with the aged, and there is an obvious reason for that. Many of the aged have limited financial resources and in many instances waning intellectual resources. They are not as capable as young Australians and those in the middle years of their life of arguing with the Government. They have to depend on other people to do it for them. They have to depend on the nursing home industry, the aged care industry, to do that. Of course, the aged care industry is always subject to the accusation by the Government and others, `But you are speaking from self-interest'. Of course they are not speaking purely from self-interest; they are speaking on behalf of many ageing Australians who cannot speak for themselves. My colleague Mr Blunt, the shadow Minister for Community Services and Health, quoted in the debate in the House of Representatives on 28 April some specific comments by members of the industry. In the limited time I intend to take up I will refer to a couple of those because they do reflect the attitude of the industry, of the people who are actually caring for ageing Australians, to the Government's legislation. In the Age newspaper of 25 April, in an article headed `New system for subsidising care for the elderly is a sham', a Mr McKernan, the Executive Director of the Villa Maria Society for the Blind, stated:
Under the proposed new system of categorising patients, it is almost impossible to have any patients in the top scoring bracket.
The categorising procedure gives no consideration to any allowance for sensory loss . . .
The industry does not believe its views have been listened to. I turn to what the Baptist Union of Victoria, another non-profit organisation, had to say:
For some reason unknown to us the Hawke Government refuses to listen to the workers in this matter.
More information from that quotation was provided in the other chamber, but I will limit the points I want to make. The Baptist Union said, in respect of the RCI:

There is no undertaking to review the system used to classify nursing home residents into five categories, despite the demonstrated fact that in its present form, very few nursing home residents come into category 1 unless the form is misinterpreted.
It also says:
The statement that residents in Victorian nursing homes would receive an average of 20 hours per resident per week means nothing until the level of Commonwealth payment per hour has been settled.

When this legislation was going through the House of Representatives those voluntary organisations and others to which I will not refer were clearly unhappy with the negotiations they had been having with the Government and the level of understanding they believed the Government had of them. As I indicated earlier, there are some groups in the aged care industry which are there because of a profit motivation. One of the major profit motivated groups in the industry is the Moran Healthcare Group. This is what it had to say:

The Resident Classification Instrument is basically designed so that service needs of residents fit into what the Minister is prepared to allow. Subjective assessment has replaced the objectivity of the Resident's General Practitioner.

I could go on with many more comments not only from the Moran Healthcare Group but from other profit motivated groups but I think the point has been made. As a consequence of the guillotine, the jackbooting of this legislation through the Senate, with the support of the Australian Democrats-who say that they will not support a guillotine-I think it is appropriate that I say no more to give my colleagues an opportunity to comment on this legislation. I move:
At end of motion, add: ``, but the Senate:
(a) is concerned that aspects of the Government's aged care policy will result in:

(i) a reduction in the quality and care standards for some aged persons through the use of inappropriate standards for the classification of nursing home and hostel residents in the Resident Care Instrument (RCI);
(ii) the provision of inadequate staff levels to provide appropriate standards of care for many frail aged patients, particularly those with sensory loss;
(iii) reduction in levels of financial support for the aged care industry which could threaten the financial viability of many facilities; and
(iv) insufficient exempt beds through the imposition of an arbitrary 6% limit; and
(b) requests the Government to not only consult closely with the industry, but conduct a review of the standards for classification incorporated in the RCI''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, a number of amendments have been moved on behalf of the Government and I seek leave at this stage to explain some of them in the spirit of trying to organise some agreement on them.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a number of amendments. The first seeks to rectify in clause 5 of the Bill a minor drafting error by the substitution of the word `benefit' for the word `prescribed'. The second amendment, which seeks to insert new clauses 29 and 30 into the Bill, is important. It represents the Government's response to amendments moved by the Opposition in the House of Representatives. In brief, those amendments sought to strengthen the anti-dumping provisions in the Bill. The Government carefully examined these proposals and accepted their thrust as supporting the Government's intention of making anti-dumping provisions effective. The Government's amendments would amend section 74 (5) of the National Health Act 1953 to do two things. Firstly, it would increase penalties on the public officer of a health benefits organisation which dumps or breaches any other condition of registration, provision or direction. The penalty is increased from $5,000 to $10,000. Secondly, the amendments would exclude a registered organisation from reimbursing the public officer for meeting any fine. Proposed new section 74ba essentially picks up in full the listing proposed by the Opposition in the other place of additional actions which may not be taken by a health benefits organisation seeking to dump a contributor. It imposes a fine of up to $50,000 on organisations which undertake such actions. As a result of the approach I outlined, paragraph (1g) in clause 30 of the Bill is now not required. The Government considers that its approach, as explained, achieves the objectives of both the Government and the Opposition in this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: During the lead-up to the debate on the Bill Senator Coulter expressed concern about the need to ensure proper consultation with various consumer, industry and professional bodies when the Government carried out reviews of its arrangements for the categorisation of nursing home residents. The Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples) wrote to Senator Coulter on 18 May 1988 indicating the Government's intention to involve relevant consumer organisations, industry associations and union and professional bodies in the monitoring process and in the subsequent review of the new arrangements. The Minister also gave his unqualified assurance that he would be seeking the advice of all the national bodies with an interest in arrangements for care of the aged and that he would take account of that advice in regular review of the principles governing the new resident classification instrument and the associated program arrangements.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1988 seeks to change the operation of a number of Acts of this Parliament but in particular it seeks to modify two aspects of legislation. One is to do with hostels and nursing home care services, their funding, the arrangements by which patients will be assessed, and the hours which will be allocated to patients. That matter was addressed by Senator Vanstone. The other main area concerns the pre-existing ailments provisions in relation to the transportability of benefits within the health insurance system.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to the nursing homes and hostels provisions. The Bill represents the implementation of stage four in a Government strategy which has been developed over a period. It is therefore to be seen in the context of a continuous process of development. It involves the restructuring of hostels and nursing homes so that the provision of various levels of care is brought more into line with needs and that those needs are based on the assessment of individual patients requiring those various levels of care.

As indicated by the Minister for Consumer Affairs, Senator Bolkus, a number of representations have been made to me-I believe they would have been made to other senators-in relation to the adequacy or otherwise of the provisions in this Bill. Those representations were made both by suppliers of the services to those requiring care and also by the various consumer groups. The representations were of two sorts. I was disappointed that Senator Vanstone confused the two important elements of those representations. They involved, on the one hand, the strategy which is laid out in this legislation and, on the other, the implementation of that strategy. There seemed to me to be enthusiasm and broad support for the strategy as laid out by the Government for bringing some semblance of order into the provision of the various levels of care. However, at the same time a great deal of concern was expressed as to the implementation of that strategy. That involves a great deal of detail as to how hours of care were to be allocated to individual patients. I want to pick up that point in more detail later. The Australian Democrats will not seek in any way to amend any parts of this Bill dealing with nursing homes. As Senator Vanstone has indicated, most of the people who finish up in nursing homes are indeed the aged-some 95 per cent-but a small but significant group, about 5 per cent, are the disabled young. In the past there has been considerable inequity between the various levels of care. Those who could afford private care were more adequately catered for than those who could not.

The intrusion of the private suppliers of the care, those who were profit oriented, led to an imbalance between the provision of various levels of care. Many people requiring some small level of care in their own homes were being admitted to hostel care and eventually into full nursing home care. We had seen over time the development of more nursing home beds than were required with the development of a more expensive system in which fewer people were able to stay in their own homes. Smaller provision was made for hostel care, that intermediate level of care. The Government is to be congratulated for the thrust of its policy. The policy is consistent and it is based on the report of the Nursing Homes and Hostels Review. As I have indicated, a very haphazard development of various levels of care had developed. It was ill-controlled and it was extremely costly to provide the quality of care demanded. The report states on page 8:
The practice has been for the States-
and I think `States' is to be broadly interpreted-
to set standards and for the Commonwealth to pay.

In other words, the Commonwealth had very little control over what it was getting. This 1985-86 report also set out the philosophy and goal to guide the new programs. This is what this part of the present process is based upon. Page 3 of the report states:
Aged and disabled people should as far as possible be supported in their own homes, in their own communities.
As I have indicated, that was progressively being abrogated by the provision of unnecessarily expensive nursing home care. The report further states:
Aged and disabled people should be supported by residential services only where other support systems are not appropriate to meet their needs.
Services should be provided in an atmosphere and using processes which promote as far as possible rehabilitation and restoration of function.

This indicated that more than a bed was required. Yet thrusting many of these aged people into nursing homes led to that development and thus the basis of the strategy. It is stated on page 4 of that report, among other points:
There should be an assurance of service availability when that point of need is reached.

Services should, as far as possible, be provided to people in their own localities and in forms which positively encourage independence and involvement in the person's own community, including the special needs of ethnic communities and Aborigines, and people in rural areas.

This was a very considerable defect and still is a considerable defect. There is markedly insufficient provision of care for ethnic communities, for Aborigines and for people with rural backgrounds who require services consistent with their cultural backgrounds. Another point made in the report states:

The point of entry to any form or level of service should be through assessment; assessment should cover three components-initial assessment of the appropriate level of care and service mix; ongoing monitoring of the need for the service; and reassessment for higher levels of service.
Again, that is addressed in this legislation by a complicated mechanism which Senator Vanstone has referred to and which I want to address again in a moment. The report also states:
All services, regardless of level, should be provided to a reasonable and adequate standard of care; standards should focus on outcomes and processes, not just inputs.

Again, that is addressed in this legislation. For many years there have been calls for reform in the nursing home and hostel industry. These problems have stemmed from the fact that too many of the resources have been going into nursing homes with very little development of other options such as hostels or better support for home care. This has resulted in many people occupying nursing home beds who did not need them and people being kept out who did need them. The cost of the provision of those services had substantially got out of control. Many aged people could not afford the care which they desperately needed. There was also a growing burden on the taxpayer. The standard of care in many homes was poor because there were inadequate funds for those lesser levels of support.

There has been a substantial growth in the proportion of people in the community who are aged. It is important to recognise that the Government is correct in addressing this problem now in this staged way because we are not simply shooting at a fixed target; we are shooting at a target in which the number of people requiring care at the various levels will progressively increase. Figures show that in the 70-plus age group there is about a 3 per cent increase per annum and that in the 80-plus age group there is about a 4 per cent increase per annum. Those are yearly increases and are leading to very substantial increases in the number of people requiring care. The median age of the population in homes and hostels is in the 80 to 89 age group. That is precisely the group that is increasing at a rate of about 4 per cent per year.

There has been a great deal of misconstruction based on the increasing number of older people. It has become one of the arguments used to support an increase in the migration program. I point out that increasing the number of migrants, even if their average age is less than that of the Australian population, only addresses a decrease in the average age of the population while those migrants are coming in. If the average age of migrants is five years less than the average age of the Australian population, five years on those same migrants will have attained the average age and they will continue to age just like the Australian population. At the same time the bringing in of that migrant population requires that we provide special services, as I have already indicated, for those aged migrants needing particular care which is based on their cultural background.

The important thing to recognise is that there has been a substantial fall in labour force dependency. In 1961 that dependency ratio was 1:1.43. By 1981 it had fallen to 1:1.18. It is projected that by the year 2021 it will still be only 1:1.17. In other words, if we are looking at the number of people in the community available to support those who are dependent-that includes both the young and the old-the ratio in the year 2021 will still be less than the ratio in 1981. That indicates that what we have here is not a problem in relation to the finding of funds for support of aged care against a static demand elsewhere in the economy; we have a considerable need to shift funds from the young to the old. That, of course, poses considerable political problems which we are seeing develop, for example in the closure of schools. Clearly, the figures in relation to the dependency ratio are the more relevant figures to use when we are considering the provision of aged care.

I turn to the details of the principles by which hours will be allocated to particular patients. Those hours will be made up by an assessment of patients when it is thought that they require entry to hostels or nursing homes and a reasonably complicated formula will be applied. It contains a number of elements and within each of those elements a number of levels of hours which can be allocated. It is those details of the principles which have been the main concern both of the providers of health care in nursing homes and hostels and of the consumer groups and potential consumers. I recall that the other day Senator Walters raised the issue of the allocation of hours in relation to incontinence and the allocation of hours in relation to people requiring movement into wheelchairs. I must say that when I first looked at this it seemed to me that that formula was inappropriate. However, the matter is one of great complexity and it now seems to me that because of that--

TALK.START.PARA: —But you have to vote for the Government so you will find excuses.

—It is an element of great complexity. What is required is a great deal more information which can be derived only from applying a formula as well as one can construct one and as close as possible to needs and then very closely monitoring the performance of that formula and allowing that review to progressively modify the formula until one gets closer and closer to one which more adequately meets real needs. With that in mind, I have entered into considerable negotiation both with the individual groups and with the Minister. As Senator Bolkus has indicated, the Minister has given an unequivocal assurance that that review will be conducted on an ongoing basis. It will involve both the providers and the users of services and it will address this critical question of the principles which will guide the allocation of hours. I would like to read into the record the assurance which the Government has given and invite any of those groups or individuals who are concerned to obtain a copy of this letter from me. I think it addresses the very issue which the Opposition is trying to introduce by way of an attachment to the second reading. The Minister stated, inter alia:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Government has committed itself to effective consultation in developing and implementing measures to reform the programs for the care of the aged-
that is what has happened in the past-
This has taken the form of:
involvement of people from the industry and the relevant professions in the development of the new system;
consultations in all States and Territories; and
discussions/negotiations with national consumer, industry, union and professional bodies.

. . . it is my intention to involve the relevant consumer organisation, the industry associations, and union and professional bodies in the monitoring process and in the subsequent review of the new arrangements. I consider it most important to have their involvement to ensure that the monitoring process takes due account of any difficulties they might encounter and that these concerns are also considered in the development of modified arrangements.

I am therefore pleased to give you an unqualified assurance that I shall be seeking the advice of all of the national bodies with an interest in arrangements for the care of the aged and that I will take account of that advice in regular review of the principles governing the new resident classification instrument and the associated program arrangements.

I take that as an unequivocal undertaking on the part of the Government to carry out that review. Moreover, I understand that the figures in relation to the working of the scheme will be provided by the various hostels and nursing homes to the Department on a monthly basis. Once the personal and confidential information has been removed from that data it will be given back to the individual nursing homes and at any stage, but at least within 12 months, that data will be the basis of a review of those principles which, as I have indicated, are extremely complicated. I certainly would not like to try to write a new formula which would more adequately address the problems. I think the only way one can do that is to go into the marketplace, apply a formula as best as one can construct it and, having done that and collected the data, then review that data and modify the formula as one goes along.

I turn very quickly to the other main section which has caused a great deal of concern; that is, the pre-existing ailment rule and the way in which the Government has changed tack. Having set up a system in which, presumably believing in the operation of the free market, it has allowed the entry of health insurance companies which have been able to offer both lower premiums and higher benefits in a free, competitive market situation, it is now attempting to change that rule and allow portability for people with pre-existing ailments. This means that those with these ailments are free to transfer from one of the older funds, which have in the main higher premiums and lower benefits, across to newer funds which have come in under this competitive market system and to claim immediately, without any preliminary qualifying period, benefits in that new fund. Personally, I think honourable senators would know that I am not in any way enamoured of the operation of the free market. I do not believe that the market does best serve the common good. I think that is eminently provable; it is eminently demonstrable. However, both the Government and the Opposition have frequently defended a great number of programs and policies on the grounds that the free market will indeed best serve the community interest.

Just this morning, for instance, we have seen the possibility of police investigation of the release of information in relation to Australia's foreign exchange rate which has evidently led some people to make profits of up to $1m overnight. Criticism is made of those who may have leaked the information. I would aim the criticism quite squarely at those who have created a free market situation which has allowed those sorts of things to occur. But having said that, it seems to me that both the Government and the Opposition should be consistent in this matter and should not have set up a system and then turned round and changed the rules. Had there been an opportunity to move an amendment to abolish the pre-existing ailment provisions which are here included, I would have done that. However, that opportunity is not available to us and I will not be doing that. I understand that the Opposition could not support such amendments.

In summary, the Australian Democrats will not be supporting the attachment which has been moved by the Opposition because we believe that it prejudges many of the issues about which we do not have enough information. In relation to the Opposition's claims of a reduction in the quality and care standards, I believe that the overall quality and care of the standards will be improved. That is the main thrust. But it will depend upon the working out of the formula in some detail. It remains to be seen whether that formula adequately or inadequately addresses the issues. On the other point-that is requesting the Government not only to consult closely with the industry but also to conduct a review-I point out that that process has already been set in place on a very firm undertaking by the Minister, and I believe that the Minister will not go back on his word.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on behalf of the Opposition to address myself to some aspects of the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1988, as they relate to the operations of certain sectors of the health insurance industry and as they amend the National Health Act 1953, in particular to clauses 29 and 30. As Senator Coulter was saying a few moments ago, these clauses deal primarily with the operation of the so-called pre-existing ailment rule. To all intents and purposes as long as there has been a system of organised health insurance arrangements there has been some form of pre-existing ailment rule in place. The rule, in essence, is that when one joins a fund one has to wait 12 months before one can be refunded, rebated or receive a benefit for any ailment one had at the time of joining the fund.

SPEECH.PARA: The law is quite specific in this regard. It refers to having `signs' or `symptoms' at the time of joining. One does not necessarily have to have identified those signs or symptoms oneself. That can be established by a medical referee if there is a dispute. There is a good reason for this. It is improper, after all, to think that one can wait to take out health insurance until one feels one is going to be in need of insurance to cover a particular ailment. Health insurance, the way it operates in Australia at the moment, is very much a system whereby the healthy subsidise the sick. Such a system would not be possible in the absence of a rule such as the one I have just described.

Nevertheless, prior to 1984 another simple principle applied: if one was insured but chose to change to another fund, it was reasonable not to have the pre-existing ailment rule apply. That seemed quite reasonable. Unfortunately, such a principle suffered from a major defect in some respects. Historically, the longer a fund is established and the longer the contributors stay in that fund the more likely the contributors are to become ill. They get older. And in Australia the elderly are the maximum consumers of our health care dollar.

Prior to 1984 a large new fund was established-Medibank Private. There is evidence that some of the other funds suddenly discovered that the new participants in health insurance were going to this new fund because they perceived it as offering better benefits or lower premiums or because they had been seduced by government advertising. All of a sudden, some of the established funds saw their portfolios getting out of balance. They no longer had sufficient young, non-claiming contributors to balance the cost of the older, claiming contributors. They responded with a simple solution. In the industry it is known as dumping. They started to induce or encourage people to join another fund or, by plain bad service, discourage people from renewing their existing membership and to take their illness with them, as there was no pre-existing ailment rule when transferring from one fund to another.

That became such a problem that in 1984 this Government decided to apply the pre-existing ailment rule to transferring from one fund to another. There is evidence that, to stop the process of dumping, people were being offered one year's free contributions to the new fund if they would shift. Other inducements were offered to private hospitals and other places to encourage long-term, chronically ill patients to leave. Clause 30 of this legislation proposes to go back to the pre-1984 situation. The amendments which have been put before us by the Minister on behalf of the Government this morning deal with the whole question of dumping. They go centrally to it.

There are a number of problems which transfers between funds can, from time to time, occasion. Speaking in the House of Representatives on 28 April 1988, the shadow Minister for Health, Mr Wilson Tuckey, gave an example which was recently drawn to his attention. A husband and wife had a family membership in a fund, one spouse being quite healthy and one having a pre-existing ailment, as a result of which neither could shift. The Opposition agrees with the right of consumers to shift from fund to fund. The Government has attempted to resolve some of the problems of dumping in the amendments which are before us. It wishes to give people this right, whilst recognising the opportunity for one fund to dump onto another. There is quite a lot of argument about dumping. Some spokesmen in parts of the industry almost deny its existence. They say that, after all, an organisation which overtly attempted to dump contributors would soon be exposed in the marketplace, that word of mouth would get the details around, and that other people would be discouraged from joining on the basis that they might in future be dumped.

All of these claims have to be regarded with a great deal of scepticism. To the extent that one can make any judgment about this matter the evidence is largely anecdotal, but all of us are aware that dumping takes place. It is unfortunate that when the Government first introduced this legislation it had not addressed questions of penalties, nor had sought to tighten up its own legislation to the extent that was necessary. This was not only unfortunate in terms of the operation of the whole health care and health insurance system but was also an obligation which the Government should have taken up, as one of the funds most likely to be dumped upon is the Government's own fund, Medibank Private.

The Opposition did not think that the penalties provided were adequate, and thought that some of the remedies were administratively extremely cumbersome. For example, section 82r of the National Health Act contains a whole complex series of procedures which have to be observed in order to enforce compliance with the conditions of registration of registered organisations under the Act. As a result of the Opposition's considerations, we drafted a series of amendments which were introduced into the House of Representatives by Mr Wilson Tuckey. The Government, at the time, did not feel it was in a position to adopt those amendments. It subsequently considered its position and has brought before the Senate this morning its own amendments, which in large part pick up the amendments originally suggested by the Opposition.

On examining the proposed amendments in detail, the Government has obviously considered that advantages accrue to it in substantially accepting them. It has, therefore, moved this series of amendments. First, subsection 74 (5) of the principal Act provides:

Where a registered organization contravenes, or fails to comply with, a provision of this Act or the regulations or a term or condition of registration imposed by or under this Act or a direction under this Act served on the organization, the contravention . . . shall, without limiting in any way the liability of the organization, be deemed to be a contravention or failure by the public officer, and the public officer is punishable for that contravention or failure . . .
The penalty under this provision is to be increased from a fine not exceeding $5,000 to a fine not exceeding $10,000.

Secondly, it is provided that the registered organisation shall not permit its money or supply of money to be used for the payment of a fine imposed on the public officer under section 74 (5). Thirdly, it is proposed to introduce a new section 74ba to list various actions, for example, threats or inducements, which may not be taken by organisations who may wish to dump contributors. Finally, the new section provides for offences relating to the conduct of a registered organisation in making offers of inducement or threats of penalties to a contributor to transfer to a health benefits fund conducted by another organisation or simply cease to contribute to the fund conducted by the first mentioned organisation.

The penalty in respect of those offences is proposed to be a fine of $50,000. That is a substantial fine. It is important that the fine be substantial, because the problem being tackled, that is, the problem of dumping, is of great magnitude. If it is not dealt with properly then, of course, the whole system risks being fundamentally poisoned. In speaking to this legislation I wish to quote one of the points which Mr Tuckey made in the House of Representatives debate on 28 April and to seek an assurance from the Minister about a particular interpretation. Mr Tuckey said:

I assume that then it will not be incumbent upon only the Government or the Minister to take action, as they would under section 73ba of the National Health Act: if another fund feels it is being dumped upon I would assume that under the normal common law arrangements in Australia it could take some action to have such a prosecution proceed. Those very interested groups will keep their competitors honest, and that is a very significant factor. I do not think it should be upon the Minister to police this provision. I would rather the Minister did not have to get himself another police force and a few more feet in doors. My view is that once we have a monetary penalty and a clear offence for dumping it could be prosecuted by the fund that feels it has been offended against.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps I could just interrupt for a moment, Senator Puplick. Nothing prevents a private individual or organisation from bringing a prosecution. That is what I am advised.

—I thank the Minister. That is precisely the assurance the Opposition was seeking in this particular matter. It was certainly our understanding, now confirmed by the Minister, that private individuals and organisations do in fact have the right to proceed in normal common law fashion against other persons for breaches of the National Health Act. Of course, there is also the possibility of appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT) by any group which feels that the Government itself should have taken action and has been negligent in failing to do so. Therefore, people may go to the AAT. The Tribunal itself may require the Department of Community Services and Health to take action. Of course, if one looks at the Director of Public Prosecutions Act 1983, section 10 (2) and section 10 (3), one will see that it is quite clearly spelt out in that particular Act that nothing there prevents private individuals from taking action to ensure compliance by other individuals or organisations with the provisions of the law of the Commonwealth-in this case, with the provisions of the National Health Act 1953. To that extent, and because we have received that assurance from the Minister for Home Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) on the public record, the Opposition will not be proceeding with its own amendments which it has considered introducing to this legislation-amendments which essentially sought a situation whereby a fund would have redress if the Government or the Department was not prepared to take the necessary action to enforce the provisions of this Act.

SPEECH.PARA: In those circumstances I will conclude my remarks by saying that the Opposition, as a result, will be supporting this particular aspect of the legislation. I have not dealt with any of the matters which my colleague Senator Vanstone dealt with on behalf of the Opposition and upon which subsequent Opposition speakers will be focusing. Nevertheless, the amendments which have been introduced by the Government today to its own amending Bill, are to be welcomed. I think that they indicate the extent to which the Government was persuaded fully by the remarks made by Mr Tuckey in the other place. I thank the Government for having considered those remarks, picked them up and introduced them as its own amendments. In those circumstances, as far as this part of the legislation is concerned, it has the support of the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I first make it quite clear that the Opposition senators only have 10 minutes each in which to speak on the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1988. This is as a result of the gagging of the debate by the Government and the Australian Democrats. My purpose in mentioning that is that Senator Coulter, an Australian Democrat, spoke for 25 minutes on this Bill, even though he and the other Australian Democrats had assisted in gagging the debate. He took nearly the full allotted time and left the rest of us to speak for 10 minutes. The Australian Democrats have only seven senators and we have 34. They should get only 6 per cent of the time.
—We get exactly the same time.

—Senator Coulter has said that the Australian Democrats get exactly the same time. They do not get the same time when they gag the debate. The Australian Democrats gag the debate but take their full time. They leave any other senator who wants to speak floundering with only 10 minutes.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to speak on just two aspects of the Bill because I have not got time to speak on others. I will refer later in my remarks to the financial basis of residential care services for the aged. My first point concerns the portability of benefits. There are further changes to the health insurance area proposed in this Bill. This legislation rectifies the mess this Government has made already in this area-or this one small mess that the Government has made. Prior to 1984 any contributor to a fund had the ability to move from one fund to another, no matter what ailment that person had. This Government stopped that when it introduced Medicare. This has created great problems with the free market aspect of the health industry. I will just briefly go through the history of what this Government has done as a result of the Medicare changes, because I think it is very important that we understand the problems the health funds have been facing.

When Medicare was introduced it cut about half the health care industry's business because the health insurance industry was allowed to insure patients only for hospital care. Medicare took away all the medical servicing done outside hospitals; indeed, it took away the entire medical side. Prior to December 1983 61.5 per cent of the population was covered by health care. By June 1984, following the introduction of Medicare, that had dropped to 50 per cent of the population. The most important thing was that as a result of that dropping out of 11 per cent of the population, the funds were left with those people most at risk, the sickest and the chronically ill. The 11 per cent of contributors who got out were the healthy and young of the community who had been paying their health insurance because they believed they should be covered even though they were not at risk.

Following that, in 1985 we found that the Government decided that the health funds would have to pay a $10 gap for Medicare treatment in hospitals. In October 1986 the Government decided to abolish the subsidy paid to private hospital patients. The funds therefore were paying out of their basic table the $140m for that grabbed by the Government. In December 1986 the Government increased the gap payable for medical treatment in hospitals from $10 to $20. Of course, it increased the Medicare levy from one per cent to 1.25 per cent of taxable income. The Government then later increased the maximum medical gap from $20 to 25 per cent, with no dollar cap. That added another $105m to the amount paid out by the registered funds.

All those changes forced up the contribution rate and hurt most the chronically ill. The Government not only did that but also reduced by $99m the Health Benefits Reinsurance Trust Fund whereby previous governments had always acknowledged the need for taxpayers to share some of the cost of caring for the chronically ill. In December 1987 the insured population had dropped to 47.6 per cent. However, that 47 per cent still includes some pensioners. As honourable senators well know, many pensioners insure themselves at great cost because that way they know that they can get a hospital bed whenever they want it. Under the present Medicare system there is no way that pensioners can be assured of getting into a public hospital.

The Government is in some small way rectifying some of the problems it introduced. Once again it is allowing contributors funds to move from one fund to another, which is absolutely essential. As I said, when the funds were first hit by the Government we had the situation where the chronically ill stayed on with their funds and some of the young and healthy got out. Now new funds are being set up and they are creaming off the top from the older funds and taking in the young and the healthy. The older and chronically ill patients cannot join those funds because they have a pre-existing ailment. They have to go through a period of 12 months without any cover at all before they can apply to go to another fund. That is what the Government is now allowing to be corrected. Because a patient who wants to move to another fund will now be able to shift, the new funds will have the same cross-section of contributors as the older funds. The older funds will then be able to reduce their contribution rates because the new funds will have their share of the chronically ill patients.

It is just and fair, and indeed, contrary to what Senator Coulter said, it is allowing true market forces to operate when contributors can insure with whichever fund they want to. The Australian Democrats are opposing this. They think it is wrong to allow true market forces to apply. Senator Coulter said true market forces would apply only if people were stopped from joining the fund they chose, and they are voting against this amendment. That sort of muddled thinking is typical of all the Democrats, and we have learnt to expect it in this chamber.

Because Senator Coulter took so long, I have only two minutes left as I want to give other senators a chance to speak. I turn briefly to the financial changes for residential care of the aged. I have before me at the moment a document entitled `Resident Classification Pro Forma'. The Government has said to the nursing homes, `Look at all your inmates and classify them by point scores'. If patients are bedridden but are able to be transferred from the bed to a bedside chair, and quite a number of patients in nursing homes are in that situation, but have to have the assistance of at least two people, they get a score of 4.37-quite a high score. If we go over the page we find that if residents are incontinent and need changing and nursing care more than once daily, they get a score of one. I can assure the Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples) that, practically speaking, this is rubbish. If patients are incontinent more than once a day, it takes considerable nursing care to change the bedclothes and to make those patients comfortable. Yet the Minister in his wisdom says that those patients will get a score of one. If the patients are fully incontinent-both urine and faeces-they get a score of 2.75. If the pressure areas have to be attended to, as naturally happens with these sorts of patients, they get a total score of 4.48.

That nursing care would be very time consuming. Do the Minister and the bureaucrats not understand the situation? I am quite sure they do not, because the person who put this scoring system together, I was told some time ago, is a statistician and researcher. Those are the qualifications for putting forward a score sheet for a nursing home to use for patients. They are not the practicalities of a trained nursing sister, who knows exactly what does occur, but of a statistician and researcher. Nothing could explain better than that last statement of mine the Government's method of handling financial changes to residential nursing home patients.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I regret that the Government's inadequacy in dealing with the business in this place is such that issues relating to the aged take a back seat, just as they did in the Governor-General's Speech at the opening of Parliament, which outlined this Government's policy for the life of this Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: The aged and aged care industry should not be hoodwinked by the claim of the Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples) in his second reading speech, in which he said that Commonwealth spending on nursing home funding has increased by 38 per cent in money terms, from $420m in 1985-86 to an estimated $580m in 1987-88. It all depends on how we look at the statistics. If we want to know whether the Government's commitment to aged care has really changed we need look only at the expenditure on nursing home care in gross domestic product (GDP) terms. Recurrent funds spent on nursing homes have decreased from 0.428 per cent of GDP in 1985-86 to 0.419 per cent in 1987-88. So much for the figures in real money terms. The number of people in aged care is increasing, so a decreasing slice of the cake has to be divided amongst an ever increasing population of aged persons.

I hope the aged care industry has not also been hoodwinked by the current proposal for funding. Last year we had the standard aggregate module (SAM) which provided for a standard fee for infrastructure costs. There are already some problems with this. This year we have the care aggregate module (CAM), the basis on which a standard fee can be applied for nursing and personal care based on patient dependency as determined by the resident classification instrument (RCI).

When the first proposals for the implementation of CAM saw the light of day, the Government was confronted by an outraged industry and outraged recipients of the benefits of nursing home funding and their representatives. It was claimed that the Government had consulted closely with the industry. That was not the opinion of the industry in my State. Along with South Australia, my State of Victoria was the hardest hit by the proposals-so much so that 27,800 constituents presented me with petitions to this chamber to express their concern. In response to this pressure the Government increased the proposed number of nursing hours per patient, but in my opinion it is not high enough to achieve the outcomes outlined in the report produced by the Commonwealth-State working party in June 1987 entitled Living in a Nursing Home-Outcome Standards for Australian Nursing Homes. I believe it puts an undue burden on directors of nursing to achieve those standards with very limited resources.

Another issue which is of utmost importance to me, as a Victorian senator, is the application of the resident classification scheme. In the development of this system 17,000 patients were assessed, which produced a continuous frequency distribution of patients along a continuum of dependency on a scale of 0 to 45. As the developers of the scale admit, a relatively arbitrary division into five classifications was made, category 5 being the lowest dependency category and category one being the highest dependency category. As I said, it is an arbitrary division and we do not really know from the report how this division was made or out of whose head it was plucked. But the arbitrary division of 20-20-30-20-10 was made, and the Government will fund that proportion in each of the categories one to five, that is, 20 per cent of category one through to 10 per cent of category 5. I wish to note and underscore a point that was not made and should have been made by the Minister. I quote from the Commonwealth-State working party's document on the development of the resident classification system:
Although the nationwide distribution would be based upon the proportions 20/20/30/20/10 the effect by State varies significantly.

The history of the aged care industry is such that, despite the fact that Victoria has the same number of people in residential care per head of population as other States, we have fewer nursing home residents and more hostel residents. Our nursing home residents fall into the high dependency category. That has been demonstrated by the RCI developers themselves. Of Victorian residents, 15.4 per cent fall into the highest dependency category. In all other States it is 10 per cent or under, with the exception of the Australian Capital Territory, which is a very different scene, with 18.3 per cent. There has been criticism by other States that Victoria has, for far too long, had an unfair share of the nursing home funding cake and the RCI development research shows why this is so. The summary of the findings and outcomes of the RCI states:

It must be noted, however, that application of these cut-off points will result in different distributions across States and across nursing homes. It is quite possible for one nursing home to have 30% of its residents in category 1, for example, and for another to have only 5% in that category. The proportions specified apply on a national basis, not on an individual home basis.

I think that `not on an individual State basis' should have been added. As a Victorian senator I will be monitoring this closely to ensure that this principle holds and that arguments about States being treated differently do not muddy the funding waters. Victoria must get its rightful share based on dependency. The application of CAM will not commence until 1 July this year. It will be some time, maybe even a couple of years, before the full impact is felt in the nursing home sector. I do not want to have to say `I told you so', but I do want to put on record the difficulties that will be faced two to three years down the track.

The Minister has acknowledged that as more category 5 residents move into hostels, the level of dependency in nursing homes will increase, but nowhere does he admit that the 20-20-30-20-10 division of categories will change. Surely, some mechanism should have been built in to deal with the predicted increase in dependency. I believe that as soon as this dependency increases, New South Wales, Tasmania and other States which have not been crying out as a result of the Government's new measure will suddenly realise that they will have to face the same situation as Victoria, with a high dependency rate, and will have to deal with average hours of nursing which are not adequate to deal with highly dependent patients.

Despite the restrictions on the time I have to speak on this issue, I cannot finish without making a comment about additional health services. The Minister has said that an additional hour per resident per week of funding for increased therapy services will be provided. That is magnificent! There is to be one hour per week per resident spread across physiotherapy, occupational therapy, podiatry, speech therapy, music therapy and other health professions. So someone's mother or grandfather will get an extra six minutes of physio and five minutes of occupational therapy per week. As Dr Woods in the House of Representatives said, that is hardly enough time for a podiatrist to cut a person's toe nails, let alone undertake any therapeutic podiatry that needs to be done on ambulatory residents in nursing homes. It does not provide time for beauty care or anything that might be needed to make the life of residents in nursing homes more adequate and more like life outside an institution.

This Bill demonstrates clearly the Government's attitude to our elderly. Its provision of an additional hour is a token. It is not real and it is not meaningful; nor is it a reasonable attempt to deal with the quality of life in nursing homes. Residents need more than their physical needs attended to. A token five minutes of occupational therapy, music or beauty therapy is not enough. We need to add life to the years residents spend in nursing homes and hopefully add years to their lives. That life we need to add to those years should include meaning, interest, activity and choice-all those things which are the rights of all, including the frail aged.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sheil Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1988 is a substantial Bill. It makes some extensive administrative alterations which will affect nursing homes and hostels and have flow-on effects for aged care, home care and private hospitals. The Bill also alters the medical insurance arrangements. In other words, the Government is stirring the same old bucket of horse manure that we have been filling up for years. Naturally, the various industries have been thrown into confusion and have shown great concern. That is understandable when one looks at the eleventh hour amendments brought in by the Government now. The fundamental fault was that over the years government has promised more and more benefits in these areas and, when it has found out that it cannot fulfil the promises, it has had to restrict the services. The Bill before us has such an effect; it is a cost cutting Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: When the original Bills were brought in years ago, the flow of patients was from their homes to hostels, to nursing homes and then hospitals, particularly private hospitals. In other words, the flow was towards the high cost area. When government noticed that, it reversed its policy. It now wants patients to go from hospitals to nursing homes, to hostels and then into home care, which is how it was in the first place and how it ought to be. Over the years there have been bottlenecks in various areas as government has twisted and turned and tried to reduce its costs.

The fear has been expressed that many nursing homes will have to close as a result of this Bill. The small nursing homes will be most adversely affected; those in country areas that supply services to minority and ethnic groups. I can understand their concern. I presume that the Bill is largely the result of the work of the assessment teams that were introduced two or three years ago at a cost of $16m. Undoubtedly, the cost will be greater now. Previously the work was done free of charge. The assessment teams are necessary only because the Government has interfered in the business. Previously the work was done by doctors, patients and their relatives and the matrons of nursing homes and hostels. Of course, once government gets in there, it has to have more and more people working for it and more and more control.

The Bill introduces bureaucratic classification of patients-the resident classification instrument. This is not based on medical need but on the cost of care. The measure will make it most difficult for very sick patients to get higher benefits, even if they are medically warranted. For instance, a blind patient who may or may not be deaf and have other infirmities of age will be hard pressed to get a high classification in order to attract top benefits. The same applies to immobile arthritics or cardio-vascular cripples. It will be almost impossible for them to get a high classification. It is no wonder that the industry is upset. Those who work in the industry are genuine caring people.

The Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples) has announced extra funding of $130m to the industry, but he has not detailed how it will be distributed. That is another reason why there is confusion in the industry. It is unable to plan ahead. The Government has not listened to industry spokesmen in framing the legislation. Although it claims that it has spoken to the heads of the various sections in the industry, it has not talked to those who are actually on the ground doing the job. I think that it may have listened to them because it has now brought in amendments to take care of some of the problems we saw.

The hours of nursing home care for patients-nursing homes have been bureaucratised-have increased. We worked out that this adds up to an increase of about 36 seconds a day. But they have been increased for the wrong patients. The new figure for exempt beds-what one might call pay beds where people want to get more benefits than the Government is able to supply-has been set at 6 per cent, which is a strange figure. It is an inappropriate and across the board figure. I think it is called a global figure. It is far too low to accommodate the industry. Our population is ageing and we need more beds, not fewer. We need less government, not more. It is patients who need the subsidy, not the nursing homes, hostels or other aged care places. Originally, the Government subsidised the patients, but then it turned around and started subsidising the homes and hostels. Once the homes and hostels accepted the Government subsidy they found themselves with government controls, restrictions, disruptions and interference.

We are not opposing the Bill, even though it provides for inappropriate classification standards-the RCI-inadequate staffing levels and qualifications and inadequate remuneration. It will reduce the aged care places in Australia when we need more of them. It provides for an inappropriate percentage of exempt beds and a reduction in the number of patients who qualify for nursing homes. What more can I say about that? On top of it all we have a reduced number of hospital beds in Australia at the moment.

With regard to the medical insurance and anti-dumping provisions in the Bill, I ask the Minister in his reply to turn his attention to the concern of the voluntary health insurance companies in Australia. They are non-profit organisations and if they are sued by any person or another company-particularly another taxpaying, profit-making insurance company that may be part of a conglomerate-that could tie them up in litigation which would be expensive and time consuming and would cut into their operating costs. I think their concern is pretty genuine. The voluntary insurance companies think that the Government has sufficient advisory powers at the moment to discipline companies that involve themselves in dumping. They think that, if they have a concern the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, not the courts, is the proper place to take it.
