TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I suggest that we have a cognate debate on the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill, the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill and the Employment, Education and Training Bill.
—There being no objection, it is so ordered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I rise on behalf of the Opposition to respond to the three Government Bills that are being debated cognately. They are concerned with education, employment and training, with the emphasis being on education. Firstly, the legislation to establish the National Board for Employment, Education and Training and its subsidiary councils is a major piece of legislation and at the committee stage 18 amendments are proposed from the Opposition and 35 amendments are proposed from the Australian Democrats. We have, because of the guillotine that has been established by the Government today, only 1 1/2 hours to debate these three Bills and all those committee stage amendments. I just make the emphatic statement that we must in the Senate achieve better management of the Senate's agenda.

SPEECH.PARA: This is the last day of debate in this, the provisional Parliament House, and as we look to the new building and to the future we must do better. We must manage our business better, to handle important legislation such as this in a much more satisfactory way. I believe we will get to an improved Bill only by amending it on the basis of informal discussions that I have been able to have with Senator Macklin, and Senator Macklin has had with the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins).

Our speeches must be very much abbreviated so that we can handle the committee stage amendments, so this will not be a traditional second reading stage speech in which I would look broadly at the Bills that are before us but, rather, I will draw attention to the speeches made in the House of Representatives by my colleagues the shadow Minister for Education, Mr Carlton, and the shadow Minister for Employment and Training, Mr Shack, and note that even their speeches were constrained by a similar guillotine in the House of Representatives.

The first five years of the Hawke Labor Government have shown a status quo approach to education, especially higher education. In the area of schools there was a radical leftist agenda at first, moderated after Opposition and public response opposing that radical approach. But broadly speaking, and especially in higher education, there has been a status quo approach under the former Minister, Senator Ryan. These five years have represented the last five years of what I have called on a number of occasions the Karmel period in education in this country; that is, the period from 1972 to 1987 when the most significant leadership and, indeed, contribution to education in this country was made by Emeritus Professor Peter Karmel. I salute the contribution he has made and I see that that era is over and that the marks of that period were to achieve various goals, various standards, but also to rationalise not only courses but also institutions. It was a period of amalgamations, of increased regulation from Canberra through not only the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission but also the Schools Commission.

In the Bill that we have before us, we see not only the establishment of a new board with a new integration of employment, education and training, and of research, but also an express abolition of the preceding bodies-the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission, the Commonwealth Schools Commission and the Curriculum Development Council. So this is a milestone and it is marking the end of what I have called the Karmel period. Whilst I have no criticism of the broad thrust of that period, I see that it is in the past and that there was an overhang of three to five years beyond that which should have been the case because of the status quo approach of the Labor Government and the Minister, Senator Ryan.

We have seen two major problems arise-unmet student demand is the first and most important, and the second is inflexibility on the part of higher education institutions, not inflexibility as to their desires or objectives, but because of the over-regulation that has imprisoned them in decisions from Canberra. The Opposition's higher education policy of March 1987, to which I was happy to contribute, announced a growth plan, a breaking of the problem of the status quo approach by the Hawke Government. We sought increased independence for institutions and whilst we called for the end of the binary system as we knew it-that is, the bureaucratically restricting measures on research and post-graduate scholarships rather than on the basis of merit in institutions-we looked for extra funds being unlocked by establishing a Commonwealth scholarship scheme that would enable institutions to enrol others on whatever basis they saw fit.

We drew comparisons with the considerable freedom for overseas students, which is not the experience of Australian students in being able to enrol in higher education institutions. I seek leave to table the document, the Growth Plan for Higher Education, and shall not say more about it.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The newly elected Labor Government of July 1987, a few months after that policy initiative of the Opposition, at last began to face squarely the impasse that it had reached. There was a change of Minister, from Senator Ryan to Mr Dawkins. There was an immediate concentration on this critical area of higher education. Indeed, it is only 10 days ago that Minister Dawkins put down even then only a six-page statement of very general but quite commendable principles with regard to taking up reforms in the schools area. That has been deferred for nine months at least because of the concentration on higher education reforms.

SPEECH.PARA: The instruments of change that Minister Dawkins announced in the first four years of his office as Minister were: first, the establishment of the National Board for Employment, Education and Training; secondly, the release of a Green Paper for reform in higher education; and thirdly, the establishment of the Wran committee to look at additional funding for higher education institutions. These three initiatives are a mixed bag. They understand the objectives that the Opposition put forward in the policy paper that I have tabled, but they get it only half-right. They embrace the objectives that we have set forth and which I believe are very much needed in Australia, but they seem to have missed the point of our means for achieving them.

Our means are to give increased freedom and independence to institutions and to be co-operatively working to loosen up new energies in those institutions to achieve good goals, whereas the Dawkins approach has been to establish a new centralism and a reinforced corporatism which relies upon wisdom being in the Department and in the Minister.

I refer very briefly to a sound and commendable speech given on these Bills by a Government backbencher, the honourable member for Lilley, Mrs Elaine Darling, on 19 May. I point to it as interesting evidence of the assessment that I have just summarised. She said:
The reality in Australia today is that tens of thousands of people are annually denied access to our institutions of higher learning.
She went on to say:

For this reason, the Federal Government has taken a long, hard look at Australia's education system and the way it operates . . . we must turn our backs on the comfortable political option of skulking in the shadows and merely maintaining the status quo . . . The system needs a shake-up.

I concur heartily with all those words. That has been the burden of my speeches in this chamber for more than five years now. At long last there is awareness, not only by the Government, the Cabinet and the Minister but also on the back benches that that time has come. I do not in any way note, or commend, that aspect of alertness in the Government and its members to embrace the particular measures or the means that they have adopted or are proposing to achieve those ends. Indeed, I am directly critical.

Very briefly, on these three instruments of change, the National Board is a healthy new integration of decision-making and advice to government in the four areas of employment, education, training and research. It does see the establishment of an Australian Research Council, which is also Opposition policy. I do not at this stage seek to draw attention, other than broadly, to the dangers involved in an all-encompassing umbrella body in terms of evaluating the priorities and policies for research in Australia.

There are dangers that by putting all eggs in one basket we will get a reduction in diversity and get a lot of things wrong. We do not want uniformity, but we do want a mature comprehensiveness to evaluate priorities and policies in research. We are, as I have outlined broadly in my remarks about the Karmel period, moving on from the past period of the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission and the Commonwealth Schools Commission to this new decision-making approach of the National Board for Employment, Education and Training (NBEET). We broadly welcome these aspects of the NBEET legislation but the approach of the Government is sadly lacking in many particulars in terms of the relationship between the Minister and the Board, in the composition of the Board, in the relationship between the Board and its four councils, in the ability for the councils to initiate and to publish matters, and in other ways.

One thing that very much is fundamental to the amendments moved by the Opposition and the Australian Democrats is to achieve a sounder basis for strong councils, an independent and expert board and the ability for these councils and boards not only to arrive at decisions independently but also to show the public, through tabling of their reports in this Parliament, that they are independently putting advice to the Minister.

With regard to the Green Paper, the second instrument of change initiated by Minister Dawkins, I seek leave, because of the limited time, to incorporate in Hansard two paragraphs out of the Liberal-National response to the Green Paper on higher education.
Leave granted.
The paragraphs read as follows-
SUMMARY OF OPPOSITION REACTION

There will be widespread community and academic support for Mr Dawkins' stated objectives of an expanded higher education system that is more flexible in its institutions and more responsive to the nation's economic and social needs.
The questions to be asked are-
Does the Minister have the right understanding of the current and potential contribution of higher education to the good of the nation, and
Are the means proposed by the Minister to achieve his objectives likely to be productive?
Quantity Versus Quality
The Green Paper places heavy emphasis on the quantity of graduates required to be produced, with inadequate emphasis
Liberal-National Alternative

In broad terms the contrast between the Dawkins approach and the Liberal/National approach is that Mr Dawkins expects to promote change by getting the institutions to compete with each other for favours from government, whereas we want the institutions to have to compete more with each other for students in the real marketplace.

We acknowledge that the institutions do need more flexibility of internal management, but they will not get this unless they are able to control their system of reward for accomplishment without interference from the centralised industrial relations system.
The choice is between tightened central direction with only nominal institutional flexibility, and real institutional flexibility subject to greater marketplace discipline.
Paradoxically the need to cater for students' needs rather than government interpretations of student needs will provide a better balance between vocational training and the humanities.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. Secondly, I seek leave to table the full document.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. With regard to the Wran report, I have just a minute to give some assessment. This is the third instrument of change in higher education. The Minister has already given support; the Cabinet has supported it in principle; and the Labor Party's Right and Centre Left and the President of the Party have indicated their support. It is to be seen next week in the Labor Party Conference in Hobart whether the principles of the Wran report into finding additional funding for higher education will be approved by the Labor Party. One would estimate at this stage that it is likely to be approved and, therefore, we would see in the next sitting of the Parliament a reflection in the legislation of many elements of the recommendations that the Wran report has made.

SPEECH.PARA: I only say then in response and in this week before the Labor Party Conference that that report offers failures on three points. Firstly, there is no short term solution. It would be the middle 1990s before there would be any substantial amount of new money gained through these deferred fees of all higher education students. Secondly, in real terms it is my assessment that there will only be an additional 10 per cent contribution to the cost of providing higher education for students and not the 20 per cent that the Wran report hopes is there. Indeed, the Wran report refers to 22 per cent. Because there is a failure to take account of inflation and an average 10-year period for paying those deferred fees, it is wrong to assume that the nominal amount of the fee for a course being about 20 per cent of the cost of providing that course will, in fact, in the end, add in real terms a 20 per cent financial contribution to the costs of higher education in Australia. I think it is much more likely to be half that amount and so even in the longer term it will not achieve the goal that has been asserted.

Thirdly, in any event, the Wran report estimates that it would raise by the end of this century only $625m and that is roughly half of the amount that the Green Paper proposes will be the funding gap by that time. That funding gap is indicated to be $900m to $1,200m. There are still major problems in meeting the funding gap and we should not over-estimate the extent to which the Wran report makes a contribution to this matter.

The Opposition approach is quite alternative to the Wran report. Our approach is to reintroduce higher education scholarships with the objective of undergirding these scholarships with guarantees that they be to not less than the number of free places already existing in higher education institutions and that the scholarship would cover tuition fees. Incidentally, this would release perhaps 20 per cent of places for new students because the priority for awarding these scholarships would not be to second degree students or to students repeating previously failed work. Therefore, there is a resource involved in the Opposition's policy that, in fact, gives new ground or a new resource to meet the present shortfall in demand.

My time is running out very quickly and I must cut short what I had intended to say about the NBEET Bill in broad terms. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the amendments which we will move in the committee stage of the Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —For about a minute each I will refer to the other two Bills that we are debating cognately. The States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Bill supplements moneys in the normal way to a total cost of $66.5m. It allows $0.6m provision for the co-ordination of teaching hospital activities and the Government's drug and alcohol offensive. The Opposition supports these aspects of the Bill but we have a second reading amendment. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion, add: `but the Senate condemns the Government for its failure to provide sufficient resources to tertiary institutions for them to meet the demand for student places, or to find a satisfactory alternative source of funds for tertiary education.'

I have already spoken to the two aspects of this second reading amendment and say no more about it. I draw attention in regard to this Bill to a speech I gave on 19 May in the Senate about the new arrangements that the Department is pursuing for student and staff records in our higher education institutions. I condemn the Government for not putting in place statutory safeguards to ensure the confidentiality and securing of those records and I have argued at length in that earlier speech.

With regard to the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill the Opposition is happy to support the Bill in terms of its usual supplementation of moneys that have already been granted to schools. There is an additional $21m to be distributed to government and non-government schools, bringing up for this financial year an amount of $1,760m in Commonwealth grants to schools. I only draw attention to the fact that the Opposition is opposed to the Government's newly announced restrictions on established grants for new non-government schools and we are opposed to the more demanding enrolment requirements for the grant of recurrent assistance to schools. It is Liberal and National Party policy to provide recurrent assistance in respect of every enrolment in both government and non-government schools.

When we come to the committee stage of this Bill I will draw attention to references to the year 1990 in terms of a reform which the Government has announced whereby schools will not need to give notice to the Department concerning change of location of parts of the school, or indeed, of the whole of the school. We welcome this initiative and we want to make sure that it has an immediate effect. I will also refer in the committee stage to the speech of the Minister on 23 May strengthening Australia's schools, a consideration of the focus and content of schooling and for the purposes of our amendment to one part of the NBEET legislation concerning standards in schools and discipline in schools.

I note the welcome references to standards and to discipline in the Minister's speech of 23 May and my surprise that the Minister did not accept those references in the House of Representatives debate. I note in conclusion, Mr Acting Deputy President, that in the time that remains after hearing most carefully Senator Macklin representing the Australian Democrats, we will need to proceed in a sensible manner to the wide range of committee stage amendments. We will do all that we can to facilitate an outcome of a much improved National Board for Employment, Education and Training Bill in the light of the initiatives that the Opposition and Democrats are making.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating three Bills. Two of them are the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill, which the Democrats will be supporting; the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill, which the Democrats will also be supporting and to which the Opposition has moved a second reading attachment. We will be supportive of that second reading attachment, though I dare say that we would differ from the Opposition parties as to what might be a satisfactory alternative source of funds for tertiary education.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to concentrate on the third Bill, the Employment, Education and Training Bill. This Bill proposes a new series of advisory bodies to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins). They are to replace the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission, the Commonwealth Schools Commission and a number of other advisory bodies in cognate areas. There will be a statutory body reporting directly to the Minister. It will have four councils reporting to it-the Schools Council, the Higher Education Council, the Employment and Skills Formation Council and the Australian Research Council.

There will also be a Commonwealth-State consultative committee comprising Commonwealth, State and Territory representatives. The National Advisory Committee of the Commonwealth Employment Service is also to be abolished, as are the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission and its associated councils, and the Commonwealth Schools Commission and the Curriculum Development Council. The various regional and local advisory committees connected to a number of those will also be abolished and a facility exists in this Bill for national, regional and local committees dealing with employment service matters to be formed under the aegis of the Employment and Schools Formation Council. It incorporates provision for the Commonwealth Employment Service within the Department and repeals the separate Commonwealth Employment Service Act of 1978.

The Bill enables the Minister to sponsor various curriculum projects and to delegate powers in relationship to this wide range of activities that the Commonwealth is engaged in. The coordination of advice to government on the broad fields of education, training and employment is obviously highly desirable. For example, increasing the number of graduates from higher education, to which Senator Teague has already referred, has obvious implications for senior secondary school curricula and credentialling. A feature of the National Board of Employment, Education and Training is that business and industry and the trade union movement are to be more influential than they have been in the past in these particular areas.

Generally improvements in these areas require changes in attitude by industry and trade unions and, I think, it is a very desirable step to move to incorporate those groupings within our community into the policy formation process. For example, improvements in training are not likely to be successful without changes in award structures. If there is to be an increased number of science graduates from higher education there must be private sector research and development at a higher level than we have seen in the past. So there is an acknowledgment in this particular structure of the interlinking mechanisms that exist already within Australia and the desirability of enhancing those links between various groups.

I would emphasise that while the Democrats support participation of industry and trade unions and other groupings within the community and the work of the National Board, we do not wish to see economic and commercial issues pursued by the Board to the detriment of social and cultural issues. Education and research must not be hijacked by industry and the trade union movement purely for instrumentalist purposes.

We have been concerned about the extent to which the National Board, as proposed, would be able to provide independent and constructive critical advice to government. Indeed, we have been highly critical of both the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission and the Schools Commission for not being more independent on offering that critical stance upon which the general community would be able to judge the Government's or, as it were, the political response to what the critical comments of a professional body might be. We are not saying that any government would always be able to fulfil all the requirements that might be optimal in any situation, but I still believe it is useful to know what those optimal requirements are so that we are able to have a debate about whether or not resources from other areas ought to be diverted to bring us closer to.

The Democrats are proposing 35 amendments to this Bill to strengthen both the National Board and its councils. They would allow the councils of the Board to embark on investigations on their own accord as well as those, of course, referred by the Minister and the Board. The situation fairly obviously is that any board which sought to ignore the requests of Ministers for advice would be marginalising itself to such an extent that it would be a useless activity to have around and would soon lose any prestige within the community. But we also believe that it is vitally important that items that not necessarily are ones that the Government wishes to pay too much close attention to for a variety of reasons, some of which of course could be political, ought also be able to be undertaken by the Board on its own operation.

In addition, amendments I will move would require, as the Opposition has moved such amendments, that reports of the council and the boards provided to the Minister must be tabled in Parliament and not just, for example, those that are the result of ministerial references. Our amendments would remove the ability of the Board to censor sections of reports because of judgments about their confidential nature.

The Bill currently proposes that advice from a council to the Minister may be presented in summary form. We say that any summary must be prepared by the council, not by the Board, and propose an amendment accordingly. Councillors appointed by the Minister to assist the Board and its councils in their work should not, we believe, report directly to the Minister. We do not think this could be a harmonious relationship and we are proposing instead that the reporting mechanism be through the Board to the Minister.

We believe that the independence of the Board will also be strengthened if those holding the chairs of the councils and the Board are not eligible for reappointment. We think that they are much more likely to give fearless advice if they are not concerned, or even possibly concerned, about securing a future reappointment. The chairs of the higher education and schools councils, we believe, should be full time. We, in fact, originally proposed to the Government that all the chairs of the Council should be full time.

The Government, however, I think quite rightly, put a proposition that, for example, the council dealing with employment and skill formation may very well need to be chaired by a business person who, in terms of prestige and eminence, would be unlikely to be obtained if he had to sever entirely, as probably the legal requirement would be, all his connections with business. It seemed to be more appropriate that the other two councils-the other council, of course, is the Research Council, which tends to be a more seasonal activity-could very well be undertaken constructively and usefully by part-time chairs. Hence, our amendment is only with regard to the higher education and schools councils.

We further propose, as far as membership of the National Board is concerned, that greater account be taken of the complexities of science and technology from non-commercial points of view and we wish to extend the criteria for board membership so that at least seven shall be people having expertise or experience in matters relating to education or training or science technology. The idea of inserting there `or experience' is to make sure that we do not rule out a person who, for example, could be a national chair of a parents' committee. That seems to be a very appropriate type of person to have on such a schools council. We believe that there could have been a possibility of that person being ruled out on a narrow interpretation of what `expertise' might be. Here I may be erring on the side of caution but I think it is a reasonable proposition that parents, for example, ought to be eligible for appointment to the Schools Council.

The Bill will allow councils to establish sub-committees to help them with their work. We propose that there should be a guarantee that at least one member of the subcommittee should be a member of that council. We are also proposing a number of minor amendments, including alternative wording in some instances. Our amendments would, amongst other things, give the Board and its councils greater independence. Further, it would be possible for them to publicly report their advice to government more extensively than would otherwise be the case.

However, it is one thing to have the right to be able to undertake independent inquiries and to make reports. There must also, of course, be the ability to do so. We have great doubts as to whether the secretariat the Government is proposing for the Board and its councils-25 people-is adequate. I might point out here that the Australian Science and Technology Council alone has a secretariat of 22. The Australian Council for Employment and Training, which will be subsumed, of course, by the National Board, has a secretariat of 24. The research granting bodies to be subsumed by the National Body-that is, the Marine Research Allocations Advisory Committee, the National Research Fellowship Advisory Committee and the Australian Research Grants Committee-have a secretariat of 24. The Schools Commission, which will have part of its functions at least subsumed-certainly not the vast bulk of them, but part-and the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission had a staff of more than 200.

In terms of the National Board, we are very doubtful about the 25 and have argued this to the Government. I would hope that in the Minister's response we might indeed see what the Government's intentions are and how it might, in fact, wish to review the circumstances with regard to the extent of the number of 25 that it is now proposing as a secretariat. The Government, of course, has argued that the National Board secretariat will be able to multiply its effectiveness by harnessing the resources of the Department. This might be fine in theory, but I think anybody who has much experience with government departments will tell you how easy it is for a department to choke advisory bodies relying on that department.

We are therefore proposing that the Bill be amended to direct, in legislation, that the Department must provide the Board and its councillors with information that the National Board sees as necessary for it to perform its tasks. If the department refuses to provide such information, or fails to do so in a reasonable time, the Board or the relevant council may report this to the Minister and the Minister must table this report in Parliament within 15 days of the receipt of the report.

To further strengthen the hand of the National Board in this regard, we propose that the Minister, before referring a matter for advice to the Board, must consult the chairperson on the matter and this will enable the chairperson of the Board to point out to the Minister any difficulty there might be in meeting his or her requests because of a lack of staff resources and a need to complete existing projects.

If the National Board is to have a high status, and we hope it will, it must have adequate resources. In many ways, I think, the strength of its policy advice to the Government will depend on the quality and effectiveness of its secretariat. We believe that the 35 amendments which we are proposing will go a long way towards enhancing the effectiveness of the Board and its councils. We would expect the Government to undertake that it will ensure that adequate resources are made available to its councils and we would also expect the Government to be monitoring the progress of the National Board, as I am sure it will, to make sure that it is effective.

In conclusion, there are a couple of subsidiary items that I would like the Minister, if he could, to respond to because I believe, given the speakers list, that the time we will have in committee will be very short. First of all, I understand that pre-school education is included under another ministerial responsibility, but I do believe that since in a number of States we have teachers and a coordination between pre-school and the early years of primary school, the National Board ought be able at least to pay attention to that fact and, if it wishes to do so, be able to give advice about the rearrangements of primary education which do come under the Board's functions. I would hope that that particular activity is not to be ruled out by the legislation as it is proposed.

What role does the Government propose for the Higher Education Council in any use of education profiles? We know that this process is almost under way. While the Government has not necessarily acknowledged this, the extended collection of data seems to point to the fact that the Government has already made a decision in this area. What is the role of the Board in that regard? Why did the Government fail to include a list of the functions of service for the Commonwealth Employment Service in part VI of the Bill, when there is such a list in the Commonwealth Employment Service Act 78, which this Bill seeks to repeal? What is the Government's commitment to establishing advisory committees to the reconstituted Commonwealth Employment Service? Obviously, as I have already mentioned, there is the ability to do so. Is the Government able to tell the Senate what its intentions are with regard to the establishment of those committees?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Employment, Education and Training Bill 1988. To understand what is wrong with this Bill, one has only to look at its title. The Bill is fundamentally flawed because it de-emphasises the importance of education. Also, the positioning of the debate on this Bill, at a very late hour at the end of this session, is very similar to the way in which debate on an education Bill was positioned in the last sitting of this Parliament, when we scrambled through a discussion on education at about two o'clock in the morning. It is indicative of the way in which this Government places education in its hierarchy of interests and activities. It is not merely through some alphabetical accident that `employment' is listed first in this Bill and in the name of the Department. Education and training are clearly intended to be the handmaidens of the goddess employment, rather than employment being the outcome of sound education.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not deny the importance of employment, which is critical to the well-being of our population, but there is a big difference between a job and a vocation. Technology has eliminated many of the formerly nasty jobs in our society, and will eliminate many more. Education is a key that opens the door to job satisfaction, pride in a task well done, and the ability to adapt to the changing requirements of the workplace. What does it mean to be educated? It means the development of whole personalities, able not only to function adequately in today's world and the workaday world, but also to enjoy it and to contribute to its further development. Is this what Australians, particularly young Australians, are being offered by this Government?

What is the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) offering? A vision for a future society in which all citizens make their unique contribution to the well-being of their fellows, not just through paid employment, but through the full measure of their talents? No; the Minister and the Labor Government are-and I quote:

determined that the education and training systems will play an active role in responding to the major economic challenges facing Australia. These challenges will make heavy demands on our human intellectual resources and labour force skills.
That statement is contained in the second reading speech. The Minister continued:

The new arrangements reflect the Government's determination to complement its commitment to restructure the Australian economy by revitalising education and training policies and programs to develop a highly adaptable and skilled work force. Equality of opportunity and the fulfilment of broad social goals are integral to this strategy. Effective and timely advice to government are essential ingredients to ensure that these objectives are realised in the most effective way available.

His throwaway phrase about the fulfilment of broad social goals is the closest he comes to recognising the value of education per se. The highly adaptable work force he seeks will not be achieved if the school curriculum leads to too early a specialisation in skills that are narrowly focused. A highly adaptable work force is one trained to collect information, analyse it, synthesise it and apply it-in whatever discipline and across disciplines. We do not see these sorts of skills mentioned in any of the discussions on education by the Government.
Before passing to more specific criticism of this Bill, I remind the Senate of what I said in my maiden speech:

If Australia is to get in front again, we need the best young minds in Australia being taught by the best, most highly motivated, teachers and researchers. Mediocrity will not see us achieve our place as a competitor in the markets of the world, nor producing the professionals with the training required to deal with the complex social, moral and philosophical issues produced by electronic, technological and biomedical developments. The training of philosophers, social scientists and others in the humanities should not be neglected, either, in the current push for education to be relevant.
The terrible danger of the approach taken in this Bill is that philosophers, writers, artists and actors are not only deemed to be irrelevant but are positively unwanted.

One of my major criticisms of this Bill concerns the structure and function of the National Board of Employment, Education and Training (NBEET). I would have liked to have been able to deal with these aspects in more detail in the committee stage. However, I am only able to highlight my major concerns. The most glaring criticism is that the Board is very circumscribed in its independence because of the joint interaction of clauses 7 (1) (b) and 7 (2). The Board is not allowed on its own initiative to advise the Minister if that advice prejudices something the Minister has directed it to do. I quote from a speech made in the House of Representatives on 21 April:

We wanted a body which would have sole responsibility for these functions, one which would be independent of the Minister but still responsible to him. We wanted a body which would be seen as impartial and free from day to day political pressures, be accountable to Parliament and have a cross-section of capable, non-government people available for advice, have continuity of people and policies, and in the end have essentially the same costs as other alternatives.

Well, surprise, surprise! I say to those honourable senators who are present that that speech was by Mr Barry Jones, the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business, when he talked about the textiles, clothing and footwear industry. That Minister at least understands the importance of independent advice. The Minister for Employment, Education and Training does not understand its importance to an area of our society which is vital. I am not saying that textiles, clothing and footwear are not vital, but they are not quite as important as education. If we do not have decent education, we will not have a textiles, clothing and footwear industry anyway. Mr Barry Jones understands the importance as far as the textiles, clothing and footwear industry is concerned, but our Minister does not understand the importance of it for education. It only goes to show how little he understands about the importance of education for the continuation of our culture and our society.

I refer also to one of the issues that the Board can deal with. It is outlined in clause 7 (3) (c). This is the provision of assistance for persons having difficulty in obtaining employment, education or training. One can only hope that this is intended to include beneficiaries of social security programs. If so, we would hope and expect to see some more concrete reference to integration of work force access with the social security system. There is an abundance of reports-for example, the report of the Social Security Review Committee, the report of the Brotherhood of St. Laurence entitled Hard Labour, and that of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training-which cite the lack of accessible, affordable, suitable child-care, both for infants and for school-age children, as one of the highest barriers to work force entry or re-entry for parents, whether there are one or two parents present in a family. I hope that somehow NBEET will address this issue.

The research functions of the Board pose some interesting questions. Clauses 7 (4) (c) and 7 (4) (f), which concern the Board's role in setting national research priorities and allocating financial assistance for research, are interesting when they are combined. As we know, much research is carried out under the umbrella of the Commonwealth, in organisations and statutory authorities such as the Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics, the Bureau of Industry Economics, the Bureau of Transport Economics, the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, the Bureau of Mineral Resources, et cetera. There is commissioned research through government departments such as the Department of Community Services and Health and the Department of Social Security. It is not made clear in this Bill whether these are to be included in the resource allocation of NBEET. One can foresee some great barneys in the community and in Cabinet unless this is clarified.

One of my other major concerns is about the membership of NBEET. The amendments we are supporting seek to minimise the big corporation approach by Government to the structure of the Board. The question I ask is: Where are the educators in this Bill? Clause 11 (2) (c) refers to persons having expertise in matters relating to education or-and I emphasise or-training. These are not interchangeable. Education is directed at broad, societal goals and training at narrow, work force goals. I also wonder whether my former academic colleagues may regret that the Federation of Australian University Staff Associations has joined the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU), when the decision is made about the appointment of a person having expertise in matters relating to unions. There has been a suggestion-I have only seen it in the Press-that a likely appointee may be Mr Laurie Carmichael. Many academics will not be pleased, if that decision is made, about the sort of person who will represent them on NBEET.

It is outrageous that we have had so little time to debate this Bill. The number of amendments indicates the extent of concern that the coalition and the Australian Democrats have about its adequacy. My most vital concern with this Bill is to see that education is not stifled and organised by ACTU reconstruction, ministerial control and bureaucratic interference.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say, as other senators have said, how poor it is that the management of business in this House means that debate on important Bills such as these has to be truncated, and how frustrating it is for senators who wish to speak to the legislation and the wide-ranging area that it covers to have to direct their remarks to particular areas that they find to be most important. They have to allow other senators to cover areas on which they also have an opinion.

SPEECH.PARA: The area which concerns me most in the Employment, Education and Training Bill is that part relating to the establishment and functions of the Australian Research Council. The Australian Research Council is one of the four advisory councils to the main Board, the National Board of Employment, Education and Training, which has the appalling acronym, NBEET. Nonetheless, the concerns that I wish to express are those that are expressed in the amendments that the Opposition will move in the committee stage, which are backed up by a large percentage of scientific and academic people in Australia. The amendments that we will be moving will require that the appointment of the Chairman of the Australian Research Council shall be made only after consultation with the Australian Academy of Science, the Australian Academy of Technical Science and Engineering, the Academy of Social Sciences in Australia and the Australian Academy of Humanities. The reason, of course, is that this Research Council is the successor to the existing body, the Australian Research Grants Committee, which has had a long and successful history and which has served this country well. Many of the people who will serve on the new Board will have had an association with the former Grants Committee.

It has come to the attention of many honourable senators, and indeed to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins)-because many of the academics concerned have made this point to the Minister-that, because of the nature of the Council and the fact that it will be dealing with science and technology, there is concern that the Chairman should be someone who is a scientist, either in the natural sciences or in the technological sciences, so that the Chairman may adequately reflect and understand the work of the scientific community. This proposal has been made to the Minister by bodies which include the Australian Academy of Science, the Royal Australian Chemical Institute, the Australian Institute of Physics, the Federation of Australian Scientific and Technological Societies, and the Australian Institute of Engineers. No less than nine eminent scientists have been prepared to put their names to a letter to the Minister, asking that this be considered. When eminent Australians, who have considered the importance of the work of the previous Grants Committee and the work that the Research Council will be involved in, make a very logical and reasoned plea, in no way hostile to the Minister or what he is trying to do, it is worthy of attention. In this area of education we should all strive for the situation where those people who have talents are best able to give of those talents.

When such eminent bodies and such eminent academics as those that I have mentioned are sufficiently concerned to make a plea to the Minister, I think it is worthy of at least an answer. Indeed, these people put forward the name of a particular scientist whom they would consider to be a suitable person for that position. But the thrust of their argument is not based on personalities; it is not designed to have a particular person appointed, although he is obviously a preferred choice. The suggestion they are making, that the permanent chair be occupied by a scientist or a technologist of distinction, is a most reasonable one. As we are about to move to the committee stage-and I understand that the legislation is to be guillotined-I will restrict my remarks at this stage and perhaps take them up at a later stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the interests of expediting the business of the Senate and avoiding delay in putting on a statutory footing the new advisory structures necessitated by the creation of the Employment, Education and Training portfolio, the Government has discussed with the Australian Democrats a number of changes that they wish to see made to the Employment, Education and Training Bill. As a result of those discussions, the Government is prepared to accept all the amendments proposed by Senator Macklin.

SPEECH.PARA: In the course of discussions, a number of points were raised that, whilst not the subject of amendment, would be better understood if the Government were to state the position. These matters are in the areas of educational profiles for higher education institutions, the status of the Commonwealth Employment Service (CES), the secretariat to be provided to support the National Board of Employment, Education and Training and its councils, and the role of the Schools Council in pre-primary education. I believe it is important to run through these issues because they were raised by a number of honourable senators in their speeches.

In regard to educational profiles, it is the Government's intention that the first task of the Higher Education Council, in association with the Department of Employment, Education and Training and other interested parties, such as the States and the bodies which collectively represent the management of the institutions, will be to develop and then negotiate these new arrangements with institutions. In regard to Administrative and Clerical Officers Association (ACOA) representatives, in developing this legislation consultations were held with a range of people and organisations, including the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the Administrative and Clerical Officers Association. The union sought and obtained a commitment from the Government on three basic points: firstly, the maintenance of a commitment to a public employment agency, consistent with Australia's obligations under International Labour Organisation Convention 88; secondly, the maintenance of comprehensive advisory structures dealing with the Employment Service; and, thirdly, the retention of an identified position of National Director of the Employment Service. All of these commitments are clearly reflected in the Bill.

Since the earlier consultations, the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) has had further representations from ACOA, relating to issues of detail in the proposed legislation. I would like to make some observations on these additional matters raised by ACOA. It seems to have a concern that more compact provisions from the Employment Service in this Bill, when compared with those in the Commonwealth Employment Service Act 1978, implies some walking away from a commitment to a public employment service. I assure the Senate, on behalf of Minister Dawkins, that there is no intention to reduce the role or functions of the Employment Service. Indeed, under the new and broader employment, education and training portfolio arrangements, the Government is currently examining the broadening of the functions of the CES, seeing it as the delivery arm for the wide range of client services that the portfolio now provides. An example is the move to have the Austudy scheme administered on a more decentralised basis through local CES outlets. If I may digress briefly, that is something that I know will be very much welcomed throughout Australia because there have been certain frustrations in my own area about some of the delays that have been occasioned by having to deal with an office based 1,000 miles from north Queensland.

Another concern raised by ACOA was the status of the advisory committee structure for the Employment Service. Specifically, it is concerned that the Bill leaves the establishment of these committees to the discretion of the Minister and that membership and meeting requirements are not specified, as is the case in the current Act. The Minister has assured me of his firm commitment to establish and retain an advisory structure for the Employment Service along the lines of current arrangements. As honourable senators would be aware, the Bill incorporates a Government-initiated amendment providing for advisory committees to report to the National Director. This is consistent with present reporting arrangements and does address the concerns of the ACOA.

The ACOA's final concern was about the lack of a requirement in this Bill for the National Director to prepare an annual report on the operation of the Employment Service. The requirement in the CES Act for the National Director to furnish the Minister with an annual report is no longer necessary. The Bill makes explicit that the Secretary to the departments of which the CES is a part will be the National Director. Under section 25 of the Public Service Act 1922, the Secretary to a department is required to furnish an annual report on the operation of the Department. A report on the Employment Service's operations will therefore be an integral part of that annual report.

Some concerns have been expressed about the adequacy of secretariat staffing for the administrative support group to the Board and councils. The Minister intends to ensure that, as well as the Department serving as the major source of many matters for the Board and councils, the secretariat will have sufficient and appropriate staff to provide the necessary support services. In addition, it is the Minister's intention to review the adequacy of those staffing arrangements after the Board and councils have had a reasonable settling-in period of six months or so.

In regard to the role of the Schools Council in pre-primary education, a concern has also been expressed about the lack of provision in the Bill for advice to government on pre-primary education. The Employment, Education and Training ministry has no general role in the area of pre-primary education. However, the Government considers that the area is one to which the Schools Council will need to pay due regard in formulating its advice about schools and primary and secondary education because of its importance and relevance to developments in the schools sector. Similarly, the Council is expected to be aware of matters in the post-secondary area that are of relevance to the Council's activities in the schools sector. I thank honourable senators for their contributions.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.

—I think Senator Teague might have something further to say. If he has he could now rise.
—I have asked the Minister why, on page 2 of the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill, there is reference to 1990.
