DEBATE.TITLE: RELOCATION OF CAPPUCCINO MACHINE IN THE NEW PARLIAMENT HOUSE

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators will recall that, in the Senate this morning, the matter of relocating the cappuccino coffee machine in the provisional Parliament House staff cafeteria to the staff cafeteria in the new Parliament House was raised. I have taken this matter up with officers of the Joint House Department, who advise me that the Department is presently taking action to have cappuccino machines installed in the staff and public cafeterias in the new building. I am informed that the replacement equipment will be available for use prior to the Budget sitting of Parliament. I should add that it is not proposed, even for sentimental reasons, to relocate the machine presently in use in the staff cafeteria in this building as it will not have the capacity to handle the estimated demand in the new House.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I inform the Senate that the Minister for Resources, Senator Cook, is absent from Question Time today as he is undertaking discussions with the Tasmanian Government in Launceston on the forest accord. Any questions normally directed to Senator Cook in relation to his portfolio or those he represents should be directed to the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister, relates to the matter which I raised with him last Monday week. Can the Minister yet tell me why the Treasurer has not delivered to the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) the terms of reference for an inquiry into non-tax government charges on industry as he announced in a Press release on 26 January this year? What about the other inquiries? In that Press release of 26 January, which got for the Treasurer a major front page coverage, he announced a forward inquiry program for the IAC comprising, firstly, proposed broad inquiries on impediments to competitiveness, namely, government charges on industry commencing early 1988; trade in services commencing early 1988; food processing commencing mid-1988; and travel and tourism commencing late 1988; and, secondly, industry reviews. The first two matters have already been dealt with in the May economic statement, namely, fabricated metal products and industrial machinery and white goods but, in addition, he announced a scheduled mid-term review of present dairying arrangements commencing mid-1988 and a sugar industry review commencing mid-1988. Is it the Government's intention to go ahead with all or any of these inquiries? Is Senator Button aware of any references to the IAC which the Treasurer has actually delivered since Mr Keating took over ministerial responsibility for the IAC from Senator Button? Finally, when will the Prime Minister deal with the Treasurer for the Treasurer's failure to deal adequately with his ministerial responsibilities in this area?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the announcement made by the Treasurer in January and, of course, I have not forgotten Senator Lewis's question of a week or so ago. I am able to say, without being able to give precise details, that in the last day or two I have sighted letters from the Treasurer which foreshadow an early reference of some of these matters to the IAC; that is to say, the time has ripened, as it were, and one can anticipate an early referral of some of the matters to which Senator Lewis refers to the IAC.

ANSWER.PARA: I am not able to answer that part of the question, which I do not think was in Senator Lewis's question of a week or so ago, relating to dairy marketing schemes and sugar. I rather imagine that at least the sugar issue has, in part, been dealt with in Mr Kerin's May statement and possibly the dairying issue has been dealt with, in part, in the May statement. I would also like to check up on whether the reference to food processing is not incorporated, in some ways, in the May statement because of tariff reductions which would have been announced there. Having said all that, I believe that within the next months there will be some references to the IAC of the kind foreshadowed by the Treasurer in January this year. Senator Lewis also asked me whether I was aware of any references made by the Treasurer to the IAC since January.

TALK.START.PARA: —Since he took over.

—Since the Treasurer took over. The answer to that part of the question is no, I am not aware of any, but that does not mean that there have not been any. I think there may have been one or two references in relation to minor manufacturing matters since the Treasurer took over. I believe that there have been but I am not sure, so I am not able to answer that part of the question with great accuracy.

ANSWER.PARA: In relation to the burden of the question as to why these references foreshadowed in January have taken this length of time to be delivered to the IAC, I can only guess, but I think the guess may well produce the answer that the Treasurer and the Treasury have been very busy in preparation of the May statement and--

TALK.START.PARA: —They have been nothing.
—They haven't done anything about it; that is what you are saying.

—Honourable senators should let me finish. They should not get too excited at this stage. The Treasurer and the Treasury have been very busy in relation to other matters. Of course, a lot of the issues which are inherent for consideration by the IAC in some of these references are matters which were on the agenda of the structural adjustment committee, the deliberations of which might well impinge on some of these matters.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. I refer to Senator Stone's comments in his column in the Australian newspaper this morning that the Minister for Finance and the Treasurer had fundamentally failed `to cut the spending programs over which their Cabinet colleagues preside'. I ask the Minister: What is the Government's record in relation to cutting spending? Further, how does that record compare with the record of the previous coalition Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did see Senator Stone's article. Of course, it is the article of a political propagandist, which he now is. In response to the last part of the honourable senator's question, I refer to what Senator Stone wrote to Mr Howard in 1983 in the hope that, by some freak of electoral fortune, he would still be Treasurer after the first week of March 1983. Senator Stone, in his previous incarnation as Treasury Secretary rather than as a political propagandist, the capacity in which he now writes a weekly column in the Australian, wrote in 1983:

ANSWER.PARA: When the estimated cost in 1983-84 of the new policy proposals announced in the policy speech is added, the prospect is for a Budget deficit of almost $10 billion.
I repeat the words `a Budget deficit of almost $10 billion'. He continued:
Such a deficit would be equivalent to . . . 5 1/2 per cent of projected GDP, the highest in Australian post-war history.
He also wrote:
First, the magnitude of the fiscal imbalance is unprecedented in Australia during peace time, as is the level of Government spending.

I could quote many other passages in that minute which make similar points. So that is what Senator Stone actually thinks about the record of the previous Government. In response to the part of the question concerning the expenditure control record of this Government, I have in front of me a graph taken from the Forward Estimates of expenditure published towards the end of last year which shows-starting back in 1981-82, the second last Fraser-Howard Budget-projected expenditure on no policy change shooting up to the extent of, in real terms, 6 and 7 per cent a year. It shows the same for the previous Government's last Budget, with expenditure increases in real terms shooting up by 6 and 7 per cent a year in the following years. The graph started to flatten out at the time we came to government, and eventually it started to go downwards. The graph indicates the $10 billion deficit--

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Mr President. I want to know whether the Minister has a proper ticket in Actors Equity or whether he is just carrying on like a fool.
—Order! There is no point of order, but the Minister would not be on his own today if he did.

—We can see here a line shooting up, showing the $10 billion deficit that Senator Stone was talking about. It took us five years to sort out the mess John Howard left behind him. It took five years, but we have sorted it out. It was sorted out in the last Budget. I cannot produce the other graph because it covers only the one year but since then, and as a result of statements made last week, the thick black line down the bottom which shows--
—Tell him to blow in the bag.

—I would be pretty careful if I were you, mate. I would be very careful. This thick black line shows that in the out years, on no policy changes, expenditure was actually falling in real terms. As a result of the May statement, it is falling even more. That is the record of this Government on expenditure control compared with the record of the previous Government, as assessed by Senator Stone, himself.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Public Service Matters. Can the Minister advise how many present recipients of compensation under the existing Commonwealth employees' compensation legislation will have their entitlements to compensation reviewed under the Government's new compensation legislation? If as a result of any review of entitlement persons presently in receipt of compensation are determined to be ineligible for compensation, will they be offered employment by the Commonwealth or will they simply lose their compensation entitlements?

—There is legislation before the Senate in respect of this matter and I do not think in those circumstances this question can be appropriately asked in the context of Question Time. I think it is out of order. Having said all that, I am unable to answer Senator Reid's question without obtaining some further information. I will seek to do that.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. In the light of the debate over the use of our valuable forest resources, can the Minister tell us whether the Government is investigating the possibility of recycling paper from government offices? Can he also tell the Senate what volume of waste paper would be involved in that process?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to Senator Aulich's question is: A great deal. At present about 35 per cent of paper consumed in Australia is recovered for recycling. While we would all like to see that figure go higher, it is of course much higher than in some comparable countries. One way to meet the demand is to tap the waste paper generated in government offices-and there is a lot of waste paper in government offices. In the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) alone it is estimated that about 20 to 30 tonnes of office waste paper are generated every week. However, because of contamination by beverages and food wastes, much of the waste paper, except for that paper separated after collection, is not acceptable to the paper recyclers.

ANSWER.PARA: In order to enhance the recycling potential, not just here in the ACT but elsewhere, a scheme which involves the separation of paper in the work place, at source, by individual employees was developed by my Department in cooperation with the Department of Administrative Services, and it has been run on a trial basis in Adelaide since November of last year. As a result of that trial, all Commonwealth departments occupying the new Commonwealth Centre in Adelaide are now adopting the scheme and it is expected that we will not only reduce the cost of disposal of office waste but also greatly increase the amount of waste paper income that can be generated. My Department now plans to promote this approach across the Public Service and, while I do not think anyone can give Senator Aulich an estimate of just how much waste paper is involved in government departments, let alone the community at large, I am hopeful that we can have a real effect on recycling and perhaps lessen the need to attack forest resources all over the country.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I preface my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer by referring the Minister to the final paragraph of a statement made by the Treasurer with regard to foreign investment policy on 29 September 1987, in which he said:

QUESTION.PARA: Pending the passage through Parliament of the proposed legislation, the Government expects foreign interests, and Australian parties with which they are associated, to comply with the new policy, and to submit all urban real estate proposals to the Foreign Investment Review Board for examination.

Will the Minister explain why this legislation still has not been introduced into the Parliament? Further, I ask whether the Government will consider tightening existing regulations to control foreign ownership of residential property in the light of comments made by Mr Robert Bevan, President of the New South Wales Real Estate Institute, as reported in yesterday's Australian newspaper:
There are so many loopholes in the regulations that someone from Hong Kong could come down in an oil tanker and bring his money in and no-one would do anything about it.
I ask whether the Minister will comment on the following statement of Mr Bevan:
I don't believe the Federal Government wanted to stop foreign investment at all . . . it-
that is, the Foreign Investment Review Board-
doesn't really work.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —This question reminds me of a comment that my colleague Graeme Campbell made when he received a letter from a city council in Perth a few years ago expressing great concern about foreign purchases of land. He wrote back to the council saying he, too, was extremely worried about this, especially if they rolled it up and took it away with them. While I would not entirely go along with that, I think this is a rather emotional question which gets some people a bit more excited than it ought to. I do have a note from the Treasurer on this matter in general which refers to the tightening of the foreign investment guidelines announced on 29 September last year. The Treasurer has also announced that amendments would be introduced to the Foreign Takeovers Act to provide legislative backing for those restrictions, and they are to be backdated to 29 September 1987.

ANSWER.PARA: The thrust of the new requirements is to restrict markedly the purchase by foreign interests of developed residential properties. I stress `of developed residential properties' because it is proposed that incomplete developments or land which is proposed to be developed for residential building should be treated quite separately. The effect of those new requirements will be to channel foreign demand for residential real estate away from established properties and into acquisitions off the plan or at the development stage. That shift will help expand the housing stock and bring more direct benefit to Australia in the form of employment. The Government welcomes foreign investment that is consistent with the needs of the community and which has that effect.

Finally, the Government is seeking the cooperation of the real estate industry and of foreign and Australian parties in ensuring compliance with the requirements. If the President of the Real Estate Institute has evidence of foreign interests purchasing residential real estate without approval, the Government invites him to put that information before the Foreign Investment Review Board.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade: What is the Government's assessment of the significance of the Reagan-Gorbachev superpower summit in Moscow? To what extent has Australia been able to have an input into the process leading to this important meeting?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government considers that the Moscow summit has confirmed and consolidated the quite obviously major improvement that has occurred in recent times in superpower relations. The state of the relations between the superpowers is manifestly of profound importance to the whole climate of international affairs and the scope and depth of the present dialogue between the superpowers is without precedent and provides strong ground for basic optimism about the future. In Moscow the two leaders built on the substantial accomplishments of the past three years, including the historic intermediate-range nuclear forces (INF) agreement and the withdrawal of Soviet forces from Afghanistan. While there, they exchanged instruments of ratification for the INF treaty, setting off the elaborate process that will eliminate all their land based nuclear missiles in the 500 to 5,000 kilometre range. They also signed agreements on prior notification of strategic ballistic missile tests and on the experimental site monitoring of nuclear tests. They signed a number of bilateral agreements, including on fisheries, people to people contact and maritime and air navigation safety in the north Pacific. They made further progress on the difficult issues outstanding in the negotiations on 50 per cent reductions in strategic nuclear forces which have generated renewed optimism that an agreement might be finalised before the end of the year.

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Government has been regularly briefed on progress in the superpower dialogue, the superpower negotiations, and we have certainly taken every opportunity available to us to inject our views into that process. Reciprocally, a senior member of the United States Administration will travel to Australia in the near future to brief the Prime Minister and other Ministers on the outcome of that summit. Also, of course, the Prime Minister will be able to obtain a first-hand account of the summit when he meets President Reagan later this month.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade of the longstanding concern of successive Australian governments for the plight of Soviet Jews, concerns which have been expressed by both sides of politics. I also refer the Minister to the fact that members of the Christian church in the Soviet Union have also been the subject of persecution and have had their places of worship closed down and other rights of worship severely curtailed. I add that that issue is very pertinent at the moment in view of President Reagan's visit to a monastery in Moscow and his expressed hope that many more places of Christian worship will be reopened. Is the Government aware of the existence of and does it support the work of the Keston College organisation, which is established in Australia and in countries overseas as a voice for silenced and persecuted churches in communist countries? Does the Government monitor the treatment of the Christian church by Soviet authorities? Has it ever expressed any concern to the Government of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics over the suppression of all religious believers there? Further, has the Government made any direct approaches on the church's behalf or on behalf of individual Christians who, for reasons of religious persecution or intolerable constraints on their ability to practise their religion, wish to leave Russia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Government is well aware of the Keston College organisation. The Director of Keston College was received by a senior officer of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade during his visit to Australia last year. The Government took that opportunity to convey its admiration and support for the College's quite invaluable activities in monitoring religious affairs in the Soviet Union, China and East Europe and in assisting believers.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the latter part of the question, the Australian Embassy in Moscow, as I think is now well known, consistently monitors human rights, including the treatment of Christian and other religious groups in the Soviet Union. When the Government's attention has been drawn to individual cases of religious persecution it has made representations to the Soviet Government. Honourable senators will perhaps also be aware that the Australian Government has negotiated a human contacts agreement with the Soviet Union which is presently under consideration by Ministers. In that agreement, the Soviet Union has accepted the obligation to facilitate contacts between adherents of various religious faiths and to permit the entry of religious material.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN BROADCASTING CORPORATION: RADIO NEWS SERVICE IN TASMANIA

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Transport and Communications aware that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) has proposed a serious downgrading of its radio news service in Tasmania, so that it would be run from Melbourne and with a 40 per cent reduction in staff in Tasmania? While acknowledging that such decisions are ones that the ABC itself must be responsible for and not the Minister, I ask the Minister whether he would agree, and convey the view to the ABC, that such a downgrading would be seen as an insult to Tasmania and would do nothing to enhance either the credibility of the news service or the loyalty of Tasmanians to the ABC.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I say generally at the outset that the ABC has recognised, with a little help from the Government, the need to streamline and reorganise its operations in order to maintain and improve its services within its available resources, and to do so all around Australia. That recognition has resulted in a recent major internal review of ABC operations right across the board. It has to be said that the resources review document which has been produced by the ABC is a major step giving a serious indication of willingness by the ABC Board and management to come to grips with some hitherto fairly intractable problems in internal resource allocation and efficiency. Without saying anything about the quality of individual recommendations affecting Tasmania or other areas, on behalf of the Government I welcome the evidence of seriousness of purpose which is now evident in the ABC's approach to these problems.
—How many chiefs have gone from Sydney?

—Hang on; we will get to that. The detailed content of the report will be a matter of consultation with the ABC staff and all relevant unions over the next little while. It is important to appreciate that while a resources review document has been prepared-and it is a thick and substantial one-no actual decisions have been yet made by the ABC Board on the basis of that document. Certainly the Tasmanian ABC staff can be expected to-no doubt they will-participate fully in the consultation process that the ABC board is seeking.

ANSWER.PARA: In response specifically to Senator Coates's concerns about ABC radio news staff in Hobart, not to mention the concern of the Tasmanian people as a whole, I accept that a major concern is the maintenance of an effective high quality local news service. I also accept that the ABC Board and management have that same objective. If, as a result of these review and consultative processes, the ABC were eventually to reduce its news staff in Hobart in the way that has been foreshadowed, I understand that measures would be taken to uphold the present quantity and quality of local news. This might be achieved through various measures such as improved technical equipment, the computerised distribution of news material and so on, the rationalisation of news schedules and the proposed greater use of journalists in actual news presentations. Again, on the current affairs side, I understand that it is part of the proposed rationalisation scenario that there be actually an upgrade to the extent that for the first time there would be a full time radio current affairs reporter in Tasmania.

Finally, with regard to that part of the question which dealt with the possible placement of the radio news editor in Melbourne, this is a matter again on which I am told that certainly no final decision has been made, any more than such decisions have been made anywhere else. The Tasmanian branch of the ABC Staff Association will no doubt be presenting a quite forceful case for the retention of a Hobart-based news editor given that Hobart is, of course, a State capital and Tasmania, as we all know, has a distinctive political, social and cultural life of its own. I am sure those factors will be taken very much into account. Having said all that--

TALK.START.PARA: —Boring!

—It is not half as boring as anything Senator Bishop has been offering us in the last two weeks. Against that background I have to say that it is a matter for the ABC Board and management mercifully. It is not a matter for the Government. I will ensure that the ABC is made aware of the noises Senator Coates has been making and the representations that are in the process of being made to me with some vigour by Senator Harradine and some of his colleagues, and Senator Tate. Anyone else?

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: LOCAL GOVERNMENT AUTHORITIES: PAYMENT OF GENERAL RATES

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Local Government. Is the Government aware that some local authorities are anxious for ministerial direction to be given to Australia Post and Telecom Australia for the payment of general rates or an amount equivalent to general rates due to councils? In view of the financial difficulties that some local authorities are experiencing at present, will the Government change its policy in relation to these instrumentalities so that local authorities are able to be reimbursed the costs of the rates due to them?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is aware of local government's legitimate concerns about Commonwealth trading enterprises paying general rates. It is for this reason that my Department, in conjunction with the Local Government Ministers Conference, prepared and circulated a brochure earlier this year to assist local government in assessing whether a Commonwealth trading enterprise should be paying an amount equivalent to general rates. I would be happy to ensure that Senator Bjelke-Petersen has a copy of that brochure.

ANSWER.PARA: On 13 May 1988, in the context of the Premiers Conference, the Treasurer announced that as part of its review of government business enterprises the Government decided to remove the exemptions for Telecom and Australia Post from local government taxes, rates and charges. This will take effect from July 1989. It is estimated that this change will be worth in the vicinity of $20m to local government and will benefit almost every local government authority in Australia. I am sure that local government will greatly appreciate this move, particularly in the light of recent announcements in the May economic statement.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to you, Mr President. At the end of the last parliamentary session I raised the question of how few portraits of women were hung in our parliamentary halls and corridors. While I have been drawn to Henry Kendall's eyes, other Tweedledum and Tweedledee gentlemen are less attractive to our corridors. Is it possible to reconsider the possibility of former Senator the Hon. Susan Ryan and former Senator the Hon. Dame Margaret Guilfoyle having their portraits done, not only to enhance our halls but also to acknowledge the great contribution of these women to Parliament? Further, is it possible to seek portraits of non-parliamentary women to hang alongside their parliamentary colleagues, as is the case with men?

—In November 1986 my predecessor wrote to the Prime Minister suggesting that the portraits of the then Senator Susan Ryan and Senator Janine Haines be painted and included in the Historic Memorials Collection. The Prime Minister sought the advice of the Secretary of the Historic Memorials Committee which, after reviewing past practice, recommended that these portraits not be commissioned. The views of the Historic Memorials Committee were sought on this recommendation and, I believe, in April 1987 the advice not to proceed was accepted by the Committee. However, I note that Senator Crowley has mentioned Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, as well as the possibility of including portraits of other distinguished women in the collection. I undertake to raise these matters with the Prime Minister and the Historic Memorials Committee at the earliest opportunity.

—I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations to yesterday's strike by metal workers, which has cost Australia about $60m in lost production, continuing industrial lawlessness by the Transport Workers Union of Australia, which has been condemned in the strongest terms by Deputy President Keogh, today's action by Telecom Australia employees, and threats of action in other sectors of the economy which are all part of the unions' 6 per cent wage rise campaign. Will the Government urge the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU), which has endorsed the unions' actions, to call off the campaign before it does any more damage to Australia's fragile economy? What is the Government's view of the appropriate timetable for the coming national wage case hearing?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have a note on the second part of the honourable senator's question, but I understood that it was just about to start. If the honourable senator is asking me when it will end, it would be a bold man who predicted that in relation to any Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission hearing. As to the 6 per cent claims to which Senator Patterson specifically referred, the Minister for Industrial Relations has already made public comments about this issue which I am sure the honourable senator will have read. The essence of those statements is that the current wage guidelines apply until such time as the national wage bench has prescribed a new wage fixation system. The Minister has said that on several occasions.

ANSWER.PARA: I do not want to get into the longstanding debate about how we stop people from expressing their views in this society about particular issues or taking particular actions which may be detrimental to other members of the community. Many interest groups do that. I do not know how we take it further in a society such as this other than adopt the attitude which has been expressed very firmly by the Minister both to the ACTU and, I think, to the unions in question.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade comment on reports that a number of Australian business people have been expelled from the Solomon Islands? What are the implications of this development for our bilaterial relations with the Solomon Islands?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the case that 12 Australian business people have been expelled from the Solomons and that threats have been made against Australian High Commission staff. Australia has traditionally had a very warm and friendly relationship with the Solomon Islands, but it is clear that the reputations of Australian business people and of Australian High Commission personnel have been damaged by unfounded allegations about the propriety of their business dealings, including allegations of gold and drug smuggling.

ANSWER.PARA: The Mr Smith referred to in Press reports has no connection whatsoever with the Australian Government or, to the best of the Government's knowledge, with any legitimate national or international agency. It is clear that his activities in the Solomon Islands have not assisted Australian interests there or those of the Solomon Islands itself. The Government is confident that the present difficulties will be resolved by continued close consultation with the Solomon Islands Government or, where legal disputes exist, through the appropriate Solomon Islands legal channels.

Certainly the Government has full confidence in the High Commissioner, Mr Gaylard, and his staff. Mr Gaylard has worked competently and effectively to protect legitimate Australian interests and to maintain good relations between Australia and the Solomons in a very difficult set of circumstances engendered in the last few months by a persistent campaign of malicious and defamatory rumour-mongering. The Government respects the right of the Solomon Islands Government to admit or exclude whom it chooses to. We, of course, regret the ban imposed on the Australian journalists and have made our position known to the Solomon Islands Government in that respect.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McGauran Sen J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Finance, who I understand is filling in for the absent Minister for Resources. I ask whether the Minister's attention has been drawn to a comment in today's Australian Financial Review by a spokeswoman for Mr Kerin which said:

QUESTION.PARA: Mr Kerin in unsure of the status of the document he was shown by Denison.
But, accepting for the purposes of the argument that it was a contract, Mr Kerin's position is still that there is no overwhelming economic justification for changing the three named mines policy.
Is this comment totally inconsistent with the information in a letter dated 26 May 1988 to Mr Kerin from Mr J. Fowler, President of Denison Mines? I seek leave of the Senate to table this letter.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the light of Denison's obligation to fill uranium contracts to the value of $2 billion from Canada if the Koongarra project in the Northern Territory does not proceed, will the Minister agree that Mr Kerin's position is totally against Australia's economic and social interests and warrants the resignation of the Minister?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly do not agree with the proposition that the best Minister for primary industry the country has ever had should resign. Without wishing to detract from Mr Kerin's excellent performance in that job at all, by and large he has not had much to beat because most of the Ministers for primary industry, at least since World War II, have been members of the Country Party, or the National Party as it now calls itself. So he has not had too much to beat. Nevertheless, he has done an excellent job and is without doubt the best Minister for primary industry the country has had.

ANSWER.PARA: In regard to the other matters, I did glance at the article in today's Australian Financial Review. I did see the passage which quotes or reports-I am not sure what it was now-Mr Kerin as saying that he was unsure of the status of that document. Indeed, as I understand it, Mr Kerin has not actually seen the contract itself; he has seen a photocopy of a contract which I understand was dated 1984. I think that is the reason he was unsure of the legal status of it. As to the letter from Mr Fowler to Mr Kerin, I have not seen that; therefore, I cannot pass any judgment about that at all, nor can I make any judgments about the other questions that have been raised. But I will see whether Mr Kerin has anything to add to my answer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade aware of the speech made by Mr Hayden at the United Nations Special Session on Disarmament, mark 3, in New York today during which he claimed that Australians are willing nuclear targets because of the so-called joint facilities on Australian soil?
—He didn't say that.

—He did say that; that is a quote from his speech. I ask: Why did the Minister not divulge to the disarmament community gathered in New York the negative functions of United States bases; namely, spying for the United States and nuclear targeting of the Soviet Union? How dare the Minister only talk about the verification and monitoring role when, firstly, North West Cape has no such role and, secondly, the SALT agreements which Pine Gap and Nurrungar are meant to monitor did not even exist when those bases were established in the 1960s? Why did the Minister not promote an Australian role in an international monitoring and verification system which the world urgently needs? Finally, does the Minister support the Foreign Minister's assertions that Australians are willing nuclear targets?

—I have not seen either the text of Mr Hayden's speech or reports of it. I am not in a position to verify what language he may have used in this respect. I am sure he would have said that Australians are very willing participants as a nation in the joint facilities that do exist as between Australia and the United States at Pine Gap and elsewhere. They exist for the purpose of making a massive contribution to the peace and stability of this world and they do so through their capacity to provide monitoring, verification and a general contribution to the maintenance of that admittedly uneasy, but nonetheless hitherto prevailing, system of peace that has existed now for so many years. The nature, the rationale and the justification for our participation in these arrangements have been very well and fully articulated on innumerable occasions by Mr Hayden and other Government spokesmen. I do not think I need to reiterate that case here today even to give Senator Vallentine the benefit of another two or three minutes exposure on a videotape that nobody is ever going to watch.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Why does the Government repeatedly deny the negative roles and functions of the bases? It is not telling the whole truth. It is lying by omission. The Minister and the Government repeatedly refuse to admit to the negative functions of these bases, the functions for which they were established in the first place-that is, spying on and targeting the Soviet Union.

—I do not accept that there are negative roles in the way in which Senator Vallentine describes them. For that reason the Government is not minded to admit to that or any other one of the conspiracy theories that Senator Vallentine is fond of pursuing in this place and elsewhere.

—I refer the Minister representing the Treasurer to reports that yesterday's national accounts statistics were leaked before the official time of release. Is it a fact that big profits were or could have been made by currency dealers with access to the prematurely released information? Has an investigation revealed whether the release was due, as suggested in one report, to clerical error? Given that this is but the latest incident in a series of apparent leaks from the Australian Bureau of Statistics, what action is being taken to tighten security at the Bureau? Have any officers been disciplined as a result of inquiries into previous leaks?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not just being pedantic, because I think it was a point of some substance, but there was a reference to previous leaks. I think previous allegations of leaks would be more accurate. I suppose that if somebody does have advance knowledge of the quarterly national accounts there is always a possibility he could make some money out of that advance knowledge in various and quite improper ways. On the issue itself, the alleged leak, I do have a note from the Bureau-I think that this has already been reported elsewhere-that it has asked the Australian Federal Police to investigate allegations that there was a leak yesterday. I do not think I need to quote all of the note but, in part, it states:

ANSWER.PARA: The figures were first reported as available in the financial markets in Sydney at 9.55 a.m.-well before the public release time of 11.30 a.m. . . .
How the figures became available is of direct and serious concern to the ABS and we believe it should be investigated and resolved as quickly as possible . . .
Mr Castles-
that is, the Australian Statistician-
said the scope of the investigation was a matter for the Australian Federal Police.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Health aware of the concern being expressed by the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) about the apparently widespread prescribing of mood altering drugs for children and adolescents? What action is the Federal Government able to take in order to make doctors and the public aware of the caution which should be exercised in such prescribing, and the alternative treatment of behavioural problems of young people which may be preferable to medication?

—I do have a note on this matter. The NHMRC concerns are essentially addressed at the medical profession. The publicity that this question has already received hopefully will alert some medical practitioners to potential problems. It is planned to circulate the findings of the Council-that is, the NHMRC-on this matter throughout the medical community and the Government will be meeting the costs of making that information available. With regard to certain specific items, namely, diazepam, oxazepam, valium, serapax and a couple of others which are more commonly known to me, doctors were advised by letter in November 1986 of the problems of dependence, overuse and abuse associated with these drugs. The NHMRC's concern will be drawn to the attention of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee in case it considers that there is some other action which might be taken in relation to any such drugs which are listed for benefit purposes. Finally, in the May economic statement the Government announced that $2m per annum would be allocated to develop and implement an education campaign to encourage more appropriate use of prescription drugs.

—I address my question to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. On 16 May 1988 the Chairman of the Industry Research and Development Board, Mr Bill Kricker, issued a Press release announcing 10 discretionary grants for research and development by Australian companies. Is the Minister aware that one such grant of nearly half a million dollars was awarded to Rib Loc (Australia) Pty Ltd of South Australia to design and develop a pipeline renovation system? Is the Minister further aware that another Australian company, Danby Pty Ltd of Queensland, already operates successfully in this field and owns patents which cover the type of pipeline renovation envisaged by the half a million dollars grant? Can the Minister explain why such duplication has occurred and what mechanisms the Industry Research and Development Board uses to review its own decisions, particularly as Danby Pty Ltd received grants from the Board in 1985 and 1986 for the development of its system of pipeline renovation?

—The honourable senator refers to the system operated by the Industrial Research and Development Board. I suppose that it is not beyond the wit of man or woman to conclude that the Board may have made a mistake and the system has broken down. I do not know. As far as I am concerned, the Board has discretion in these matters. It operates at arm's length from government. It may have made a mistake in this matter. I do not know. Every time a grant is made there are allegations by some other failed applicant for a grant, or some other company, that the grant has been made to somebody totally inappropriate. I am not saying that is the case on this occasion. But I will make some inquiries and try to provide the honourable senator with an answer to the question as soon as possible.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security aware of descriptions of the Department of Social Security field officers as being like `jack-booted stormtroopers'? What is the Minister's reaction to these claims?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the report to which Senator Childs refers. The issue has been raised with me, not only by Senator Childs, but also by Senator Cooney, who seems to have close contact with the organisation that made the criticism, the Welfare Rights Unit in Victoria. That group is one of the groups in Victoria that have access not only to him, but also, indirectly through him, to the Minister. That is one reason why the Minister, when approached about this report, was surprised at the attitude of the Victorian Welfare Rights Unit. The Unit not only has direct access to the Department of Social Security in Victoria, but also has access to the Minister in his office direct and through members of parliament such as Senator Cooney.

ANSWER.PARA: The second reason why the Minister indicated surprise at the reaction of the Unit is that when one looks at its annual report one sees that only about 6.67 per cent of social security matters involving the Unit deal with field officers. That means that 17 contact calls a year deal with the sorts of people who are involved in the allegation that has been made both in the Melbourne Herald and on Melbourne radio.

However, the Minister has asked me to pass on to Senator Childs and others interested in this matter that the access the Unit has had to the Minister in the past will be maintained. If it provides specific information about the allegations it makes, those allegations will certainly be investigated. It is also apparent from the allegations in the newspaper that the Unit is concerned not with what laws or guidelines govern field officers but with alleged misbehaviour by individual officers of the Department of Social Security. At least, that is the impression one gets from reading the report in the Melbourne Herald and the transcripts of radio interviews.

The Government's response as indicated by the Minister is twofold. One can respond to these sorts of problems in an anecdotal way or in a systematic way. With the encouragement of Senator Walters, I remind honourable senators that in the economic statement last week the Government made two announcements which should have a direct impact on the way the Department of Social Security handles cases. We announced that the Social Security Appeals Tribunal will, as from 1 November this year, no longer have merely a recommendatory power but will have-although being an informal, accessible, independent tribunal-the power to make binding decisions in every case it considers in the future. This is a major advance in protecting the rights of social security recipients.

The other announcement made last week was that the Government will be taking steps to enhance the quality of counter services in the Department by improving training, experience and decision-making capacities. These two initiatives should go some way towards addressing some of the problems in the system. The Government sees the Department of Social Security as generally being a department with extremely dedicated and competent people, but obviously, if a unit has a complaint to make about it, we will take it up.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Local Government to comments attributed to her in last Tuesday's Hobart Mercury that the proposed constitutional change concerning local government would not prevent a local authority from being replaced by a commission or some other form of non-elected administration. On what basis does the Minister assert, `What it will do is ensure that after a suitable interval the local council will be returned.'?

—I have not seen the article to which Senator Calvert refers. Perhaps under the circumstances it would be best if he at least lets me have a look at what has been reported. I have said that constitutional recognition of local government is very important in terms of the status of local government and its relationship with both State and Commonwealth departments. I would want to see the alleged quotation before I comment further. Senator Calvert and I will be putting our respective views about constitutional recognition of local government. I am sure that we can clarify what I mean by constitutional recognition, in putting the Yes case, and what he means by it, in putting the No case.
—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Does the Minister deny making the statement? I did show her the article. It contains a photo of her.
—Oh, that one.

—Yes, that one. Is the Minister also aware that the New South Wales and Western Australian Constitution Acts specifically allow for the existence of other than elected councils? Is such a provision within the terms of the Government's referendum proposal or do we face the very real possibility of a drawn-out legal challenge in the event of a State government deciding to replace an elected council with some other form of administration?
—That is really another question, but I will ask Senator Reynolds to deal with that part of it which is supplementary.

—I welcome the opportunity to do so. I apologise to Senator Calvert. He did show me the article. But he said in his question `last Tuesday', which I assumed was the Tuesday just past. In fact, he refers to a much earlier article relating to a visit I made to Tasmania over a fortnight ago. The questions that Senator Calvert has raised should properly be referred to the Attorney-General.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. In view of the reputation of General Pinochet's Chilean regime as one of the most brutally oppressive dictatorships in the world, being responsible for the imprisonment and torture of its critics and the death of an estimated 50,000 people, what is the Government's attitude to the multimillion dollar investment of Australian companies in Chile? Does the Minister agree that the Australian investments in Chilean industries give a regrettable economic and psychological boost to the Pinochet regime and that this runs counter to Australia's strong stance as an advocate of international human rights? Has the Government made any attempt to dissuade Australian companies from investing in Chile because of the substantial support that such investments give to the regime? Does the Government intend to issue guidelines to ensure that Australian companies remove their existing investments in Chile and that companies do not make any further such investments in Chile?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is an unfortunate fact that Chile is one of many countries where domestic policies fall far short of acceptable standards. The Australian Government has for a very long time taken a strong and prominent role in condemning human rights abuses in Chile. That has been reflected not only in Australia's work in the United Nations, notably the Commission on Human Rights, but also in very frequent representations to Chilean Government authorities. It follows that the Australian Government would wish that Australian employers and entrepreneurs abroad in Chile, as elsewhere, conduct their activities as they should in Australia, that is to say, with respect for human rights.
—You had better talk to Bondy.

—We have, Senator Stone. Whether Senator Stone would in these circumstances is a matter for fascinating speculation, given his Party's track record on human rights, domestically or anywhere else. In September 1987, when Mr Bond's investments in Chile became a subject of public discussion, Mr Hawke drew Mr Bond's attention quite forcefully to the views of the Australian Government on the human rights situation in Chile. That message, which was very publicly conveyed, would not have been lost on other Australian companies.

ANSWER.PARA: Might I say, more generally, that the Australian Government does not normally intervene in the investment decisions abroad of Australian companies except in special cases, the most obvious among them being South Africa, where the racist basis of the regime singles it out for widespread condemnation and sanctions. Regrettably, it is a fact that that widespread condemnation is not nearly as evident today from the Opposition parties in Australia as it was under the previous leadership of Malcolm Fraser when there was a very strong bipartisan spirit in our approach to South Africa and associated southern African issues. It is a matter of great regret and concern for the Government that there is a manifest impending backing away now from that bipartisan policy.

Might I distinguish the South African case from the Chilean one, in response to Senator Macklin's specific question, by saying that several things are relevant. One is the absence of any wide call by Chileans in Chile for sanctions against the Chilean regime. Another relevant consideration is that there is in existence a program for a return to a form of democracy by early 1990. That has led us, after careful consideration of the sorts of issues that have been raised by Senator Macklin, to form the view that the kinds of guidelines he proposes are not justified in that instance.

TALK.START.PARA: —In Question Time today Senator Lewis asked me a question about Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) references. I said at the time that I was uncertain about the fate of the sugar reference and the dairy reference. I understand that the dairy reference will go ahead because there is the mid-term review of the so-called Kerin dairy plan that was foreshadowed when the arrangements were introduced two years ago. As I understand it, sugar will not now be referred to the IAC.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 30 May Senator Cooney asked me a question about the Westpac Bank in Seoul. It was alleged that certain employees at the bank had been locked up by the bank. I have obtained an answer to his question which seems to suggest that, although the front door of the bank was locked, the back door was open and it was all a mistake. However, as it is a long answer, I seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows-

Westpac has advised that some of the information in the newspaper reports was factually inaccurate. The bank maintains that whilst the main door of the Seoul Branch premises was closed on 27 May, following the cessation of normal business, there was an alternative exit open for use. Furthermore, before locking the main door, the bank ensured the availability of that exit and that one of the building guards was available to ensure the safety of the union members.

Furthermore, the bank has advised that it fully recognises the rights of the union. Contrary to newspaper reports the bank has indicated it has not asked for a promise to forgo group action in the future. To further progress the wage claim concerned a meeting took place on Monday, 30 May 1988 at which Korean Ministry of Labour officials and representatives of the Korean peak trade union organisation were present. The meeting did not resolve the dispute and further meetings will take place. Westpac has maintained close contact with the Korean Ministry of Labour who have not been critical of the bank's handling of the dispute.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 23 May Senator Michael Baume asked me a question about the Prime Minister's guest list for the opening of Parliament House. The Prime Minister has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: I do not intend to provide a list of my personal guests; nor do I intend to ask the Presiding Officers or the Leader of the Opposition to list their personal guests.

There are about 260 former Senators and Members, each of whom was invited with spouse or partner. It was not possible to accommodate these 520 persons in the Great Hall. Accordingly, they were invited to be seated in the Members' Hall, except for former Prime Ministers and Deputies, former Presiding Officers and a very limited number of other former Senators and Members such as Sir Paul Hasluck who, by virtue of their eminence in other fields, were seated in the Great Hall.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I regret to advise the Senate that yesterday in answering a question earlier asked of me by Senator Bjelke-Petersen I inadvertently provided some inaccurate information. It concerned the trans-Pacific flight by Sir Charles Kingsford Smith in 1928. I am indebted to that latter day aviator in our midst, Senator MacGibbon, for pointing out to me and the geniuses who briefed me that Kingsford Smith made landfall north of Ballina on9 June in the year in question and proceeded up the coast to land at Brisbane's Eagle Farm Airport. I think that someone took the view that landfall meant falling on land, rather than passing over the coast at the point in question.

ANSWER.PARA: For those honourable senators who wish to pursue the full details of the matter, as I am now duly chastened, I am referred by Senator MacGibbon and others to the definitive account of the flight in Kingsford Smith's own book, which I now propose to refer to the departments in question which are engaged in organising the commemoration to ensure that they get right the flight, the aircraft, the date and the places that we are commemorating.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Newman asked me a question concerning certain investigations by the Australian Federal Police (AFP) into alleged problems with certain cheques provided to doctors. She asked:

ANSWER.PARA: Was not a comprehensive list of doctors provided to the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts and was not that information passed on to the police late last year?
I do not know whether such a list was provided to the Joint Parliamentary Committee, but in any event the AFP has not been provided with a list of doctors' names. She asked further:

Is it not also true that details of cheques dated after November 1987, namely in February, to Dr Alan White for $10,700 and in March 1988 to Dr Evans for $90 and $636.90, have also been given to the police?

The answer to that is yes, the AFP has been given copies of these cheques. Inquiries with the Health Insurance Commission (HIC) have revealed that these cheques were issued as a result of computer error. I informed the Senate of this fact on 10 May 1988. She then asked:
Did Constable Warren Grey of the AFP advise Dr Menon in April that the only information which was still required by the police was the telephone numbers of the doctors involved?

The AFP advises me no. As I informed the Senate on 20 April and 10 May, the AFP has approached Dr Menon on numerous occasions seeking comprehensive details of the doctors who Dr Menon has claimed are in receipt of bogus cheques. This information has not been forthcoming. As part of its inquiries, the AFP developed a list of its own from copies of correspondence to members of parliament and senators from members of the medical profession. I understand that Dr Menon was asked whether he knew the telephone numbers of the doctors on the AFP list. Fourthly and finally, Senator Newman asked:

In light of the fact that on 4 May Constable Grey advised Dr Mackay that there was a need for a proper and fuller investigation of the allegations and that he planned to go to Hobart the following week to interview Dr Mackay and Dr White and that he has not done so . . .

I understand from the AFP that in the normal course of events the AFP would seek to close the file on the assessment of the cheques previously cleared by the HIC and, in so doing, would seek statements from Dr Mackay and Dr White. Originally an AFP officer from Sydney, the region in which the complete investigation was undertaken, planned to visit Hobart to take those statements. Those doctors will now be interviewed by AFP officers from Hobart. I understand that that will be done as soon as possible and at a mutually agreeable time.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Wednesday, 25 May Senator Peter Baume asked me a question concerning the circumstances of the advice provided to the President of the Senate on the parliamentary qualifications of former Senator Wood. In particular, Senator Baume asked about the timing of legal advice received by the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs and about future action should the same circumstances emerge in future. With respect to the first question, I draw Senator Baume's attention to the Hansard record. On page 98 evidence is provided that, in addition to subsequent written advice, oral advice had been obtained from officers of the Attorney-General's Department before the letter to Senator Sibraa was signed. The evidence there noted that there was no legal obligation to inform the President of the Senate; however, it was the view that it was both desirable and appropriate that the President should be informed of a matter which went to the composition of the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —It so happens there are some five or six minutes remaining before the guillotine has its full operation in the Senate, in the procedure that this Government has adopted, with the support of the Australian Democrats, to allocate precise times for packages of Bills so that it can complete its program by the end of this day. I can only say, nearing the conclusion of these matters in the chamber, that an hour and a half for the consideration of substantial education, employment, training and research matters is a minuscule and most inadequate amount of time for this chamber to do justice to the importance of the matters that are before us. I know that Senator Macklin and Senator Haines, who are in the chamber, agree with the view that we ought to be more enlightened in the way in which we handle the business of this chamber, not least in this education, training and employment area. I can only urge that in future sessions of parliament, when we have moved from this provisional Parliament House to the chamber in the new House, we actually put into practice the aspirations we have expressed here today-that we manage not only the final week but the final month of parliament in such a way that we give proper attention to important Bills such as these.

—I agree with the comments Senator Teague has made. An appalling number of amendments went through the committee stage without being discussed in any detail. As a former educator I find it appalling, as I am sure do many of my colleagues, that education should be dealt with in such a way. We on this side of the chamber have been criticised for delaying some of the discussion, but had the Employment, Education and Training Bill been brought forward earlier, appropriate and proper consideration could have been given to it. I want to put on the record my displeasure at the way in which such a serious and important matter for Australia and Australia's future has been dealt with in this chamber.

—I have listened to the continual harping about the guillotine being used on legislation. We on the Government side are not happy that the legislation has had to go through in this fashion; but blame for that is not on this side of the chamber. I ask honourable senators to take their minds back to the filibustering debates in this chamber in the past two weeks and previously, and to remember the number of matters of public importance and urgency motions that have been raised and the amount of time wastage that goes on in this place when fruitful and meaningful debate could be taking place, instead of what we had the other night-the repetitious, boring and continual arguments. Four hours were spent on one clause of one Bill before a gag and the guillotine had to be used. I think we should all have learnt a lesson from the situation we find ourselves in, and I hope that we will address that in the new Parliament House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I feel I am obliged to respond to the comments made by Senator McKiernan. There has been absolutely no filibustering by the Opposition throughout this session. What we must recall is the mismanagement by this Government of the program, right from week one, when we sat here for weeks and weeks, and on Senator McKiernan's own admission, only a few weeks ago, very few Bills managed to get through this place-only because of the Government's gross mismanagement. He talks about matters of public importance, urgency motions and so forth. The Australian Democrats, who decided to go against every agreement and arrangement that has been made in this place in the last few weeks, moved the urgency motion the other day-not the Opposition, but those members of the left wing of the Labor Government. They are sitting on the wrong side. They should be over there where they belong, with the left wing of the Labor Government.

SPEECH.PARA: We have not filibustered. Those constitutional amendments were particularly important to get the message to the Australian public about the lies and deceit that this Government is trying to put across to it. There is absolutely no cause for the Government to say on any account that we have filibustered in any sense of the word. I want to make sure that we have put to rest any accusation that that is so. We have seen particularly important referendum legislation absolutely rammed through this place, thanks to the Democrats, who have no morality whatsoever when it comes to making sure that legislation is attended to in a proper fashion. Important legislation, such as these education Bills, the Comcare legislation and the rest, is now going through, thanks to the Democrats.
