DEBATE.TITLE: COMMONWEALTH EMPLOYEES' REHABILITATION AND COMPENSATION BILL 1988UNITED STATES NAVAL COMMUNICATION STATION (CIVILIAN EMPLOYEES) BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 24 May, on motion by Senator Tate:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Commonwealth Employees' Rehabilitation and Compensation Bill 1988 is an important Bill, as are all the other Bills which are being jackbooted through this chamber. For instance, the education package, which was just shoved through with the support of the Australian Democrats, was equally important, particularly the Bill dealing with the National Board of Employment, Education and Training. As the title of the Bill before us indicates, the Bill deals with rehabilitation and compensation for Commonwealth employees. This is an area that is long overdue for reform. There is no disagreement between the major parties in this chamber, including the Democrats, that this area does need reform.
—They are not a major party.

—I was including them after the major parties. The costs of compen- sation for Commonwealth employees have es- calated in the past decade, to a point almost beyond belief. The people from Comcare have been kind enough to supply me with a graph outlining real and actual expenditure in the years from 1977-78 to 1986-87. It shows that real expenditure-that is, expenditure for previous years expressed in the current money value-went from just above $70m in 1977-78 to around $210m in 1986-87. That is an enormous rise. I remind the chamber of the publicity given to the increase in Commonwealth compensation last year, and I think the year before, by the coalition's Waste Watch Committee. Something had to be done, partly because of the enormous blow-out inexpenditure in this area. But there are other reasons why something had to be done. It is not simply a question of the cost blow-out. It is a question of the situation in which people who, unfortunately, need compensation find themselves.

SPEECH.PARA: There is agreement that the existing system is inadequate. It is a disaster. It benefits some people much more than others, leaving some people, partly perhaps as a consequence of their own activities but partly through the luck of the way the cards fall, in much more unfortunate circumstances than we would care to leave them. So for two reasons we agree that this area is long overdue for Government attention. We are very concerned at the position of those who need compensation and at the disparity between one person and another. I think that that outlines the need for this reform.

The Government originally presented us with a Bill that was defective in two respects and has now sought, at least marginally, to improve that. The original Bill denied Commonwealth employees access to compensation through common law. The coalition parties simply could not wear that. It was totally unacceptable to the coalition parties to deprive Commonwealth employees of that avenue of compensation. That matter was raised in the debate in the House of Representatives, I think in April.

There was a second area of concern to the coalition, and that was that the position of existing beneficiaries needed to be protected. We agreed that we needed to make changes for people who required compensation from the date of application of this Bill onwards-we agreed that something needed to be done there-but we most certainly believed that existing beneficiaries were entitled to have their position protected. We could get into long arguments about whether changing the dollar value that an existing beneficiary receives is in some way retrospective. The two arguments are quite clear. The one which I presume the Government would endorse is one that says, `No, we are not retrospectively affecting any dollar value; we are prospectively affecting it. People cannot expect to continue to retain the benefits they have'-given, of course, that they are legitimately in need of compensation.

The other side of that argument is to say that the first argument is totally ridiculous. People who have been injured through their work and are on compensation have made plans on the basis of what they have been told and are entitled to make those plans and not have the Commonwealth back out at some later stage. We believed very strongly that the position of existing beneficiaries needed to be protected for the future, while not denying that changes needed to be made to Commonwealth compensation and rehabilitation arrangements for people who received an injury or required compensation as a consequence of their work. That was where the debate was at in the House of Representatives.

The Government acknowledged that there was some merit-I think that is a fair way of classifying it-in the position we put. The Government was prepared to negotiate and to see whether improvements could be made. The negotiations reached the stage where the Government was prepared to say that it would protect the position of existing beneficiaries aged 65 years and over but would not make the same allowance for those aged 65 and under and, with respect to our concern for access to compensation through common law, would make some other changes. Basically, the Government is prepared to say that one can, for economic loss, go only to Comcare and receive 70 per cent of one's updated weekly salary for the rest of one's life. In relation to the other elements of compensation, the non-economic ones, if one wanted to go to common law under the amended situation one would be entitled to do so but there would be a $110,000 cap on that access to common law. Irrespective of whether one received compensation for non-economic loss through Comcare or common law, one would receive compensation for economic loss at 70 per cent of one's updated weekly salary.

There is no denying that the position the Government is now taking is more acceptable than its previous position. It is an improvement. I think everyone acknowledges that it has been made only as a result of the arguments put forward by the coalition in the House of Representatives and the Government's reconsideration of the matter as a consequence of those arguments. The coalition is very pleased that the Government has at least seen some sense in what we have suggested. We are pleased that, as a consequence of our work, it seems that this Bill will now be amended and put into a far more satisfactory form than it was in the first place. I am sure that all senators and members gain some satisfaction when a Bill is amended and improved. Even though it is not improved to the extent that we would like it to be, it is certainly an improvement.

We are very pleased that the position of existing beneficiaries aged 65 and over will now be protected, as it should be. We are concerned about the position of beneficiaries under 65. We could argue in this chamber for a long time about the relative position of existing beneficiaries under 65 under the old system and under the new system, but the bottom line of the coalition's view is that their income ought to be protected. The Government has agreed to do this for beneficiaries over 65 but not for those under 65. I understand that the argument for what is, in effect, a real reduction in the income of existing beneficiaries under 65 is that they pick up other benefits. As I said, we could argue for a long time about the give and take in that respect, but, given the time limits on this debate, suffice it to say that the bottom line that the coalition will not go beyond is that the income of existing beneficiaries under 65 ought to be protected. The Government came part of the way by protecting the position of existing beneficiaries over 65 but could not see its way to protect the position of beneficiaries under 65. It is a matter of regret that it could not do that.

Let me turn now to the common law position. It has been a fundamental feature of our legal system that if one believes one is injured as a consequence of someone's wrong-doing or negligence one can, to put it colloquially, have a go at him. One can let the courts test what damage has been done and recoup a benefit. To remove that option from Commonwealth employees is a change that the coalition could not and would not come at.

The Government has said, `Well, let's see whether we can compromise'. Some people say that politics is the art of compromise but in the end someone has to wear the outcome of a compromise situation. Sometimes it is appropriate to stand by the principle that we want implemented and not compromise. That is our position in this debate. We tried to negotiate with the Government to bring it to its senses and to allow Commonwealth employees who were seeking compensation to choose whether or not they wanted to go through common law.

The Government has now suggested that, provided the income loss portion of compensation goes through Comcare, the other, non-economic, portion could be dealt with under common law with a cap of $110,000. The coalition simply cannot accept that position. It is untenable to restrict the access of anyone-it just happens that this Bill deals only with Commonwealth employees-to common law. Accordingly, as an expression of our very strong dissatisfaction in those two elements of this Bill, we will be voting against the third reading of the Bill. We shall express our dissatisfaction with the fact that the Government could not see its way to protect the existing beneficiaries aged under 65 and has consistently refused to allow Commonwealth employees who are seeking compensation full access to common law. Accordingly, we intend to move a second reading amendment that reads:
At the end of motion, add ``, but the Senate condemns the Government for:
(a) restricting the access of Commonwealth employees to compensation through Common Law and;
(b) failing to adequately protect all existing beneficiaries aged under 65''.

I wish to comment on the second element of that motion, which reads `failing to adequately protect all existing beneficiaries aged under 65'. We are aware that, with the passage of this legislation, the situation of a significant number of beneficiaries aged under 65 will be very much improved. The economic situation of those who are receiving compensation at the moment and who do not have superannuation will be improved quite substantially. But it is those who at the moment receive more than 70 per cent of their updated weekly earnings who will suffer. They will suffer because the amount of income they receive will effectively be frozen until it falls in real terms to 70 per cent of their updated weekly earnings. Obviously, someone who is receiving only 75 per cent at the moment will not experience much of a fall but someone who is receiving 90 to 100 per cent will experience quite a substantial fall progressively over four years. We believe that it is inappropriate that they be asked to do that. They are existing beneficiaries and ought to be dealt with under the existing system.

I have seen a costing of a $100 food basket over three or four years at varying rates. We could strike no acceptable rate of increase in the cost of a $100 food basket which would leave the existing beneficiaries in a good position at the end of four years. The price of food, on which a high proportion of a lower income is spent, as we know, rises at a very substantial rate, and these people are going to be prejudiced in a very real way if their present position is not maintained. We understand that there are some people-that is, existing beneficiaries under 65-whose position will improve under this package. But some-those receiving more than 70 per cent of their updated weekly earnings-are going to suffer, and we say that their position should be protected.

Finally, let me make a few remarks with respect to the conduct of these negotiations. I feel that it is particularly appropriate for me to make these remarks having, as you may know, Mr Acting Deputy President, discovered an inconsistency in one of the referenda Bills and the Government having made an amendment to that Bill, the Constitution Alteration (Fair Elections) Bill. It acknowledged that the words in the Bill did not really mean what it wanted them to mean, so it had to change them around. There are differing views on that matter. Some people are of the view that the Government knew all along what it meant in its original Constitution Alteration (Fair Elections) Bill. It meant that systems, such as the d'Hondt system, which is being suggested for the Australian Capital Territory, were unfair and undemocratic. The Government, having had it pointed out that a system of election that it was suggesting for the Australian Capital Territory was inconsistent with what it had described as fair and democratic, changed the definition. I do not want to say any more about that other than to highlight it as an example of this Government not paying attention to legislation that comes before the chamber.

We have another example of that. Late yesterday afternoon I had discussions with some people from Comcare and from the Minister's office to go through the Government's proposed amendments. That, in itself, should be something of an indication of the care that has been put into this legislation. Members of the coalition were given the specific wording of the legislation as late as yesterday afternoon. There is no denying that negotiations had been going on for some time. It is not just the coalition and the Government that were parties to these negotiations; the Australian Democrats and the various people who are to be affected by this legislation were included.

Sometimes people think they are talking about the same thing when they are not; so when we see the final wording it may not represent what we thought we were negotiating for. That could be because there was a genuine misunderstanding about what we were negotiating for, but it could also be as a consequence of sloppy drafting and the people who were writing the legislation not understanding what the Government wants. That is the very reason that there should always be a full and proper examination of legislation in both chambers, but particularly in this chamber, the House of review. We should have every opportunity to go through legislation before the chamber word by word, think it over the next day and go through it word by word again. If we do not, perhaps not through any malice but through lack of opportunity to review legislation, bad legislation goes through and everybody says, `That is not what we meant'.

We have a very good example of that. I was looking through the suggested amendments to clause 133 of this Bill. Last night the Government was of a mind to include a proposed new subsection (3). For the benefit of those honourable senators who have not perused the Bill completely, perhaps I should explain that clause 133 deals with people over 65 years of age who had superannuation. The proposed new subsection (3) states that whenever the former employee's superannuation amount is increased, the amount of compensation payable under subsection 2 shall be reduced, or further reduced as the case requires, by an amount equal to the amount of the increase.

In other words, as people get increases in their superannuation the Government will take away compensation. That effectively meant that people over the age of 65 would have their nominal incomes frozen. The Government was presenting this to us as an amendment which would protect the position of people aged 65 and over. I had some discussions with relevant officials and we entered into a debate over who meant what when we were talking about protecting the position of existing beneficiaries over the age of 65. Some people put it to me that perhaps the Government meant all along that it would protect the existing dollar value of existing beneficiaries over the age of 65. But, of course, the existing beneficiaries over the age of 65 said, `Oh, no. If you protect only our existing dollar value, in real terms we will be on a declining income. We will be no better off than what you are planning for people under the age of 65'.

There have been a few discussions. What was I told this morning? I was told this morning that it was a mistake, that the draftsman did not understand what everybody wanted. I can understand that. People make mistakes. I mean no abuse of the officials or the draftsperson involved. It is simply a function of doing things at the last minute. The Government does not give the Opposition or the coalition its amendments; so we do not have sufficient time to peruse them. We found that flaw in the legislation. One wonders what would have happened if we had not. Would the Government have found it? It certainly did not find the flaws and inconsistencies in its own referenda package-another package that has been shoved through this place with the assistance of the Democrats. I do not know whether the Democrats noticed that flaw; I do not even know whether they were involved in these discussions last night. But that is a classic example of the Government not understanding what it wants to do and then coming into this place and saying, `You have 1 1/2 hours to discuss this. You had better make up your minds. Here are the amendments', and away we go. It is an appalling situation.

In conclusion, we are grateful that the Government has seen the error of its ways and has chosen to amend the Bill as it has. We consider it a matter of real regret that the Government has refused to protect the existing beneficiaries under the age of 65 and that it has not seen the merit in allowing full access to common law compensation for Commonwealth employees should they require it. I have circulated some amendments and, if we have the time for a committee stage debate, we will be debating these amendments. In the event that there is not time, I will seek, at the conclusion of time for this debate, to rely on a contingent notice of motion and have those amendments voted on in a block. I move the following amendment to the Commonwealth Employees' Rehabilitation and Compensation Bill:
At the end of motion, add ``, but the Senate condemns the Government for:
(a) restricting the access of Commonwealth employees to compensation through Common Law; and
(b) failing to adequately protect all existing beneficiaries aged under 65''.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the information of honourable senators, I table a supplementary explanatory memorandum relating to the amendments to be moved by the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to participate in the debate on the Commonwealth Employees' Rehabilitation and Compensation Bill 1988. At the outset, I point out that, to a certain degree at least, this is a reform package with regard to Comcare. Firstly, I wish to mention some of those aspects of the Bill which the Australian Democrats believe are positive. This Bill raises the incomes of generally younger recipients of compensation payments who have little or no superannuation entitlement. Their situation will be improved because they will now receive 75 per cent of pre-injury earnings with a floor, or lower limit, of $195; $50 for a dependent spouse and $25 for each dependent child. The current flat rate is $182.20 per week per adult, $47.70 for a dependent spouse and $22.70 for each dependent child. That is one of the improvements in the situation of a great many people.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, I wish to point to those aspects of the Bill which increase payments for support services. Currently, only a flat rate of $32.30 per week is available for support services. Under this scheme, up to $400 a week will be available for attendant care; for bathing, grooming, assistance with artificial aids and exercise, up to $200 a week, and for household and family support services another $200 a week. The Democrats believe that this is a particularly important move for people on compensation payments, firstly, because I think all of us agree it provides an opportunity for people to be able to live in their own homes even though they may have disabilities of any kind, whether or not they are on compensation payments. Secondly, the availability of these additional payments would in many cases enhance the rehabilitation of people on compensation payments. So in general terms those reforms are noted by the Democrats.

However, we have several significant problems with this legislation. The transitional arrangements in the legislation for those currently receiving compensation will, to some degree, result in a reduction of some people's income. Present recipients are entitled to rely on past Government promises to pay compensation awards on which, of course, they have budgeted for their retirement years and as a result of which in many cases they have forgone their rights to sue at common law. To these people the legislation, as I have said, is to some degree retrospective in a punitive sense. It is the first time since the Commonwealth Workmen's Compensation Act was introduced in 1912 that the rights and entitlements of pre-existing cases are not fully protected. It is particularly unjust and harsh to place the people affected in the position of being on fixed incomes for indefinite periods which, in many cases, could be lengthy.

The new compensation Acts recently introduced in some States have all been prospective. The Government has agreed with that and there are amendments before us under which it will forgo its original intention to reduce the incomes of those aged over 65. This is to be commended and I believe that it is a positive outcome of the negotiations to which Senator Vanstone referred earlier. However, the legislation will still reduce these people's income over time to 70 per cent of their normal weekly earnings. Those people who really thought that the Commonwealth Government had committed itself to an agreed level of income support and arranged their lifestyles on that basis will now be put on a fixed income for an indefinite period until their incomes are eroded by inflation to the 70 per cent level.

Our other concern, apart from our concern about the transitional arrangements-although we do concede that there is transition at least built into the package-relates to common law access. Clause 44 (1) of the Bill abolishes the right of Commonwealth employees to sue the Commonwealth for injuries or death before or after the commencement of the Act. We do now have, of course, Government amendments that will allow common law access in the case of death and common law determination of non-economic loss to lump sum components for permanent impairment and pain and suffering up to a maximum of $110,000. This is a concession but it does not really go as far as we would have liked. As a general principle, we believe that common law action should be available to an injured worker in a system so that there is some choice. The Government claims that the benefits it is offering are so generous that there is no need for common law access. If that is true, of course, it could have left the option of access there and then persuaded injured workers to opt for Comcare rather than risking common law action.

It is dangerous to make the Commonwealth immune from prosecutions. This encourages bad work practices, and we note most strongly that the Government has not yet introduced its occupational health and safety legislation, which would be an alternative way of encouraging safer work practices in the absence of common law access. We strongly make the point to the Government that this legislation should be part of a package. We understand that the Government is moving in that direction, and we are hopeful of seeing that legislation early in the next session. It is important that the occupational health and safety legislation be there to encourage, as I have said, safer work practices and to provide further protection for Commonwealth employees. At the moment the balance is very strongly tipped towards the Government's side.

A further complaint we have is that the Government does not have the table of maims for us which will be the basis of making determinations when determining a lump sum payment for permanent impairment. Even if it could be argued that the benefits provided by this legislation are generous, the Democrats believe that common law access is still needed to ensure they remain generous, as a kind of balance. If individuals feel they will get higher benefits under common law, the Government would have an incentive to continue to improve Comcare's benefits. So denying common law access to future compensation candidates enables the Government, if it is so moved, to reduce gradually its benefits in real terms over time. We believe that would be a most unfortunate thing for any government to do. As well, common law assessments of damages can act as a general indicator of community standards and a benchmark for moving compensation to new directions. The recent asbestos cases and a number of repetition strain injury cases can perhaps be cited as examples of that process in action. Common law assessment of damages is the only system which assesses compensation on a truly individual basis. It takes into account the special circumstances and needs of the disabled worker as opposed to dealing with that worker in accordance with a prior prescribed formula.

I have just a few words to say about what we believe is a compelling case especially for members of the defence forces and the Australian Federal Police for access to common law. We understand that the Government intends to legislate a separate compensation scheme for members of the defence forces, and certainly I believe the Government should consider giving members of the forces the right to sue under common law. If that is so, they in particular should be exempted from this attempt to limit common law access. Members of the defence forces are also concerned about clause 5 (5), which states that the Commission is not liable to pay compensation if an injury is sustained by the employee voluntarily and unreasonably subjecting himself or herself to abnormal risk of injury. The very nature of service life means that members are often exposed to high risk circumstances, and the question of what is unreasonable and voluntary arises in those circumstances. If a senior officer deliberately places himself or herself at risk or in a dangerous situation to protect others and is injured or killed, is that unreasonable and voluntary? As I said, we now have some concessions from the Government with regard to access to common law and, although it is limited, it will be there as a result of the Government's amendments, and the Democrats are pleased about that.

I want to make a couple of points about the revenue aspects of this legislation. It is clear that the major reason the Government has not been inclined to be more generous on the issue of the retrospective punitive treatment of many people currently receiving compensation benefits and in the area of access to common law rights to sue is, as usual, its desire to save more money. In fact this scheme will require more expenditure in the first years of operation anyway, and the substantial savings, estimated in the explanatory memorandum to be $350m immediately and over $1,900m by 1988, are savings of outstanding liability-that is, future savings. Nobody is denying the Government these massive future savings, most of which will come from discontinuing compensation payments after retirement age. The question is really whether the Government can afford to maintain payments to those who are currently in the scheme, and whether it can afford general access to common law. The Australian Democrats believe that governments should continue to meet past commitments and that a good compensation system needs to give people the option of common law action. These problems are of concern to all of my colleagues, as I have outlined. I refer in particular to those remaining elements of retrospectivity, which are at least to some degree punitive for some people. My colleague Senator Macklin has asked me to place on record his opposition to the Bill on this basis in particular.

In conclusion, I will take a couple of moments to refer to the Opposition's amendments. We will support Senator Vanstone's second reading amendment. It expresses, as I think I have already said, substantially the views the Australian Democrats hold on the two issues concerning existing beneficiaries and access to common law. Senator Vanstone referred to substantive committee stage amendments and outlined in her contribution the situation at the time of the debate on this legislation in the House of Representatives in April and the subsequent negotiations which have resulted in the Government's concessions and its amendments. I must say I was astounded when, 10 minutes before the debate began, the Opposition's committee stage amendments were circulated.

While Senator Vanstone referred to negotiations, I want to put it on record as the Australian Democrats social security spokesperson responsible for carriage of this Bill that I have had no contact whatsoever from anybody in the Opposition in relation to the amendments which appeared on my desk 10 minutes before the debate. Since I have no amendments to move to this legislation there has been no need for me to speak to the Opposition. Since it is a frequent practice of the Opposition to move amendments in the House of Representatives and not to move them in the Senate, I had no reason to expect amendments on this legislation, or on any other. A number of groups have been involved in the negotiation and lobbying process, as I am sure everybody in this chamber is aware. In line with the frequent practice I have mentioned, it did not surprise me when others who had been speaking with us on this were of the opinion that negotiations with the Government needed to continue, because there was no expectation of the Opposition's amendments being proposed.

The important point which was impressed on me by groups with concern about this legislation was that we should continue to negotiate with the Government to get the best possible case. The Australian Democrats often find themselves in such a situation. As I said, we have received representations from a great many people. This legislation introduces reforms in the area of rehabilitation and compensation for Commonwealth employees. I have clearly outlined those-(Quorum formed) I am outlining the position of the Australian Democrats on the committee stage amendments of the Opposition. Faced with these amendments just a few minutes before the debate begins, of course there is no time to go to all my colleagues-most of whom are now here-and, particularly, to those groups with whom we have been in discussion in the many weeks since this Bill was first debated in the House of Representatives.

Most people-I believe even the Opposition-are concerned about those people who will be advantaged by this legislation. Now that the Government has proposed two amendments, on common law and on protection for at least some of these people, there is a feeling that, although this legislation is not everything we would want, we do not want to lose this reform altogether. There is the danger that if the Bill is amended in the way proposed by the Opposition in this House and goes back to the other House the Government will take it off altogether and will reintroduce the original, unamended legislation in the Budget session, at which time, following former practice, the Opposition will pass it because it will be a Budget measure which cannot be denied the Government. That has happened in one of my other portfolio areas. There is a fine history of this.

The Democrats do not consider that the Opposition's position is legitimate. Farmers in this country have been denied income equalisation deposits (IEDs) for tax purposes for more than four years because the Government took exactly the action I described. The Opposition, along with the Australian Democrats, opposed the removal of income equalisation deposits provisions. We attempted between us to amend the IED legislation because there were tax rorts in the system. As we wanted the legislation amended, the Government took it away and brought it back in the next Budget session as Budget legislation. The Opposition refused to support the Democrats in tossing it out as Budget legislation. The Government was therefore able to eliminate income equalisation deposits.

The Democrats concern is that the same process would recur and that those people on 20 or 25 per cent and other low levels of their former earnings would have to be there for goodness knows how much longer if this reform were denied. We are also concerned that the Government could bring back the legislation without the negotiated concessions which have improved the legislation to some extent-Senator Vanstone has suggested the Opposition has also been involved in the negotiations-for people in receipt of Commonwealth compensation and rehabilitation. For those reasons, the Democrats will not support the Opposition's committee stage amendments. However, we will support the amendment to the motion for the second reading of the Bill because it expresses our views as well as those of the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Once again we have seen an example of the very convoluted logic of the Australian Democrats, but I do not wish to spend much time on them when we have so little debating time today-thanks to the Government's behaviour. I begin by saying, as so many of my colleagues have before me, that it is unacceptable that a far-reaching and important piece of legislation for many Australians is being rushed through the Senate in this unacceptable fashion with a restrictive time limit. The Government seems to be wanting to get off to its winter break in Hobart almost at any price.

SPEECH.PARA: In the last few weeks we have all suffered from the pressure of Bills on the constitutional amendments and the May statement being pushed upon us at the last minute, holding up very important Bills which the Government did not see fit to bring forward until it had the opportunity to guillotine them through. I think it has been a deliberately planned strategy and it is quite unacceptable. As Senator Vanstone spelt out in her speech, a number of drafting errors have been brought to light in the Senate recently, particularly because of her good work on the defective constitutional amendment Bill. A subsequent amendment was defective. Goodness knows the quality of the Democrats amendment which went through yesterday without any time for consideration of its drafting.

Once again, amendments have come before us which we have not had the opportunity to study in detail. Despite what Senator Powell said, the Democrats have had the opportunity to study the Opposition's amendments for something like six weeks now, if they believe in doing their job. However, they are great on talk but not too great on work. It is so often said that this is a House of review. This is where the crunch comes: how does a House of review do its job if it is given a guillotine and given only so many hours to deal with so many Bills? We cannot do our work properly if Bills are pushed through without the opportunity for proper scrutiny and debate. Such important legislative measures need deliberate and informed consideration. It is totally unacceptable that the Government is using the Senate in this fashion. It is not just the unintended consequences that we are likely to find afterwards; I fear that it is also the hidden intended consequences.

I shall be brief so as to allow my colleagues time to debate this legislation. Therefore, I draw attention to those matters which have been of particular concern to me. Senator Vanstone has mentioned the detrimental effect on existing beneficiaries. I am very proud of the fact that it is thanks to the Opposition's negotiations-and it is admitted now by the Australian Democrats that they have had no part in these negotiations-that Government amendments have been produced. They are not good enough, but they are a step in the right direction. The Opposition should take some satisfaction from the fact that a Bill that was quite unacceptable has been made somewhat more acceptable as a result of its negotiations on behalf of those people who were to be put in jeopardy by the Government's legislation.

The problem seems to be fixed for those who are over 65 years of age, as Senator Vanstone said, but clearly the position is not acceptable for those who are under 65. I should like to mention what Mr Bill Mansfield, from the Australian Council of Trade Unions, said some time ago:
The fact is that there are people out of the work force on compensation who have already made decisions about their lives who would face quite serious disruptions under this suggestion.

Those people are still in the same boat. The Government has not chosen to amend the legislation to help people in that position. I call on the Government to defer action until such time as it is able to produce amendments that will look after those people.

As a lawyer, I am particularly concerned about the removal of access to the common law. This is the standard method for socialist governments, I fear. It is certainly what was done by the previous New South Wales Government. It removed the right of New South Wales residents to go to common law in compensation matters. In Victoria I understand that the situation is that there is a partial removal of access to the common law. The limited amendments that the Government has provided us with at the last moment will make some improvement in relation to access to the common law-but they are very limited. I do not believe they are good enough. They allow the relatives of deceased Commonwealth employees access to common law, and in certain cases Commonwealth employees themselves are able to elect to go to common law purely for the pain and suffering component of the compensation claim. I do not intend to go into the details of that now. The Law Council of Australia has set out why it is important that these rights should not be given up. It has stated:

There are no valid grounds to justify abolition of the common law right. It is not justified on the ground of decreasing disincentives to rehabilitation. Nor is it justified on economic grounds. Experience under the Victorian Workcare scheme has shown that restriction of the common law right is likely in fact to be more costly and a disincentive to rehabilitation. Actuarial evidence from a number of respected sources supports the view that costs will increase.

No-fault legislation with scheduled benefits has its place, but it should not exclude the right to recover at common law where fault can be established. The Law Council believes that the interests of accident victims are best served by a dual scheme of compensation incorporating the best features of no-fault compensation with the common law right of recovery.
The Law Council also pointed out:

It is important that Commonwealth employees should understand that the Government's present proposals, if implemented, would significantly limit their existing rights and place them in a worse position than most other Australian workers.
It is incredible that the Government would propose to put its employees in a worse position that most other Australia workers, but that is exactly what it is proposing to do under this legislation.

I draw attention, as Senator Powell has done, to the problems with soldiers and policemen. I am glad that she has given recognition to the problems that they specifically face with this legislation. One problem she did not mention is that servicemen, especially, have early retirement ages, and that affects the basis on which the calculations in the legislation are based. There is also the question of whether they have been injured through some voluntary activity. Senator Powell gave a scenario in which somebody may have been deemed to have voluntarily put himself in a position in which he was liable to be injured. In the defence forces-and I think it is the same with policemen-fitness is an important element of their ability to do the job, and there is a moral obligation, at least, to keep themselves fit at all times through sporting activities. Most sporting activities would be deemed to be voluntary. I could not be sure that that would not be the case under this legislation.

It does not seem to be appropriate for soldiers and policemen to be covered under this piece of legislation. There has been talk of new legislation which would cover servicemen, but once again the Government is talking about a totally new piece of legislation. I believe, as do a number of defence welfare groups, that they should be covered under the Veterans' Entitlements Act or the Defence Act. But certainly we should not introduce yet another piece of legislation which will affect the rights of servicemen. It is too complicated to administer if we have to turn first to this piece of legislation and then to another when dealing with claims.

I leave the matter there because others wish to speak on this legislation. I am very glad that the Opposition has been able to achieve some sort of improvement in the legislation, but, as Senator Vanstone has demonstrated, the measures that the Government is proposing do not go far enough. As I hope I have demonstrated, the rights which are being taken away from Commonwealth employees are too important just to say, `Ho hum'. They are of vital importance to them, and no senator should willingly allow this to happen to Australian citizens.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The legislation before us deals with compensation payable to Commonwealth employees. I want to raise not the general issue but a specific case where compensation has not been paid to a Commonwealth employee. I am not sure-and I would like some response from the responsible Minister-whether a similar case would be compensable under the proposed legislation. Senator Powell has already drawn particular attention to the needs of members of the defence forces, munitions workers and members of the Australian Federal Police concerning access to common law and fair and equitable compensation payments. I look forward to seeing-I hope in the Budget session-a separate compensation scheme brought forward for members of the defence forces and others such as munitions workers and members of the Australian Federal Police who are in a particularly vulnerable area of service to the country and hence to the Government. We also need to remember that the defence forces in particular were only granted access to common law in 1983, and then only following a High Court case.

SPEECH.PARA: I, like Senator Powell, am concerned about the fact that the Commission for the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation of Commonwealth Employees is not liable to pay compensation if an injury was sustained by the employee voluntarily and by unreasonably subjecting himself or herself to abnormal risk of injury. Senator Powell raised the general question of how people in the defence forces, ammunition workers and Australian Federal Police officers are much more vulnerable than are other public servants simply because of the nature of the work they do. But there is another aspect that I want to raise, and that is the position of women in the services who have been subject to sexual attack. We are all aware of the fact that there are still people who believe that any woman who is sexually assaulted has brought it on herself.

I am particularly concerned about a case that I have been involved with for some time now which the Commonwealth Government is loath to settle. I am aware that we are short of time so I will only be able to give a summary of this case. I am raising it because I have so far got absolutely nowhere with the Government on getting an ex gratia payment for this woman. The women in question joined the Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) in June 1980. She was posted to Canberra from Melbourne on 26 November 1982. The night before she left for Canberra a fellow officer tried to rape her. He was unsuccessful, but that was more good luck on her part than good management on his-or bad management on his part. Not wishing to spend extra time in Melbourne and delay her arrival in Canberra, she did not report the event in Melbourne but waited until she arrived in Canberra the following day. She then reported the matter to a sergeant, who not only said that he was not surprised when he found out who the other officer was but advised her to keep her mouth shut and to say nothing.

The sergeant she reported to told another officer, who over a period then proceeded to subject the woman concerned to abuse and to harassment, both sexual and otherwise. In fact, that culminated in the submission of an unofficial unsuitability report on the woman concerned. I would say at this stage that in the intervening period the two officers concerned, and some others who became involved in this little game that they were playing, were eventually dismissed or disciplined in some other way for their actions. So there was an acknowledgment by the Air Force that the woman had been subjected to the treatment that she claimed. However, once the investigation of her complaints about the sexual assault in Melbourne had begun certain members of the RAAF police retaliated by trying to smear her character. She was alleged to be a homosexual and this allegation was put forward as the reason for rejecting the advances of the people who had subjected her to sexual harassment. This in itself is not an unknown element of these sorts of relationships.

She was interrogated for something like 16 hours on this alleged homosexual inclination and some very sensitive and personal questions were asked of her. She was kept under 24-hour surveillance at one stage while she was on holiday in Adelaide and photographs were taken of her movements without her knowledge or consent. Despite the failure of the trumped up allegations to lead to any charges against her, she-I suggest quite understandably-suffered tremendous trauma as a consequence. She was so distressed that she brought her marriage forward by some considerable time in order to facilitate a discharge. After being discharged in December 1983 she submitted a redress of grievance to the Air Force.

It is important that it be noted that the following events occurred post-December 1983, because it was in that month that the sex discrimination legislation passed this place, although it did not come into operation until some time the following year. Since then she has continued to suffer at the hands of some sections of the Air Force from people who are ex-colleagues. For example, in June 1985 she lost a work contract when the contractor made inquiries about her previous employment and was informed by the relevant RAAF personnel section that she was, in fact, a homosexual. As a consequence, she lost some considerable weekly income. In short, this woman has suffered appallingly. Sexual assault, improper investigation of her private life, gross infringements of her civil liberties, smearing of her character, loss of employment and promotion opportunities, stress, mental anguish and a nervous disorder clearly stemming from her experience, are just some of the complaints she is quite justified in putting forward. She was, as so often happens in the area of sexual assault, made the scapegoat for the misconduct and the guilt of other people. She disclosed facts which have since been proven correct-there is no questioning that matter-yet she has been the one to suffer.

She and I have contacted the Government with a request for an ex gratia payment by way of compensation. She has undergone an appalling amount of trauma and I think it is only fair that the Federal Government accept its responsibility in this area. She has received some redress through the Criminal Injuries Compensation Act in the Victorian courts, but that is not the point. The point is that she suffered while she was a member of the Commonwealth Government's force of employees and it must accept responsibility for this. Indeed, the Ombudsman has ruled that she is entitled to some redress-the Defence Ombudsman as well as the Commonwealth Ombudsman. I think it is important that we know that while the harassment started prior to the time that defence personnel were entitled to take common law action and prior to the time the sex discrimination legislation came into effect, it has continued since then.

I find rather offensive the final paragraph of a letter from Senator Walsh that he wrote to me a little while ago suggesting that it remains open to her to institute legal proceedings against the Commonwealth if she believes that a case of negligence can be substantiated. I think she is entitled to compensation from the Government for the treatment that has been meted out to her. I hope this legislation means that no other woman under these circumstances would be subjected without some form of compensation to the treatment that she was subjected to. I think the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Senator Bolkus), who is at the table, ought to take up this matter with the Government with a view to getting the act of grace payment that she deserves.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are discussing the Commonwealth Employees' Rehabilitation and Compensation Bill, and I shall refer to the matter that Senator Haines has just described in some detail. The Australian Democrats ought, in that case, to be supporting our amendment with respect to retaining common law rights so that a person in that situation could do something about it. The Government says that one reason for introducing this legislation is the increased cost to government of the compensation that is presently paid. The Government ought to look at the reason why increasing numbers are seeking compensation rather than merely trying to address the matter by penalising those who are on compensation and seeking to cut the benefits they will obtain. When I say benefits, we are not really talking about benefits; that is the wrong word. It is compensation for the fact that people have, for one reason or another, lost the ability to be in the work force. As I say, `benefit' normally implies something that is good and sought after, and it is not quite the right word in this situation.

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation also indicates how little regard this Government actually has for people in that it is prepared to cut funds and expenditure by cutting those payments which are quite reasonably paid to so many people who are affected by the Bill. The Government does say that in this Bill it is putting greater emphasis on rehabilitation and getting people back into the work force. One could only say that that is a laudable claim. Many Commonwealth employees in receipt of compensation would far rather be in the work force. They would like to be able to get on with their jobs and their careers, to move up the ladder within the Public Service, to be in a position to provide more for their families than is possible by being fixed at the level at which they became injured. Their families' lifestyle is significantly changed as a result, and, as a consequence of this legislation, many will have their living standards will be reduced even further. It is quite apparent that there are escalating costs. One hopes that before too long the cause will be looked at in somewhat more detail.

There are a couple of aspects in this legislation which have already been referred to which are entirely unacceptable. They are, firstly, the abolition of the common law rights of Commonwealth employees to sue their employer, where the employer has been negligent, in the way that other employees in the work force are able to do; and secondly, the retrospective application of the new compensation entitlements to those who have already established their entitlement under the existing legislation. Many thousands of Commonwealth employees or former employees will be affected by this legislation. Many will be affected prospectively, and that is another aspect.

I wish to deal with the removal of the common law right to sue, and its retrospective implications. It covers all Commonwealth employees, the Australian Federal Police, the defence forces and persons employed by the Commonwealth or its authorities under contract or apprenticeship. It is incredible that the Government brings this Bill into the Senate today and, with the support of the Australian Democrats, restricts discussion on it to 1 1/2 hours. We all know that it has taken the Government months-years-to come up with this legislation. We have heard it stated today that even in the last hours the Government has had to agree to amendments to make the legislation workable. Apparently, it is completely unaware of the anguish which the knowledge that this legislation was being looked at has caused so many people over the last couple of years. There have been rumours. People on compensation knew they would be affected but have not been able to find out what was going on.

Now, the legislation, with minimum opportunity to discuss it, is being rushed through the Senate by the Government. We are putting forward amendments which would improve the legislation, to restore and protect the common law rights these people are entitled to, and to protect those who are retrospectively affected by having their present payments reduced. I recognise that some people presently on compensation will have their situation improved, but it is not right or reasonable for others on compensation to have it reduced. A large number of people will be affected.

We are told that some of the Government's amendments will restore some common law rights. To put it crudely, that is absolute rubbish. The amendments may use the words `common law rights', but the restrictions on those rights, which have already been spelt out, make them completely meaningless. Everybody knows what the common law right to sue is. It is the right to sue one's employer for injuries one has suffered as a consequence of his negligence. That right will not exist for Commonwealth employees once this legislation goes through. I repeat: The amendment which is being put forward is a pale shadow of an employee's right to sue his employer, in this case the Commonwealth, for negligence and for the consequences of that negligence. The right is effectively abolished under this legislation. No-one should be under any illusion about that.

The new Comcare commission will not be liable to pay, as has been indicated, where an employee sustains an injury as a result of subjecting himself or herself to abnormal risk of injury. Nobody could possibly predict how this could be interpreted. There are some employees in high risk areas: Airline pilots, members of the armed forces and officers of the Federal Police. For example, an Army instructor teaching cadets or soldiers how to use grenades as a consequence of the actions of one of the cadets or soldiers he is teaching may be injured. One could talk about the sorts of examples that might occur for a long time, longer than we have this afternoon. That is one of the faults of the legislation being presented to us. To suggest that Comcare will not pay where the subject has put himself at abnormal risk will involve considerable litigation.

As far as rehabilitation is concerned, we need to be realistic. It is said that great efforts will be made to rehabilitate people, to get them back into the work force. It cannot be denied that that is a laudable aim. In New South Wales, where Transcover came into effect, rehabilitation was to be an important factor. But we all know stories about people in New South Wales being unable to obtain rehabilitative treatment because there were no treating doctors available. I ask the Government what steps it is taking to provide the facilities and the doctors for meaningful rehabilitation.

Many people who would like to return to work will not be able to do so. In Question Time today I asked whether those who were to be re-assessed and found to be capable of work would be cut off from the compensation they presently receive. I was told that efforts will be made to get them employment. I asked whether the Commonwealth would give a guarantee of employment. I suggest that it will prove quite difficult to obtain employment in the private sector for a person who has for some time been on compensation as a former Commonwealth employee. Such people will be regarded in the private sector as being in a high risk category. Those on compensation will feel particularly nervous about going into a job. They will feel apprehensive as to whether they will be able to cope with it. What happens if they go into the private work force and cannot cope? How much difficulty will they have obtaining a resumption of Commonwealth employee compensation? Or will they merely be told to go to the Department of Social Security and finish up on welfare? There are some significant problems which people who are concerned want to know the answers to. They want assurances as to what their future will be. The fact that they will be regarded as high risk people is quite significant.

One cannot think about this matter without contemplating the present situation within the Commonwealth work force of those who are presently redeployed from the jobs they had. If the way they are treated is any guide at all, one can only be cynical about the words in this legislation that refer to rehabilitation. Most redeployees are regarded as being on the scrap heap. Virtually nothing is done to get them back into employment, to get them other jobs and allow them to get on with their lives. A stream of people come in and out of my office who had good jobs but who are no longer able to continue with them and would like to be able to get back to work. In the event that jobs are found for them which they are able to do, they are branded. It is as though `redeployee' is written across their foreheads for the rest of time. The chance of their getting into another job and being able to pursue a career path is minimal. Even within the Commonwealth Public Service no department wants to hear about a redeployee. Departments will not look at a redeployee from another department. If honourable senators think I am exaggerating, they should go and talk to some of the people I see quite regularly. What assurance is there under this legislation that people will be any better off, that it is not just a question of words?

The Bill allows for some lump sum payments, but they are limited. I have referred to this aspect. The death benefits involve a maximum amount of $120,000, and a weekly payment of $40 for each dependent child. How many people with teenagers would agree that $40 a week is the actual cost of supporting a teenager? If one takes every cost into account one may agree that the Law Society figure of $90.64 is the more realistic cost of providing for a teenager in a middle income family. Many families with financial commitments who are presently on compensation will lose money and be significantly worse off. The stories I have been told of people who have worked out the arrangements and what will happen to them are devastating. Why should people be forced into that situation? Most of them have already spent all their savings surviving on what they have been getting until now. A public servant above the level of administrative service officer grade 7 will not receive 100 per cent of his or her salary for the first 45 weeks. For impairment, that public servant will receive a maximum of $80,000. Nothing is payable for impairment to a degree of less than 10 per cent. Of course, the guide to what in fact will be paid for impairment is yet to be published. We do not accept that it is appropriate to limit in this way the compensation which an injured employee or his dependants are able to receive. As I have said, we will oppose the abolition of the common law rights.
I want now to refer to some of the examples put to me. I got a letter from the rector of the St Alban's Anglican Church in Lyons, who had been consulted by some of his parishioners. He said:

Several parishioners who are already retired on invalidity and compensation benefits will be adversely affected. They were advised by the Commonwealth Employee's Compensation Authority that, as the resultant disability would continue throughout their lifetimes, compensation would be payable until death. On the basis of that advice they made financial commitments which they will be unable to meet if the proposed legislation is enacted.

One parishioner will lose up to 52 per cent of her income. As a single person, she will in all probability, be unable to maintain her home and be forced to sell what she has worked many years to acquire and on which the mortgage is still being paid.

I have a number of letters illustrating such examples. I have a letter from a person who was employed in the Public Service until 1984 when he was involved in a motor vehicle accident while travelling to work. His injuries have prevented him from returning to work. In March 1986 he was invalided out of the Public Service. He is aged 33 years, has a dependant wife and three children, two of whom attend a special school. There are significant costs involved in that. Many people support the objectives of Comcare and the concept of having injured employees return to the work force. However, the difficulties for many people in surviving are quite extreme. I have a huge file of letters, certainly from the organisations already referred to, but from individuals as well. These are people well under the age of 65 years who no longer have employment as a consequence of injury and who see their lifestyles being shattered. I have received one such letter today. As it would be regarded almost as too emotive, I will not quote from it, but it is from a man indicating his distress and the distress caused to his family by the delay in finally getting this legislation introduced, when for so long we have known that it was coming. People have been worrying about the impact of the legislation and what it would mean to them.

I urge the Government to accept the amendments which will maintain the rights of the people to whom I referred. As well as the existing common law rights, I most certainly urge the Australian Democrats to accept these amendments of ours to protect the people to whom we are referring. Certainly, the amendments which the Government is proposing are better than the provisions in the original Act. That perhaps is to be applauded but it does not go nearly far enough. In concluding I would like in particular to refer to the Superannuated Commonwealth Officers Association letter which was sent to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) earlier this year. The Association in its letter referred to many areas in which former Commonwealth public servants have been affected by decisions taken by the Labor Government. I shall not read all the letter but there is a portion which I think ought to be read out because it is revealing. The letter states:

Never before in the history of this Association, which goes back to 1923, has a Government been perceived as setting out so deliberately to reduce the living standards of people who, throughout their working lives, served to the best of their ability the people of Australia and the Government of the day regardless of its political persuasion.

These former employees are not ``fat cats'' as is so often portrayed by the media. Many thousands of them served the people of Australia as postmen, mail sorters, labourers, linesmen, tradesmen, technicians, typists and so on. Their salaries were modest and this is now reflected in the correspondingly modest level of superannuation pension received by them. Although I have made the point previously, do members of your Government fully appreciate that the level of superannuation pension received by former Commonwealth Government employees is such that in excess of 63 per cent of them are eligible for either a full or partial Social Security age pension. This percentage may be as high as 93; I am unable to be more precise due to the manner in which records are maintained in the office of the Commissioner for Superannuation.

The letter goes on to mention some of the detail. Some of these people will be affected by this legislation. These are people who have part superannuation and, in this instance, part pension and, in fact, whose total income is the same as that of an age pensioner but without any of the benefits. These are people who have found only in the last week that they have to pay an extra dollar on pharmaceutical prescriptions. These are people whose incomes, as I said, are the same as that of age pensioners but who get none of the benefits of age pensioners. There are a lot of such people in my electorate who know just how hard it is to get by and to survive.

There are so many aspects of this debate. I could give so many more stories, but I think I have sufficiently indicated why it is that we feel so strongly about the matter and why we feel that the amendments we have proposed are appropriate and ought to be passed. I make one last plea both to the Government and to the Australian Democrats to have some regard for the people concerned-people who have served the Commonwealth and who now are on compensation as a consequence of their injuries.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will very briefly reply to a couple of points raised in the debate on the Commonwealth Employees' Rehabilitation and Compensation Bill 1988. The debate has been an ongoing one both in the Parliament and outside. I refer in particular to the matter raised by Senator Haines, which drew great sympathy from this side of the chamber. I undertake to take that matter up with the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) and get back to Senator Haines with an answer as quickly as possible. In saying that I refer the Senate to section 6 (1) (a) of the Bill, which may go some way towards accommodating the sort of problem that Senator Haines raises. In fact, it should substantially cover the problem raised. However, we do have, as Senator Haines said, an ongoing case which has to be addressed. We will do so.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Reid asked whether people who might be found ineligible for compensation under the current review of permanent cases would be offered permanent employment. She raised a question on this matter during Question Time as well. I think I might have just enough time to go through the answer on that. The permanent review finds people ineligible for continuing compensation if they are found fit for work. All the services, except for the new income arrangements, of the Bill will apply to current beneficiaries. They will therefore be eligible for rehabilitation case management. I stress that.

Work tests will be applied. If the person has not retired on invalidity grounds and, therefore, remains an employee of the Commonwealth, employment will be sought for that person in the Commonwealth. In the first instance the former employer will be asked to find suitable employment for that person. If the person has retired, suitable employment will be sought inside and outside the Commonwealth. I should say in this instance that if that person has retired then the rehabilitation plan program will apply directly to him if an exhaustive process does not find him employment.

It should also be stressed that it will not be easy to redeploy most permanent beneficiaries. As I have already indicated, the Government is accommodating those particular problems. The Government is introducing Comcare with its premiums, rehabilitation and redeployment provisions specifically to encourage the return to work of people injured at work. Managers will be made financially accountable for compensation and will have direct responsibility and incentives for rehabilitation and redeployment.

The only other thing I want to say in conclusion is that this measure represents a major reform of the compensation system available to Commonwealth employees. It is a measure that has been worked on for quite a number of years within the Government. TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate turns now to debate a package of some five Bills, the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill 1988, the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1988, the Anti-Dumping Authority Bill 1988, the Customs Legislation (Anti-Dumping Amendments) Bill 1988 and the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill 1988. The Opposition has circulated a number of amendments which will be dealt with at the end of the debate.

SPEECH.PARA: The Customs Tariff Amendment Bills cover a range of changes including surcharges on aviation gasoline; amendments which give effect to the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) reports on pulp, paper products and printing industries, medical and scientific equipment, and glass and glassware; amendments to international agreements; amendments in the context of the textile, clothing and footwear (TCF) sectoral plan; amendments to the harmonised tariff; and all of the changes to the passenger motor vehicle sectoral plan-some 154 pages in content plus 10 pages of explanatory memorandum. All of these Bills are to be dealt with within the 1 1/2 hours allowed to us, thanks to the Australian Democrats supporting the Government's guillotine. In many ways there is no doubt that these Bills, in particular the anti-dumping Bills, should clearly have gone over to the next session of Parliament.

The industry-wide basis for each of the tariffs in these industries is to be 15 per cent for the large majority of products, and this will be phased in where necessary on a tops down basis. Coupled with the May economic statement, this is part of a long overdue micro-economic reform package so far as it relates to the reduction of tariffs. Since the stock market crash of October last year there has been speculation on tariff cuts and a clear acknowledgment of the necessity for change. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), Mr Dawkins, Senator Button and others have been floating the ideas of some tariff reductions for some considerable time in the hope that they would be able to persuade industry and in particular the unions to accept these tariff changes.

That has proven to be successful because industry and the unions have in fact not created much fuss about the tariff changes which have been announced. The truth of the matter is that in the meantime there has been a very substantial cutback in investment, as managers of various industries have been concerned about taking long term investment decisions at a time when it was clear that the Government was going to do something about reducing their tariffs. Until such time as those announcements were made, many investment decisions were put off.
