My criticism of the Government in this area goes further than that, because the Government should have been making these tariff changes not just since last October. Some considerable time ago, for example when the Treasurer (Mr Keating) talked about the banana republic, the Australian economy had so changed as a result of the devaluation of the Australian dollar that one could say that from late in 1985 it was ready for some substantial readjustment downwards of the tariff protection being given to Australian industry. If these changes had been made at a time when the Australian dollar was down as low as US70c, it may very well be that lower tariff protection could have been introduced than has been introduced.

The Government has so fiddled around in this matter that it has ended up introducing these Bills at a time when the dollar has risen to about US80c, an increase of about US10c on US70c, a one-seventh increase in its value, and this has created great difficulty for industry. If the tariff reductions had taken place, as I say, a couple of years ago, industry would have been coping with them much better than it is now required to do.

I am not promoting the idea that tariff changes should take place in accordance with the change in value of the dollar. I am merely pointing out that, as a result of the massive fall in the value of the dollar under this Government, the Australian economy had so changed that industry would have been able to cope much better with a lower tariff protection. If this Government would only get off its tail and deregulate some other areas of the industrial structure in this country, industry would be able to cope much better with the tariff changes which are introduced in these Bills and which could have been made a long time ago by this Government.

As I said in a speech I made yesterday, I am delighted to see that at long last the Treasurer has worked out that what is needed is a deregulation of the Australian labour market in order to enable this country to become more export oriented and more production oriented and to enable our manufacturing industries, and in particular our transport industries, to create an opportunity to take advantage of a lower tariff regime. Both industry and unions have criticised the Government for the uncertainty which the Government created by itself in its speculation about tariff cuts over the last six or seven months. The Chamber of Manufacturers of New South Wales has claimed that tens of millions of dollars worth of investment plans were delayed while textiles, clothing and footwear unions argued that people did not want to work in the industry because of the uncertainty.

Apparently, Mr Keating was pushing for an across the board cut of about 15 per cent. At one stage he was talking about a 25 per cent across the board tariff cut. Then we heard that he was talking about a 20 per cent cut and then, finally, we understood that he was promoting a 15 per cent cut. I understand that in the meantime Senator Button was pushing for a 10 per cent across the board tariff cut. It is quite clear that Senator Button had a very substantial fight on his hands. Before Christmas 1987 I criticised the Government for fuelling speculation about changes to the plan-not because the changes were not necessary for any industry but because of the damage that was being done as restructuring plans and other investments were delayed while industry and managements waited for the Government to come clean and announce its intentions.

The legislation proposes a series of amendments to the current TCF sectoral plan, including changes to quota arrangements for goods from developing countries-that is, changes in the type of garments and quantities that are allowed to be imported at concessional rates. The textiles, clothing and footwear industries were firmly of the belief that Senator Button had broken a promise to them by changing the plan which he announced in 1986 and repeated in 1987. Before the plan comes into operation in March next year it will have been changed. The industries believe that Senator Button has broken a promise. However, Senator Button seems to have persuaded them that it is not his fault. Although he is a very senior Minister, somehow or other he seems to be able to escape criticism of the Government by saying, `It is not really my fault. The Prime Minister, the Treasurer and other senior Ministers have done this. I have been battling strongly for industry'.

TALK.START.PARA: —The unionists do not believe him.

—As my colleague Senator Newman says, there is not the slightest doubt that the industries no longer trust him. They realise that when he makes a promise about tariff arrangements, he cannot deliver, because ultimately the Treasurer may require him to support changes of which he is not in favour.

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation also proposes a series of amendments to the car plan. In the mid-term review of the car plan, it became evident that that four-year-old car plan was not succeeding in Australia-certainly in terms of reducing the relative cost of cars in Australia. In fact, the price of some popular cars has risen from between 43 and 63 per cent since the introduction of the plan. It now takes 46 weeks wages of an average worker to buy a standard Commodore, whilst in 1985 it took only 39 weeks wages.

The changes to passenger motor vehicle plan tariffs, which were announced on 13 April 1988, abolish tariff quotas on passenger motor vehicles altogether and reduce customs duty from 57.5 per cent to 45 per cent, phasing it down by 2.5 per cent each year until 1992, when the rate will reach 35 per cent. Those reductions put pressure on local manufacturers to lift their game. This pressure should have been exerted much earlier, when the devaluation of the dollar was having a major impact on imports, and would have been much more effective if, at the same time, the Government had introduced some deregulatory moves so as to give Australian manufacturers an opportunity to take advantage of these lower tariff protection arrangements.

It appears that section 23 (3) of the Industries Assistance Commission Act is being contravened by changes to the passenger motor vehicle tariffs that we are debating today. I ask the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button): Where is the IAC report recommending these changes? There is in existence, and floating around this place, the Industries Assistance Commission Amendment Bill, which would regularise the changes proposed in this legislation and allow the Government to do whatever it pleases to tariff levels without the safeguards that the IAC provides. However, that Bill is not being debated during this session. The Government's action in bringing forward this legislation without the passage of the Industries Assistance Commission Amendment Bill is not only an administrative bungle on the part of this Government but also an unlawful act. The Oppositions amendment to the question that the two Bills be read a second time condemns the Government for the tediously slow pace of reform and the confusion, uncertainty and speculation which has abounded in the interim, resulting in a widespread reluctance to invest.

The Anti-Dumping Authority Bill 1988, the Customs Legislation (Anti-Dumping Amendments) Bill 1988 and the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill 1988 amend Australia's anti-dumping legislation and implement the Government's long overdue decisions on the report of the Review of the Customs Operation (Anti-Dumping) Act 1975 by Professor Gruen, which he completed in March 1986. We now have the spectacle of the Government rushing through-although Professor Gruen reported in March 1986-this most important and indeed vital piece of legislation. The Government is pushing through the legislation under the guillotine and is not allowing adequate debate. The legislation is being pushed through at such a rate that industry has had to try to respond to it without having had an opportunity to consider some of its proposals about which people have been talking. This reflects on the incompetence of this Government and the cavalier manner in which it treats both the Parliament and the people.

I wish to acknowledge the benefit which I have had from briefings by departmental officers, Mr John Hawksworth and Mr Ken McInnes-they are in the chamber-who have been very kind in explaining to me some of the somewhat complicated aspects of the legislation with which we are dealing and the practical consequences of the proposed changes.

Professor Gruen recommended that the present anti-dumping and countervailing system be continued, subject to some substantial changes designed to, firstly, reduce the discrepancy between the concept of unfair trading practices as it is applied within Australia and as it is applied by Australia to its imports of goods and secondly, discourage too extensive use of the anti-dumping system as a more readily available system for restricting imports. In other words, it is not right and proper that industry should try to use the anti-dumping system as some way of obtaining protection for an industry. Professor Gruen said:

The anti-dumping system should not be used to shield import-competing industry from the necessity to adjust to changing longer term economic conditions-unless the IAC has at least examined the circumstances justifying such longer-term insulation from world market trends.

Professor Gruen pointed out that some industries had been endeavouring to use the anti-dumping measures to obtain protection. They should not do so. If they are entitled to protection, the IAC should be so reporting. Proper long term protection facilities could then be introduced.

The legislation establishes a one-member Anti-Dumping Authority as a statutory body to advise the Minister as to whether dumping or countervailing duties should be imposed on specified imported products and to review and make reports to the Government on anti-dumping matters. I point out that this was not Professor Gruen's recommendation; it was one of the Minister's ideas. In our view, it adds a layer of bureaucracy. I have my doubts about whether that is necessary; nevertheless, it creates an avenue of appeal from a decision of the Australian Customs Service. The proposed Anti-Dumping Authority has been seen in a favourable light by industry. We will not be opposing its establishment, although I have considerable reservations about the creation of statutory authorities for this sort of purpose. I will come back to that later in my speech.

It is also proposed that policy guidelines will be developed by the Authority and established by regulation. The legislation restricts the life of dumping notices and undertakings to a maximum of three years. Professor Gruen recommended two years but the Government's proposal is three years, and the coalition parties do not oppose that proposition. The legislation prescribes the manner in which the Australian Customs Service is to conduct preliminary investigations of dumping complaints. It amends the IAC Act to remove from the operations of that body the review of dumping matters, transferring that function to the Anti-Dumping Authority. It allows anti-dumping complaints to be initiated by any person on behalf of the relevant Australian industry effected. For example, a trade union or a farmer affected downstream by some dumping action can institute an anti-dumping complaint even if the industry does not wish to make such a complaint. I might add that there is a sunset clause of five years on the Anti-Dumping Authority Bill and I totally support such a provision.

These Bills require the Customs Service to conduct preliminary investigations of dumping complaints and to determine whether the facts alleged constitute sufficient prima facie evidence to warrant commencing an investigation within 70 days. In other words, the Customs Service has 70 days in which to make its preliminary inquiry. The legislation allows the Customs Service a further 180 days to make a finding as to whether dumping or countervailing duties should be imposed. That makes a total of 250 days, which industry says is too long. The coalition parties also believe it is too long. We will be moving an amendment to reduce the period back to the period provided for in the previous legislation and before the Government allowed the Australian Customs Service last August to extend its time for making investigations. We believe that a period of 55 days for the prima facie case should be substituted for the 70 days proposed by the Government. We also believe that the period of 120 days should be substituted for the 180 days proposed for the hearing. There are suggestions that the Canadians operate much more quickly, but on investigation I am advised by the departmental officers that this is not the case. Although their legislation might appear to enable them to operate more quickly, in fact they take just as long as, or longer than, the Australian Customs Service has been taking with its investigations. The Americans are in a similar position.

The Customs Service officers believe that they need the periods of time set out in the legislation. We believe that they should be under the pressure of the shorter period and we will move an amendment to that effect. If that proves to be unsatisfactory, perhaps the Minister will come into the chamber to explain that to us and introduce regulations to change the time allowed. Australian manufacturers have alleged that, under the previous procedures, the Customs Service has been manipulating the times to fit its own timetable by seeking more evidence or seeking in some way or other to defer the inquiry, but we believe that it will make a valiant attempt to comply with the timetables allowed under the legislation, or under our amendment if the Australian Democrats support it.

There is no doubt that flexibility and adequate staffing of the Australian Customs Service is needed to ensure speedy resolution of the cases. The apparent procrastination could and should be overcome by the Authority providing guidelines and perhaps a standard document that clearly details the information needed to commence a case. However, I hope that the standard form does not itself cause some delay by becoming a formal requirement used to frustrate and delay an applicant.

Since the Gruen report was prepared there has been a steady decrease in the number of anti-dumping cases, due in part to the devaluation of the Australian dollar. There were 35 tariff items under investigation in 12 countries at 31 March this year compared with 74 at 1 January this year and 285 cases in 1985. Under the legislation the decisions of the Customs Service are to be subject to review by the Anti-Dumping Authority, which must then report to the Minister within a further 120 days. One would presume that there may be some overlap between the time allowed for the Customs Service and the Anti-Dumping Authority's investigation. The reduced time for the Customs Service activities as provided for in the amendment to be moved by me appears to be a sensible compromise between the longer period sought by the Government and the even shorter periods that some industry spokesmen have suggested to me. The imposition of this time limit will bring some discipline into the Customs Service. It will also introduce some discipline into industry, which will be required to comply with the Customs Service's notices and requirements in regard to evidence of dumping applications.

Professor Gruen saw the upgrading of the resources of the Customs Service as the real key to the speedy resolution of complaints. The Bills do not take up Professor Gruen's recommendation for a complete rewrite of the anti-dumping legislation, nor do they adequately address problems of simplification. That is one of the reasons for our criticism of what the Government is doing. The Bills do not repeal section 5 (9) of the Act, which was a recommendation of Professor Gruen, but tighten it. Manufacturers have considerable reservations about the tightening of section 5 (9) because a zero profit figure is to be assumed. I merely point out that we will have to see how that works out. Under the legislation the Minister has a power to change that by regulation and in due course some changes may well have to be made in that area.

As I pointed out earlier, industry is strongly supportive of the establishment of the Anti-Dumping Authority, in particular because it creates an appeal mechanism so that, if a case for anti-dumping is not upheld by the Customs Service, industry will be able to go to the Anti-Dumping Authority and appeal against the decision of the Customs Service. The member of the Authority is to be chosen from outside the Public Service and for economic and commercial expertise. Associate members and consultants may be appointed for limited periods. The Minister will have a total discretion which will enable him to take into account national interest in his final decision. National interest is not to be taken into account either by the Anti-Dumping Authority or by the Customs Service.

I am pleased to be able to report that the Minister is not going to hide behind the decisions of the Anti-Dumping Authority because he has agreed to amendments which will enable the Authority's reasons and the nature of its findings to be published. The Minister then will have to make a decision one way or the other as to whether he accepts or rejects the Anti-Dumping Authority's decision and recommendation. I believe that that is the way it ought to be so that Ministers are fully responsible for decisions made on important matters such as this and are responsible and accountable to the people and to the Parliament for their decisions. I approve very strongly of that proposal.
I have had some representations from industry. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard recommendations made to me by Pacific Dunlop Ltd entitled `Anti-Dumping Legislation'.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
ANTI-DUMPING LEGISLATION
Introduction

A legislative package of three bills which together are intended to change Australia's anti-dumping policies have just been passed through the federal lower house. These bills are now en route to the Senate.
The bills are:
Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Amendments Bill 1988
Customs Legislation (Anti-Dumping Amendments) Bill 1988
Anti-Dumping Authority Bill 1988

According to the Government this legislative package will establish an effective anti-dumping policy. Earlier in a press release, on 30 October 1987, Senator Button committed himself and the government to a `level playing field' approach. Australian industry, Senator Button stated, should not be provided with lesser safeguards against unfair competition than that provided by others like the EEC, USA and Canada.

This government commitment to a level playing field approach in anti-dumping areas is particularly important for Australian industry as it continues to restructure. The reductions in tariffs that are proceeding are placing pressure on Australian industry to be at least as competitive as other nations. And so long as these tariff cuts are implemented with appropriate adjustment times for the industries concerned they are to be welcomed by efficient companies. However it must concurrently be recognized by government that there are occasions when some industries face unfair trading practises in the form of dumping in Australian markets by overseas competitors.

The General Agreement on Tariffs Trade (GATT) and legislation in other places (like the USA, EEC and Canada) does recognize dumping as a practice to be outlawed and one that is detrimental to a fair world trading system. Like predatory pricing by a well capitalised company, dumping can send efficient Australian firms and industry out of business. Should this occur the predatory importer can then charge whatever the market will bear in the future and recoup the costs of their earlier dumping. Competition in the industry is diminished and the economic gains from lower prices while the dumping occurred must then be offset against the economic inefficiencies of less competition and possibly even in the extreme no remaining Australian based industry.

With this legislative package the government does recognize the possibility of dumping. However the government contention that this legislative package is constructed on the basis of a `level playing field' philosophy is incorrect. The new Australian policy towards dumping is weaker than that of the GATT, the USA, the EEC and Canada. Indeed the legislation is so loose that there is reason to believe that it could be ineffective.
Weakness in the Legislation

There are basically two difficulties with the legislative package as it now stands. First the time allowed before any action is taken against dumping is too long. Indeed by the time action is taken Australian firms could be in big economic trouble and well on the way to bankruptcy. The second difficulty with this legislation is the extent of Ministerial discretion permitted. In other words the anti-dumping legislation may only be effective if the Minister responsible has the time, enthusiasm and intent to make it work. There are in addition several other weaknesses which taken together suggests that this legislation does not give Australian industry a `level playing field'.
(i) Timing provisions:

For the first time in Australia statutory timing limits on investigations into dumping are set. First Customs examines the dumping complaint and conducts preliminary investigation. They must have this done in 70 days (ie. two months). If there is a prima facie case to support dumping then Customs have a maximum of 180 days (ie. six months) to make a decision about whether to impose dumping duties. If Customs make a preliminary decision that there is dumping they then have 7 days to refer the matter to the Anti-Dumping Authority. The Anti-Dumping Authority then have 120 days (ie. 4 months) to complete their examinations. This whole process could take almost one year without breaching the statutory time limits.

It should be obvious that this timing is not fast enough. Setting a maximum time limit for investigations will encourage the time spent on investigations to expand so that the maximum is always reached. And as time passes the potential damage to Australian firms and industry multiplies.

In addition it is worth noting that in Canada 90 days is allowed for investigation and in the USA 160 days are allowed. The longer time being for Australian investigations does not represent a level playing field and will encourage some overseas companies to dump here ceteris paribus.
(ii) Ministerial Discretion

The Minister can direct the Anti-Dumping Authority to act on or to ignore a wide variety of matters. This could be either good or bad, depending on the Minister, but it is not a sign of tight legislation.

There are provisions in the Act (s.5.9) which allow appeal against Customs Decisions and for cases to be initiated by outside parties. This is sensible. However the Second Reading Speech also makes clear that the Minister will consider anti-dumping decisions on the basis of both economic and commercial issues. While national interest considerations are not defined in the legislation it is made clear in the Second Reading Speech that if a dumping company is from a country which has a trade deficit with Australia then its imports to Australia (including dumped imports) will be given different (more favourable) treatment.

Many of the companies in the past who have been subject to positive dumping charges are from countries with trade deficits with Australia, so this interpretation is of great concern. Companies from the Eastern Bloc (eg. Romania, Poland, Yugoslavia) as well as companies from Korea, Malaysia, PR China and India have all fallen in this category at various times.

Giving countries who have a trade deficit with Australia some favourable treatment in this area is of course quite contrary to a fair multilateral trading system. It is aggregate trade balances that are important in a global fair trading system. Focusing on bilateral trade flows aids and abets the breakdown of multilateral trading as the Australian government has itself asserted in many international forum for some years.

In addition this Ministerial discretion allows for special pleading on any number of grounds. Foreign policy considerations, for example the desire not to upset some country for some unrelated reason, will almost certainly get brought into considerations about dumping. While there may be occasional and exceptional circumstances where such issues might dominate the dumping decision they should not be treated such potential importance.

It has also been suggested that when there are generally depressed world prices the decision about dumping will be judged differently from in more normal trading circumstances. This too opens the door for abuse and it would be more rigorous to argue that dumping should simply be judged on the basis of whether GATT defined normal prices are being breached. And in this judgment the intent behind the behaviour (ie. whether predatory or something else) is not relevant.
(iii) Normal Prices

In calculating normal values (which roughly speaking are the prices charged for the goods in question in the alleged dumper's domestic market) it is proposed that the assumed profit rate of the producer will be zero. In other words in calculating the normal prices that Australian industry must compete against we assume a price based on zero profits. Any company that makes zero profits continuously cannot survive which in turn suggests that zero profits are an illogical benchmark for comparison. This benchmark is also quite out of line with practise elsewhere. The GATT suggests that some positive profit element be included in the valuation of normal price and the USA require a minimum of 8%.
Comment
It would be in Australian industry interests if this anti-dumping legislation was amended so that:
(i) the timing for a decision and action was shortened:

(ii) the number of matters left to ministerial discretion were fewer. In particular dumping allegations should not be able to be judged on the basis of aggregate bilaterial trade flows or other irrelevant facts to the specific dumping case;
(iii) the definition of normal price used was more in line with the intent of GATT and more in line with that used in other countries.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. Of course, Pacific Dunlop is a very highly respected, successful and innovative company with interests as a manufacturer, exporter and importer. I believe that its representations succinctly summarise the major concerns made to me by industry and that is why I have incorporated them in Hansard. There is a need for Australia to have anti-dumping legislation that is perceived to be fair, in conformity with the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, and prompt in dealing with complaints. I am concerned that the statutory authority adds another layer of bureaucracy but, as I have mentioned, in the end the legislation places final responsibility firmly in the hands of the Minister and, therefore, in the hands of the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition has given careful consideration to a further submission by the Law Council of Australia which recommends that the legislation be referred to a committee and also suggests that the Anti-Dumping Authority should be given powers such as those of the Administrative Review Council or one of those administrative appeal bodies. While we see some merit in that proposal we think we ought to go down the path suggested by the Government in this regard. As industry is anxious to have this legislation in place I believe that, on balance, we ought not to try to defer its passage by referring it to a committee. As I have explained, while the legislation remains far from ideal, it is an improvement on the existing legislation and will be supported. I move:

At end of motion, add ``, but the Senate condemns the Government for the tediously slow pace of reform and the confusion, uncertainty and speculation which has abounded in the interim, resulting in a widespread reluctance to invest''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The three Bills I wish to address, the Anti-Dumping Authority Bill 1988, the Customs Legislation (Anti-Dumping Amendments) Bill 1988 and the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill 1988, create the Anti-Dumping Authority and make consequential amendments to other pieces of legislation. I would like to reflect the remarks of Senator Lewis and say how pleased I am to have had so much discussion with Mr McInnes from the Australian Customs Service in relation to these complicated pieces of legislation. I guess that most of us in this chamber have no practical experience of this legislation and, therefore, need some guidance as to the operation, in practice, of these quite complex changes. I would have to disagree with Senator Lewis's claim that this sets up yet another level of bureaucracy. It really takes over the review function of the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) and puts it with the new Anti-Dumping Authority.

SPEECH.PARA: One other thing Senator Lewis mentioned which is pleasing is that this legislation broadens the ability of people and groups to bring an action. Increasingly, as large amounts of trade are taken up by multinational corporations, it may well be that a company is both producing in Australia and importing from other countries and may be loath to bring an action in relation to dumping which nonetheless may be harming aspects of employment and the economy in Australia. It is pleasing to see that that has been broadened.

As Senator Lewis has said, the three Bills seek to implement the Government's response to the report of the Gruen Review of the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act 1975 by establishing, firstly, the Anti-Dumping Authority, which takes over those review functions from the IAC; secondly, amending the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act 1975, chiefly to restrict to a maximum of three years the life of dumping notices and undertakings made under the Act; and thirdly, amending the Customs Act 1901 by prescribing the manner in which the Australian Customs Service is to conduct its preliminary investigations into dumping complaints.

The Bills impose for the first time statutory time limits within which the Customs Service must determine its investigations and the Anti-Dumping Authority must conduct its review. When a complaint is made, that is, an application for the imposition of dumping duties on goods entering Australia, the Customs Service will have a maximum of 70 days to determine whether there is sufficient evidence of a prima facie case to warrant further investigation. If that prima facie case is established, the Customs Service then has a maximum of 180 days to make what is defined as a preliminary finding. It is at this stage that it will be possible for the Customs Service to impose duties, which can be made retrospective for up to 90 days, and that decision would then be referred to the Authority. The time available for the Customs Service to refer the matter to the Authority is a further seven days. The Anti-Dumping Authority then has a further 120 days to conduct its review and report to the Minister. That review process can be carried out whether the findings are positive or negative.

The Australian Democrats strongly support the establishment of the Anti-Dumping Authority and we support the general thrust of the legislation. We have no problem with the 120 days allocated to the Authority to conduct its review, particularly in view of the fact that, if at the preliminary finding stage the decision is to impose duties and that decision is reversed by the Authority, those duties can be held for only 120 days. In other words, there is complete congruence between the period during which the Authority must carry out its review and the period for which the duties can be held. However, the Australian Democrats, like Senator Lewis, have some concerns about the time required for the Customs Service to determine whether there is sufficient evidence for a prima facie case to warrant a review which may then continue for a further 180 days before a preliminary finding is made.

We appreciate that these are maximum times and that there are some fast-track options which could speed up the process. It is possible to conceive of situations in which the case would be sufficiently strong for the Customs Service to choose to limit the time during which each of those stages-the 70-day stage and the 180-day stage-is conducted. It is possible, by way of regulation, to change those times. Moreover, it is possible for the Authority, of its own volition, to take up a matter, deal with it and, presumably, make a recommendation to the Customs Service. Moreover, if an industry were of sufficient importance nationally, one could conceive of representations being made to Parliament and, through Parliament, to the Minister, or directly to the Minister and the Minister could give a direction to the Authority and, through the Authority, to the Customs Service and that could fast track this procedure. Of course the time limits need to be sufficiently wide to allow natural justice to all parties. Clearly one does not want to bring into existence a situation in which the claim of dumping cannot be sufficiently refuted by the party against which that claim was made.

The purpose of these Bills is to ensure that goods cannot be dumped in Australia and cause injury to Australian industry. After a great deal of consultation with both the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce and representatives from Australian industry, we believe it is necessary to support the Opposition's amendment to shorten the times needed by the Customs Service from 70 and 180 days to 55 and 120 days respectively. Despite the Government's safeguards, such as the fast track methods I have mentioned and the regulatory ability to shorten the time interval, on balance it is better to begin with a shorter time which may be lengthened by those processes rather than start with a longer time.

We point out that under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade it is possible to collect duties retrospectively for up to only 90 days, whereas with the Government's proposals of 70 days and 180 days we have 250 days altogether, admittedly as a maximum, before a preliminary finding can be made. Against that 250 days during which damage may have been accruing, duties can be collected retrospectively for only 90 days. That leaves a significant window for potential damage.

While it may be difficult to construct scenarios, one could imagine the situation in which the importation of goods which are sold only once a year and over a very short time. One could imagine, for instance, Christmas decorations-tinsel and the like-where an industry in Australia was providing a large amount of the Australian requirement. An overseas manufacturer could come in, sell over a very short time and that time might be within the period before duties can be collected retrospectively. That could significantly damage the Australian industry. So the compromise suggested by the Opposition seems to us to be a better proposal, bearing in mind that that can be extended if a substantial case can be made. The opportunity is in the legislation, if the Government so wishes, to extend or shorten the relevant time by regulation. Professor Gruen, who conducted the review on which this legislation is based, recommended 55 days for the prima facie case and 120 days for the preliminary finding stages. While we certainly do not support everything that Professor Gruen said or recommended, we believe that on this particular point the Government should have taken his advice.

The Opposition's other proposed amendment, that the Authority in any report to the Minister include reasons for its recommendations, seems to us to be rather trivial. Although we agree with the Government that that provision would appear to be implicit in the legislation because the other advice has to be given to the Minister, we will nonetheless support the Opposition amendment. It seems trivial but not in any way damaging to the thrust of the Government's legislation.

A number of other aspects of the legislation concern the Australian Democrats. There appear to be no penalties in the Bill for breach of confidentiality, and while there is a requirement that the Authority and officers employed directly by the Authority or those who might be employed as consultants must not breach confidentiality in relation to information provided to the Authority either in support of a claim or in defence of a counterargument, nonetheless we are informed that under common law an action could be brought on the part of an aggrieved person for which the appropriate remedy would be damages. It is also actionable under the Commonwealth Crimes Act 1914, relating to offences by and against Commonwealth officers. In particular, section 70 provides that such a breach would subject the person to a maximum of two years imprisonment. That would seem to us to be sufficient deterrence against breaches of confidentiality.

Representations from a number of groups have raised other issues in respect of this legislation. One which has given us some cause for concern is that the Authority will be required to accept overseas selling prices with zero profit margin as being in the ordinary course of trade. We understand that in America that is taken as a base price, but an 8 per cent nominal profit margin is added to that. We are concerned that there may be many situations in which an overseas manufacturer would have excess capacity which may be related to the efficiency of his production, and that excess capacity could be dumped on the Australian market at cost. That could quite seriously damage Australian industry. We ask the Government to review the situation quite regularly to ensure that while setting a zero profit margin it properly prevents the dumping of goods in Australia. We give notice that if we become aware of damage to Australian industry because of this method of constructing a price-and we accept that it is very often, even with zero profit, a largely constructed price-we will seek to amend the legislation at a later date.

Another issue raised by concerned companies and groups is country hopping, where importers alter their source of supply of dumped imports in an endeavour to avoid the penalty of dumping duties. It was felt that much of the benefit arising from the imposition of dumping duties will be lost as Customs endeavours to carry out a large number of separate and independent dumping investigations. However, we have accepted the Government's assurances that where a company attempts to shift its port of export the essential elements of material injury and causal link will already have been proved and in that event the imposition of duties on the re-sourced goods can be quite rapidly put in place.

Another issue of concern to us is whether the national interest can be taken into account. The legislation specifically excludes the Customs Service and the Authority from taking into account questions of national interest. That is absolutely justified because those bodies are not the appropriate bodies to consider what the national interest is. I guess one could reflect here on the way in which organisations such as the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation have attempted to interpret what they see as national interest, and the sorts of problems organisations such as ASIO and the Central Intelligence Agency have brought upon governments and people by interpreting `national interest'. That should be a function of properly elected parliaments.

Other groups have expressed concern about the guidelines for the Anti-Dumping Authority. The Authority will, as one of its first duties, write draft guidelines. It is to be hoped that industry will have the opportunity to provide an input in establishing these guidelines, at the very least being able to comment on the draft guidelines before they come into operation. As to whether anti-dumping action constitutes additional and unjustified assistance to industry, we believe that the Government has bent over backwards in writing this legislation to avoid this very thing. Indeed, it could have been more generous to Australian industry but it has dealt quite fairly with this matter. Dumping does occur and there are well documented cases of it. Action is required to prevent it and, as I indicated earlier, as more and more industry is subsumed by large multinational corporations, it becomes very important that wide powers be given to individuals, union groups and so on to initiate action under this legislation.

We believe that the only shortcomings in this legislation are on the question of the time allocated to investigations. As I have indicated already, the Democrats on this occasion will support the amendments moved by the Opposition. I draw the attention of the Opposition to that, particularly in view of the abusive remarks we had this afternoon in relation to the position taken by the Democrats on several other pieces of legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking on the Anti-Dumping Authority Bill 1988, the Customs Legislation (Anti-Dumping Amendments) Bill 1988 and the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill 1988 I start by welcoming the change of heart by the Australian Democrats. It is nice to see them on the right side for once. I also would like to pay tribute to the departmental officers mentioned by my colleagues for the briefing which they gave. I found it very helpful as well. The Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act 1975 provides that dumping occurs when the products of one country are exported to another country at less than their normal value. Subsidisation occurs when any subsidy, bounty, remission or reduction of freight or other financial assistance has been applied to the production, export or carriage of goods imported into Australia. A dumping or countervailing duty, with a few exceptions, will be imposed only when it is shown that the importation causes or threatens material injury to an established industry or when it hinders the establishment of a potential industry or the expansion of an existing industry.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition believes that trade should be conducted fairly. Consequently, we support the idea that there is a need for proper tariff reductions, provided that anti-dumping systems are speedily and readily available. However, measures must protect against the possibility of anti-dumping laws being used to protect a local producer who has not taken the necessary steps to protect himself from foreign competition and is simply using the mechanisms to delay having to face the real world. I welcome the fact that action can now be taken before the goods arrive in the country. I understand that this has been happening for the last few months under operating procedures of the Australian Customs Service. These are to be established on a legislative basis in these Bills. In a case now taking place a prima facie case has been found to exist in regard to the dumping of cement on the Australian market before the cement has actually arrived. I welcome this ability to speed up the process as a means of helping to diminish the injury to Australian industry and Australian jobs where there is a case. Mr Enderby, the then Attorney-General, in debate on the legislation in 1975, said:

The legislation has to be flexible, and yet it should not be so flexible that it avoids certainty. It has to be certain to give assurance yet it has to be flexible so that it can be administered in such a way that it is capable of adjustment and being kept up to date with changing circumstances.

I support those sentiments. The Bills before us seek to establish an anti-dumping tribunal, to codify the decision making process and time frame, to introduce a sunset clause for duty notices and undertakings, and to change the standing requirements of complainants. The time limits are substantially different from the 55 and 120 days recommended by Professor Gruen. The Opposition supports his recommendation but the legislation allows a total of 370 days. It prescribes that investigations must start within 70 days. A further 180 days are allowed in which to make a preliminary finding as to the need for dumping or countervailing duty to be imposed. Decisions are subject to review by the Authority and must be reported to the Minister within 120 days. The Minister has total discretion and will take into account the national interest in making his final decision. This is far too long a period for the making of decisions. Certainty and speed are essential to the injured party. Hence we will move amendments to give effect to Professor Gruen's recommendations, as Senator Lewis said earlier.

The Australian Customs Service needs not more time but more resources to do the job. Professor Gruen said that the biggest problem with the dumping situation is that there are not enough resources to make anti-dumping measures effective. I understand that currently the Australian Customs Service is acting very speedily and treating the times set out as maxima. But in my opinion when the pressure is on it will need to use every available day. Consequently, the Government should closely monitor the problems of the Customs Service so that resources can be thrown into the job as soon as they are needed and not delayed in such an important area.

Clause 13 of the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill proposes to limit the period of a dumping notice or undertaking made under the Act to three years from the date the notice is issued or the undertaking accepted. This will not prevent a new application for duties being lodged. This is a sunset clause such as was strongly recommended by Professor Gruen as a mechanism to ensure that duties do not become a source of continuing tariff protection. The Anti-Dumping Authority, in performing its functions, is to have regard to the Government's policy in relation to anti-dumping matters and Australia's obligations under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. It is not to impose duties as a form of substitute assistance to import competition or to protect industries from the need to adjust to changing economic conditions. I am glad to see that we will be getting support for our amendment to require the Minister to give reasons for his decisions. It is very important for the democratic process that the Minister be openly accountable for his decisions.

I rather suspect that the establishment of the Authority is primarily an attempt to distance the Government from the responsibility of decision making, thereby legitimising its final response. I also think that it is quite possible that the Authority will be swamped with routine inquiries and referrals for review, particularly if the current economic climate should change, returning the country to a level similar to that which existed in 1983, when the number of formal investigations initiated reached 86. If this occurs it is doubtful whether the proposed system will be adequate. One factor, however, which will restrain a flood of applications is the onus on the applicant to include in his application information as to the matters which he believes constitute reasonable grounds for the imposition of a duty. Given the detailed information requirements set out in the complainant questionnaire, capricious applicants will certainly be deterred. I understand that the number of applicants who have their applications sent back for them to start again is one of the reasons for delays. Perhaps that means that there should be better procedures to help applicants to make the initial application in the right form. Former Minister John Brown, as an Opposition member in 1982 in a debate in the House of Representatives, said:

The fact is that a dumping action tends to come at a time when an industry is on its knees. These industries are in no position to spend valuable resources on gathering evidence to substantiate a dumping allegation . . . We-
the then Labor Opposition-
would shift the burden of proof from local producers and the Department towards importers after a prima facie case has been established . . .
I have some sympathy for that view, although I recognise that it is not widely shared.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that the same Mr Brown?

—It is the same Mr Brown; the man with the desk. The review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT) is regarded as highly desirable not only by the Administrative Review Council but also by the Law Council of Australia and Professor Gruen. Admittedly, a specialist body such as the proposed Anti-Dumping Authority is desirable to the extent to which it can bring a broad, commercial perspective to anti-dumping issues. I recognise that. Its capacity to review negative prima facie and preliminary decisions of the Comptroller-General quickly and effectively will no doubt be welcomed by Australian industry. However its deficiencies, which are its inability to cope with complex legal issues, its lack of jurisdiction to review final ministerial decisions, and the absence of independence from Government policy, may outweigh its benefits as a forum for review. I personally hope that, when the Anti-Dumping Act ceases operation five years after the day it commences, the Government will see fit to act on the Administrative Review Council's recommendation that anti-dumping and countervailing duty decisions should be reviewable by the AAT. I regret that the time limit imposed by the Government on the Senate for this debate-in my view, it is an important debate-prevents my covering the matter in greater detail. I shall be supporting the amendments moved by the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise, in the short time allocated to us, to address the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill 1988, the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1988, the Anti-Dumping Authority Bill 1988, the Customs Legislation (Anti-Dumping Amendments) Bill 1988 and the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill 1988, which we are debating cognately. I will restrict my remarks to the Anti-Dumping Authority Bill, which is the Government's response to the Review of the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act 1975 by Professor Gruen, whose report was completed in March 1986. There has been a great delay in implementing these recommendations. I can think of no reason for that, except probably poor Government management.

SPEECH.PARA: As has been pointed out, the Bill creates a new statutory authority to administer anti-dumping mechanisms. There will be a one-member Anti-Dumping Authority headed by someone from outside the Public Service, no doubt, as Senator Newman said, as a punching bag which corporations can punch instead of the Government. The Authority will advise the Minister as to what duties to apply.

In the past, Australia has made greater use of anti-dumping measures than any other country. I have had personal experience with the superphosphate issue, to which I will address remarks towards the end of my allotted time. In practice, anti-dumping hinders beneficial international competition and can become a protection for inefficient industries in Australia. If Australian industries need protection, I believe they should get it in the proper way, by using the tariff system, so that everything is out in the open, rather than the anti-dumping device.

The Opposition agrees with certain measures in this Bill and believes that there is a place for anti-dumping measures based on principles of fair trade, but anti-dumping systems must be speedily and readily available. The present system is far too cumbersome. The Opposition objects to the provision that investigations be commenced within 70 days, with a further 180 days to make preliminary findings and then a further 120 days for proceedings to be finalised. That is far too long. Professor Gruen recommended 55 days and 120 days, a total of 175 days, which is a considerably shorter period than provided for in this legislation. The Opposition supports that recommendation. I understand that that is the basis of the amendment that has been mooted.

As has been pointed out, Canada has a lesser but far more effective period of 30 days and 60 days. Industry needs certainty at any time, as well as in relation to anti-dumping measures. Australian industries that are to be protected should not be at the mercy of dumped products for 12 months plus so many days before any action is taken. The Opposition doubts that the Bill will provide sufficient certainty for industry on this important matter. There is doubt about allowing proper resources for the new Authority to do the important job it will be required to do. It requires professional assistance. Without these resources, this new Authority will not achieve anything. I can see nothing in the Bill which provides such resources.

I come back to the superphosphate industry as I know it in Western Australia, and it is probably the same across the board. In Western Australia and, I am sure, in the rest of Australia the manufacture of superphosphate has been a monopoly since, to my knowledge, at least 1969 when CSBP bought out it last competitor, Cresco. I think that took effect in 1970. Since then the price of straight superphosphate has risen from $13 a tonne to about $115. The point of CSBP using this device as a tariff device will be borne out in the figures I will give. In the early 1970s a lot of importation by a private source of di-ammonium phosphate (DAP) started to build up. DAP was a very good quality fertiliser because of its nitrogenous content. Its strength lay in the fact that it had about a 15 per cent nitrogen content but also contained a high percentage of phosphorus, whereas the Australian-manufactured superphosphate nitrogenous fertilisers have a low content of phosphorus. If they are used continuously on phosphorus deficient ground, the soil will be even more deficient in phosphorus. It was being imported for $270 a tonne, landed, in Fremantle.

Compared to the straight superphosphate that CSBP was selling at the time for $88 a tonne, CSBP saw that it was out of context. In other words, DAP was virtually the same as what CSBP manufactured in the form of triple-strength superphosphate. If one multiplied by three the then price of straight superphosphate, it came to far more than the cost of imported DAP. Fortunately, CSBP found a small manufacturer of DAP in New South Wales. Whether he was manufacturing or was intending to manufacture or even got off the ground, I do not know.

Anyway, CSBP found a peg to hang its hat on, so it asked for an anti-dumping measure. It claimed that the landed price of the superphosphate, considering the price overseas, should have been around $340 a tonne. It went to Customs and applied for and received those measures. Overnight, the price went to $340 a tonne. There was the big profit for CSBP. It was not interested in preventing DAP coming in; it was interested in pushing its single-strength superphosphate. As soon as it got the imported price forced up by anti-dumping measures to $343-and if we divide three into $343 it comes out at about $114-it increased the price of its single superphosphate from $90 to $113 and got away with it. With the same costs that year for the superphosphate having been manufactured, in the sheds and waiting to be sold, it was able to shift the price from around $90 to $113 or $115. Who got the big profit? It went straight into CSBP's pocket. And I do not mind telling it so. That is something that the Government has to look at: these anti-dumping measures should not be used for tariff protection. With my examples of superphosphate in Western Australia I have borne those figures out. I hope that the Ministers take that on board.

I mention briefly the anti-dumping measures on dumped cement that the Government is looking at. Clinker cement has supposedly been dumped in Australia. I had in my office the other day-as have a couple of other senators on this side of the chamber-shop stewards from cement factories all around Australia who put their case for the dumping. I would not mind putting it on record, for Senator McKiernan's knowledge--

TALK.START.PARA: —They are nice people, aren't they?

—They are nice people. No member of the Government would see them on that day. When they knocked on my door, I said, `God, why are you coming into a Liberal office?'. They said, `Because the Labor fellows won't see us'. But I have only got their word for it. However, on this matter there could be a problem. What worries me is that dumped cement or dumped clinker is coming into Western Australia, getting processed and going out. It is being sold off to ready-mix concrete operators. I am using that term not as a trade name but to describe a trade. What gets me is that it is coming in at a dumped price but the benefit is not going to those who are buying ready-mixed concrete. Jobs are being lost as a result. That angle should be examined.

SPEECH.PARA: I commend parts of the Bill, but, as I have said in regard to cement and concrete, and superphosphate-and I believe that it goes for other industries, too-it should not be used as a tariff protection. My watch has bleeped off, so I will close on that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —This cognate debate covers several items of legislation relating to customs and tariff matters. Legislation such as this requires detailed consideration. I believe it is disgraceful that the Government, with the support of the Australian Democrats, is guillotining these pieces of legislation through in just one and a half hours. Part of the legislation that is being debated relates to the harmonisation of tariffs. As with an earlier Bill on a similar matter of harmonisation, this legislation gives rise to certain anomalies. At a time when the Government is preening itself about tariff reductions which it announced in the May economic statement, we find that under this legislation a number of items will gain an increase in tariff protection.

SPEECH.PARA: When one examines specific classifications for tariff adjustment under harmonisation, it appears that often the tariff rate is set at that of the most highly protected similar item, rather than reduced to that of the lowest comparable item. Yet again, the Government appears to have taken the soft option while claiming to be taking hard decisions. The absurdity of the impact of the harmonisation of tariffs is demonstrated by the increase in the tariff on high quality lightweight woollen cloth from 2 per cent to 40 per cent import duty under this procedure. This has occurred despite the fact that very little of this fabric is made in Australia and despite the fact that it is manufactured overseas from exported Australian superfine wool. So Australians are being denied reasonable access to this already expensive material although it is more suitable for Australia's hot climate than it is for many other countries. The fact is that the raw material, the superfine wool from which this product is manufactured, is almost exclusively produced by Australian woolgrowers. A significant part of the $200m which is provided by Australian woolgrowers and, following the May economic statement, to an ever-diminishing degree by the Government for wool promotion, is directed towards promoting garments made from this cloth. This must be one of the supreme ironies of protection. Of course, it highlights the absolute folly of protection.

Australian wool producers produce the finest apparel wool in the world, but we cannot supply in Australia the cloth produced from it to our own citizens in ample variety or at a fair price. This is not the fault of the woolgrower, who receives between $10 and $20 for the wool contained in a $400 finished worsted suit. That $10 to $20 represents about 6 per cent of that finished cost. On the contrary, the woolgrower is severely damaged by this situation. Woolgrowers are losing a potential market for their wool through the reduced demand for this product in Australia as a result of the high cost caused by excessive protection. As we all know, because of protection production costs for woolgrowers are inflated and their export returns are subject to the hidden tax of protection. Furthermore, Australian consumers are paying more than twice the price for comparable products bought by overseas consumers and made from the very same Australian wool. So in Australia we find that high quality woollen garments are needlessly losing market share through excessive protection causing them to be overpriced and limited in range.

That is not the only way in which Australian farmers are disadvantaged by this process of harmonisation. Recently under this process duties on diesel engine parts were increased from 2 per cent to 25 per cent even though none of these parts is made in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have got them knocked off, though.
—It is about time.
—It took us six months to do it.

—We have had promises to that effect. Of course, this is yet another example of the Government claiming that it is reducing protection whilst it is surreptitiously dramatically increasing costs to farmers and others through this harmonisation process.

SPEECH.PARA: Recently we heard the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Senator Bolkus) attempting to bolster this facade of dramatic reductions in protection when last weekend he made a claim in Adelaide to the effect that tariff changes announced in the May economic statement would reduce the prices of shirts and blouses by 48 per cent, Mazda 323 cars by 13 per cent, and footwear by 10 per cent. The Minister knows only too well that these tariff cuts are to be phased in over a number of years. So it will be a long time before the price effects of these tariff cuts are felt. Of course, the price effects will be much less dramatic than the Minister would have us believe. To deliberately create the impression of immediate price reductions as a result of the May economic statement is a gross distortion of the facts by the Minister for Consumer Affairs. This delayed impact of the tariff reductions means that the rural community has received yet another kick in the guts for having, for the second time in five years, rescued the Australian economy. Under the May economic statement rural people will pay much more than their fair share of the Government's so-called restructuring of the economy.

No other sector of the economy has been hit as hard by the statement as the rural sector, as the following list of measures directly affecting farmers shows: an increase from 50 per cent to 60 per cent in grower contributions to export inspection charges; a $20m reduction in Government funds for wool promotion, breaking the promise telexed by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) to the Australian Wool Council pledging to continue the current arrangements; abolition of the super- phosphate bounty; removal of immediate tax write-off for the cost of electricity connections to rural properties; removal of accelerated plant and equipment depreciation arrangements; an increase in livestock valuation for tax purposes, costing farmers $35m; the virtual abandonment of produce marketing underwritng schemes, subjecting producers to the vagaries of a corrupt international market currently subject to subsidies on the part of other countries as the basis for determining domestic pricing; road funding cut by $50m; local government funding cut by $20m; higher State government charges caused by the savage $870m cut representing 89 per cent of total expenditure cuts by the Commonwealth Government, in State revenue grants; likely higher telephone charges resulting from income and payroll tax being levied on Telecom Australia; and, finally, the introduction of an assets test, as well as the income test, to determine eligibility for the family allowance supplement-discriminating against farmers having bad years.

They are the measures from which the farmers and the rural community in general will suffer as a result of the May economic statement. Yet, while these massive losses are being suffered immediately by farmers, they will have to wait patiently for a considerable time for the promised offsets, in particular the removal of tariffs on farm machinery, spare parts and chemicals and the reintroduction of income equalisation deposits. So under this legislation, through the harmonisation of tariffs, tariff levels on a number of items are increased to the detriment of primary industry.

The Government is practising economic apartheid. There is one rule for efficient rural export industries, which have adjusted quickly to world competition, and another rule for inefficient but electorally sensitive manufacturing industries. The Government yet again is unduly punishing the very sector which allowed its early popularity through the kick-start given to the economy by the 45 per cent increase in the value of rural production after the disastrous drought broke in 1983. More recently, improved wool prices have restored economic demand to keep Australia afloat, despite the present Government's appalling economic management, which has caused an ever-rising tide of debt. Some thank you the rural sector gets from the Government, in particular the wool producers, who have saved the Treasurer's economic bacon yet again with their export earnings. One would think that the Treasurer, as Australia's best dressed man, would have a higher regard for wool; but it would seem that to the Treasurer wool is just something to pull over people's eyes.

This legislation, far from reducing the tariff levels which will apply in a number of areas through the harmonisation process, increases those tariff levels. It is for that reason, as well as because of the Government's general administration of this issue, that the Opposition has moved an amendment to the effect that the Senate condemns the Government for the tediously slow pace of reform and the confusion, uncertainty and speculation which have abounded in the interim, resulting in a widespread reluctance to invest. I support the Opposition's amendment and urge its passage through the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not heard all the comments that have been made about the legislation. I heard Senator Newman's speech, which I thought was a most erudite commentary on the pros and cons of all the issues relating to dumping, but without a conclusion. Unfortunately, the Government was in the difficult position of having to draw a conclusion from all those arguments. That is what we have done in respect of this legislation. I have just heard Senator Chapman's speech. It mounted a good piece of rhetoric on the basis of a highly selective set of facts which, in some particulars, were not even correct. I do not want to debate that issue because I think Senator Chapman was seeking to make a political point rather than any point of substance.

SPEECH.PARA: Having said that, there are no particular comments I want to make about the legislation at this stage. There has been little comment about the changes to the passenger motor vehicle plan; there has been some detailed comment about changes to particular tariffs arising from the harmonised tariff changes; but that is about all. There are, however, some issues in the dumping legislation which are subject to second reading consideration and about which I will comment in the committee stage. I commend the Bills to the Senate.
Amendment negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time, and passed through their remaining stages without amendment, requests or debate.

DEBATE.TITLE: ANTI-DUMPING AUTHORITY BILL 1988CUSTOMS LEGISLATION (ANTI-DUMPING AMENDMENTS) BILL 1988CUSTOMS TARIFF (ANTI-DUMPING) AMENDMENT BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 24 May 1988, on motion by Senator Gareth Evans:
That the Bills be now a second time.
Amendment (by Senator Lewis) negatived:
At the end of motion, add: ``, but the Senate condemns the Government for:
(a) further complicating customs procedures; and

(b) adding another layer of bureaucracy thus increasing costs to the customs service while still denying the service the expertise recommended for it in the Review of the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act 1975''.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.
The Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move the following amendments to the Customs Legislation (Anti-Dumping Amendments) Bill 1988:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 6, clause 6, proposed subsection 269tc (1), line 3, leave out `70 days', insert `55 days'.
(2) Page 6, clause 6, proposed subsection 269tc (2), line 19, leave out `70 days', insert `55 days'.
(3) Page 7, clause 6, proposed paragraph 269tc (4) (c), line 13, leave out `180 days', insert `120 days'.
I move the following amendment to the Anti-Dumping Authority Bill 1988:
Page 4, subclause 7 (1), at end of subclause, add the following word and paragraph:
`; and (f) which shall include all reasons for any recommendations.'.

The Anti-Dumping Authority Bill amendment requires the Anti-Dumping Authority to state the reasons for its recommendations to the Minister. That will mean that the recommendations of the Anti-Dumping Authority and the nature of the recommendation of the Minister will be exposed. The three amendments to the Customs Legislation (Anti-Dumping Amendments) Bill 1988 change the times required for the investigations by the Australian Customs Service to 55 days for the preliminary finding and 120 days for its ultimate decision in lieu of the 70 days and 180 days proposed in the Bill.

I ask the Minister for some explanation as to why the Government has adopted, in clause 5 (9), an assumed profit rate of zero, instead of the assumed profit rate of 8 per cent which is adopted in the United States. Could the Minister elaborate on that proposal?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I undertake to provide Senator Lewis with an answer in writing. It was a policy decision. The assumed profit rate was always a difficult thing to assess and calculate. We were proposing to be a little more stringent about finding normal values than we had been in the past. I will give Senator Lewis a further answer.

SPEECH.PARA: There are just a couple of other matters I would like to refer to. I have already indicated to Senator Lewis that in regard to the amendment moved by the Opposition, in so far as it relates to the inclusion of reasons for recommendations by the Anti-Dumping Authority, that was a matter with which the Government had no difficulty and that henceforth, after the Authority's establishment, reasons will be given by it. I have also indicated that we would be prepared to accommodate that amendment in any subsequent amendment to the legislation. However, if the amendment is supported in this chamber, I do not mind it being carried.

TALK.START.PARA: —What can you do about it?

—Senator Haines, I said `if it is supported here'. I do not know whether it will be. Senator Haines seems to have changed her position several times, which is not unusual. I do not mean that Senator Haines has changed her seat either; I mean her intellectual position.
—Haven't you had dinner yet?

—No, I have not had tea yet. I accept the proposal on timing with considerable regret because I think it is a matter of judgment. The judgment of the Opposition has been dictated by pressure from Australian industries. I think that is freely admitted. I think it will make it much more difficult for the Australian Customs Service (ACS) to reach the sort of quality findings it has been reaching in the past. There is more likelihood of negative findings and rejection of anti-dumping cases if there is not sufficient time to establish the evidence satisfactorily. I think that is a real difficulty. However, I understand that Senator Lewis has said that he would support any regulation changes to extend the time, if that became necessary. These are changes which could be made by regulation. Of course, I will hold him to that.
—I did not say that, Minister. Just give me a chance to respond. Give me one minute.

—Senator Lewis said that to me. We will hold him to that. After all, the times in the legislation are maximum times for reaching a decision by Customs; they are not minimum times. We are concerned that there be some flexibility so that Customs can reach the best possible findings. It is better for Customs to reach good findings than hasty ones.
—Give me 30 seconds to put into Hansard what I said.
—I will give the honourable senator 30 seconds.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —What I said is that under the legislation the Minister would be able to introduce a regulation to extend the time if the Australian Customs Service was not able to comply with this Bill. The Minister would then be able to come into this chamber and explain to us why he was extending the time. We would then give that our most earnest consideration in light of the experience of the Customs Service.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments agreed to.
Bills, as amended, agreed to.

Anti-Dumping Authority Bill 1988 and Customs Legislation (Anti-Dumping Amendments) Bill 1988 reported with amendments and Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill 1988 reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bills (on motion by Senator Button) read a third time.
Debate resumed from 23 May, on motion by Senator Tate:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition will not be opposing the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1988. However, we have proposed an amendment to the second reading motion and when we come to the committee stage of the debate we will be moving an amendment to clause 42 of the Bill which deals with the appointments to tax agents boards and, most particularly, the chairmanship of such boards. Copies of both those amendments have been circulated already to honourable senators at my request. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion, add ``, but the Senate notes that:
(a) this is the highest taxing Government in the post-war history of Australia;
(b) it is its continual emphasis on revenue collection, rather than expenditure restraint, that has eliminated the budget deficit in 1987-88;

(c) it has mainly relied on bracket creep through the various personal income tax brackets, and also on the introduction of new incentive-sapping taxes such as the fringe benefits tax and capital gains tax;
(d) such new taxes represent increased complexity and uncertainty in the administration of the taxation system and so decrease efficiency and equity; and
(e) without an effective tax system Australia will find it increasingly difficult to trade itself out of its $87 billion net foreign debt''.

Mr Acting Deputy President, I take the opportunity to correct that figure of $87 billion. It should be $88 billion as a result of figures published very recently. Because we are, of course, operating under a guillotine, total debate on this Bill will be restricted to one hour. This Bill runs to 42 pages, plus a schedule, and contains approximately 60 amendments to the existing legislation. I simply want to note those figures in passing to illustrate the absurdity of the process in which we are now forced to participate by decision of the Government supported by the Australian Democrats. So far as the second reading amendment is concerned, we said some of the things that need to be said yesterday in the course of debate on the Government's May economic statement. If only for that reason, it would be neither meritorious nor appropriate to repeat them.

Indeed, on those general aspects perhaps the only significant development since our debate yesterday has been the publication yesterday of the figures for the national income and expenditure accounts for the March quarter. I do not propose to spend much time on them, but I must say that those accounts are rather worrying. During the last 12 months, gross domestic product has grown by 5.1 per cent in constant price or so-called real terms. But, and this is the key point, net exports, that is to say exports less imports, have contributed very little to that growth. Of course, it is essential that we get growth in net exports if we are to correct our extraordinarily worrying balance of payments position and begin to contribute to the solving of that net foreign debt problem which is referred to in the proposed amendment to the second reading motion of the Bill.

On the other hand, government consumption grew during that 12 month period by 5.3 per cent. That is faster than the economy as a whole grew during that past 12 months. By contrast, public sector capital expenditure fell by 9.3 per cent during that time. Of course, so far as the private sector is concerned, we have had a very sharp rise in private investment in dwellings, which is up by 15.5 per cent in constant price terms. While no doubt laudable from many points of view, that, of course, does not contribute to the productive capacity of the economy, which in the end is either going to make or break our capacity to deal with Australia's current problems. Indeed, so far as that segment of the economy is concerned, I note in passing that private investment in capital equipment in the 12 months ending in the March quarter rose by only 3.1 per cent and, indeed, actually fell on a seasonally adjusted basis in the March quarter by just over 2 per cent.

I suppose that in those circumstances it would be hardly surprising if the Government were worried about the present state of affairs. We have a situation in which debt is still climbing. Net debt rose by a further $1.3 billion in the March quarter, as I indicated when noting the change to the amendment, despite the beneficial valuation effects of the rising value of the Australian dollar during that quarter. As the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has now twice admitted in the last three weeks, the balance of payments improvement has stalled. The only thing that has improved the balance of payments position in the past 12 months has been the sharp improvement in our international terms of trade, that is to say, the sharp improvement in Australia's export prices.

The other thing that has stalled, of course, is the Government's own performance in cutting its own expenditures. That performance is stationary, if indeed it is not going backwards. The Government has, of course, been quite effective in cutting funding to the States, but that is quite a different matter from cutting the spending proclivities of its own spending Ministers. We saw that pathetic performance by the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, in Question Time today in response to a dorothy dixer.
