We had the Minister for Finance posturing in front of the television cameras. I think at least on this occasion he had his shoes on. All of this has happened while the external winds have been blowing favourably and we have had world economic growth going on at quite a reasonable clip and, as I said before, international commodity prices have been rising. These are all favourable external circumstances in which to be performing and, notwithstanding that, the Australian economy is at best dead in the water so far as any improvement in the underlying problems of the economy is concerned. Mr Acting Deputy President, I propose to conclude at this point my remarks on the second reading but I will have some further remarks to make.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that it is the desire of the Senate to continue sitting during the period of the normal dinner suspension to consider the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) and the Crimes Legislation Amendment Bill.

—Yes, Mr Acting Deputy President. I was about to say that I should conclude at that point my remarks on the second reading debate but I shall, of course, have some further remarks to make when we come to the committee stage and we consider clause 42 of the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) makes a number of major changes to legislation, one of which is to amend the Income Tax Assessment Act in line with recommendations made by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and the Administrative Review Council. It goes much further than that and picks up a wide range of issues in the tax-related areas. For example, it extends the scope of income tax deductions allowable for cash bids paid for offshore petroleum exploration permits. It removes from 1 January 1988 the exemption from income tax of payments received under the Aboriginal secondary assistance scheme for students 16 years of age or over. It removes the exemption from income tax of the carer's pension, where the handicapped pensioner cared for is of age pension age and the non-relative carer is not. This brings the income tax treatment of carer's pensions received by non-relatives into line with relatives caring for a handicapped person.

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation also modifies the rules relating to the registration of tax agents and changes the composition and powers of the tax agents boards. This of course is one area of considerable contention to those of us on the Opposition benches, although we are concerned less with the actual appointment of somebody from the Australian Taxation Office to the board than we are with that person taking up a position as chairman of the board. Tax agents boards, as I am sure most people in the chamber are aware, monitor registration of tax agents. They examine applications from tax agents and they act on complaints about tax agents from members of the public and the Taxation Office.

Currently the tax agents boards consist of the officer in charge of the Commonwealth Department of Finance in the State, and that particular person acts as the chairman of that board. The other two members are the officer in charge of the Australian Audit Office in the State and a person appointed by the Governor-General, which essentially means somebody appointed by the government of the day.

The legislation will reconstitute the board in a fairly significant way so that it consists of an officer of the Australian Taxation Office who, under the legislation as it stands, would be the chairman of the board; that is, under the legislation as it is proposed. Under the Bill as it stands and under the legislation as it is proposed to be, he would be the chairman of that board and then two other persons would represent specific areas of relevance here, namely, accounting and the legal professions.

Our concern is less with the fact that the Government has decided to put on the board a member of the Australian Tax Office who is currently employed by the Tax Office, not simply somebody who has been employed by the Tax Office. But it is planned to make that person the chairman. We have spoken to representatives from the Institute of Chartered Accountants and from other areas. These are the people who, as I said earlier, are likely to be going to the Taxation Board for some reason or other. They have indicated to us that they are not generally concerned about the fact that there is a member of the Australian Tax Office on the Board. But they do see some merit in amending the Bill to provide that one of the two other persons appointed by the Minister be the chairman and that role not be granted under the legislation to the person from the Taxation Office.

They argued that, if the Government has its way, somebody from the Taxation Office could be asked to adjudicate on a complaint referred by the Taxation Office itself and this is a conflict of interest situation quite clearly. I have also had a letter from a lawyer who practises in this field and he takes a similar view. He has pointed out that `currently no person from the Australian Taxation Office may be a member of the Tax Agents Board'. However, the Bill provides that not only shall a tax officer be a member of the reconstituted board but also that that tax officer shall be the chairperson of the Board. He says:

In my view this is wholly undesirable as it could create the impression that any agent who upsets the Tax Office could be subjected to harsh treatment by the Board. A person who is a chairperson of a board has greater control in the setting of the agenda for the meeting and in the conduct of the meeting of the Board than does any other member.
He then points out:
. . . Justice must not only be done but be seen to be done.

I think it is worth while pausing at that point to note that there is an innate suspicion in the hearts and minds of the community generally about the way tax officers operate and about people involved in the Taxation Office generally. So he is quite right. There is a need to have a person other than somebody from the Australian Taxation Office in the chair. He goes on to say:

A move in the opposite direction was recently made. It was previously the case that the Chairman of the Taxation Board of Review was a former officer of the ATO. That situation was remedied by abolishing the boards and transferring their functions to the AAT where a former tax officer would not assume the role of chairman of a three-person tribunal. It was recognised at pages 17 to 19 of the report to the Attorneys-General by the ARC entitled `Review of Taxation Decisions by boards of review', report No. 17, that the previous situation was undesirable and could be seen as being unfair.
He finished his letter by saying:

I would appreciate it if the Australian Democrats would attempt to have proposed subsection 251d (1) (A) of the Bill amended to provide that one of the two other persons appointed by the Minister shall be the chairperson of the Tax Agents Board.

Indeed, that is what the amendment that I had circulated in the name of the Australian Democrats earlier this afternoon does. It would still allow the Government to appoint somebody to the boards from the Australian Taxation Office but would ensure that the person who was chosen to be in the chair would come from one of the other two positions. With time being short, and I know Senator Michael Baume wishes to make some points, I will leave my second reading contribution at that point. That is the major area of contention in the legislation and while we will not be supporting the Opposition's amendment to prevent an Australia tax officer from actually going onto the boards, I look for Opposition support because I think it coincides with its view that that person not be in the chair.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like first of all to thank Senator Haines for cutting her speech short so that Senator Watson and I may be able to contribute to this debate. This debate, of course, is taking one hour to deal with these tax matters. I should point out to the Senate that two hours was allowed to the House of Representatives and that is a jackbooted organisation down there under the heel of the Government. Here we are in a House of review being allowed by the Government, with the assistance of the Australian Democrats, one hour to deal with review of legislation which was rammed through the House of Representatives in two hours. This, of course, is an absolute disgrace.
—It is absurd.

—As Senator Watson says, it is absurd. I would like to restate the amendments that I am strongly supporting to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2). This is the highest taxing government in the post-war history of Australia; it is continual emphasis on revenue collection, rather than expenditure restraint, that has eliminated the Budget deficit for 1987-88. It has mainly relied on bracket creep through the various personal income tax brackets and also on the introduction of new incentive-sapping taxes such as the fringe benefits tax and the capital gains tax. Such new taxes represent increased complexity and uncertainty in the administration of the taxation system and so decrease efficiency and equity. Lastly, without an effective tax system, Australia will find it increasingly difficult to trade itself out of its $87 billion net foreign debt.

SPEECH.PARA: This point, of course, about making the tax Act more and more complex is underlined by the fact that approximately 60 amendments are to be made to the existing taxation laws through this proposed legislation. As the shadow Treasurer, Mr Peacock, pointed out in the other place, given the Government's past record of shabby drafting and its continual prattling about unintended consequences, we will no doubt be getting more amendments to these amendments from the Government, not only now but as time goes by.

I am particularly concerned about some developments in the way powers are being increased, not only by this legislation but also by administrative fiat within the Australian Taxation Office. We had an extraordinary situation recently where the Taxation Office seized the membership list of the Australian Small Business Association. This is absolutely incredible. There is no tax merit whatsoever, that I am aware of, in the seizing of the membership list of the Australian Small Business Association. The only merit I can see in seizing such a list is to intimidate the members of that Association who have been vocal in their criticism of this Government and its taxation policies.

If the Taxation Office can demonstrate that there is some merit in acquiring forcibly that list of members, I would be glad to hear it. Otherwise it strikes me as most unfortunate evidence of the manner in which this Taxation Office has been inclined to operate. It may be held that if a person is a member of the Australian Small Business Association, therefore that member is a small business person and therefore that member presumably should have put in a tax return. Maybe that requirement is to see whether tax returns have been submitted. I do not know. All I know is that it looks most unfortunate and I hope that the Minister will encourage the Taxation Office to explain itself, particularly the arrogant and assertive way in which the list was demanded in the first place.

I am absolutely convinced, having talked to the Australian Small Business Association, that the manner in which the Taxation Office went about seeking that list was totally intolerable in a free society. This, of course, follows a previous situation in which confidential documents held by tax accountants which deal with taxpayers' business affairs are now being routinely sought by the Australian Taxation Office. Accountants protested earlier this year to the Commissioner of Taxation, Mr Boucher, both as individual firms and through the Institute of Chartered Accountants, because they believe that the access power is so sensitive that it should be used by the Taxation Office only as a last resort; for example, in cases of suspected fraud. After all there is, in many instances, confidentiality of a high level between clients and their accountants.
The other point I would like to make about this Bill relates to the report of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. It had this point to make:

Clause 15 of the Bill amends section 57 (a) under the Income Tax Assessment Act and will restrict concessions available to a purchaser of new or substantially modified ships in that a taxpayer, so as to obtain the concession allowed by the section, must comply both with taxation legislation and the Ships Capital Grants Act 1987.
The amendment is retrospective to 22 December 1986. As the bipartisan Scrutiny of Bills Committee says:
The clause is a further example of legislation by Press release.

The Committee also draws the Senate's attention to the fact that the Press release announcing the proposed change and its retrospectivity to 22 December 1986 was itself released on 2 April 1987. So not only have we waited a year from the Press release until the legislation eventually emerged, during which time of course it could have been altered in some material way-this government by Press release in bad enough-but that 2 April announcement was retrospective itself to 22 December 1986.

Here we are, in 1988, passing laws which are retrospective to 1986. That is an intolerably bad way to run a country. It is an appalling way to run a tax system. The Government should lift its game very significantly in this area. It is all very well saying that because the Government is making what it calls reforms, or because it is chasing tax dodgers or doing all sorts of other things, therefore any action it takes is justifiable. That `end justifies the means' stuff just will not wash. The Commissioner and this Government must, I believe, do a lot better than the instances I have outlined today indicate they are doing.

Very briefly, I would like to deal with the question in our amendment of the record taxes of this Government. As I mentioned earlier on another matter, the latest statement by the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) reveals that tax revenue has increased 10.6 per cent so far this year. Revenue is up $5.8 billion. That means that the people of Australia are contributing $5.8 billion more this year to the Government's big spending than they did last year. Half of that total rise is made up of pay as you earn tax. It is not rich people's tax; it is tax coming from the workers, the people who are paid as they earn their money in Australia.

It is no wonder then that there has been no significant increase whatsoever in people's standard of living. Not only that, in fact the standard of living of ordinary Australians has been falling largely because of the massive tax rip-off of this Government. The national income figures that came out yesterday revealed that the major factor in increased consumption expenditure was government spending, which rose at twice the rate in the last 12 months; twice the rate of private sector spending, which went up only about 2.6 per cent.

We have here in these Bills and in this amendment in particular clear evidence of the extent to which this Government has been ripping off the taxpayers of Australia; ripping them off more and more. The deferment-and that was the bad news for taxpayers-in the May statement of any suggestion of tax cuts until just before the next election is associated with a refusal by the Government to cut its own expenditure and that is why tax cuts have been deferred. It is because this Government will not cut its spending and any propaganda that it has put out in recent times that its word is in fact totally phoney. It is bunkum. The only people who are having to cut their spending are, of course, the States.

This Government is not cutting its own spending one jot. In those circumstances I believe the Senate should pass the amendments to this legislation which point out the massive tax rip-off. The people of Australia are becoming increasingly aware of the fact that they are paying far more than they need to pay in tax and that this Government's budgetary surplus which in itself is inadequate in many ways, has been gained only by milking the Australian citizen, the Australian taxpayer, and by the Government's determined refusal to cut its own spending. I commend Senator Stone's amendments to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Those who have participated in and have followed the tax debates that have occupied this chamber for many hours in recent times will by now have become familiar with the pattern of tax legislation under this Government. We have seen a succession of haphazard and fragmentary Bills that give the appearance of being stitched up to fill in the gaps of a highly complicated tax system and the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) is certainly no exception because it deals with a wide range of issues and in doing so amends six taxation Acts. Principally, the Bill deals with a modification of rules relating to the registration of tax agents and the creation of tax agents boards. In addition it covers depreciation concessions for Australian trading ships, tax exemptions and allowances paid under the Disability Services Act, modifications to the tax credit system and changes to the capitalisation rule.

SPEECH.PARA: I also draw the attention of senators and listeners to this radio broadcast to the fact that amendments to the foreign tax credit system and thin capitalisation have been appearing before this Parliament with monotonous regularity. The Government just cannot get it right. Time and again we have these tax credit amendments coming through, affecting these areas, which indicate the Government's incompetence in this tax issue. So this lack of foresight shown in drafting of tax legislation is simply not good enough. Only last year the Income Tax Assessment Act was reprinted to incorporate the masses of changes and already we have a stock of amendments that will send the legislation further down the road to incomprehensibility. In fact, the Income Tax Assessment Act is now in serious need of complete overhaul, not just an endless procession of minor and major amendments that do nothing more than tinker at the edges of this problem because taxation laws in Australia have become intolerably complex and beyond the comprehension of the vast majority of taxpayers.

Despite continued reminders from this coalition, the Government continues further to complicate the system. The Australian Taxation Office is wallowing in the consequential mire. We see losses of a quarter of a million dollars as a result of a clerical error in the Taxation Office. Warnings have come from the Commissioner of Taxation that up to 300,000 taxpayers could be paying around $400m in provisional tax more than they need to pay. Complaints have come from auditors that the confidentiality of clients' affairs has been breached by the push by the Australian Taxation Office to investigate large companies. In fact the Taxation Office is in such disarray as a result of its struggle to keep up with Mr Keating's regime of high taxation that it has been forced into a public relations exercise to try to salvage its image. Only last week we saw the Government give the okay for an advertising agency to handle the sale of the new taxation file number system.

All this is just an additional burden on the taxpayer. We, in fact, are now paying to be convinced that paying more tax is actually good for us. The slogan is `Taxes building a better Australia'. I hardly think so. This approach is simply a further example of the arrogance of this Government and its Big Brother approach. We have often heard, and I think it bears repeating, that this is the highest taxing government in Australia's peacetime history. In fact, since Mr Keating took over the purse strings of the Treasury, tax revenue has soared from $44 billion to $78 billion, an increase of $34 billion in just five years. It is little wonder that the electorate is becoming alienated from the policies of this Government.

There are a number of amendments to clause 42 and my colleague Senator Stone will cover these in the committee stage of the debate. But in the interests of clarity I would suggest that if this Government is serious about protecting taxpayers from the vagaries of the taxation system, it should also look to the infringements by the Australian Taxation Office itself. I have already mentioned some examples of inefficiencies of the Taxation Office and I believe it is pertinent to add a few more. Many taxpayers are faced with lengthy delays in the processing of their returns.

One of my constituents has only just received a 1985-86 tax assessment. Small businessmen have to wait up to six months from an initial notification from the Taxation Office that they are to be audited. They have then to wait for the job to be eventually commenced. Complaints have been registered that the confidentiality of clients' affairs has been breached by officers of the Taxation Office. All these inefficiencies are symptomatic of the new tax system that Mr Keating has brought upon us.

We all know about the problems of the computer system-people getting assessments that are not even yet due for payment; not getting credits for amounts that have already been paid and so on. All this is a consequence of the rush to push up tax receipts with new taxes and a myriad of new regulations, all of which indicates that things have simply got out of hand. In fact, there appears to be a new philosophy that taxpayers are defrauding the system. The onus of proof has been reversed. Despite what Mr Keating would have us believe, the average taxpayer is honest; he complies with the system to the best of his or her ability.

I do not think the Tax Office or the Government should be judging the great bulk of taxpayers by standards set by Keating himself because the bulk of the taxpayers are honest. I believe that there are significant problems with the formation of a taxation board and these are going to be subject to some amendments that will be put forward by my colleague Senator Stone. While most are in favour of reasonable levels of regulation of any profession, it is accepted and a fundamental premise that anybody who has the power to prevent an individual from working within a profession should be wholly independent. This is the thrust of one of our amendments.

However, this Bill provides that one member of a three-man board will be an officer of the Australian Taxation Office and, in addition, that he or she should be chairperson of that board. Surely this is a classic case of conflict of interest for an officer of the Australian Taxation Office to be presiding over a body that controls the registration of taxation agents. At the very least, such a structure will affect the confidence placed in the board by members of the profession.

If the boards are to function effectively there must be no question about their impartiality. This will not be the case should the proposed composition of the boards be implemented. I regret that time prevents a further evaluation of these complex changes included in the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2).
Amendment negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, I rise to speak in relation to clause 42 of the Bill which has already been referred to by Senator Haines in her remarks during the second reading debate. Clause 42 of this Bill provides for two things. It provides first that in constituting the new tax agents boards, one of the three people to be appointed shall be `an officer of the Australian Taxation Office appointed by the Minister'. The clause provides secondly that that member of the board-that is, the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) officer-and again I quote, `shall be the chairperson of the board'.

SPEECH.PARA: I put it to the Committee that both these proposals are objectionable. I regard the first proposal, that each board shall contain as one of its three members an officer of the Australian Taxation Office, as totally inappropriate. I think it is quite wrong for a serving public servant to be appointed to sit on a board, the chief function of which is to assess and to pass judgment upon the fitness of private individuals who earn their living in a field in which they are in daily communication with the agency-in this case the Australian Taxation Office-of which that member of the board is a serving officer. I think that is totally inappropriate and I am astonished that the Government should bring such a proposal forward. I can only say that the rules seem to be changing in the Australian Public Service.

As it happens, we have some experience in a related and very similar field-the field of taxation boards of review which recently, of course, have been done away with. But during their long history, I think going right back to about 1922, taxation boards of review were chaired by people who had previously been officers of what is now called the Australian Taxation Office. These people, who had retired before taking up their appointment to the boards of review therefore combined two qualities. First, such people were knowledgeable about the taxation law and had worked throughout their professional careers in that field; and, secondly, they no longer were employees of what is now called the Taxation Office and were therefore capable of being, and being regarded as being, independent. Nevertheless, it is instructive to note that up until the time the boards were abolished, even those arrangements drew considerable disquiet and discontent.

In 1983 the Administrative Review Council undertook a review of taxation decisions by boards of review which was stimulated by that growing discontent about the modus operandi of the boards of review under their ex-Taxation Office chairmen. I can only say in summary that the view even that retired officers of the Taxation Office should chair boards of review did not commend itself to the Administrative Review Council. Although debate on this measure is limited, I think it is of a sufficient importance to spend at least a few minutes elaborating on the view that was taken at that time by the Administrative Review Council. Paragraph 88 of the Council's report No. 17 states:

The possibility that a specialist tribunal may lack independence from the department whose decision it reviews arises in several ways. Whenever a tribunal has one particular party appearing constantly before it, as is the case with the Boards and the Commissioner of Taxation, there is a risk that tribunal members may become attuned to the kind of arguments put by that party.
The report continued:
One way in which the risk may become evident was pointed to in an editorial article published in the Australian Taxation Review ((1980) . . . p. 2). The editors observed:
and this is a quote within the Council's report-

there is . . . a belief-whether or not it is well founded being not presently to the point-that taxpayers find themselves at a disadvantage, at least in certain classes of cases, before Boards of Review. Thus it has become commonly believed that taxpayers have very great difficulties in persuading Boards of Review that their purpose in acquiring property has not been a purpose of profit-making by sale. Indeed, it does not appear to be going too far to say that there is an apprehension that taxpayers appear prima facie to be treated as untruthful and as persons whose evidence should not be accepted.

That viewpoint was strongly challenged by the Commissioner of Taxation in his evidence to the Administrative Review Council. But the Council, while obviously noting and acknowledging the Commissioner's views, rejected them. In paragraph 89 of its report, the Council stated:
The nub of the problem is, as one member of a Board put it, that `independence is a state of mind'.
The Council went on to say:
The confidence which litigants have in the independence of the judiciary is a great strength in our legal system. Such confidence is no less important in the context of administrative review.

I could quote many other opinions, all of which are cited in this most interesting report of the Administrative Review Council, which tend to the same conclusion, namely, that there had developed a very unsatisfactory feeling on the part of the taxpaying citizenry as to the disinterested and objective qualities of the now defunct taxation boards of review. I pass no judgment upon whether or not that view was justified. I simply observe, as the Administrative Review Council did, that the view had become widely prevalent and was clearly damaging to the confidence in the administration of the taxation law. That led the Council, in paragraph 91 of its report, to pass the following judgment:

. . . the present practice of appointing not merely as a member but as Chairman a former officer of the Taxation Office or the former Deputy Commissioner of a State giving to him power to rule on evidence that may be admitted and control of procedural matters such as adjournments is a matter of adverse comment not only among practitioners but also among clients.

I turn from that piece of history to the tax agents boards which will be constituted under the Bill which we are now considering. I put it to the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) that the proposal in this Bill to appoint to these boards a serving officer-not a retired officer-of the Australian Taxation Office is bound to lead to the same kind of discontent and distrust, which can only be damaging to the administration of the law. Tax agents may feel that they have not been appropriately treated by the boards. If they are dealing with officers who, in another capacity, on another day, wearing another hat, will be dealing with perhaps the taxation returns of their clients, they are bound to feel that their freedom and their discourse with the tax agents boards are inhibited.

I would like the Minister to answer specifically why the Government feels a need to break from a longstanding tradition and move to appoint a serving officer of the ATO to the boards. The provision in clause 42 which would allow the Minister to appoint a taxation officer as chairperson-as the term is described-merely compounds the offence. I would like the Minister to respond.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In regard to the direct question concerning the composition of the tax agents boards, I am told that neither the Australian Audit Office nor the Treasury wanted to have an officer on such boards and a decision was made that it should be an Australian Taxation Office (ATO) member. I do not think Senator Stone raised this, but it should be mentioned for the record: the Opposition in the House of Representatives had claimed that the chairperson of the tax agents boards, who it is proposed will be an ATO officer, would have as much power as two other members. This was obviously based on the assumption that there would be a casting vote as well as a deliberative vote. I do not think Senator Stone said that, but I am putting the record right. That is simply incorrect. The chairperson has a deliberative vote, but not a casting vote.

SPEECH.PARA: The view of the Government is that the proposed composition-that is, one member from the Taxation Office, one from the accounting profession and one from the legal profession-is an appropriate mix. Senator Stone disagrees and the Opposition disagrees apparently, which I guess they are entitled to do. But the Government does not agree with their proposed amendment and, therefore, will be opposing it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) for his answer, as far as it goes. But I have to say to him that I do not find it in the least bit convincing. What the Minister has told the Committee is that because neither the Treasury nor the Australian Audit Office wishes to have officers of their institutions-quite rightly I may say; and I am very glad to hear that they took such a view-placed in this position of conflict of interest, therefore the Government has decided that an officer of the Australian Taxation Office should be placed in that position. That is not an answer. That merely, in effect, provides further evidence, if you like, as to the inappropriateness of what is proposed.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister has not responded to the question of how it comes about that it is thought by the Government to be appropriate to have a serving public servant from the key agency involved serving on these tax agents boards. There is no need to have a public servant on the boards at all. But if it were desired to have on these a member who had demonstrated professional expertise in the taxation field-and, of course, it is possible to find those people both in the legal profession and in the accounting profession as the Minister indicated by referring to the qualification of the other two members-it would be perfectly possible to resort to the device to which over many years the taxation boards of review resorted, namely, to appoint a retired officer from the Australian Taxation Office. Perhaps a retired Deputy Commissioner might be rather senior for such a job, but a retired officer of acknowledged expertise and ability would be appropriate. The Minister has not addressed that possibility. He has not addressed the question of why there is a need to have a serving public servant from wherever on the board. I would be grateful if he would now address the question.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know what else I can say. There is just a difference of opinion here between Senator Stone and the Government. He does not think that a serving public servant should be on the board at all. That is not the Government's view. I think he has paid insufficient attention to the fact that there are two other members on the proposed board-that is, a majority will be people from outside the Public Service; people, as I said before, from the legal and accounting professions. Just in case it is not entirely clear to those who may be listening or who may ultimately read the Hansard record, I want to stress that this particular board is not one which will be determining any disputes about taxation liability. It will determine disputes which may arise about the registration of tax agents. I do not think it is at all inappropriate to have a serving officer of the Australian Taxation Office-who, as part of his duties in that Office, could be expected to have a fairly intimate knowledge of tax agents-represented on the board, though in a minority capacity. Just in case I do not have time to indicate later on, I state for the record the Government will accept the Australian Democrat's amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I know we are under the guillotine, Madam Temporary Chairman, but I simply want to say that the further response of the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) is, I think, as unsatisfactory as his initial response. If the Minister cannot see what is wrong with it, let me put it to him, without I imagine further response from him, that it is utterly inappropriate to have a board which will, as he acknowledged explicitly, have the power to deregister a tax agent-after all, that is what this board is about; it is about assessing the appropriateness of particular people to serve in the capacity of tax agents-and, at the same time, have as a member an officer of the Australian Taxation Office who, with his other hat on, may be dealing with that tax agent, or some other tax agent. It does not take any imagination at all to see the kind of pressures that can be brought to bear upon a tax agent by the Taxation Office through that conflict of interest.

SPEECH.PARA: I will not pursue the point. I can see the Minister does not propose to budge on it. I simply put it to him that the Taxation Office will regret this action because it will serve to lower its reputation for integrity in the minds of the public and members of the tax agents' profession who deal with it. I regret that very much. I will not prolong my remarks. I move:
Page 23, clause 42, paragraphs (a) and (b), lines 33-40, leave out the paragraphs, insert the following paragraphs:
``(a) by omitting paragraphs (1)(a), (b) and (c) and substituting `appointed by the Minister.';
(b) by inserting after subsection (1) the following subsections:

`(1B) The Minister shall appoint a member of the Board to be Chairperson of the Board.';''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to reiterate Senator Stone's comments that in this time of complicated taxation laws and uncertainty about taxpayers' positions, it is not difficult to envisage real situations where tax agents are frequently in conflict with the Australian Taxation Office. To have a chairman of a tax agents board presiding over these conflicts is just not good enough. I think the amendment, that the Opposition has put forward must be supported.

``(1a) The Minister shall appoint as Chairperson one of the persons referred to in paragraph 1 (b).''.

[COGNATE BILL:
CRIMES LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1988]
Debate resumed from 26 May, on motion by Senator Gareth Evans:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating two pieces of legislation-the Crimes Legislation Amendment Bill 1988 and the Crimes Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1988. The first of those Bills seeks principally to repeal the sunset clause contained in the National Crime Authority Act 1984-in other words, it will enable the National Crime Authority (NCA) to continue and not be curtailed by that sunset provision. Furthermore, the Bill will enable the present Chairman to be reappointed for a further year. In addition to those two principal amendments, there are also some changes to the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979.

SPEECH.PARA: The second of the Bills does a number of things but the principal amendment is designed to empower the National Crime Authority to use listening devices in its own right in the investigation of illegal drug offences, subject to judicial warrant and on the same basis as the Australian Federal Police. Therefore, these Bills cause us to focus clearly upon the National Crime Authority, its structure, its achievements and, in particular, its future. As I said, the legislation will enable the Authority to continue as a permanent body and the Chairman to continue for a further year. Again, the legislation will further extend the Authority's powers.

In recent times a number of criticisms have been made of the NCA. In the minds of some, there has been a growing number of criticisms and clearly those criticisms are causing public concern. As we focus our attention on the NCA tonight it seems to me to be sensible to look at some of those criticisms and attempt to analyse whether or not they are valid and, if they are, to look to some remedial action. As I said on a previous occasion, public support for the NCA is important if it is to do its work properly. If it loses public support, it will soon be undermined and pressure will be applied for it to cease to be. As I said on a recent occasion, I do not think that would be in the best interests of our fight against organised crime.

The first criticism that one has read in recent times is that the NCA is too secretive. That criticism has not only been applied in relation to the NCA but also it has been applied in relation to the monitoring committee-the Parliamentary Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority-and, to some extent, it is a fair criticism. The Committee has recently put down an interim evaluation of the NCA and perhaps it overdid the need for secrecy by holding all of its meetings in camera. If we had held some of our hearings in public, I think public support for the work that we were seeking to do but, more importantly, for the NCA, might have been enhanced. I think we have learnt a lesson from that.

The more difficult question is the level of secrecy required by the NCA itself. When the body was set up some four years ago I can remember debating in this chamber and also in the committee that considered its structure in depth, the question as to whether or not it should operate in secret or, rather, whether it should follow some of the American models which carry out a lot of their work in public. I was of the view, and the committee was of the view, that if this body was to carry out investigative functions somewhat similar to those of the police, it was important that it did its work in secret. In other words, we rejected the American model, which is really designed to warn the public against particular individuals without those individuals having been convicted of any crime. We were of the view that that method was contrary to the system and the values of justice that we think are important in this country.

The fact that the NCA operates in secret is not by chance; it was intended to operate in that way and is doing so. Of course, criticisms can more easily be made of any secret organisation because people are uncomfortable with the secrecy per se. This criticism has come to the fore in recent times because of the comparisons between the NCA's work and that of the Fitzgerald Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct.

I stress tonight that both bodies are performing different functions. The function of the Fitzgerald inquiry has been simply that of a public inquiry to establish a set of facts which, as I said, must be compared to the entirely different structure of the NCA, which is to investigate a target and to determine whether there is sufficient evidence to prosecute that target before a criminal court. To establish a set of facts on the public record, as the Fitzgerald inquiry does, requires, sensibly, a large amount of this work to be done in public. That is the way in which it operates. To criticise the NCA because the proceedings of the Fitzgerald inquiry are held in public is to confuse the two different functions of two different bodies. Just as we would not want police officers to make their investigations public, I suggest we would not want the NCA to make its investigations public. The problem, of course, is that if it does so, it has the effect of placing in people's minds the suggestion of guilt before guilt is proven-something that does not seem to be of great concern to the Americans, but, as I said, which would certainly be of concern to us and should be protected. Both systems can, of course, be complementary. The NCA will take the public evidence of the Fitzgerald inquiry and, where targets are established from that, conduct its own investigations in secret and, if evidence is sufficient, bring prosecutions arising out of those investigations.

This whole question of secrecy is complex. At the next step it raises the practices of some courts, particularly in my State, in regard to their very liberal approach to the granting of suppression orders, so that the public is not made aware of who is before the court or the circumstances of offences. There are those who say that that is a wise course of action, in that guilt has not been proven in those cases and the public has no right to know. On the other hand, there is a security, I would suggest, in matters being put on the public record in a court. It is not only a security for the public in general that matters are being handled properly, but, whether or not the defendant believes it at the time, it is also a great security for the defendant that justice will be done. It is a difficult debate, but overall I support public hearings as much as possible, even at the magistrates court stage. I place on record tonight that I think that South Australian courts have gone too far in the other direction and the public is not made aware of information of which it has a right to be made aware.

If we are to have a body such as the NCA with wide powers, there must obviously be securities. This is not appreciated often enough in this debate. The numerous methods of safeguards that we have applied to the NCA are far greater than those applied to any other police force. There is the safeguard of the annual report. That might be just a small contribution. There is the greater safeguard of the supervisory committee of this Parliament, the monitoring committee, which can go quite a bit further. It can be a forum for complaints by individuals against the NCA, and it has acted as such. If individuals are unhappy with the operational performance of the NCA, they can complain to this Federal Parliament. On occasions they may do so, and their complaints would be properly investigated and appropriate action taken.

The supervisory committee goes further than that. It can fulfil a responsibility to the public. When there are criticisms of the performance of the NCA, as there are now in relation to the Harvey case in South Australia, where the magistrate was critical of the NCA, and, more recently the Grassby case in New South Wales, this Parliament will investigate those public criticisms in order that we can either satisfy ourselves that the criticisms are valid, in which case remedial action should be taken, or, if they are invalid, we can say so in this Parliament and, hopefully, give the public of Australia some extra assurance. So this extra safeguard of a supervisory committee is placed upon this body.

The committee also has the responsibility of trying to make some assessment as to whether the NCA is achieving its objectives. State police forces, of course, do not have the same challenge in a parliamentary form. The parliamentary committee has sought to see whether it is effective. How does it do so when the Authority's function is to act as a deterrent as well as, of course, to assemble evidence to be presented in courts against major criminal figures and, hopefully, to obtain convictions? It is not an easy task.

Certainly, the NCAs record in relation to convictions and material benefits can be directly pointed to. The figures at this interim stage of its operation are really quite impressive. At the time of our report, 194 persons had been charged with a total of 540 offences, and so far 46 have been convicted and are serving very long sentences. A number of major cases are currently before the courts. Over $17m in understated or undeclared income has been assessed by the Australian Taxation Office as a result of NCA investigations, and another $13m has been notified to the Taxation Office. Proceedings have commenced for forfeiture of assets from criminals in the sum of $3.3m.

On the face of it, it looks as though the NCA is achieving something positive. What we do not know is, had the same powers and resources been given to existing State police forces, whether the figures would be very different. I think we are quite happy to acknowledge the difficulty in making that assessment. With respect to deterrence all I can really say is that in our investigations on the witness protection inquiry what did seem to be emphasised to us was that criminals are concerned and have a real consciousness about the NCA-its powers, its resources, and its interdisciplinary structure.

We concluded in our evaluation that the body should continue, although it was premature to make a final assessment, and that has been the attitude of the Opposition. We believe that the sunset clause should be lifted. The NCA has enough runs on the board to justify its continued existence so that, with public support, which we hope we can assure, it can continue to play a worthwhile role in combating organised crime in this country.

There are a number of extra safeguards which the Senate should be aware of. The first is one that we also stressed in the original report some four years ago-that is, the safeguard of appointing the right people to the body. I stress to the Minister for Justice, Senator Tate, who is not here tonight-nevertheless, no doubt it will come to his attention-the importance that we attach to the fact that if one gives a body such as this coercive powers, one must appoint the right people to that Authority.

The fourth safeguard, of course, is that those people would be rotated-that is, the so-called Hoover principle that we learnt from the experience of the United States, that it is unwise to leave members of such a body in office for too long a period. Although we have agreed to this Bill, I think we are probably making a mistake in agreeing to the Chairman's-Mr Justice Stewart's-term, being extended. I say that with no disrespect to him. Once one breaches the principle, it is easy to breach it again. There will always be good reasons to extend someone's term. There are good reasons in relation to Mr Justice Stewart, in that he is part of the way through a number of inquiries. As I said, those good reasons will always exist. I think it is probably better if one recognises the importance of the principle and stands firmly by it. The final safeguard is the inter-governmental ministerial council to which the Authority is responsible, which met last Thursday.

In summation, we find that, although the NCA has great powers, it is in many ways answerable to many more bodies and authorities than a normal police force. I have said that it is the opinion of the Opposition that the NCA should continue. I draw the Senate's attention to the recommendations in the evaluation report which we would endorse-that is, there needs to be a better working relationship between the NCA and traditional police forces. We made some suggestions regarding investigative teams comprising both bodies. I remind the Senate of our suggestion that we should appoint a senior, respected serving or former police officer as a member of the Authority to try to overcome this barrier that seems to exist between an authority which, at the moment, consists only of lawyers, and the police forces around the country. We said that in setting up more task forces the Authority also can help to overcome this gap that seems to exist at present. If the Authority could get more support from traditional police forces, in turn it would get more public support, and that will be in its best interests.

I do not want to take up too much more time because I want to give Senator Macklin a reasonable opportunity, having regard to the limitations imposed by the guillotining of this legislation. I mention the other criticisms of the NCA that have been made. The second criticism was the Costigan-type criticism-that the body is not putting together a sufficient picture of organised crime and that that should be its function. That was not the function that was determined by this Parliament. The function determined by this Parliament was that it should be chiefly an investigative body. Out of those investigations, a picture of organised crime would come. It should not be set up on the model of the Costigan inquiry. That was a different type of inquiry and it, in turn, suffered criticisms. There were those who said that it did not produce evidence in a form that could be put before the courts which could therefore lead to convictions. I am not critical of Costigan because that was the nature of his inquiry. This is a different body and, therefore, criticisms of that type do not appreciate the determination of the Parliament as to the nature of this body.

I will end my comments. Let me simply say that, in trying to evaluate the performance of the NCA to date, I ask those who are trying to make that assessment to recognise that its budget-$15m to $16m a year-is not a great budget when one compares it with the enormous sums of money that are being produced by organised crime in this country. If one thinks purely of the drug trade-the huge masses of money with which those who are involved in such criminal activity can buy protection for themselves from all levels of authority in our society-one has an indication of just how difficult a task the NCA has in meeting its charter. Nevertheless, in accepting that difficulty, we accept our responsibility to be able from time to time to assure the Parliament that the NCA, in our view as a monitoring committee, is doing its job properly. I can assure the Senate that we will continue to meet that responsibility in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Hill for allowing me some time to make a few comments on the Bills which are before us-that is, the Crimes Legislation Amendment Bill 1988 and the Crimes Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1988. The first Bill contains amendments to the National Crime Authority Act and to the Telecommunications (Interception) Act. The principal item that we are dealing with is the repeal of the sunset clause, which now places the National Crime Authority on a permanent footing. The Australian Democrats wholeheartedly support the National Crime Authority and the work that it is doing, and we therefore welcome this move to entrench the Authority's position.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is worth remembering at this stage the reasons for the establishment of the Authority. During the late 1970s and early 1980s it became clear that the traditional law enforcement methods in Australia could not cope adequately with increasingly sophisticated methods of crime, particularly those employed by international groups and, probably more importantly, by the overwhelmingly powerful, moneyed interests involved in drug trafficking. Three commissions at that time-the Williams, Costigan and Stewart commissions-identified these problems. It is interesting to note that none of those sought-in their earlier stages, at least-to declare the existence of organised crime in Australia. I, a number of members of the monitoring committee and, I believe, the National Crime Authority, now differ from those earlier positions. We now recognise the existence of organised crime in Australia. The evaluation report of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority attempts to look at that in the Australian context. I think it is a worthwhile exercise because there is probably enough sensationalism in this area without adding to it. A more sober approach to the type of problem that we are facing in this country is certainly necessary.

The Australian Democrats, while supporting the concept of the Authority, believe that it is necessary to ensure that the very important powers and activities that it has are balanced against the civil rights of the citizens of this country and the fundamental principles of fairness which we have sought to entrench within our judicial system. History will certainly reflect the important role that the National Crime Authority has played to date and undoubtedly will play in the future to try to make Australia and our society a safer place against crime. A range of other pieces of legislation over the last few years have also added to that.

The point that Senator Hill raised is an important one. It is not necessary to say that we might not have been able to achieve the same result by granting these powers to State police forces and to the Australian Federal Police. The problem was that there did not seem to be a parliament that was willing actually to grant those police forces those types of powers. Hence, we were in a difficult position. There did seem to be the need for a new body with the type of role undertaken by the National Crime Authority, yet one which could be monitored by a parliamentary committee. The role of the parliamentary Committee is vitally important. It is one which increasingly will become an advantageous element in this whole exercise. It had a very rocky road earlier on, which I think is public knowledge, but since that time, certainly it has been my experience that the relationship between our Committee and the National Crime Authority is becoming increasingly productive.

I certainly endorse the comments made by Senator Hill with regard to the type of role that that Committee can play that it has not sought to play in a great way so far. It can be the recipient of problems that citizens may have with the National Crime Authority. It is not our role to engage in censorship of the Authority in any shape or form, but we hope that our constructive relationship with the Authority will enable us robustly to raise problems that we see might arise and, hopefully-certainly, knowing the Chairman of the Committee, this will be the case-get an equally robust response.

I think that that is an important role. It is an innovative way of dealing with things in this country. It is probably made possible by the willingness of members of parliament to look at their role in a more expanded light and to realise that while we cannot have our finger on the pulse of the details, Parliament has a role to play in our type of society that has to change and develop over time. This is one aspect. There are others-in fact, there is another statutory body which, unfortunately, still has not been established, with regard to the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation. Indeed, I wonder when it will be established, as is required by legislation. We are still waiting. We thought we would see it introduced in this session, but we have not yet seen it. I imagine that the Government, at some stage, will belatedly get around actually to fulfilling the requirements of the law in that regard. I see both this role and the role of that other statutory committee, when established, as being ones that develop the traditional role of Parliament.

The other Bill about which I wish to make a couple of comments is the one which amends five separate Acts. The amendments to the Customs Act are designed to empower the National Crime Authority to use listening devices in its own right in the investigation of illegal drug offences, subject to a judicial warrant, and otherwise complying with the requirements applicable to the Australian Federal Police. Most senators would be aware that the majority of references to and general investigations by the National Crime Authority involve drug-related offences. Indeed, the work of the Committee has certainly been a revelation to me in terms of the density of crime, as it were, in the whole area of drugs. One cannot help being amazed that that single problem, if removed from the criminal system, would certainly lead us back to the old fashioned notions of crime-breaking and entering and murder. This problem, however, seems to have grasped in its tentacles almost everything else that has been operating in our society. Even the lesser crimes that are caught up in the web of investigations by the National Crime Authority seem, in some way or other, to be related to drugs.

It is a terrible scourge in our society. I believe that most citizens do not realise the cost that our society has to bear, not just in terms of the lives that are lost but in terms of the money that is generated to promote and extend the criminal activity into so many areas-to provide the money which is being used in Australia, as we well know, to bribe officials, to bribe police, to bribe judges, to bribe politicians. It is a cost that is probably not recognised by most people in our society, but one which does not seem to be lessening. It is one which seems to be on the increase.

I do not have time to deal with the other amendments in detail. These types of amendments to the National Crime Authority were envisaged in the original Act, upon request by the Authority or upon review of its functions and powers. The extension of the powers of the National Crime Authority are an indication of the continued trust and support that this Parliament has in the National Crime Authority and in the work that it is doing. Unfortunately, I believe that we will long need such an authority, and we have made a good start in that regard.

I, too, support the point made by Senator Hill with regard to making sure that there is a rotation of the chairing of that committee. There is, as Senator Hill said, always a good reason why it should not occur. I think that Mr Justice Stewart has done a magnificent job, but the principle is a vitally important one. We also know that a good job was done by a number of other people who stayed too long. Mr Justice Stewart has got the thing up and running. He has, in fact, stamped his particular mark and approach on it, which will long endure when he goes on to other activities. I believe that we should be excessively careful in extending the terms of anybody serving on the Authority and should seek, rather, to abide by that principle. This will be to the benefit of the Authority and to the fight against crime in this country.
