SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Amendment Bill is an important Bill. It proposes several changes to the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act designed to bring the Act into line with similar provisions in the Commonwealth Electoral Act. The Commonwealth Electoral Act relates to the conduct of elections, whereas the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act deals with the conduct of referendums to alter the Federal Constitution.

SPEECH.PARA: Last year the Commonwealth Electoral Act was amended in a variety of ways to implement the recommendations of the second report of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform. That report was prepared following a reference to the Select Committee to review the Electoral Act in the light of the experience gained at the 1984 general election. That general election was the first to be conducted after the major changes which were made to the Commonwealth Electoral Act in 1983. The Government rushed through the 1987 changes to the Electoral Act to enable them to be in place in time for the hastily called and totally unjustified election in July 1987-an election, one might recall, that added yet another notch to the Prime Minister's gun of broken promises. The result of rushing through those changes to the Electoral Act in 1987 was that several of the provisions in that Act became inconsistent with the provisions of the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act. Prior to 1987 there had been no inconsistencies between the two Acts.

The Bill before the Senate this evening is designed to remove those inconsistencies and it also proposes several other amendments which flow from the second report of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform. The Bill seeks to make 10 changes to the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act. I will come back to the specifics a little later. Let me just indicate here that the Opposition accepts seven of the 10 proposals but opposes three. I have circulated on behalf of the Opposition proposed amendments to those three and I will comment further on them in the committee stage.

I would like first to make a few general comments about the Bill and related matters. I said at the outset that the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Bill is an important Bill. It is important because it proposes changes to the ways in which referendums are conducted in this nation. As we all know, referendums are of vital importance because they are the only way in which the Constitution of this nation can be changed. The Constitution is the very basis of our federal system and it is therefore the very basis of our democratic system. The machinery provisions through which changes to the Constitution are made are therefore of great significance. It is essential for the preservation of confidence in our parliamentary democratic system that all aspects of the electoral and constitutional processes, including the ways in which they are conducted and the ways in which they are altered, are also held in high confidence by the Australian people. Any proposals to change the arrangements should therefore be subjected to close scrutiny.

I therefore believe it is scandalous that this Bill should be jackbooted through the Senate in half an hour using the razor of the Government's totally undemocratic guillotine, a guillotine which, it must be stressed, the Government has been able to employ only because of the agreement and connivance of the Australian Democrats. For years the Democrats have trumpeted their total opposition to the use of the guillotine, but we now find them prostituting all the so-called principles at the altar of shabby, cynical, sleazy political opportunism. The debt owed by the Democrats to the Government for calling a double dissolution election last year and thereby ensuring their survival when political oblivion was imminent is enormous, and the Government is now demanding and taking not just its pound of flesh. By now it must be up to a tonne, with no end in sight.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would have been peaceful if they had been wiped out, wouldn't it?

—It certainly would. It is not just sad to see a party of self-described principle so totally prostituting all those so-called principles: quite frankly, it is disgusting. Although the proposals in the Bill flow from the recommendations of the highly regarded Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform, the actual Bill not only deserves but also requires much closer scrutiny by the Senate than is possible in a rushed half-hour on the very last night of what has been a long, tiring and demanding session.

SPEECH.PARA: In recent months we have seen two classic examples of the abject failure of this Government to get its legislative drafting right. There have been many other examples of perhaps lesser moment. Late last year we discovered a fatal flaw in the Government's Australia Card Bill. Only this week a major flaw was discovered in one of the vitally important referendum Bills. So it is perfectly clear that we cannot have any confidence in the Government's ability to draft any of its legislative proposals accurately. It has been in the Senate where most of these flaws have been detected. Yet it is the Senate, the watchdog on behalf of the Australian people, which is being subjected to today's brutal guillotine and it is the Senate's watchdog role which the Government is seeking to emasculate in its referendum proposals to be put to the people in September, which proposals must be defeated if the Senate is to remain the guardian and watchdog of the interests of the Australian people.

I also express my concern at the frequency and the extent of the changes we have made to the electoral laws in recent years. There have been a great number of changes, some major and some less so. Obviously, many of the changes have constituted improvements. However, I believe some have resulted in an erosion of confidence in the integrity of the electoral process. This confidence has been further eroded in recent months by concerns expressed by the Electoral Commissioner about the accuracy of the election returns after the 1987 election.

I believe I would share the experience of most senators and members when I say that nowadays I receive a very large number of allegations of electoral malpractices. Those allegations may be ill-informed. Certainly, frequently it is difficult to have them backed up with hard evidence. But the very fact that the allegations are made clearly demonstrates that the public has declining confidence in the electoral system. Such a decline in confidence is, in reality, a concern about the integrity of our democratic processes, the core of which is free and honest elections. This decline in confidence may well be due, at least in part, to the frequency of the changes we have been making to the electoral laws. Tonight we are considering further changes. Although they are to referendum rather than electoral provisions, the two are closely interrelated.

There is in the Parliament another Bill-the Electoral and Referendum Amendment Bill-which proposes a whole raft of still more changes. In addition, the Joint Committee on Electoral Matters is currently engaged on a review of the Commonwealth Electoral Act in the light of the experience of the 1987 Federal election. That inquiry is bound to lead, in due course, to many more proposals for change. I consider, as does the Opposition, the Committee's inquiry to be an important one. I am not suggesting that it should not proceed and with expedition. Rather, I am saying that we need to step off the merry-go-round of change before too long, before confusion and lack of confidence in our electoral processes become endemic. In view of the time I will reserve any further comments, particularly in relation to the amendments that I have in mind, until we move to the committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not intend commenting at the second reading stage of the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Amendment Bill, but I was provoked by some of Senator Short's comments about the Australian Democrats' role in exercises such as this. He made what I consider to be the most extraordinarily wild but serious allegation about connivance between the Democrats and the Government over legislation. In other words, he suggested some type of pay-off. I did not at that time seek to take a point of order but I consider that the most serious and wild allegation, obviously one that would be made only inside the chamber. It would certainly not be made outside, because it would constitute a case that I would love to take to court.

SPEECH.PARA: If Senator Short wants to go outside and repeat the allegation I would be very happy for him to do so. One of the television or radio stations might ask him a question about it. I would like to see whether he made the same types of remarks. His proposition can easily be displayed as extraordinary by looking at today's events. Senator Short would not know this because he would not have read most of the legislation to have come before this chamber, but I amended one Bill 35 times. I am sure the Government would be very happy not to have us here amending legislation time and again. The Democrats end up amending more Government legislation than the Opposition has even bothered reading.

The exercise that Senator Short just engaged in was an extraordinary one in light of the type of Bill that we are trying to discuss. The prostitution of the methods of this House that the Opposition has engaged in with its filibustering reflects the importation into this chamber of methods used in the House of Representatives. The idea is to waste enough time so that time for debate runs out and certain Bills do not pass. It is a pretty crude method but it works. There is only one method of avoiding it.

I have said on occasions, and I say it again, that we need a far better method of processing this and other types of legislation through this chamber. We will probably need to sit longer-although I must admit that that is a daunting prospect this Thursday-because we have far more legislation to deal with. But I wonder, for example, whether we need the vast second reading debates that we have or whether we might be able to use far more of our time in the committee stage. If we are indeed constituting ourselves-because we are not so constituted by the Constitution-as a House of review, perhaps we ought to see whether the majority of our time on Bills is spent in reviewing legislation rather than in stating positions about it, which is what the House of Representatives does and does effectively in its adversarial politics. There are many ways in which we ought to be dealing with legislation. It seems to me that Senator Short's claim is a very odd one. I repeat that it is one that he would make only in here and not elsewhere, because it is a fabrication of furphies and lies. Indeed, I would be happy to have a case in the courts with regard to that particular allegation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not going to take up most of the issues raised by Senator Short. We will have it out one day as to whether there are rorts and ramps in the Australian Electoral Commission, but not tonight. I will not speak in the committee stage. I just want to indicate in general the three issues the Opposition considers important. The first one relates to clause 8. I am not going to canvass the committee stage here but will just go to the generalities. This amendment arose out of contact between the Australian Electoral Commission and the Attorney-General's Department. Sample ballot papers were sent to the Attorney-General's Department and it found that one section of the legislation was probably in conflict with another. The section that we are proposing intends to clean that up.

SPEECH.PARA: I will not speak at any length on it but I wish to make one plea to Senator Short. If he is to persist with his amendment he should delete clause 8 (b). Quite frankly, leaving 8 (a) by itself is an embarrassment to us all because it has no real meaning. In the committee stage Senator Short might add 8 (a) and 8 (b) to his amendment. We would give leave for that because it will just make for a sensible approach to this amendment.

The other two amendments that will be moved were passed by this chamber, without opposition, last June. They have already been passed in the electoral Bills and I think it will be quite consistent to put them in the referendum Bill. If we do not, we will have two different Acts for the Australian Electoral Office to enforce. Just imagine what would happen if this was not changed again. We would have, in an election that had a referendum attached to it, two different sets of criteria to deal with. It would make it absolutely impossible.

Let me deal with the point raised relating to the extension of time to perform certain acts. This proposal is to provide extensions of time in which acts must be completed in the event of the unforeseen failure of a person to discharge an associated statutory duty. This was agreed by the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform and it was done to overcome that problem of industrial blackmail. It seems that Senator Short and his colleague in another place have argued that this will encourage industrial blackmail. It takes from certain sections of society an immediate ability to upset an election through industrial action and it allows for extensions of time. It was accepted in the Electoral Bill 1987 and it should also be reflected in the referendum Bill.

I will finish on the last point raised concerning the abolition of the three-month rule. The third amendment would delete those provisions in the schedule to the Bill which amend section 30 of the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act. The schedule amendments are designed to delete the requirement that an elector must have resided in the division of his enrolment at some time in the three months immediately preceding polling day in order to vote in the division. It must be emphasised that the three-month residence rule, as it stands, only operates as an additional test over and above the requirement that a person must have resided in a subdivision for one month before being entitled to enrol for that subdivision. The residence requirement for enrolment is not to be changed in any way. The amendments will simply make a person's appearance on the roll conclusive evidence of his or her entitlement to vote, which is what most people presume to be the case anyway.

The analogous amendment to the Commonwealth Electoral Act was made in 1987 on the unanimous recommendation of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform. In the course of a detailed discussion of that issue the Committee noted in paragraphs 3.25 and 3.32 of its 1986 report:
the three month rule is . . . in practical terms incapable of across the board enforcement.
It states further:
Its operations are anomalous in that it only works to disenfranchise those electors who have not correctly maintained their enrolments, but are honest enough to admit it.
The report emphasised:

the rule . . . is not an obstacle to fraud or impersonation. Very few electors were ever asked the complex pre 1983 prescribed questions . . . and there is nothing to suggest that any more were asked the sub-section 229 (3) question regarding places of living during the past 3 months. Any person contemplating fraudulent voting can, without difficulty state addresses or make declarations which will not of themselves prevent the admission of the vote.

There are real practical difficulties which would arise in a joint election and referendum if the three-month rule were to be retained for referendums only. The most important would be the frustration which would be caused to electors who would be allowed to vote for the election but not for the referendum. Different questions would be prescribed to be asked of persons voting at the election and the referendum and different declarations might also be required. I make the point that, if the Liberal Party of Australia is serious about these amendments--

TALK.START.PARA: —We are always serious.

—If members of the Liberal Party are serious, they will get another crack at it in the spring session. The point I am making is that if we were not to change it there would be different electoral rules for a referendum and an election held on the same day. There is a new electoral Bill coming up in the spring session, and if the Opposition is serious about these amendments it would be better to consider the matter then and amend both Bills at the same time. I assure the honourable senator that we are not likely to have a combined election-referendum in the next few months.
—Why not? It is a very unstable government.

—Senator MacGibbon laughs. I will give him 50:1, anything up to $100,000. I make only one other point. These rather improved and generous rules for getting on the roll have not saved the Liberal candidate for Ballarat North. I read in tonight's Herald that the Liberal Party is still trying to get up their candidate for Ballarat North. If the Opposition's amendment went through and was put into the Electoral Act he would never have a chance; he would be wiped out absolutely.

SPEECH.PARA: In summary, and I will not address myself to the Bill again unless asked a specific question in the committee stage, the Government wants to reject the three amendments. If the Opposition and the Australian Democrats want to persist with amendment No. 1, it seems to me we should take out (a) and (b) just to make the Bill logical. I will not be broken hearted about that. We can always look at it again in the spring session and have a longer discussion on what we mean by it, et cetera.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 5, paragraph 8 (b), lines 13 to 16, leave out the paragraph.
(2) Page 5, clause 10, lines 27 to 36, leave out the clause.
(3) Page 6, Schedule, leave out the following:
``Subsection 30 (3):
Omit the subsection.
Paragraph 30 (5) (a):
Add at the end of paragraph `or'.
Paragraph 30 (5) (b):
Omit the paragraph.
Subsection 30 (6):
Omit the subsection.''.
Although I have moved these three amendments together, we would prefer that the questions on each be put separately. The first amendment is to leave out paragraph 8 (b), which states:
For the purpose of ascertaining a voter's intention, regard shall only be had to the word `Yes' or `No' written alone or without words of qualification.

The Minister for Home Affairs, Senator Ray, has suggested that if we are going to move to delete that we should also move to delete paragraph 8 (a), and the Opposition is happy enough with that. That would, as I understand it, leave the existing Act unchanged in relation to this aspect and, as the Minister said, perhaps we can look at it in the spring session. Therefore, I seek leave to amend my amendment No. 1, in effect to leave out the whole of clause 8.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 5, clause 8, lines 9 to 16, leave out the clause.

In view of the discussion that has taken place, the comments of Senator Ray and the time, and the fact that as I understand it the Australian Democrats will be supporting this clause, I will not elaborate on it other than to say that the reason we are moving for the amendment of the clause is that we believe it does not do what the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Matters intended, and with which we agreed-namely, to have a vote in a referendum regarded as valid if there is a clear `Yes' or `No' in the appropriate box and also if there are words outside the box that have no relevance to the question. The proposal in the Bill that regard shall be had only to the word `Yes' or `No' written alone or without words of qualification seems to us to spell out the opposite of what was proposed by the Select Committee. Indeed, in section 24 of the existing Act the method for determining the vote is already very clearly defined.

The first of the other two amendments is to leave out clause 10, which enables the Australian Electoral Commission to extend by 48 hours the time in which acts must be completed in the event of a failure by any person to perform a statutory duty or function. The inclusion of that provision in the Bill has been proposed because of certain threats of industrial action which occurred, as I understand it, at the 1984 election, as a result of which the Electoral Commission considered that the remedies in existence were inadequate. It did not see an increase in penalties for failure to observe as the solution. Therefore, it has sought an extension of time in the event of industrial disputation or other causes preventing officers from carrying out their statutory duty. The Opposition believes that that is really an acquiescence to the power of industrial action. We think that that is very bad in principle and therefore we oppose the amendment.

The third amendment proposed by the Opposition is to delete various sections of the schedule which is contained under clause 11 of the Bill. Basically, we are seeking the exclusion from the Bill of the changes concerning the requirement that electors enrolled in a division must have lived within that division at some stage within three months prior to voting. I fully recognise, as Senator Ray said, that this proposal in the Bill is to bring the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act into line with the Commonwealth Electoral Act. Considerable concern was expressed about the amendments that were made to the Commonwealth Electoral Act in 1987. There have been allegations of electoral malpractices, not necessarily hard evidence, which I mentioned in my second reading speech. It is the view of the Opposition that those allegations and the matters pertaining to them should be considered carefully in the forthcoming inquiry of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform into the Electoral Act regarding the 1987 election. Until such time as that inquiry has been completed and the Parliament has had a chance to consider the report of the inquiry, we believe that the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act should remain unaltered. It can then be looked at in the light of the findings and recommendations of the forthcoming report of the Joint Select Committee. On behalf of the Opposition I commend the three amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that the three amendments moved by Senator Short be agreed to. By leave of the Committee I will put them separately. The question is that amendment No. 1, which was amended by leave, be agreed to.

—Mr Chairman, I intervene to say something that I should have said before. The Opposition's view is that these three amendments are all very important. If the Committee does not subscribe to the three amendments, we will oppose the third reading.
—The question is that amendment No. 2 moved by Senator Short be agreed to.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that amendment No. 3 moved by Senator Short be agreed to.
