DEBATE.TITLE: RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 24 May, on motion by Senator Gareth Evans:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —The Research and Development Legislation Amendment Bill 1988 contains amendments to the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 and the Industry Research and Development Act 1986. As the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans) said in his second reading speech, the amendments arise from a technical review in 1987 of the 150 per cent tax concession for research and development. The thrust of the amendments was foreshadowed by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) on 20 November last year.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill implements those decisions affecting the Industry Research and Development Board. Other decisions announced at the time were implemented by the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1987, which the coalition did not oppose. The current Bill extends the powers and functions of the Board in relation to administration of the 150 per cent tax scheme and contains consequential amendments to the Income Tax Assessment Act. The coalition parties recognise the importance of industrial research and development to the future prospects of Australian industry and the valuable catalytic role that Commonwealth support for industrial research and development can perform in small innovative companies. The coalition introduced some of the measures this Board now administers.

The Bill we are now debating extends the discretionary powers of the Board to enable it to determine the eligibility of companies and projects to participate in the scheme and to restrict the tax concession from being exploited other than as intended. This includes ensuring that projects have sufficient Australian content and that the results of revenue subsidised research and development are exploited on normal commercial terms for the benefit of Australia. The coalition parties recognise that the potential for abuse of programs such as the tax concession for research and development must be minimised. The Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills drew attention to clause 16 of the Bill. In due course I would like the Minister to let us know what action he intends taking in response to the Committee's concerns. The Bill increases the access of small companies to expert research and development resources by enabling the Board to register a wider range of research agencies which can be contracted to conduct eligible research and development for companies. It also enables firms to joint venture for costly or risky projects.

The coalition supports these amendments as they are in accordance with the thrust of our policy, which in part is to increase the access of small business to the scheme and also to specialist research and development facilities. It is arguable that these sorts of measures should have applied from the commencement of the initial Act, particularly the provision for registered research agencies, which can include private sector specialist research organisations, that replaces the previous provision for research institutes, which was limited to public sector organisations.

What was not foreshadowed in the Minister's statement last November is the provision in clause 11 to increase the number of other members from 10 to 13; that is, to increase the total membership of the Board, including the Chairman and public servant appointee, from 12 to 15. The Opposition parties are opposed to this provision. In the committee stage we will oppose clause 11. The explanatory memorandum is deficient and states that the `amendment increases the number of Board members from 10 to 13'. This is clearly incorrect. The explanatory memorandum also states:
This increase will enable the Board to carry out the additional functions imposed on it since its inception in 1986, including those included in this Bill.

The Opposition does not accept that explanation or the explanation offered by Minister Jones in the other place for increasing the size of the Board. When the Board was established in 1986 it was known that the functions of the Board would increase and the Industry Research and Development Act 1986 contained provisions to enable the Minister to give additional functions to the Board. To cover that contingency, the Board was established with provision for a total membership of between six and 12 members. The Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones) was not satisfied with having the maximum number of 12 members. He now proposes to increase it to 15.

I recognise that the current Bill amends the long title and object of the principal Act. However, the other amendments relate to the effective administration and operation of the tax concession scheme and hence would not be outside the scope of what may have been considered when the range of membership was determined in 1986. Since 1986, the Board has received only one additional function which could be considered to be separate from its initial responsibilities for the grants for industry research and development scheme and the tax concession scheme. That extra function is its role in administering the national procurement development program, which it received this financial year. I doubt whether that role justifies three extra Board members.

In the other place, Minister Jones attempted to justify the increase in members by referring to the number of committees which support the Board. To me, the existence and operation of the committees ought to reduce the need for increases in Board membership, as they appear to exercise many of the functions of the Board and reduce the work of the actual Board. When the members of the seven committees are taken into account, the number of people administering the research and development programs can be seen to be very large.

I would like to suggest an alternative reason why the Government is now seeking to increase the membership of the Board, and that is to compensate for its inefficiency in some areas. The Board was very late in publishing its 1986-87 report, which we did not get until 26 April 1988. I was concerned by the cynical attempt to muddy the waters in relation to the late filing of that report by having a letter accompanying the report dated October 1987, although the report was not tabled until April 1988.

Last week we heard the Treasurer talking about measures to increase the efficiency of the economy and announcing tariff cuts. But it was noticeable that the Government ignored the hard issues. Notable also was the Treasurer's failure to announce any measures to deliver a more flexible labour market or to reduce the majority of the anti-competitive burdens on industry through meaningful reforms in such areas as deregulation and communications and transport. In a perverse form of consistency, rather than the Minister attempting to ensure that the Industry Research and Development Board becomes more efficient and better uses its resources, he is attempting to paper over the problems by increasing the membership of the Board. The coalition is opposed to the Government avoiding the issue and will oppose clause 11 of the Bill to ensure that the maximum number of members of the Board is not increased.

The other amendments in the Bill protect the public's investment by restricting abuse of the tax concession and increasing the access of smaller companies to the tax concession and to specialist research and development resources. The coalition will support those amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will not be opposing the Research and Development Legislation Amendment Bill 1988 and will not be supporting the amendment to be moved by the Opposition to that Bill, but I would like to say a few words about the main thrust of the body with which this legislation deals because it bears on a matter which the Democrats feel is very important. I refer to the role and the commercialisation of research. It is certainly true that we should be spending a great deal more money on research, but the direction which that research takes should not necessarily be towards the commercial application of the research findings.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is an historical fact that when science first got under way it was directed towards discovering the structures and the working of God's universe. It was an esoteric activity which was not in any sense directed towards the conquering of God's creation. It was a purely investigatory activity so that one could better understand that working. It is really only in fairly recent times, the last few hundred years, that that attitude has changed. Not only have we been involved in research for its own sake, for the discovery of knowledge, but increasingly research has also been directed towards what Sir Julian Huxley called the heuristic idea of conquering nature-the idea of discovering truth simply so that one can turn that to one's pecuniary advantage. It is self-evident that that attitude of discovery applied to exploitation has led to catastrophic and increasing damage to the environment. If one listened to the words of Professor David Suzuki in the Science Show last Saturday, one would have been informed--

TALK.START.PARA: —Why bother?

—That is a very interesting remark. Senator Bishop has asked why we should bother to listen to Professor David Suzuki. That is a remark from the Opposition which I would like on the record as typical of the views being put forward by the Opposition in regard to the views of Professor Suzuki when he was speaking to the Junior Australian and New Zealand Association for the Advancement of Science conference. I would like Senator Bishop to write to me some time to tell me precisely what is wrong with Professor Suzuki's argument.
—I would be delighted to.

—I thank Senator Bishop very much. Professor Suzuki said that, if one looks at the total energy flows through the total biosphere, one will see that a large proportion of that energy now flows as a result of human activity. It far exceeds the energy which flows through every other aspect of the biosphere, on which we are ultimately dependent. The continuation of this exploitative attitude to the discovery of the workings of nature is--

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. The good senator who is speaking issued an invitation to me to explain to him why I found Dr David Suzuki's arguments less than satisfying and convincing. If he ceased speaking, perhaps I could explain to him now why I have that view.
—There is no point of order. Senator Coulter has the floor.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. That is the level of debate in relation to this important matter. One of the things one notices about members of the Opposition is that the important things to them all deal with money. Of course, here we are talking about a tax measure. That is important to the Opposition because it involves money. However, I believe that that money is being spent in a direction that is increasingly damaging. For that reason I wish to proceed to point out some of those damaging consequences.

SPEECH.PARA: What is required now is a paradigm shift in our view of research and the application to which that research leads. It is self-evident that if one funds research which is going to produce material gains for those who fund it, certain sorts of research will be underfunded and other sorts of research will be neglected altogether. It is also true that even those research projects which have led eventually to major financial gains usually have been of the nature of fundamental research which at the time it was conducted was not conducted with any view to material gain.

The Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Jones), who introduced this legislation in the other place, is wont to speak of the potential advantages of superconductivity, but I point out that the research which is going on in that area may not lead to, and is not at this stage directly related to, those applications but is of a more fundamental nature, attempting to discover why certain materials can be superconducting at temperatures far above absolute zero.

One could point to the original work on DNA, the applications of which we may deal with later tonight. The fundamental research which went on at the time was not intended in any sense ultimately to lead to applications which may have a financial return. The research on nuclear energy-something that the Opposition often wishes to bring to our attention-went on without any idea of an ultimate application which would return a profit. The transistor is another example of fundamental investigations in physics which have led to enormous changes in lifestyle and applications which involve enormous commercial activities. That research was not the sort of research, as I read it, which would be undertaken in the activities envisaged by this Bill and which the processes it is amending would support.

So the Australian Democrats have considerable reservations about the support of this sort of research and these sorts of activities directed towards short term material gains. Nonetheless, as I indicated earlier, we are neither opposing the legislation, nor supporting the Opposition's amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to thank both honourable senators for their warm support for this legislation. I am grateful that they understand it and appreciate the purpose to which it is directed, which was described very carefully in the second reading speech, and indeed was touched on by Senator Lewis in his remarks. Senator Lewis made a sort of stock speech. I do not know that he is going to do when we deregulate the labour market in this country. He will not have anything left to talk about. His hit list has got shorter and shorter as he has gone on.
—Go on; get around to doing it.
—The honourable senator will have a real problem and the size of the problem is indicated by the gusto of the interjections from his colleagues.

SPEECH.PARA: Two points have been raised which have some slight substance and with which I might deal. The first is the question of the report from the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. I wrote yesterday to the Chairman of that Committee. I indicate to the Senate that since the Bill was drafted the Administrative Review Council has circulated a discussion paper suggesting that some discretionary decisions of the Industry Research and Development Board should be reviewable by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. It refers in that paper to some of the discretions which it says should be reviewable. I am advised that the Board has decided to support the suggestion but is reluctant to pre-empt discussions of the more general issues by the Administrative Review Council. There is some additional information which the Scrutiny of Bills Committee saw tonight. Some of that information was provided to the Chairman in a letter, and I will provide him with any further information he requires.

The second point relates to Senator Lewis's amendment. The Opposition feels strongly about this issue of the number of members on the Board. When the Opposition moved the amendment in the House of Representatives it did not go on with it; it abandoned it.

TALK.START.PARA: —You had a guillotine down.
—No, the Opposition abandoned it.
—We did not.
—The Opposition did not vote on it.
—I am in charge of this Bill and we will vote on it. Don't you worry about what happened in another place.

—Righto. It is no good barracking me. The honourable senator can do so at the football on Saturday if he wants to, but it is no good barracking me. There are a number of reasons why the Government wants this additional membership of the Board. I will explain them now because I do not want to have to deal with them at the committee stage of the Bill. Since the Board was established in 1986 it has been given a number of additional functions by the Government. The Board was established with 10 members other than the Chairman and a departmental representative.

SPEECH.PARA: It is proposed to increase that number. The Board has since been given a lot of additional functions. Four generic technologies have now been declared and there is a subcommittee dealing with each of those generic technologies-biotechnology, information industries, new materials and communications technology. It has been required to administer the national procurement development program to which Senator Lewis referred in his speech. That is not the only enlarged function which has been given to the Board. It has been given a task in respect of the promotion of research and development, and encouragement of international collaboration in research and development and additional functions in relation to the tax incentive.

In order to ensure proper policy development and administration, the Board is of the view that two additional Board members should be added so they might handle all these functions. Each subcommittee has at least two Board members on it. Quite a range of functions have to be dealt with which were not present when the original legislation was passed. I make the point that the Board members are very busy people in industry. Senator Lewis chastised them for inefficiency. A better sharing of the workload is envisaged by the proposed increase of the size of the Board. I do not want to address that issue at the committee stage. That is why the Government has amended that portion of the legislation in that way. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 4, clause 11, leave out the clause.

This clause was referred to in the second reading debate. I indicated the reasons the Opposition parties believed that it was wrong to keep increasing the size of boards. Increasing the size of boards can be likened to Parkinson's law. If the Industry Research and Development Board was doing its job, it would be much better to employ people and utilise expertise which was not on the Board. Senator Button explained that there are two Board members on each committee. In that case I suggest to Senator Button that there is probably no need for all those people to be on the Board. I am sure that any organisation-private company, public company or statutory authority-is a much better organisation if it has a small, lean, efficient board of management which can meet rapidly and quickly and make decisions. As the size of a board is increased decisions become greyer and flatter. I am a firm believer in small boards of management in any organisation. I say to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) that, if this organisation has grown to the stage where it needs 15 Board members, the Board is far too large and needs to become more efficient.

I conclude by saying that I am disappointed in the Democrats once again. As has been indicated throughout the course of the day, one can never tell what the Democrats will do until they actually vote in the chamber. About three hours ago, when we checked out with the Democrats what they were going to do in relation to my amendment, the advice was that they would support it. Senator Button has since given them their riding instructions and now they will not be supporting the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must refute Senator Lewis's claim. Senator Lewis has not contacted me. I have not discussed the matter with him. It has been quite clear all the time that we would oppose the amendment for the very good reason that it is an ideological amendment only and does nothing worthwhile.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will not accept the amendment. Senator Lewis has a vision of a small, lean board employing people to perform its functions. He had better have a look at its functions: accountability for Commonwealth money, for taxpayers' money. If we have a whole series of subcommittees which are not peopled, at least to a significant extent, by members of the Board we will not have proper accountability for taxpayers' money. Senator Lewis has gone on with his usual ideological mumbo jumbo about this Board, but it is a working functional board. It is not like a board of directors which meets and gets its riding instructions from a managing director; it is a working board of experts. That is why the extension of the membership of the committee has been proposed by the Government. The amendment is not acceptable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister says that this Board is highly efficient. The truth of the matter is that this Board is so efficient that the letter from the Chairman addressed to the Minister and presenting the last annual report is dated October 1987 but in fact the report was not tabled in this chamber-and I presume, therefore, was not completed and delivered to the Minister-until early this year. The Minister is required, no doubt, by the Act to table the annual report within 21 days of his receiving it. The report must have been delivered to the Minister in about March of this year but the letter accompanying it is dated October 1987. That is not efficiency; that is shonkyness.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.
Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Senator Button) read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: SUPERANNUATION BENEFIT (INTERIM ARRANGEMENT) BILL 1988DEFENCE (SUPERANNUATION INTERIM ARRANGEMENT) AMENDMENT BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 24 May, on motion by Senator Tate:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Superannuation Benefit (Interim Arrangement) Bill 1988 and the Defence (Superannuation Interim Arrangement) Amendment Bill 1988. The coalition will be supporting the second and third readings of these Bills. However, we have a second reading amendment to the Superannuation Benefit (Interim Arrangement) Bill 1988. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At the end of the motion, add: ``, but the Senate deplores the Government's failure to develop consistent superannuation policies without imposing additional taxes, its reliance for over 3 years on `legislation' by press release causing confusion and lack of confidence in superannuation for those planning their retirement, and the anxiety which has been caused by the superannuation changes announced in the May Economic Statement''.

As of late, superannuation has been a high profile political topic. Certainly in my State, with the by-election for the Federal seat of Port Adelaide occasioned by the retirement of Mick Young, it was a very high profile issue. The result in that electorate indicates a number of things. As has been indicated a number of times in this chamber, the first thing it is indicative of is the failure of this Government to keep in touch with its grassroots-its home base, if you like. There was no better example of Labor's home base than Port Adelaide. As honourable senators would be aware, there was a very big swing to the coalition parties in that electorate. The second thing that that swing showed was not only the dissatisfaction with the direction of the Labor Party as a whole but also the real concern and anxiety of Australia's working community with this Government's attitude to superannuation. Of course, that is why the Labor seat of Port Adelaide is regarded, at least in terms of the percentage swing now required to win it, as a marginal seat.

Superannuation has been a high profile issue in the media, quite apart from the by-election in Port Adelaide. It has taken prominence in the media in the last few days as a consequence of announcements made in the May statement. It is in that context that we are dealing with this Bill tonight. The coalition parties and, presumably, most people in this chamber would like to see all Australians providing for their retirement through superannuation. They need some incentive to do that. There is no doubt that there is some incentive at the moment but perhaps not enough. They need more than that. They need certainty and clarity in government announcements, and clarity requires simplicity. That is where this Government has fallen down. Very few of those people who have seen interviews on the television with the Treasurer (Mr Keating) following the announcements in the May statement, those who have listened to the Treasurer on radio trying to explain the announcements in the May statement, or those who have read Press reports of announcements in the May statement understand with any real clarity or certainty the net effect of the announcements that have been made.

Australians very strongly suspect that the Treasurer, Mr Keating, is playing a pea and thimble trick. He is taking from one end, adding on to another and saying, `In the meantime no-one has to pay any more. No-one loses anything'. This has really heightened the anxiety in the community over superannuation. There is no doubt that it is in the interests of the whole Australian community if more people take out superannuation and, in that sense, are more self-sufficient in their retirement. But they will not do that if there is no certainty and they cannot rely on the Government to put into practice that which it preaches.

The second reading amendment that I have moved not only highlights the anxiety caused by the announcements in the May economic statement but also emphasises the reliance by this Government on legislation by Press release. It has been a feature of this Government, not only in the superannuation area but also in other important areas, not the least of which is the taxation area, to make announcements by Press release and then months and months later down the track produce the legislation which is meant to reflect the content of the Press release. I served for some time on the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances and on the Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations, both committees of this chamber. In both of those committees the question of legislation by Press release was raised. Of course it has been raised in other places as well.

The problem created by that sort of approach is this: If a government engages so much in legislation by Press release there develops a climate where the business community is inclined, probably out of necessity more than as a result of the standard the Government has set, to make decisions on the basis of Press releases. The business community cannot afford to say, `Oh well, this has been announced by the Treasurer but we won't take any notice because there is no legislation'. Not at all. It has to rely on the Press release. We have found on numerous occasions that the legislation does not reflect what the Press release indicated many months before.

Superannuation is an area, like tax, where we simply cannot afford this kind of approach by any government and certainly not by this Government, which seems on a day to day basis not to know what it is doing. There are a number of aspects by which one needs to judge a superannuation scheme. In other words, there are a number of essential elements. The first question one needs to ask oneself is whether it provides people with adequate income for retirement. Surely that is what we are looking for in superannuation. Secondly, does it reduce access to social security benefits? The economic climate we have at the moment, with the debt that has been incurred by this Government, and its own spending, notwithstanding its determination to decrease the spending of others, highlight the need for us to reduce access to social security benefits. Thirdly, we need to ask ourselves: Is it a superannuation scheme which benefits the nation, both sociologically and economically? When we consider the superannuation situation in Australia today we have to say, having regard to those three criteria, that the Government has failed and failed badly.

Let me give some background to the Bill. In September of 1985, as a part of the accord mark 2, the Government agreed to support the claim of the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) for superannuation benefits equivalent to 3 per cent of ordinary time earnings to be granted to all wage and salary earners on the basis of increased national productivity. While supporting the extension of superannuation, we condemned the 3 per cent productivity agreement as just another example of the ACTU dominating Government wages policy. It ignored the capacity of industry to pay.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was an arbitrated decision, Senator.
—There was no requirement for a demonstrable increase in productivity, and it denied employers the right to enter into superannuation agreements with their employees voluntarily.
—It was arbitrated by the Commission. It was the umpire's decision.
—Senator Cook, I will call you if you wish to speak. Otherwise, let Senator Vanstone have the floor.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. The Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission rejected the ACTU's productivity claim in its June 1986 national wage case decision. However, the Commission decided that it would ratify agreements negotiated by employers and employees for additional superannuation benefits as long as they were consistent with the Commission's guidelines. In March 1987, in the national wage case decision, the Commission reconsidered its position and decided that where the parties were unable to negotiate an agreement the Commission would arbitrate. The Commission would award no more than 1.5 per cent of ordinary time earnings to operate no earlier than 1 January this year, and no more than a further 1.5 per cent to operate no earlier than 1 January 1989, next year.

SPEECH.PARA: At the time we said that the additional costs of the extension of the 3 per cent increase to the public sector could not be justified as most Commonwealth employees already had access to a superannuation scheme which was generous when compared with most private sector funds. Certainly that view would be endorsed throughout the community were we to have a reliable opinion poll taken on that matter. The interim arrangement contained in this Bill generally covers Commonwealth employees and employees of approved authorities for the purposes of the Superannuation Act 1976. There are however some exceptions. They are as follows: firstly, those who have superannuation arrangements other than under the Superannuation Act 1976; secondly, those who have no superannuation cover and who are employed by authorities that provide superannuation arrangements other than under the Commonwealth superannuation scheme; and, last, the Northern Territory and its authorities. Where authorities have superannuation arrangements other than the Commonwealth superannuation scheme and/or employees have special superannuation arrangements, it is expected that a 3 per cent benefit will be provided.

The first main feature of the interim arrangements is that it provides benefits for most employees, including temporary, part-time and casual employees who have previously not had that access. I am informed that some 75,000 public servants, not being full-time public servants, have not in the past qualified for superannuation under the Commonwealth Superannuation Fund Investment Trust arrangements. That is one of the reasons that the Opposition does not oppose this Bill. It is absolutely fundamental to our approach to superannuation, and one would hope to that of the Government, that the sooner all people in the work force have at least the opportunity to provide for their retirement the better. That is a very significant feature of this Bill. The second feature is that benefits above $500 generally must be preserved until genuine retirement and are not to be taken before the age of 55. Employees may not contribute to the fund. It is an unfunded arrangement; that is, there is no central invested fund to which contributions are to be paid. The third feature is that employers will be required to calculate and pay benefits as they fall due, including payments in respect of persons who leave employment between 1 January 1988 and the date of passage of the legislation. The interim arrangement is separate from the Commonwealth superannuation scheme administered by the Australian Government Retirement Benefits Office.

One further aspect of this Bill which is of concern is that we may be seeing the beginning of a trend where Australian employers, irrespective of their capacity to pay and irrespective of whether they already have a suitable superannuation scheme in place, will still be required to fund a further significant increase in superannuation without any contribution from their employees. The approach the Government is taking will ensure once again that Australia's level of productivity will not necessarily increase to the extent that it should and, worst of all, that we will remain uncompetitive in the world markets because of the impact that this will have on overall costs of labour. It needs to be borne in mind that if someone gets a benefit, someone else pays. It is the old saying: there is no such thing as a free lunch. Nor is there any such thing as a free addition to one's superannuation entitlements. In the current economic climate we need to make our industries more competitive, more productive. The only way we can do that is to ensure that they get a reward for payments they make, for costs they incur. That means that when necessarily an increase is paid to employees via superannuation, there must be a consequent increase in productivity-otherwise productivity falls and our international performance falls, and the situation for all Australians, not just in the accounts we publish but on an individual level, falls.

In closing my remarks I remind the Senate of the Opposition's proposed amendment to the motion for the second reading-that is, that we support the second reading of this Bill, but we deplore the Government's failure to develop consistent superannuation policies; we deplore its reliance, for well over three years, on legislation by Press release, which has caused confusion and a lack of confidence in superannuation for people planning their retirement; and we further deplore the anxiety which has been caused by the superannuation changes announced in the May economic statement which Treasurer Keating has as yet been unable to satisfactorily explain.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will support the second reading of the Superannuation Benefit (Interim Arrangement) Bill 1988. We also support the amendment moved by the Opposition.
—That is a good idea.

—I am pleased that that has finally been acknowledged. We are getting some positive response from the Opposition benches. This machinery Bill simply grants a decision by an arbitrating commission. We have no objections to that, of course. The Opposition's proposed amendment makes some pertinent observations about the Government's superannuation policies. There are two significant words in the title of the Bill-`interim arrangement'. In a sense those words encapsulate what has been the nature of the Government's superannuation policies for some time now. They have been very much of an interim nature. The proposed amendment cites this inadequacy in Government policy on superannuation. It makes a number of obviously valid criticisms that can be levelled at the Government's superannuation policies.

SPEECH.PARA: We are told that life was not meant to be easy. There is something about this area of Government policy which suggests that life is meant to be uncertain. I believe that probably the common denominator in the Government's superannuation policy is that it has required Australians to live in uncertainty, to be uncertain as to how to plan for their retirement, because there has been no firm, clear policy in place over an extended period which has allowed them to bed into their basic values of self-reliance and to plan for their future. In fact, I think many Australians have experienced in the last few years a degree of uncertainty which they find uncomfortable. For decades we were able to plan our lives and to look forward to the provision of housing and education for our children and retirement benefits for ourselves. There has been a degree of uncertainty in the last few years which Australians essentially have found uncomfortable. Unfortunately the area of superannuation is one such area. So I think it is not unreasonable to identify with the criticisms inherent in the Opposition's second reading amendment, and the Australian Democrats do so.

There is one dimension of this Bill which cites a specific example of penalty, we believe, in relation to superannuation-namely, for those in the defence forces. It is a fact that about two years ago a flow-on of 2 per cent to the defence forces retirement benefits was frozen and that freeze remains in place. Members of the defence forces have suffered a penalty which simply adds to their uncertainty about how to plan for their retirement. The Opposition's amendment is citing a major area of inadequacy in government policy. We identify with it because it urges the Government to move through this period of uncertainty and to clarify what the circumstances are in this nation so that Australians can plan constructively, without penalty and without disincentive for their future. Not only has this uncertainty affected investors in superannuation funds but, unfortunately, it has also affected those who operate superannuation funds. We are joining with the Opposition in supporting its amendment to the second reading. We are joining with the Opposition in calling upon the Government to move us into a period of stable, clear policy in relation to superannuation.

In summary, not wishing to take up the time of the Senate, the Australian Democrats support the second and third readings of this Bill and in doing so also support the Opposition's amendment to the second reading.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Superannuation Benefit (Interim Arrangement) Bill we are debating this evening provides the opportunity for a large number of people who have previously been excluded from the benefits of entering superannuation for their later retirement to take up those benefits. It is very appropriate that we are debating such legislation at this time, just a week after the May economic statement has destroyed superannuation opportunities for Australians by imposing a new and additional tax on the earnings of superannuation funds which will significantly reduce the retirement benefits of superannuants. It is for that reason that the Opposition spokesman, Senator Vanstone, has moved an amendment which will apply to the motion for the second reading of this legislation.
—Mick Young took his superannuation.
—Of course, he was a Minister in a Government that was planning to impose a superannuation tax. He was smart. He took the money and ran. He knew when to get out.
—He took $3,000 a week; $1,000 a day.
—Is that his superannuation or is that his Qantas fee?
—That is his Qantas buy off.
—That is right; so he has superannuation and a Qantas fee as well. He knew when to get out, that is for sure. As I was saying, the amendment moved by my colleague Senator Vanstone states:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion, add: ``, but the Senate deplores the Government's failure to develop consistent superannuation policies without imposing additional taxes, its reliance for over 3 years on `legislation' by press release causing confusion and lack of confidence in superannuation for those planning their retirement, and the anxiety which has been caused by the superannuation changes announced in the May Economic Statement''.

In passing, it is relevant to that amendment to recall the legislation that was passed through this chamber a few weeks ago. It was a prime example of legislation by Press release. That legislation in relation to superannuation and the treatment of annuities for tax purposes came into this chamber more than a year after a Press release had announced that annuities would be treated in a certain way for tax purposes. It was legislation which, as I said at the time, a significant body of opinion regarded as having a quite different effect from the effect that was outlined in the Press release.

But the most significant aspect of this amendment is the anxiety that has been caused by the superannuation changes announced in the May economic statement. The Government's inherent dishonesty with regard to that statement is very much in evidence with regard to its treatment of superannuation. The Treasurer (Mr Keating), in the May statement, claimed that these measures `will allow the Government to bring forward nearly $1 billion of its own tax money-now lying in superannuation funds-without diminishing any personal end-benefit by one cent'. That is simply not true. Certainly, the tax of 15 per cent on the employer contributions to superannuation funds merely offsets the reduction by 15 per cent of the tax on lump sums. However, the 15 per cent tax on the income of superannuation funds is a new and additional tax. In theory, this can be offset by using imputed tax credits from fully franked dividends received from those Australian companies providing such dividends. In practice, this is simply not possible. This is to be expected of a scheme which was thought up by some Treasury boffin who awoke in the middle of the night and which was cobbled together in a week in time to be presented as part of the May statement.

It was clear from his answer to the question which I asked in this place a couple of days ago that the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) is not very well informed about the implications of this 15 per cent tax on superannuation funds because, in his answer to that question, he slid all over the place without directing attention to the specifics which I had asked him. He clearly demonstrated that he does not understand the long term implications of this tax.

According to the Government document that was published with the May economic statement that specifically dealt with the new taxation treatment of superannuation, superannuation funds currently have about 15 per cent of their total investment in equities offering franked dividends. To have sufficient tax credits to offset the 15 per cent tax they would have to raise to about 60 per cent the level of equities in fully franked dividends. That is the case because dividends in companies give a much lower yield than do other sources of income such as interest, rent or whatever.

A number of funds would be precluded from such a high percentage of investments being in such equities. These include capital stable approved deposit funds, capital guaranteed funds and annuity funds. For the rest it would be most imprudent to have such a high percentage of their total investment in equities. So, in the first instance, prudential management of contributors' funds will prevent the tax being fully offset.

Money currently invested in superannuation funds in Australia totals about $50,000m. About $10,000m of that is in equities, with about $7,000m being in franked dividend equities. Given that they need to raise that percentage of equities in their total investment to about 60 per cent, the superannuation funds must, therefore, lift their total investment to nearly $30,000m, an increase of nearly $23,000m. Again, given that not all Australian equities provide fully franked dividends, in reality that requires an increase of some $25,000m to $30,000m in overall equity investment by the funds.

It must be remembered that this increase in investment has to be achieved in a total commercial and industrial equities market of about $110,000m. Of course, it is the commercial and industrial sector of the equities market that provides regular dividends. However, not even all of those are fully franked dividends. Furthermore, that $110,000m consists of many equities which would definitely not be prudent superannuation investment, leaving aside the imprudence of a 60 per cent investment in equities anyway. There are simply not enough shares available to allow funds to acquire an additional $25,000m to $35,000m in equities; nor would appropriate shares be capable of being issued to meet that demand.

The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Treasurer and the Minister for Finance had better return to their basic economic texts. They are guilty of the fallacy of composition-something which a first year economics student learns about. Because it might be possible for one or two of the funds to meet the equity requirement they have assumed that all the funds can do so. But they cannot. As I have said, there are insufficient equities to go around. In trying to reach the required percentage of equities the funds will cause an unsustainable, at least on earnings, increase in share prices. But this in turn, of course, will reduce the yield on dividends, thereby reducing tax credits and pushing them further away from the goal of having sufficient tax credits to offset the tax. It is about time the Government came clean on this issue of the taxation of earnings of superannuation funds at 15 per cent.
Opposition senators-Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the support of my colleagues for that comment. There is no doubt that this superannuation tax is yet another rapacious revenue raiser on the part of this Government which will substantially reduce the accumulation of benefits, thereby destroying the retirement plans of millions of Australians. The Treasurer has staked his credibility on his claim that nobody will lose one cent of his superannuation payout under the new rules. Andrew Peacock told the Treasurer on television last Wednesday week, on the night of the May economic statement, that he was wrong. We can see from the analysis that I have presented tonight who in fact was right. It was the shadow Treasurer, Mr Peacock, who was right, and the Treasurer who was wrong.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government must come clean. It must admit that this is an additional revenue raiser and that it will not be possible for superannuation funds to establish a tax neutral position with regard to the new tax and, therefore, it will be the retirees who will be the losers. Of course, the Government will earn additional revenue at their expense.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I guess that on the last night of the last sitting of the Senate in the provisional Parliament House it is too late in the day to divert from what has been a hallowed tradition in this chamber. The hallowed tradition to which I refer is to address a Bill in terms of the speech one would have given on a major political issue. Although it is not directly relevant to the Bill one nonetheless gets one's views into the Hansard. Tonight we have had a number of speeches on the Superannuation Benefit (Interim Arrangement) Bill which were not directed to what the Bill is about. Nonetheless there has been an opportunity for three speakers from the Opposition benches to put on the Hansard record speeches which they wanted to make anyway and no doubt draw the attention of their constituents to them. That is an old tradition. It is not surprising that on the last night of the last session of the Senate in the provisional Parliament House it should be adhered to. I think that we would do ourselves a disservice if we did not recognise that the speeches delivered have not been relevant to the subject of the Bill before the chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: We are debating the Superannuation Benefit (Interim Arrangement) Bill and the Defence Superannuation (Interim Arrangement) Bill 1988. These two Bills do specific and machinery things. Perhaps it is necessary to reply to the debate once again by citing what the Bills are about. The two Bills in fact implement decisions by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. Those decisions relate to judgments handed down by the Commission in 1987 which gave superannuation increases of 1.5 per cent from 1 January 1988 and 1.5 per cent from 1 January 1989 to Commonwealth employees and to defence personnel, and the Government has chosen now to implement those decisions in the form of these Bills.

The significant thing is that many Commonwealth employees have superannuation, and the benefits that apply in these Bills will go to them as add-ons to their existing scheme. The other major aspect of these Bills, and the one which it seems to me was missed entirely in the debate, is that there are a number of Commonwealth employees who do not unfortunately have superannuation cover but who by the passage of these Bills will get it and will thus be able to provide for themselves upon retirement.

Many of the speakers have eulogised the need to have superannuation cover and to provide for retirement. Indeed, it is one of the proud achievements of the Hawke Government that, through the prices and incomes accord and in pursuit of superannuation with the trade union movement, we have witnessed the extension of superannuation coverage to many millions of Australians who did not have it before. That stands tall as a major social welfare reform of this Government. What we are doing in these Bills is making sure that Commonwealth employees who do not have cover now obtain it; and that is for them a significant achievement.

In terms of all that was put, I think that is the only comment that is necessary from me. The arguments put by the last speaker, Senator Chapman, are arguments which he has advanced through questions in other places and which the Government rejects. The other arguments are noted and--

TALK.START.PARA: —Let us hear your arguments to reject it.

—I will answer those in the appropriate forum. This is not it. We are dealing with these Bills tonight, Senator. It would have been useful if the honourable senator had actually addressed them. On the basis of those remarks, I have nothing further to say.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Vanstone's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Original question, as amended, resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time, and passed through their remaining stages without amendment or debate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 24 May, on motion by Senator Tate:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The hour is late. We have only 30 minutes to debate this Bill, and if my colleagues will allow the shorthand writers to hear what I am saying we may get on with it faster. The Audit Amendment Bill 1988 has been brought forward by the Government with a view to making a number of what might be called machinery amendments, to which the Opposition of course has no objection. But there are two aspects of the Bill which have excited the interest of the Opposition. The first of them relates to the arrangements whereby each month the Commonwealth publishes an account of its financial transactions for the month just completed, the so-called Commonwealth financial transactions statement, or what was called the Niemeyer Statement when I was a boy, a long while ago.

SPEECH.PARA: In October last year the Government sought to amend the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill 1987 to give the Minister for Finance authority to approve variations in the form of the Commonwealth financial transactions statement, subject to tabling details and explanations in the Parliament. The Opposition, with the support on that occasion of our sometimes friends, the Australian Democrats, rejected that proposed amendment in the Senate on the ground that it would diminish existing parliamentary control over the form of reporting the monthly financial performance of the Government. In, I think, clause 6 of the Audit Amendment Bill the Government has proposed a different change to enable a similar outcome. The change proposed will enable the form of the Minister's monthly statement to be varied by way of regulation. Of course, such a variation would be subject to tabling in this place and consideration by the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances and may be disallowed in this place or, for that matter, in the House of Representatives, although the House is not normally the place where such things happen.

I say in passing, without dwelling on the point, that, contrary to the assertion made by the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) in the second reading speech, an amendment along the lines proposed would not accord with the suggestions which he alleges were made by the Opposition in the debate on the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill last year. It is true that my colleague Senator Lewis, who had the carriage of that Bill, canvassed the possibility of the Minister proceeding alternatively by way of regulation, but he did not indicate that the Opposition would support such a proposal. On the contrary, I think a close reading of his words indicates that he said that we would still oppose the amendment. That is the case.

The question is whether amendment of the monthly financial transactions statement format by regulation would diminish parliamentary control of the process. Quite clearly it would. It is true that it would diminish it less than the original proposal last October, which would have given the Minister sole power, without reference to the Parliament, to make such changes in the format. Nevertheless, it would diminish it because, as is well known to all honourable senators, any regulation, once made, is valid until disallowance. For example, a regulation made tonight would lie on the table of this Senate until some time in August, when we resume, and not be subject to disallowance for up to 15 sitting days after we resume. So we would be well into September and, meanwhile, the statement would be in a different form.

On this basis I foreshadow that we shall be opposing that clause of the Audit Amendment Bill 1988 when we come to it. The other area of the Bill to which I want to direct some brief remarks, speaking as we all are tonight under the shadow of the guillotine--

TALK.START.PARA: —The phantasmagoric shadow.
—As Senator Aulich has interjected, that phantasmagoric shadow--
—Madame Defarge.

—Monsieur Defarge, yes. Currently, the Auditor-General has a discretion not to report certain minor or immaterial breaches of the Audit Act 1901-a very old Act. Some breaches of it are committed from time to time which the Auditor presently has a discretion not to report.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 15 of the Bill proposes to provide the Auditor with a more general discretion covering all departments and all statutory authorities in that respect. I think it is material to the consideration of this area of the Bill by the Senate that the Joint Committee of Public Accounts considered this proposal by the Minister and indicated its opposition to it. Indeed, I take this opportunity to quote from a letter addressed to the Secretary to the Department of Finance, Dr Michael Keating, by the Chairman of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, Mr Tickner, MHR, in the course of which Mr Tickner said:
. . . the Committee wishes to outline its concern regarding the proposed amendment to Section 63md-
That is, section 63md of the Audit Act. He went on to say:
The Committee feels that the Auditor-General should be obligated to report all such breaches-
that is, breaches of the Act-
to the Parliament. The Committee is of the view that it cannot support amendments that further erode the requirement on the Auditor-General to report to the Parliament.
In acknowledgment of the fact that what is being proposed here is said to relate only to minor breaches, the Chairman of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts went on to say:
In cases where the breaches are relatively minor these need not be detailed reports.
The Chairman concluded:
I reiterate that the Committee does not support this amendment as it stands.

That letter was written prior to the consideration in Cabinet of the proposal by the Minister. Cabinet in its wisdom, or lack thereof, decided nevertheless to proceed with this proposal and the Minister has duly brought it forward to the Senate. I again foreshadow that, when we come to the committee stage, the Opposition will move not to accept clause 15 in its current form. In our opinion, the Auditor should continue to report to Parliament all legislative breaches and where such breaches are considered trivial or minor we would agree with the suggestion by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts that they could be reported in an abbreviated or even tabular form.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The elements of the Audit Amendment Bill that I want to concentrate on are exactly the ones that Senator Stone has just given the Senate an outline of. Certainly in the debate in October last year on the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill we shared the concern of the coalition, though I am not sure whether it was a coalition then. I think it was.
—We always have been, in our hearts

—Whether or not the Opposition parties were a coalition in their hearts, last year they shared our concern about the Government's Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill and voted against the Government's amendments to section 49 (2) of the Audit Act. The Government's amendment essentially would have given the Minister for Finance the authority to approve variations of the format of the monthly statement, replacing the current requirement for the prior approval of both Houses of the Parliament. The Minister for Finance's monthly statements are progressive reports of performances against the annual budget, and it is important that this Parliament have a regular review process in place for it to use it as it sees fit.

SPEECH.PARA: Interestingly, Senator Lewis, speaking in the Senate for the Opposition parties, expressed his concern about this. In doing so he made the suggestion that rather than leaving Parliament powerless to do anything about such changes, which of course was what the Government was planning through its amendment to section 49 (2) of the Audit Act, it could make the changes by regulation. Clause 6 of the Bill before us has taken up that suggestion made by Senator Lewis and, as he said in his speech in October last year, this means there will be some power for the Parliament to disallow the format proposed if it is considered unsatisfactory.

TALK.START.PARA: —But go on and quote the rest of what he said, please.

—Senator Lewis then asked Senator Tate what would happen in the event of the regulation being disallowed and whether it would leave the Government in some sort of hiatus. As I read the response from Senator Tate, he said that in fact the schedule would remain unaltered. Is that the part Senator Stone wanted me to read? I thought he just wanted the bit immediately after. He said the Parliament would still have the power to disallow.
—The Government would like you to get your act together so that we know what your opposition is.
—I thought I answered the interjection in the way Senator Stone wanted but obviously I did not. I do not think we should conduct this conversation any longer.
—What did that sentence mean?

—I have no idea. Look at it again tomorrow after Hansard has fixed it up. In any event, I think the Opposition's concerns are unjustified. The Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills drew the attention of the Senate in its recent report to the delegation of legislative power, as it frequently does, but it also pointed out:

SPEECH.PARA: The amendment proposed by clause 6 of the Bill provides that the format of the Statement would, in future, be specified by regulation which would be subject to tabling and disallowance in the normal manner.

It is a foolhardy government indeed which tries to back the Senate into a corner, so to speak, by putting down a regulation the day after the Senate rises from the autumn session knowing that it cannot be disallowed until the Budget session, because if it does do that, and if and when the Senate exercises its legitimate right to disallow, the Government is in the position of having, as in this case, to produce the statements anyway. So I think the fact that we do have the regulatory element applying rather than what the Government originally wanted, which was no control over it at all, is satisfactory.

However, what the Government is proposing with regard to clauses 9 and 15 is most unsatisfactory and while we will not be supporting the first amendment that the Opposition is putting forward, we will certainly be supporting amendments Nos 2 and 3. They are linked; in essence, they are consequential. Currently, the Auditor-General has a discretionary power, amongst other things, not to include in his reports on some statutory authorities details of what the Government would like to believe are trivial breaches of the legislation. Clause 15 extends that discretion to other bodies and authorities which require the Auditor-General to report to a Minister. Quite properly, the Opposition is seeking to omit the relevant parts of clause 9 and section 63r in clause 15 which affect the extension of the discretionary authority to the Auditor-General.

The question we have to ask ourselves is: Who makes the decision about what is and what is not trivial and how do we find out what has been decided is or is not trivial? That leaves not only a considerable burden on the Auditor-General but also a question mark hanging over this place with regard to the performance of its function as a review mechanism. The Minister for Finance, in his second reading speech, spoke a lot about positions of trust. Nobody in this place is casting any aspersions on the Auditor-General but the fact is that we in this place are responsible to the people and we ought to be able to have as much information as possible with regard to the decisions taken by people such as the Auditor-General. The Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills drew attention to clause 15 and appropriately described it as an inappropriate delegation of power. The Committee believed that the difficulty with such a discretion was that, of its nature, it would clearly not be possible for persons outside the Auditor-General's office to determine the circumstances in which the discretion had been exercised, if and when it were exercised. We would be in the position here of having no knowledge about what had happened, who had made the decisions, what the decisions were, and why they were made. Indeed, I suspect that we would not even know what departments were effected, what areas were effected, nor what were the criteria for making the sorts of decisions that had been made.

The Committee reported to the Senate that it considered-and it thought the Senate could well do the same-that there was a breach of principle 1 (a) (iv) of the Committee's principles and that these clauses together constituted an inappropriate delegation of legislative power. Knowing that Senator Baume is about to follow me and that we have a very short amount of time I repeat--

TALK.START.PARA: —And being anxious to hear him.

—I am always anxious to hear Senator Baume. We can see no real difficulty with the Government's move to the regulatory mode, so to speak, in clause 6 but we have grave misgivings about its plans for giving discretion with regard to so-called trivial matters and whether they are reported that are set out in clauses 9 and 15. We oppose the Opposition's first amendment and support the other two.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I plead with the Australian Democrats to apply the same rational argument to clause 6 as they have applied to the rest of this legislation. The Democrats have very simply been conned on clause 6. Senator Haines has quite wrongly taken the view that somehow Senator Lewis had recommended this course of action of making changes in this legislation so that the vital monthly statement of financial transactions of the Minister for Finance could be changed by regulation. In fact, he said no such thing. He said that if we have to impose this kind of thing it is `far less worse' to do it by regulation, which can be disallowed, than to do it by ministerial fiat, which is disgraceful. I reject the first part of what Senator Haines had to say. The second part, the extent to which the Democrats have been conned, is evident from a very simple point the Minister made in responding to the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. He was justifying the reason that the Government must have the opportunity to change the format of the Niemeyer statement in minor ways. The Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: Advance notice of proposed changes to the format (as required by the existing arrangements) could reveal Budgetary details-
It is a pity that Senator Haines is not listening to this because it demolishes her case.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't be so pompous.

—The honourable senator should not be so rude, speaking in front of me, between the Acting Deputy President and me. I was trying to address the Chair through her thick hair, should I say, rather than head. The Minister said in response to the Committee:

SPEECH.PARA: Advance notice of proposed changes to the format (as required by the existing arrangements) could reveal Budgetary details before the presentation of the Budget.

Surely, even the Australian Democrats can recognise that if that is a crucial element of the Government's desire, the Government could in June bring in a regulation which the Parliament would not have the capacity to reject before August, as Senator Stone said. The implications of that are that the vital Niemeyer statements, particularly the one of June, would and could be altered in such a way as perhaps to hide a particular point, to make the statements not as useful to the Opposition or to other observers as they have been in the past. To allow that kind of gap in the crucial area of the end of year balances strikes me as absurd, and certainly puts at risk the power of the Parliament to look over and supervise these statements at the most important time of the year. Senator Haines says that `no government would be silly enough to change the system frivolously'. If a government sought to mislead the Parliament in the run-up to the Budget and, say, not give a hint of budgetary details, of course it could get away with doing that sort of thing. Once again we have the clear problem of what a minor way is. Will the Government define the phrase `in minor ways' when it is talking about changing the form of the statement? The question about the phrase `in minor ways' is exactly the question that Senator Haines addressed so sensibly on the other issues. She said that without a definition of `minor' it is improper to allow that kind of control.

As we have only a few minutes to deal with these many Bills, I would like now to draw the attention of the Senate to the guidelines for annual reporting by government authorities which were determined by the Minister for Finance and which are referred to in proposed new section 50aa. The interesting thing about these guidelines-and they cover many pages-is that not one of them refers to the need for annual reports to be prepared with cost in mind. It seems to me extraordinary, having seen this year some annual reports by governmental authorities that cost up to $20 each to produce, that there is no suggestion in the guidelines that anyone preparing an annual report should, in fact, pay some attention to the cost of preparation.

In particular, I draw the attention of the Senate to the annual report of the Australian Capital Territory Electricity Authority, which is 40 pages of the most extraordinarily high quality gloss printing that I have come across and costs something like $15 each to produce, which I believe is utterly disgraceful.

As I said, I wish the Australian Democrats would apply the same sort of logic to clause 6, which the coalition will be opposing. I believe the Australian Democrats are giving away some very significant powers of this Parliament to a government which would have the opportunity and certainly, I believe, in many instances, the intent to get around the requirements of being honest and reasonable with this Parliament. I encourage the Australian Democrats to reconsider what I believe to be a very foolish and damaging decision not to support the Opposition in this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me attempt, no doubt equally fruitlessly, to persuade the Australian Democrats to change their minds on their attitude to clause 15 in particular, because it does seem to the Government to be quite misconceived to take out the provision that is in there at the moment about the Auditor-General not being required to pursue--
—Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I thought Senator Watson was on the list to speak next.
—Order! There is no point of order. The list is merely a guidance. The call goes to alternate sides of the House.

—I am sorry; I am not familiar with any list, but I am familiar with some bad quality arguments when I hear them and they need to be replied to in the 3 1/2 minutes that are left, and I propose to do so in the following terms. The Parliament has given the Auditor-General some discretion about pursuing or reporting matters that he considers to be immaterial or trivial. Existing provisions allow this discretion for most reports. The clause in question makes the Audit Act uniform in the reporting requirements it imposes on the Auditor-General.

SPEECH.PARA: The Auditor-General is the Parliament's watchdog and the Opposition in its amendment is attempting to force him, against his better judgment, to bark at every little thing. A watchdog that barks at everything is simply an annoyance to all and eventually loses value to its owner. We have to rely on the Auditor-General's judgment and his application of professional standards in this area-that is what we are paying him to do-otherwise we might as well employ an automaton or robot that does not need to exercise any judgment at all. There may be other mechanisms for Parliament to assure itself that the Auditor-General is pursuing his tasks in an appropriate manner. The upcoming inquiry by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts into the Auditor-General's Office might explore such procedures and do so in a rather more sensible way.

I will finish on this sentence to give Senator Watson a chance to make whatever contribution he had in mind. To place such trivial requirements in the law brings the law very simply into disrepute and exposes the Auditor-General to undeserved ridicule when he is made out to be concerned about trivial, nitpicking matters. I would have thought that Senator Watson, as a former businessman, would appreciate the significance of that and act accordingly when confronted with a silly proposition for an amendment of the kind that this is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to remind the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans) that, if he had a modern, up-to-date Audit Act-I remind the Minister that this is a 1901 Act-the amendments currently before the Senate would not have been necessary. Why is the Government hiding behind such archaic provisions? Why is it doing no more than patching up by bandaid treatment things that should normally be within the opinion of an Auditor-General acting in accordance with modern audit practice? Why does it not follow the precedent set by its Western Australian Labor Party colleagues and get a modern, comprehensive Act in and then we would not have this patch up treatment?

SPEECH.PARA: I regret there is no opportunity to speak at length on this Bill. It is deplorable that we do not have a full and frank debate on an important matter to do with an Act that needs current and future substantive amendments. I certainly look forward to the Joint Committee of Public Accounts coming down with a report on its current inquiry into the operations of the Australian Audit Office, because the Auditor-General is constrained by the present legislation.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

Page 4, subclause 9 (1), proposed paragraph 51 (1) (c), leave out ``, being cases that are, in the opinion of the Auditor-General, of sufficient importance to justify particulars of the cases being set out in the report''.

Auditor-General shall report on all cases of non-compliance

`(2) In this section:
``statutory body'' means a body or authority established by or under an enactment.' ''.
