Debate resumed from 24 May, on motion by Senator Gareth Evans:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is an historic occasion. This is the last Bill which will be debated in this historic, august chamber. To that extent I believe, Mr Deputy President, that you will grant me on this splendid occasion the indulgence to say a few words about things unrelated to the Australian Film Commission Amendment Bill by way of introduction.
—Order! Your remarks, Senator Puplick, will have to be not too distant. After this debate we will have that sort of discussion.

—I do not propose to transgress too far. It is interesting that on the first day ordinary business was conducted in this chamber, that is, 5 October 1927, one of the matters on the Notice Paper for that day, first dealt with by Senator Andrew, was the question of performing rights, which relates very directly to matters of the film industry. The next matter which was dealt with-I see Senator Aulich, Senator Watson and a number of other Tasmanian colleagues in the chamber-was the question of the duty on potatoes. The third matter, the first substantive Bill which was debated in this chamber, was a Commonwealth Electoral Bill. Related to that, the Senate was considering a report from a parliamentary committee in relation to enrolment, postal voting, polling facilities, donations or gifts by members or candidates, and additional safeguards necessary to prevent impersonation and duplicate voting, including the result of the extended reference of the committee to report on informal voting, absent voting, joint rolls and the administration of the compulsory sections of the Commonwealth Electoral Act. So I suppose that in the history of this chamber very little has changed.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish in this introductory comment, with your indulgence, Mr Deputy President, and, through you, to express formally on behalf of the Opposition our thanks to Mr President Sibraa for the gift made to all senators this evening of an Australian flag. All senators this evening were presented with an Australian flag which had flown for one day over the Parliament House here in Canberra. That is an extraordinarily fitting gift to have been presented by Mr President to senators just prior to our move to the new Parliament House. The flag which was presented to me flew over this Parliament House on 8 September 1983. A cultivated man like yourself, Mr Deputy President, would be aware of these things--

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh!

—And a cultivated, artistic gentleman such as Senator Richardson would be equally aware that that date was the 147th anniversary of the birth of the composer Dvorak, composer, appropriately enough, of a New World symphony, and the 39th anniversary of the death of the composer Richard Strauss. It is also the anniversary of the coronation of William IV. My South Australian colleagues undoubtedly would wish that to be noted in relation to Her Majesty Queen Adelaide. It is the anniversary of the date upon which Mr Smuts became Prime Minister of South Africa, the last occasion on which that country had a decent Prime Minister leading it. I note that on that particular day the newspapers were full of headlines about jobs lost in the car industry, about Mr Hayden's softer line on the guilt of the Soviet Union for shooting down the Korean flight KA007, and demonstrations taking place in the Public Service over promotion matters. Again, I do not think that much has changed, and that gives us a very good introduction to the Australian Film Commission Amendment Bill.
—Order! I was about to ask Senator Puplick to drift slowly around towards discussing the Australian Film Commission Amendment Bill.

—Mr Deputy President, the Australian Film Commission tends to make one wander on these things. I will come directly, therefore, to the Australian film industry. Australia has a very distinguished history in terms of its film making. The first film made in Australia which survives is a film of the 1896 Melbourne Cup. That is a very historic film-one of the earliest films to be preserved anywhere in the world. The first feature film made in Australia was made by the Salvation Army, by Captain Perry. It was entitled Soldiers of the Cross and was made in 1906. The first commercial feature film, The Kelly Gang, was made in 1907.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a sad reflection on the decline of the Australian Film industry that one reads in yesterday's Sydney Morning Herald that a group in the United States of America entitled the Sundance Institute, the pet project of actor-turned-filmmaker Robert Redford, has decided that its next feature film will in fact be a film based on the life of Senator Sanders. The extent to which the Australian film industry has descended from the giddy heights of Soldiers of the Cross and The Kelly Gang to a film about the life of Senator Sanders, I suppose, could be reflected by saying that it has gone, in the space of 80-odd years, from a film about one rogue to a film about another.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order.
—Order! I do not need to hear the point of order, Senator Sanders. I ask Senator Puplick to withdraw that remark.
—Absolutely, Mr Deputy President. I entirely withdraw the reference to the Kelly gang.
—Order! Senator Puplick, you will withdraw that in good order.

—Mr Deputy President, I withdraw. The purpose of the Australian Film Commission Amendment Bill is to remove Film Australia from the control of the Australian Film Commission and to establish it as a wholly Commonwealth-owned company to be known as Film Australia Pty Ltd, required to operate along commercial lines. It is interesting to note, within a few days of the May 1988 economic statement, that this decision, this comment about the change of the status of Film Australia to Film Australia Pty Ltd, was in fact announced in the May 1987 statement of the Treasurer (Mr Keating). It has taken a year and four days for the Government to convert an announcement from the last May statement into a piece of legislation in this Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: Film Australia is an important part of the film making culture in this country. The Commonwealth's first direct involvement in film production occurred in 1911 under the aegis of the Department of External Affairs, as it then was. In 1913 Bert Ive was appointed to coordinate Commonwealth film activities. In 1921 film was placed under the responsibility of the Cinematic and Photographic Branch of the Development and Migration Commission. Thereafter, film activities were controlled first by the National Film Council in the Department of Information from 1940 to 1945, the National Film Board from 1945 to 1950, the Film Production Unit from 1950 to 1956, and then the Commonwealth Film Unit from 1956 to 1972.

In the 1972 Film Australia was established within the Department of the Media, which, of course, was presided over by Senator McClelland as Minister. As you would know, Mr Deputy President, Senator McClelland went on to become a very distinguished President of this Senate. In 1975, with the passage of the Australian Film Commission Act, which we are now proposing to amend, Film Australia was placed under the Australian Film Commission as the production division responsible for the special activities of the Commission.

In January 1987 a major review of Film Australia was presented to the Government, prepared by the consultants McMurchy and Neilsen. This review canvassed four options ranging from the complete closure of Film Australia through to the establishment of Film Australia as a more economically efficient operation focusing on the production of both departmental films and films of special national significance. The Government in this legislation has adopted the fourth of those options with some modifications. Indeed, Robin Hughes, the General Manager of Film Australia, described this proposal, in the Australian newspaper of 25 May 1987, as `option four with knobs on'.

Whilst supporting the general thrust of this Bill, the Opposition nevertheless has a number of matters which it wishes to raise, and in particular it wishes to move an amendment to the second reading motion, and I formally move:
At end of motion, add ``, but the Senate:

(a) condemns the Labor Government for allowing the run-down of the Australian film industry and for the confused and inadequate responses to the problems of the film industry announced in the May Economic Statement; and
(b) calls upon the Government to table forthwith the Guidelines to be issued to Film Australia Pty Ltd relating to its proposed commercial operations''.

The Liberal Party and the National Party have a very long and distinguished record of support for the Australian film industry. It was Prime Minister Gorton who took the initial steps which led to the establishment of the Australian Film and Television School. It was Prime Minister McMahon who brought that to further development, and it was under the guidance of Prime Minister Fraser that the amendments to the Taxation Act that introduced division 10ba were made. Division 10ba provided financial assistance for the development of the film industry in Australia. Over the life of division 10ba an estimated total of $876.6m of Commonwealth revenue has been forgone in support of the Australian film industry. That is well in excess of three-quarters of a billion dollars which has been invested indirectly in terms of revenue forgone in the Australian film industry since the introduction of division 10ba, and that is a record of which members of the Liberal and National parties are extremely proud.

It is a great tragedy that in recent years there has been a monumental decline in the activities of the Australian film industry. There are now only four projects in production compared to 64 at this time last year. The level of film funding has dropped from $140m to $40m in the last year as a result of Government policies and inactivity. There have been no major starts on new productions this year. The Government is about to impose an additional disastrous 20 per cent sales tax on the production of videos and sound recordings, and the promises continually made by the Ministers with responsibility for the arts to develop a comprehensive package of support for the film industry have simply not been acted upon in good time.

This Government was told some time ago that the film industry was in crisis. It was told in January 1987 that there was a major problem in the Australian film industry, and it refused to act at that time. For instance, the Canberra Times carried an article on 31 January 1987 under the heading `Film industry faces a bleak future', yet it was not until almost 12 months later that the Minister for the Arts and Territories, Mr Punch, admitted that he was suddenly aware of the crisis looming in the Australian film industry. His response has been the introduction, in the May mini-Budget, of the Film Finance Corporation. If we phone the Government's own hotline dealing with the Film Finance Corporation, no-one can tell us the details of the scheme. The questions which I have asked of Senator Richardson in this place have not been adequately answered in terms of the specific details of the matching funds of 30 per cent or so which are supposed to be required from the private sector over the whole range of the operation of the Film Finance Corporation. Indeed, the film industry has been left in a considerable state of confusion. For instance, if someone is making a film in Australia at the moment, he may have to contend or shortly will have to contend with questions arising from Film Australia Pty Ltd, from the Australian Film Commission, from the Film Finance Corporation, from the Australian Children's Television Foundation, from the Department of the Arts and Territories, from the Australian Taxation Office and from the Australian Film Industry Trust Fund. All of those bodies are currently relevant to people who are making films of various kinds in Australia. It is an absolute disgrace that, instead of people being able to deal easily with these Government creations, this confusion and cacophony of bodies is being placed before film makers in Australia.

The May statement failed to address a number of significant issues in the film industry. It failed to address the question of exorbitant fees being charged by producers and executive producers. It failed to deal with the matter, for instance, of film distribution and exhibition. The Tariff Board in its 1973 report Motion Picture Films and Television Programs proposed a scheme for the divestiture of ownership of control of cinemas and distribution outlets. That has not been addressed in all of the continuing changes which this Government has made to the film industry.

The Government has failed to publish the guidelines which are to be issued for Film Australia. That is the basis of the second part of the amendment which I have moved on behalf of the Opposition. We presume that the Government will now be happy to see the closure of the small unit which Film Australia has in Canberra to produce low budget films, because I understand that under this legislation programs costing less than $10,000 are supposed to be subcontracted out to the private sector and not produced by Film Australia. However, despite my requests, and despite requests by the industry in general, it has not been possible for the industry, or for me as shadow Minister, to be provided with a copy of the guidelines which will regulate the operation of Film Australia Pty Ltd in terms of its relationship with the Government and the private sector.

As I understand it, the Australian Democrats are to move a number of amendments to this legislation. I will simply indicate a general position on those because I am anxious to give Senator Jenkins time to formally introduce the amendments and to make a few comments on the Bill. As I understand it, there are two areas in which the Democrats will be seeking to make amendments. The first relates to the transfer of staff and the second to the provision of annual reports. Under this legislation staff may be rendered as surplus to the requirements of Film Australia Pty Ltd. That organisation has already made substantial reductions in its staff numbers. In recent years it has declined from a quite high level of staff employment to a much leaner and more efficient organisation and is now proposing to reduce its staff members from approximately 105 to about 82 or 83. Redundant staff will be transferred to the Australian Film Commission, which may in fact find them surplus to its requirements. As a result, there will be created a pool of cinematographers and others, such as in-house directors, who are no longer required by Film Australia Pty Ltd and they will be employed on a general freelance basis, which is one of the characteristics of the industry throughout Australia. The Democrats amendment proposes that those people should have the right to retain their employment with Film Australia Pty Ltd and that the redundancy, if it takes place, should take place from there.

We do not believe that that is an adequate provision because, first, the Government's proposal protects the redundancy provision of those people-indeed, the Australian Film Commission, through which they will become redundant, has a greater capacity to make those redundancy payments, because money has already been provided to it, than Film Australia Pty Ltd, which would not be in a position to so pay-and, secondly, we believe that Film Australia Pty Ltd should be required to operate as a leaner and more efficient organisation. To that extent, therefore, we are not in a position to support the Democrats' preliminary amendment. We will, however, support their second amendment, which requires an annual report to be made by Film Australia Pty Ltd to the Minister and through the Minister to the Parliament. This matter was reported on by the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills in its ninth report dated 1 June 1988. Having received the Minister's assurance about how he would proceed, the Committee said:

As the Committee noted in its Second Report of 1988, legislation which provide for the establishment of new Commonwealth bodies, including incorporated companies, should also provide for the tabling of that body's annual report in the Parliament.
Consistent with that principle, we will support the second amendment.

Film Australia has an exciting program ahead of it. It has been doing some extremely good work. The work that it has done, for instance, in the production of the film Roads to Xanadu, in co-production with Sunshine Australia Ltd, the work it has done with the drug offensive on educational films and the comments made by John Baxter in his article of 31 March 1987 entitled `Can the Good Times Roll Again for Film Australia?' are indicative of the very considerable work which Film Australia is involved in at the moment and which we believe should continue.

I raise one final point as far as this legislation is concerned. I wish to indicate it clearly to the Minister because it is a matter of some substance. We have been advised that Mr Gonski is to be appointed as the Chairman of Film Australia Pty Ltd. Mr Gonski, I understand, is the Managing Director of Westfield Capital Corporation Ltd. Westfield has extensive interests in the television industry. I believe that there is very considerable potential for a conflict of interest between Mr Gonski's role as Managing Director of a major television producer, namely, Westfield Capital Corporation, which is the licensee of the 10 Network, and his role as the Chairman of Film Australia, which will be a direct competitor in a number of areas with Channel 10 and the rest of the private sector. I express very considerable reservations about the appointment to the chairmanship of this organisation of somebody who might have that conflict of interest.

I raise also the other issue that was of very considerable concern to me. I read in this week's edition of the Bulletin that the Government is contemplating-I direct the attention of the Minister for the Arts, Sport the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) to this matter as well-the appointment as a successor to Mr Kim Williams, the Chief Executive of the Australian Film Commission, of Mr Bob Debus, the former New South Wales Minister for Finance who was roundly defeated at the last State election in New South Wales. If that occurs, the bipartisan support which has been given to the Australian Film Commission and to the Australian film industry in general will be put substantially at risk.

I say in conclusion that I am pleased to see you, Mr President, in the chair for the conclusion of this debate, because I want to reiterate the comment which I made at the beginning of this address. I thank you personally for the donation of the Australian flags to members of this chamber. You have our very considerable support for that initiative and I thank you for that. I am pleased to yield some time to Senator Jenkins to allow her to move her amendments formally and to make some remarks on this Bill which, after we have moved the second reading amendment and supported one of the two Democrats' amendments, will have the support of the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree that the Australian Film Commission Amendment Bill 1988 is the most appropriate Bill to be chosen as the last piece of legislation to be passed in the Senate in this provisional Parliament House and that it is appropriate for this debate to be filmed for the Australian Archives. The Government's intention of privatising Film Australia Pty Ltd to some degree has been known by the industry for some time. Not everyone is happy with the notion of privatisation, but I believe that in general the Government's plans in this case have been quite well accepted. I have had meetings and conversations with representatives of such diverse bodies as the Screen Production Association, the Australian Screen Directors Association, Independent Consultants and Filmmakers, the Administrative and Clerical Officers Association, the Australian Writers Guild, Actors Equity, the Australian Theatrical and Musical Employees Association, and delegates and employees of Film Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: In general, the Government's plans seem to have the approval of the industry, but there is one area in which the legislation, or the planning behind the legislation, is greatly deficient. The primary asset of any creative organisation, whether it be a broadcasting corporation or a film studio, is its people. It is an irony that it is a Labor government that is intent on losing this most important asset of Film Australia. In mid-1987, Film Australia reduced its staff to a minimum through a series of retrenchments. The present legislation proposes to reduce the staff still further by the device of giving the Minister the discretion as to who of the present staff may be transferred to the new company. The Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans) said in his second reading speech:
the Government expects the new organisation to be more attuned to the realities of the marketplace.

This would mean the voluntary retrenchment of some 30 employees. According to the staff profile put forward by the new company, virtually all the production staff will be eliminated, apart from those involved in management, post-production and servicing facilities. This is justified as being normal industry practice but, in itself, is a doubtful proposition if one looks at the staffing policies of such major organisations as the Grundy organisation, Crawford Productions Pty Ltd, the Australian Broadcasting Corporation or the major television studios. There is, of course, a place in the Australian film industry for the non-commercial film.

Unfortunately, I have to draw to a conclusion at this stage. I hope that, through a contingency motion, I will be able to move my amendments at the conclusion of the debate on this Bill. We support the Opposition's attachments to the second reading of the Bill. In general, this legislation is supported by the Australian Democrats, even though there is no provision for an annual report and we feel that it is grossly unfair that staff do not have the choice between redundancy and an opportunity to join the new Film Australia Pty Ltd.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the eleventh report of the Committee of Privileges on the circulation of petitions, together with submissions received by the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

It is perhaps fitting that one of the last reports to be presented in this Senate chamber is one which deals with parliamentary privilege. On 16 March 1988, the following questions were referred to the Committee of Privileges, by way of amendment to a motion moved by Senator Chaney:

Whether the circulation of a petition containing defamatory material for the purpose of gaining signatures and subsequent submission to the Senate, is, or ought to be privileged, and how such issues should be determined and in what forum.

The majority of the Committee, after receiving written submissions from 10 persons and organisations, and advice from the Clerk of the Senate, has concluded as follows: firstly, that, while the question whether the circulation of a petition for the purpose of gaining signatures and subsequent submission to the Senate is privileged is a question of law for the courts to determine, the Committee believes that the circulation is not absolutely privileged and is probably not subject to any form of qualified privilege; secondly, that, if the Parliament were to determine that the circulation of a petition should be privileged, absolutely or otherwise, a change to the law would therefore be required; thirdly, that, in the light of the dangers inherent in denying a citizen the right to pursue action in the courts to redress an attack on his or her character or reputation, the circulation of a petition containing defamatory matter should not be protected by parliamentary privilege; and, fourthly, that the circulation of other petitions requires no special protection and therefore that no change to the present law is warranted.

In a dissenting report, Senator Durack has concluded that statutory provision should be made, by amendment to the Parliamentary Privileges Act 1987, to give some protection, at the national level, to a limited and largely private publication of a document in the form of a petition which is subsequently presented to the Senate. Senator Durack also expressed the view, shared by another member of the Committee, that the person whose circumstances gave rise to the reference of the matter to the Committee should have been afforded the opportunity to indicate the practical problems experienced in the circulation of a petition.

I am particularly grateful to the other members of the Committee whose accumulated experience in matters of privilege was invaluable in reaching a conclusion in which only minor differences developed. I want to express the thanks of the Committee to Anne Lynch, newly appointed Deputy Clerk of the Senate, for which we offer our congratulations, and to Christine McDonald, who together guided us to a speedy conclusion to this reference.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry that on the occasion of the last report Senator Giles has tabled in the Senate from the Committee of Privileges I have to disagree with the findings that were made by that Committee. But it was a very important reference and I think it is one that needs to be debated seriously by the Senate at a more appropriate time than this evening. As honourable senators will remember, the reference was the subject of a good deal of rugged debate in the Senate and was considerably changed from what was proposed by Senator Chaney. From being as proposed, an investigation of conduct by the former Premier of Western Australia, Mr Brian Burke, which may have amounted to a contempt of the Senate, it was changed to an academic inquiry by the Privileges Committee as to whether a petition containing defamatory matter should have any particular legal immunity.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Collins, who was responsible for this amendment, envisaged clearly that the Senate would take evidence from the person whose complaints led to this matter. Senator Macklin, speaking on behalf of the Australian Democrats, said, `I believe it would be very odd to go into a general inquiry without looking at that specific item', meaning the facts of the specific case. My very deep concern about the proceedings and conclusions of the Committee was that it decided to maintain this as a totally academic exercise and decided not to hear any evidence about the difficulties people have in circulating petitions and obtaining signatures for them.

The person who felt aggrieved and concerned about the way in which he was treated in this matter by Mr Burke, the former Premier of Western Australia, made a submission to the Committee which did not raise the question of Mr Burke's conduct, but did seek to raise before the Committee the problems that he found in circulating a petition and, clearly, that is a matter of very great general interest. Senator Teague agreed with me on this matter. We believed that these questions should have been the subject of evidence called by the Committee. There are other more technical matters raised by this report, but I simply draw the attention of the Senate on this occasion to the most unsatisfactory way in which the Committee, in my view, approached this very important question.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like other senators, I have not had the opportunity to see this report. I merely have to rely on what the Chairman has reported and on the speech which Senator Durack has just made. I simply want to express my disappointment that the Committee of Privileges has apparently chosen to treat this matter as an academic exercise.

SPEECH.PARA: Tonight is a great night for a party. We are leaving the Senate and we will have a wonderful time celebrating the fact that we are going to move to a new building. What this report indicates is that a Senate committee was not prepared to hear a citizen of the Commonwealth who was prevented from petitioning the Commonwealth by what I described in the Parliament as bullying conduct.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are a fraud.

—Now I get from the Minister that I am a fraud. I am deeply disappointed that that individual was not given a chance to present his case. As I said when I raised this matter in the Senate, there were serious questions of a conflict between two principles. The first principle is that any citizen, including a Premier or ex-Premier, is entitled not to be defamed. I accept that as an important principle of law. It is also a principle that citizens of this Commonwealth are entitled to petition this Parliament. On the facts as they were put to me and as I put them to this Parliament, the reality was that a citizen wished to petition this Parliament and did so in terms which he did not regard as defamatory and where his advice was that it was not defamatory when he was subsequently challenged.

SPEECH.PARA: The facts of this situation as they were presented to me-and I stress that I can speak only in the terms that they were presented to me-were that this individual withdrew his petition not because he believed it to be defamatory, but because he could not afford--

TALK.START.PARA: —They are not free to defame.

—Senator Cook's knowledge of his portfolio is so limited, as illustrated in Question Time, that it is not for him to suggest that he has any knowledge of the law-Senator Cook, a traditional trade union oppressor of the people. I take no notice of Senator Cook. To get back to a subject of substance--
—I take a point of order, Mr President.
—Is the clown taking a point of order, Mr President? I did not think clowns had status in here.
—Order!
—There are ways and means of fixing wimps like you, Fred.
—Order!

—Mr President, there is a matter before the chamber. Honourable senators and support staff are very tired. The chamber would appreciate it if the Leader of the Opposition could quit his sanctimonious rattle and get on with the debate on the matter before us.
—Order! There is no point of order. There are too many interjections. I also ask Senator Chaney to ignore the interjections.

—I will try to do that, Mr President. There is not point of order, I agree. I note that Senator McKiernan is protecting his own. I understand the rules of the game. The point that I put before the Senate was that a citizen of the Commonwealth claimed that, because here was an inequality of his capacity to fight a case, he had been prevented from petitioning this place. That is a matter which I squarely tried to put before the Senate and which the deft Senator Collins managed to turn into what Senator Durack has described as an academic exercise. I congratulate Senator Collins for his footwork, if not for his morality in the matter.
—Mr President, I will not wear that in the dying moments. It is highly disorderly for senators to make personal reflections on other senators. I ask Senator Chaney to withdraw.
—Order! Senator Chaney, will you withdraw?
—Mr President, if you are suggesting that it is disorderly to say that I am not reflecting on his morality, I withdraw it.
—I am saying that you were making an imputation against Senator Collins and I am asking you to withdraw it.

—I withdraw it if I have made an imputation that is disorderly. I express my disappointment that the Committee, apparently, chose not to hear this person and his complaint because, in treating the matter as an academic exercise, which is what Senator Durack has described, it seems to me that it simply avoided the issue. That is a pity. It is a very sorry end to the Senate sittings in this chamber. An important point of principle was raised. It was a difficult point because it involved a conflict between the principle of protection from defamation as against the principle that a citizen should be--
—It was a slander that was raised. You know that. You can go on your sanctimonious high horse for as long as you wish. That doesn't alter the fact.

—Senator Cook again gives us a legal judgment which he clearly does not have the capacity to make. The simple point is that no attempt has now been made by the Senate to deal with this matter on its merits, on the facts which I raised in this place. I wished on this occasion to express my disappointment. I trust that the Senate will consider this report carefully and look at the circumstances, which I believe have sullied this place, and I seek leave to continue my remarks.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The issue before the Senate in regard to this report of the Committee of Privileges is whether the privilege of this chamber and the privilege that attaches to members of parliament speaking in this chamber and the House of Representatives should attach or does attach to petitions submitted to them. I concur with the majority report, which stated that the privilege which we enjoy in this chamber does not, and should not, attach to petitions that are submitted to us. There must be a proper forum in the courts of each State that attaches to defamation to judge whether a petition is in order or should be pursued in presentation to this chamber. Whilst a petition is to be highly regarded, and regarded as a genuine document when it is presented to us in this chamber, it should not ever be used as an excuse for defamation that is based on any untruthful or unsound statement.

SPEECH.PARA: In this matter I have to say that whilst I agree with the conclusions of the Senate report, I also very much agree with the remarks of my colleagues Senator Durack and Senator Chaney that it was most unfortunate that in the conduct of the inquiry into this matter, the Committee did not agree with the requests of those of us who put the view that the particularity of this issue should be further explored by asking the original petitioner, from whom this matter arose, to appear before us. He gave a submission to the Committee but the Committee chose not to hear that petitioner. Therefore, I wish to say that I concur entirely with the three-quarters of the dissenting report of Senator Durack, the preamble in which he outlines that point. Yet, because of my strong conviction, undeterred by that lapse in the Committee's procedure, that privilege should be in this chamber and not attach to petitions, I nevertheless concur with the majority view of the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table a paper concerning the history of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances. Mr President, I seek leave to make a short statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry to inflict something as pedestrian as a Regulations and Ordinances Committee report this late in the day but, in my defence, I did in fact intend to deliver it at 10 o'clock this morning. For the benefit of honourable senators, I intend to seek leave to incorporate most of what I want to say in Hansard. However, this is an historic occasion-the last presentation of the Regulations and Ordinances Committee report in this place. It is only the 350th historic occasion in which I have been involved this week: the last cup of tea in Senate Committee Room 6, the last cup of cappuccino in the parliamentary dining room-it goes on and on.

SPEECH.PARA: Peter O'Keeffe, in his usual impeccable fashion, has given me a complete tapestry to present to the Senate tonight, but I must say that, particularly because of what I have just heard, I intend to add a few useless and unnecessary threads of my own to it. Last night we attended a very pleasant dinner in the parliamentary dining room, at which I heard a number of very witty and very memorable speeches. One in particular that I recall was that of John Button, and indeed another was from my friend up the back there, Senator Sheil from Queensland. They all had one common thread, and that is that they were recollections of senators who had been in this House for a very long time. I have been in this House only a very short time and therefore my memories of it are necessarily much shorter.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a weighty contribution.

—Indeed, I have made a weighty contribution. I assure the honourable senator that I have enough fat jokes of my own. Of necessity, the memories I have of this place are of a much shorter period, but I must say that probably two of the more indelible memories I will take from here are instances which occurred in the last 48 hours.

SPEECH.PARA: The first was yesterday when I went up to the parliamentary dining room, as I am wont to do, with my friend and colleague Senator Robert Ray. We all have our political heroes. Some people I look up to particularly are Russ Hinze, Robert Ray, David Lange and, to a lesser extent, Kim Beazley. We were walking past the parliamentary billiard room, where Senator Ray spends the odd hour, and as we walked past I happened to glance in the door. Even I, who do not play billiards, got a bit of a shock because on the floor in 50 pieces was the billiard table and standing over the pieces were two workmen who had just disassembled it. They did in fact look like a pair of vivisectionists attacking a body. I thought, `My God, Robert can't see this'. Somehow I was able to obstruct his view and we proceeded on to the parliamentary dining room. We had, as the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) would say, `a cuppa cappuccino'-in fact we had two. But it availed me nothing-this is a true story; well, mostly true-because as we came out of the parliamentary dining room and opened the door, Robert Ray froze on the spot. Passing in parade in front of us were two workmen, each one of whom had a dismembered leg of Robert Ray's friend under his arm, and Robert Ray broke down and wept unashamedly.

I have another indelible memory, and I am sure I will not be the only one who takes it from this chamber. I must admit I was provoked by an earlier exchange to tell this story; I did not intend to. There are some sharp exchanges in Parliament from time to time, and it always comes to the attention of the public when politicians get stuck into each other. I have been involved in it myself over the years, standing in the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly and being called a cretin and a mindless idiot by Everingham, being thrown out on points of order, standing in front of a television camera and saying, `Yes, indeed, it is dreadful to have parliamentary standards lowered by such dreadful behaviour', and then walking away and thinking to myself, `If they reckon that is crook, wait until I drop the bucket on him this afternoon'. We saw an example of it tonight.

I quote another example from just 48 hours ago to show that there is in fact another story behind the curtain of Parliament which the public is never permitted to see. Tonight I intend to draw aside that curtain just a little, something I would not normally do. This is an exchange that took place here in the Parliament just 48 hours ago between Senator Walters and Senator Bolkus. Senator Walters said to Nick Bolkus, `You are a fraud', to which he replied, `In the interests of my relationship with Senator Walters, I am glad I did not hear her interjection . . . ' and so on. Of course, people hearing that exchange in the chamber would go away thinking what a dreadful place Parliament is. However, had the public been permitted to see what we saw last night in the parliamentary dining room, when Nick Bolkus kissed Shirley Walters, their faith in the institution of Parliament would have been fully restored.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Collins, children may be listening to this!
—Mr President, is it appropriate to ask the honourable senator to withdraw?
—Mr President, I am a politician and I cannot tell a lie. I must say that I have made--
—Are you going to take a point of order, Nick, or will I?

—I have made only one, much talked about, visit to the new Parliament House. I concur completely with the excellent and very witty paper prepared by our Clerk, Harry Evans, on the new Parliament House in which he said that it is the institution of parliament that is important; not the building. He does not dislike the new Parliament House. He just objects having to bow to it every morning on his way to work. I think that that is correct.

SPEECH.PARA: There are some beautiful works of art in the new Parliament House. The only room that I looked at was the main meeting place in which there is a beautiful tapestry and a long embroidery along one wall. As I stood in front of that embroidery, which was put together with painstaking labour by the Embroiderers Institute of Australia, whose members worked in small groups around Australia-this thing of beauty and a joy forever-being the crass politician I am, I looked at it and thought `Well, if those ladies reckon this is a good piece of embroidery, wait till the speeches start in the new chamber'.

It is indeed the institution that is important, not the building. Without being too maudlin about it-I am not a maudlin person-I want to say something which I truly believe: we are all aware that this institution has its defects and deficiencies. It has its share of childish behaviour at times. However, I am indeed proud and grateful for the institution of parliamentary democracy which has provided the greatest bastion for individual freedom and liberty in the world. I am proud and grateful to be a small part of it.
Honourable senators-Ha, ha!

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators are quick tonight. I seek leave to have the rest of my speech incorporated in Hansard.
—I wondered how the honourable senator's comments were relevant to the Regulations and Ordinances Committee. I am sure the Senator Collins will not wish to speak on the valedictory.
—No, Mr President.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

As honourable senators will appreciate this is a day of some significance for the Senate. It is also a day of-I am tempted to say-even greater significance for the Regulations and Ordinances Committee, a Committee which, as Senator Ray knows, is renowned for its humility.

For the past 56 years, the Committee has played out in this provisional Parliament House the drama, and I say again the drama, of scrutinising delegated legislation to ensure that it does not trespass on personal rights. Those around me, who scoff at the word `drama', might wonder what it feels like to have 10 or 20 of your own Government's regulations subject to your own protective notices of disallowance, sitting on the Notice Paper, ticking away to the fifteenth day, while you wait for an official to give a Minister a letter, and a pen to sign it, saying: yes, we will provide appeal rights; yes, we will remove strict liability offences, yes we will table subdelegated instruments; yes, we will protect rights, which in our haste we overlooked. It's personal, inner, drama from about the 10th sitting day onwards I can assure the Senate.
In 56 years the Committee has encountered many remarkable instruments of delegated legislation which it has challenged because they removed individual rights and liberties. I can but mention a few.

As Chairman of the Committee in the 1950s and 60s, Senator Ian Wood, so frequently and so strongly criticised the conferral of unreviewable administrative discretions on public servants that his Committee helped to create the parliamentary climate from which developed the new administrative law that eventually appeared on the statute book in the 1970s.

Senator Cooney and his Committee, in 1986, restored the right to trial by jury for all defendants in the A.C.T. and not just those accused of the most serious offences. The right had been removed some 30 years previously and never restored. Senator Cooney was also instrumental in bringing about an official re-thinking of the range of protections that should exist in extradition regulations particularly those concerning extradition to South Africa.

Senator Lewis and his Committee will always be remembered for the tact and skill with which they managed to persuade the High Court to amend their own legislative Rules of Court because they infringed the Committee's principles relating to prejudicial retrospectivity.

Senator Missen and his Committee brought about the first amendment of the Committee's principles for nearly 50 years by recognising that the existence of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal had created a new criterion for scrutiny of discretionary decisions. Senator Coates and his Committee brought about the amendment of National Crime Authority Regulations so that a Superior Court judge in chambers should have power to initiate certain unusual procedures rather than the actual members of the Authority in hot pursuit of certain witnesses.

Nor should it be forgotten that it was Senator Wood, who in 1976, brought to light a Telecommunications Commission by-law which made it an offence to tell a lie in a telephone conversation. In the pantheon of important Chairmen of the Regulations and Ordinances Committee, Senator Wood ranks very highly for this and other achievements, but it fell to Senator Devitt as Chairman in 1974 to bring to Parliament's attention the novel but extremely serious offence of ``being in possession of seaweed in Jervis Bay'', for which the penalty was no less than a $2,000 fine.

Mr President, on this day of all days, in my capacity as the twentieth Chairman of the Regulations and Ordinances Committee, I wish to pay a special tribute to all of my nineteen predecessors and all of the 100 or more Senators who have served on this Committee, in this House. They showed the courage and independence which the present Committee must imitate. They set the precedents which the present Committee must follow. Of course, in following them, we ourselves set precedents for future Committees. And the grand design, the hidden agenda is nothing other than to ensure that bureaucratic law-making always remains observant of personal rights and subject to parliamentary control. This has been a Committee which has had in its ranks some of the most able Senators this Senate has produced. It is perhaps invidious to name names but a few must be named as outstanding in their roles on this Committee. I speak of course of Senator Wood and Senator Devitt, Senator Cavanagh and Senator Missen, and the person to whom history a allots a fair measure of the credit for having started the whole process in the late 1920s and early 1930s, Senator Colbatch.

Mr President, having mentioned those names there are some other names I would like to mention because, for the Committee's future in the new Parliament House, these are the names which are as important to us as are those of the people who set standards in the past. These are the names of people who have served on the Committee and are still Senators, indeed some of them are Ministers: Senator Button, Senator Evans, Senator Tate, Senator Coates, Senator Durack, Senator Colston, Senator Teague, Senator Foreman, Senator Hamer, Senator Lewis, Senator Walters, Senator Archer, Senator Cook, Senator Cooney, Senator Gietzelt, Senator Richardson, Senator Vanstone, Senator Zakharov and perhaps some others whose names I have missed. It's like a mini Call of the Senate all over again. There will be in the new House a reservoir of knowledge, experience, and tolerance of what the Committee is about, attributes which will exist in the Ministry and on both sides of the Chamber. It is the support and encouragement of the members of this Chamber which makes it possible for the Committee to act with authority and determination in protecting personal liberties and in safeguarding the parliamentary right to scrutinise delegated legislation.

Mr President, for the occasion of the last sitting of the Senate in this place I have had prepared on my behalf a paper which tries to capture the essence of many of the 83 reports of the Committee tabled in this House since 1932. My intention is to convey to honourable Senators and others some flavour of the historical development of the Committee and the evolution of its bipartisan mind on questions of personal rights and liberties. I urge Ministers and their advisers who are puzzled by the persistence of the Regulations and Ordinances Committee to obtain amendments to their delegated legislation, to read this paper and understand the power of the historical traditions of personal liberty and parliamentary propriety to which this Committee owes its existence.

DEBATE.TITLE: NON-STOP SOLO CIRCUMNAVIGATION OF THE WORLD

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate congratulates Kay Cottee on the near completion of her attempt to non-stop solo circumnavigate the globe, and wishes her every success in the final days of her journey.

It is fitting that this is the last motion to be considered in this chamber because it acknowledges the achievement of Kay Cottee. She is only days away from achieving her ambition-that is, to be the first woman to solo circumnavigate the world. Her ambition reflects the capacity and determination to be found among Australian women. Her achievement, which I have no doubt will be realised, will be a symbol to all of what women can achieve, especially Australian women. It will also be an international symbol of sporting achievement. It is appropriate, perhaps, to acknowledge the role of private enterprise in this achievement through the sponsorship of a company called Blackmores Laboratories Ltd. In conclusion, I ask my colleagues to support the motion and, in doing so, to recognise a great Australian achievement.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Senator Harradine-Mr President, I raise a point of order. I have not heard papers called. Is it proposed that papers be called today? I raise the point of order on the basis that there is a paper on the list of Government papers entitled `Recombinant DNA Monitoring Committee' which I seek to address. In accordance with the `Red' that we have before us there is a provision for papers.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Government papers were not called because they were overridden by the guillotine. You would have to seek the leave of the Senate to make any statement now. That is provided under Standing Orders. There is to be no discussion of papers.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Harradine-Mr President, I seek your advice as to whether those papers will go onto the Notice Paper.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, they will.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I am sure I speak for all senators and parliamentary staff when I say that I am experiencing mixed feelings on this historic occasion. On the one hand I am sure that we are all looking forward to the increased facilities and space in the new Parliament House, while on the other it is always with a sense of regret that one leaves familiar surroundings behind. I do not intend to dwell on the past tonight but I am certain everybody who has worked in this building in whatever capacity over the past 61 years will have memories of his or her time here: of the great characters who have served in this chamber; of the memorable political events which have occurred here since 1927; of the celebrations and wakes which have been held in various parts of the building; and of the people who have served the Parliament in so many ways over the years.

INTERJECT.PARA: The Senate farewell dinner to the provisional Parliament House last night demonstrated the strong sense of camaraderie and the bonds which have been forged across political lines in this building. Whatever the failings of the provisional building, it has allowed an intimacy to develop among all people who have worked here. One never knows who one will run into in the rabbit warren corridors and offices of the building. This has resulted in many a political problem having been solved in the most unlikely of places. I hope that this sense of community will become a feature of the new building and that the feelings of comradeship built up here will be transferred by all of us to the new building.

As President, I am aware that there will be many problems associated with the first sittings in the new building. I seek the patience and understanding of all senators and staff in our first months up on the hill. I am, however, looking forward to the Parliament gathering for the inaugural meetings in the new building on 22 August, particularly as so many distinguished parliamentarians from all over the world will be present. This occasion cannot be allowed to pass without my thanking all parliamentary staff for their efforts in the often trying circumstances which have been inflicted on them in the past and especially over the past three weeks. I thank all senators most sincerely for their forbearance and support, and I wish senators and the parliamentary staff a smooth transition to the new Parliament House over the winter recess.

In conclusion on behalf of all honourable senators, past and present, I want to pay a special tribute to this building, a building which, despite its shortcomings, has served the Parliament of Australia well in the years since 1927. I am sure it will not be forgotten by any of the thousands of people who have worked here over the years, many of whom will say, `Thanks for the memories'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Now is the hour-an expression which I hope will not provoke Senator Walsh to sing. Mr President, as is customary at the end of the parliamentary session, I pay tribute to the way you have carried out your difficult task with fairness and distinction, and I join you in thanking the Senate staff, Hansard, the Australian Broadcasting Corporation and all the others who have contributed to the operation of the Parliament. This is the end of another parliamentary session but it is somewhat different. It is the last meeting of the Senate in this building, the home of the Commonwealth Parliament for 61 years. Federal Parliament has had three buildings; the first, the Victorian Parliament building for 26 years; this one, the provisional Parliament House; and now the new Parliament House. I venture to predict, perhaps irreverently, that the first home will be judged to have been the most elegant by future generations.
—A conservative at heart.
—Yes, I am.
—He is fighting for Camp Hill again.

—Yes, I still am. It is a bold task to try to capture the essential character of this building and its place in Australian history because it is a topic which engenders a multitude of passions. I suppose all parliaments around the world have something of the same character about them. Honourable senators who were at the dinner last night would realise that I have been reading a novel by an English parliamentarian and recently I have been re-reading it--
—Not again.
—Yes, but I propose to quote a different passage this time. In that novel, Wilfred Fienburgh, in talking about the House of Commons and a member, said this:

SPEECH.PARA: He had found his only happiness and fulfilment inside the House, where there was always something to occupy him, even though the constant activity was sometimes more fabricated than genuine. Inside the House he had found the comfort of a routine and the loose comradeship of the group. The structure of each day was set by habit-coffee in the tea-room, open letters, meeting of a standing committee, lunch, coffee in the tea-room and a relaxed gossip until Question Time at 2.30, listen to the opening speeches of the day's debate, 4.30 and time for tea, five o'clock and a meeting of the Finance and Economics Committee, or the Foreign Affairs Committee, or an hour's work in the library on the notes of a speech, the day punctuated by divisions, spells spent listening to the debate when the member worth hearing held the floor, dinner at eight, more reading, more talking, more coffee, more gossip, more listening, division at ten, pack up papers and `Who goes home?'

That could have been said about this place. I think it very much captures the life of many members in the House-the sort of political groupies which many of us are. The House of Commons and certainly the House of Lords have always been different, largely because of the structure of British society. Ernest Bevin, in his great autobiography In Place of Fear, described his arrival in the House of Commons. Looking at the ancestors of the politicians who were there in his day he made the point, `These are not my ancestors. My ancestors worked in the mines for these men'. Politics in Britain will always be influenced by class; it has always been influenced by class. It is not so true in Australia-there has not been much class here. Nonetheless, there have been 26 Parliaments and 36 ministries in this building and the value of each of them depends on one's point of view. In 1927, when this building was first opened, a member of the Opposition asked the Prime Minister, `When is the House intending to resume? It seems to me to have been adjourned ever since this Government was elected'.

There have been great figures in the other place, or people with some of the attributes of greatness-Hughes, Scullin, Curtin, Chifley, Menzies and Whitlam. In the Senate there have been others who have had the same sorts of attributes, but judgments about senators are much more personal and direct. There have also been some great dramas-the rise and fall of governments and changes in ministries. The House has witnessed great historical events.

Great and terrible things have happened in this building. Each of us has his or her personal memories, and mine are mostly of the terrible things. I remember missing my first division and Senator Wheeldon, then a Minister in the Whitlam Government who had a great poker face, came up to me and said, `You are in very serious trouble'. I asked, `What has happened?' He said, `The Opposition has refused Supply'. He said, `Come round and I will buy you a drink. It will be your last here'. So I went round feeling very apprehensive about everything and thinking that my career had been cut short. I said, `What am I to do?' Senator Wheeldon said, `The only thing you can do is get out your cheque book and write a cheque for $400m'.

I remember another moment of horror. I had the habit of sunbaking on the roof of this building, which one could only get to through the catwalk upstairs. One day I went to sleep there. There was a thunderstorm. I had no clothes, apart from a pair of shorts and a suit which I had taken out there. I went to the window where I had climbed out to try to get in but, because of the thunderstorm, somebody had locked it. I remember seeing a couple of journalists walking across the catwalk and I was out there gesticulating in the rain, trying to get back in.

Some disgraceful things have also happened in this chamber. I remember one day Senator Wheeldon was very upset because he was passed a note by one of the attendants which was said to have come from the gallery upstairs. The note said: `Senator Wheeldon, I am a pensioner on $52 a week. You sit down there on $500 doing crosswords. You are a national disgrace'. Senator Wheeldon was very upset about this, and it took him a year to find out that the author of the note was Senator Chaney.

This is said to be an intimate building. It is said to be a great advantage that one always bumps into people. As far as I am concerned, that is a matter of taste. I suppose my own impression of the building is its reflection of a period of Australian history. When I first came here as a young man who had just left school, I remember buying at the Post Office downstairs a postcard which had on it a picture of Parliament House, and superimposed over it all was the enormous figure of Bob Menzies. I still have the postcard. Of course that was a very symbolic postcard of those times.

This is a provisional building in a compromise capital, a sociological wasteland. At times, I must say, it has reminded me not so much of Westminster but more of Port Arthur-remote in character, away from ordinary life and commerce. To get out of the place one has to run the gauntlet of a doorstop, the equivalent of the sharks at Eaglehawk Neck, or walk for miles though crematoria lawns dotted with rose bushes. Whatever it may be-drama, intimacy, greatness, history or just plain monotony-this House has played a great part in Australian history and reflected the times in which it was the centre of government in this country.

If I might trouble honourable senators, I want to just say that I hope that the new House will symbolise wider visions and aspirations for this country, but I cannot be sure about that. None of us can. Might I burden honourable senators who were at the dinner last night by quoting again from the Melbourne Argus of 1927, when people moved from the Parliament in Victoria to this House. The Argus wrote:

The fact that the parliament has been sitting for years in one place and will for the future sit in another place leaves every person in Australia much the same as he was before. The old men will assemble in the new house: they will be `National' or `Provincial' as they were before, and will continue to believe that the last opinion which they expressed was wiser than an earlier one . . .

Parliamentary warfare is not likely to undergo a change in the new surroundings. There will be misrepresentation, conscious or unconscious; satire, ponderous and pointed; argument, close to and wide of the mark; facts which look like fiction, and fiction dressed to look like facts.
The article reminds us, of course, that we are just changing buildings, and the Parliament goes on. I hope that what the Argus wrote in May 1927 will not be true.

Mr President, I wish all honourable senators and the staff of the Senate well in the new building and thank them all for the personal associations we have built up here. I hope that some of that, some of the intimacy at least, can be translated to the House on the hill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is one of those occasions when I can speak in support of the comments of the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button, and I would like to start by congratulating the Whips for the excellent attendance in this building. I hope it indicates what is likely to happen in the new House on the hill.

SPEECH.PARA: I have had only one message from a constituent which matches the sort of evident joy and party atmosphere there is here tonight, and that message was that that person, just as much as we here, would like to celebrate this great occasion, but would have preferred the old building with a new set of senators. I do not know how the rest of Australia feels, but I hope that that constituent is not totally representative.

The speech of Senator Button was important because we all knew the remarkable qualities of Senator Wheeldon. He was one of those few people who could speak in this chamber and fill it rather than start speaking and empty it. What I had not known to this time was that he also had prescience, and had understood the risk of refusal of Supply-one of the great dramatic occasions in this place. We should get Senator Button to put a date on his story so that we can pin Wheeldon down. I would like to question Senator Button about his childhood memories because I also came to this place as a child. My recollection is that the politicians were more impressive, substantial people-rather larger people. I remember raising that with my father. He looked pityingly at me and said, `Well, they were larger'. I do not know whether Senator Button has had that same experience. Like Senator Button, in looking to the new building I look back to the time when politicians moved into this building. Being a parochial Western Australian I want to quote what a Western Australian senator had to say because it demonstrates how little has changed since 1927. Senator Lynch, on the adjournment on that first day of sitting, said:

Having had a little parliamentary experience, I recognise that the opinions that have been expressed outside as to the unwillingness of this parliament to stand up to and perform its duties are but part and parcel of the unfair criticism that is generally directed at parliaments and parliamentarians in this country.

I interpolate and say that we have managed to stamp that out, except from that lot up there in the Press gallery. Most of the Australian people seem to think we are a splendid bunch of fellows and females. But Senator Lynch was concerned about that at the time and he went on to say this:

I do not know that the motive of these critics is a very lofty one, but I do know that among those who have spoken or written as the Minister (Senator Sir George Pearce) has described are many who would like to bring parliamentary institutions into disrepute and contempt. It is certain that their aim is not to extol or place them on the high plane they should undoubtedly occupy.

Thinking of Senator Lynch's complaints in 1927, I was trying to work out whether the activities of the Senate while it has occupied this chamber have increased or lessened that public criticism of the Parliament. I totally accept the view of the Clerk, which has already been referred to, that we are not tonight saying goodbye to the Senate; we are simply saying goodbye to one of the Senate's temporary premises.

From what has happened in the Senate since 1927 it can properly be asserted that this chamber is the only parliamentary chamber in Australia that has, in a genuine sense, retained its legislative function. Whilst I do not believe that that attracts widespread admiration and support, it has been a very worthwhile development for Australia and something which has benefited Australia. Since 1927 we have had the establishment of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, which was the first time that a parliament of this type had tackled what in the 1920s was described as the new despotism-the great proliferation of regulations and ordinances which removed people's freedom. This chamber broke new ground for the parliamentary world in its establishment of the Regulations and Ordinances Committee. The late Senator Missen promoted internationally what had been developed here. I believe it has been a great contribution to Australia and to the parliamentary world.

The introduction of a wide-ranging committee system, promoted I think initially by the late Senator Murphy-no doubt with the opposition of the government of the day; as governments of the day always oppose the exercise of parliamentary authority and power-has been an important contribution to Australia and to its welfare. The more recent establishment of the Senate Standing Committee on the Scrutiny of Bills in 1981 is an acknowledgment that for many of us the proper scrutiny of legislation is pushed aside and into a corner. The various people who have manned that Committee have made a very significant contribution.

I believe that we are all entitled to be proud of some of the genuine committee debates which have taken place. I remember again back to the days of the Labor Government from 1972 to 1975, and there are very few senators here now from that period--

TALK.START.PARA: —Seven.

—Seven, I am told. I remember the committee debates on Bills such as those on trade practices and matrimonial causes. They were a splendid exercise of parliamentary activity. More recently, I remember the debates on the identity card and the Bill of Rights which honourable senators opposite might remember with revulsion but which I see as having been very educative debates for the Australian public. I remember some committee operations. I remember Senator Button earning the undying affection of Gough Whitlam for his part in the report on the then Government's proposal for a national compensation scheme. Senator Button was one of the three Labor members of a Senate committee which suggested that the Bill should be withdrawn and redrafted. Like Senator Button, I remember moments of high drama, and most of all, I suppose, the experience of 1975, for those who were here at that time, which had a very powerful influence on senators on both sides of this place in terms of the attitudes that they subsequently adopted in political life in this country.
—Hear, hear!

—I acknowledge the Minister's quiet interjection. I remember our conversations at that time about that issue. In all this and in all the recollections we have of this chamber, it stands out that none of the recollections is about the bricks and mortar of this place; they are all about the people who have occupied it. I join with all those who acknowledge the senators in the past who have occupied this building and who have made a contribution to good legislation and on occasions to good government in this country. The quality of the Senate is totally dependent upon senators and not on furnishings and buildings. But at the same time I express real optimism that the new quarters that we have been given will provide a new environment in which we will have a parliament which, in a physical sense more separate from the Executive, will become a more genuine legislative institution.

SPEECH.PARA: The thing that gives me greatest pleasure about leaving this building is the appalling conditions under which staff have worked for the whole of the time that I have been here. I express my strong personal thanks to the staff who have worked for me, for my colleagues and for everybody here, because I think they have worked under the most difficult conditions imaginable. I do not think that very many Australians in the work force understand just how cramped and unpleasant the working conditions have been for many people. Those people, to whom I express my personal thanks, will be major beneficiaries of this change.

Mr President, I thank you for your conduct of the Senate during this session and for your great activities in smoothing the transition to the new Parliament House. I hope that your own work is rewarded by a smooth transition. I join the Leader of the Government in thanking all those who have worked here with us and for us-the cooks in the kitchen below, the attendants, the drivers, and all those who enable the place to function.

I leave this place with the nostalgia which has been expressed by so many over recent days but with a very great sense of optimism that the movement into the new building will direct our thoughts and our attention to the future of this country. That is where our attention should lie. As in so many areas, which I am sure those trade unionists opposite would have discovered, when the workers are given decent conditions it is amazing how productivity increases. I express my hope on behalf of the people of Australia that they will see a better parliament in the new place, that what we have learned that is positive here we will take with us, and the negative aspects of this parliament which have earned our disrepute at times we will leave behind us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure that valedictories of this kind are something of an art form in this place. Others who have spoken here tonight have been here a great deal longer than I have, and I am sure they are much more versed in this art form. As honourable senators know, I am a relative new boy in this place. I have been coming to the Parliament for a very long time, but not in any senatorial capacity. When I did come to it I tended to come to the other end of the building because that is where Treasurers generally reside and that is, therefore, where those who serve Treasurers generally visit them. Nevertheless, I have always had a great affection for the Senate and the role of the Senate. I have to say with great pleasure that that feeling has been thoroughly borne out even in the short time I have been here. I think it was Boswell in his Life of Johnson--
—Not Ron.

—No, not Ron; I will come back to Senator Boswell. Boswell at one time said that Johnson uttered a most terrible indictment of a man about London town when he said, `He is not a clubable man'. Of course, Senator Boswell is an eminently clubable man. I am sure that at the time Boswell was not thinking of Senator Walsh, and I am equally sure that Johnson would never have referred to a clubable person. These days, I suppose, we might be more sensitive and would have to refer to clubable men or women. Of course, from time to time there are many clubable women in this Senate, but I will not pursue that line of thought. But whatever-men, women or persons-the Senate not so much demands but at least invites a certain clubability. I have found myself comfortable in that environment. When we go up on the hill we will take with us our colleagues, including honourable senators opposite, and our devoted staff, and, above all, I hope the spirit of this place. I look forward to our new home.

SPEECH.PARA: Friday, 3 June 1988
2-3 June 1988 SENATE
SENATE 2-3 June 1988
2-3 June 1988 SENATE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Transport and Communications and Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, we have all uttered many hundreds of thousands of words in this place. Some of us, it is true, have uttered a few more hundreds of thousands than others. To utter some more just because they are our last in this place seems to me to savour just a little of vulgar excess. I at least have an excuse to get to my feet because, as Manager of Government Business, a job about as thankless as that of being the last Emperor's eunuch, I have some special thanks to give to those who make my job marginally less horrible than it would otherwise be.
—Bring back Don Grimes.

—It is no good looking wistful, Shirley, you are not going to get a mention in this context. I am referring especially to the Parliamentary Liaison Officer, Paul Conn, the most recent in a long line of very dedicated and very professional officers from the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, who is one of the most implausible looking radio rock and roll disc jockeys that I think any of us have ever seen and whose last night it is in this job. I am thinking of people not only like you, Mr President, but Harry Evans, Anne Lynch, Terry Brown and others of the Clerks who have not allowed their congenital whiggery, as Harry put it last night, to get in the way of giving very good procedural advice, not only to me but to all sides of this chamber. In particular on this occasion I wish to thank the Whips on all sides of the chamber and their assistants-including in particular on the Government side Joan Harvey, who is with us in the chamber tonight-who have been admirably competent, level headed and sensible on nearly every occasion when those commodities have been conspicuously lacking or in short supply elsewhere.

SPEECH.PARA: Having said all that, I do not propose to deluge honourable senators tonight with my own contribution to that torrent of lukewarm nostalgia in which the chamber will no doubt shortly be knee-deep. Of course there have been plenty of marvellous moments, funny moments, dramatic moments, riotous moments, sometimes all at once, in the life of this chamber. I have to say that my own overriding sentiment about this place is that it is time we got out of it and made a new beginning. Maybe it is just because I have had too little sleep over the last few days; maybe it is because I am afflicted with all of that accumulated distrust of human nature that overcomes Managers of Government Business and Whips after a time in those jobs. But when I look around these walls I tend to think, more than anything else, of some of the ghosts. My perception of those ghosts, I suspect, would be a somewhat different perspective from that of Fred Chaney in his earlier contribution. I think, for example, of the ghosts of poor old Jimmy Scullin and his Government, forced out of office in 1931 more than anything else by the utter intransigence of the hostile Senate he faced for the life of that Government. I think of the ghost of Bertie Milliner, so dishonoured by the circumstances of his replacement in this place, which very much precipitated all the events of 1975.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the Senate was right again.

—I wish some people were ghosts a little earlier than would occur in the natural course of events. I think of the livid scars left on the history of parliamentary democracy by the rejection or delay in this place during the life of the Whitlam Government of some 93 pieces of legislation-30 more, it will be recalled, than in the whole previous history of Federation in the Senate; and ultimately, of course, of the blocking of Supply that occurred in October and November 1975. I think finally, perhaps more than anything else on this occasion-

SPEECH.PARA: 2-3 June 1988 SENATE

2-3 June 1988 SENATE

TALK.START.PARA: —This isn't appropriate.

—It is appropriate, Senator. I think more than anything else on this occasion of the ghost of Lionel Murphy-not a flawless man, by any means, as we all know, but perhaps the greatest Senate man in the history of this place in terms of the contribution that he made to giving it life and vitality through the committee system, who, in a very cruel irony, was torn down from high office and very much driven to his grave, more than anything else, by the course of events that occurred in this place.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe, and I have always believed, that there is a vital and very legitimate democratic role to be played by the Senate in the scrutiny of legislation, Executive behaviour and the generation and promulgation of ideas in this country. But they are not roles that have yet in the history of this country been played with very much distinction by this institution or within these four walls. We can do better. I believe that our new environment will give us an opportunity to make a break with the past and to make a fresh start in more ways than one.

On this occasion, in which there is so much determination to wallow in nostalgia-and it is perfectly understandable-my sentiments about this place can perhaps be more gently summarised by corrupting, just a little, the immortal suggestion that was made to the Rump Parliament a few hundred years ago: We have sat here too long for any good we have been doing. Depart, I say, let's have done with this place. In the name of God let's go.
