Dennis Strangman, my staff member, has been here for longer than any other, except one. I do not think that person would care for me to mention her name. He has been here for 23 years, save for a period of two years in the Department of Administrative Services and the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. Finally, I share with honourable senators a story which I intended to tell them in the early hours the other morning when we were discussing the freedom of religion question to be asked in the referendum. I was trying to work out whether the commencement of the day with the Lord's Prayer was followed by legislation or by tradition. I know the answer to that. It is this: Some time last century a Prime Minister of Great Britain took his granddaughter into the House of Commons. Afterwards, she said, `Grandfather, why does the Speaker start the day with the Lord's Prayer?'. His response was, `Well, my dear, the Speaker comes to the Parliament in procession, enters the chamber, takes one look at the assembled politicians and prays for the country'. I do hope sincerely for the good of this country that that tradition continues in the new Parliament House.

TALK.START.PARA: —The last sitting of the Senate in the provisional Parliament House is a time not only to look to the future but to reflect upon the great times and traditions of the past. One of the great traditions is the opportunity for senators of all persuasions to gather in a spirit of bipartisanship and conviviality at the end of a session. That reminds me about the complaint that was made here very recently about a certain senator singing off key. That is not the worst thing that can happen in the world. I am aware of another certain senator who actually had to sing to be released from prison. Camaraderie in the Senate is far stronger than in the House (both on the staff level and among the politicians) probably because of the Senate's smaller size and (till recently) its aggressively defensive feelings about its parliamentary significance. This esprit de corps in the Senate is strengthened by social gatherings. Parties in the Senate Records office are a regular feature late on Thursday nights sitting weeks, particularly towards the end of a session. There is plenty of singing and dancing, drinking and arguing among those who attend, including government and opposition senators, parliamentary officers and attendants, ministerial staff, journalists, and Hansard reporters.

TALK.START.PARA: —When this site was first chosen for the Federal Parliament of Australia, the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) had a population of 1,762 horses, 1,714 people and 224,764 sheep. In 1927 this temporary and provisional Parliament House was opened. Since then it has been extended to 2 1/2 times its original size, and it is still cramped. It has been suggested that as well as the constant refurbishing it is the annual coats of paint which keep the building standing. Much of the colourful history of this building has been described tonight, both the better known and some of the odder and more delightful and even indiscreet anecdotes.

SPEECH.PARA: As someone who set foot within these historic portals only after the last Federal election-that is, some 10 months ago-I nonetheless have felt myself surrounded by the historic events of the past and by some almost tangible ghosts. I have been impressed by the number of tourists and school students-visitors of all kinds-who come to see the provisional Parliament House, and I have reflected on the changes which have taken place even within the memory of some of my colleagues in this place.

However, I am more concerned about the future of this historic building. It has been said that this place will become a museum, perhaps a constitutional museum. I believe this is a splendid idea. Could I float the notion that it should become a living museum, that it should have certain current and living functions. This chamber, perhaps, could perhaps be a seat for the ACT Assembly now that the ACT is seen to be poised-perhaps I should say tottering-on the verge of self-government. This would be a purpose-built home for the new small Parliament of the ACT, with all the ancillary benefits in place, that is, Hansard, members' offices, and a Press Gallery which would be the envy of State and local governments, however warren-like it might seem to the teeming journalists attendant on the national Parliament.

On other occasions, perhaps, both chambers could be a venue for conferences, political education seminars and such nostalgia for visitors and tourists. I can see the tourist brochures right now and hear the voice of Paul Hogan saying, `You can sit on the very chair which was sat upon by Sir Robert Menzies.

—We have thanked almost everybody who has anything to do with the Senate. We have thanked the telephone operators, and I think they deserve thanks. Apparently all sorts of people say that there are ghosts. I do not know about that; perhaps they come up and grab them behind the neck as they stroll down the corridors. It is interesting to wonder also how one gets to be a ghost. Mostly, by definition, I think a ghost is--
—Try dying.

—I thank Senator Crichton-Browne. I think that a ghost is the consequence of death, if you like. I also think that a ghost is not created unless it is as a result of some matter of passion. No boring, dull, colourless person becomes a ghost around Parliament House-only people who stab others in the back; people who rise to the great heights of literary merit; and most of the people who sat here in 1975. Those people and the things they were talking about-particularly the matters of passion of those days-I think are the substance of ghosts, or what leads to them, apart from death, Senator Crichton-Browne.

I think the notion of what a ghost comes from and the passion associated with that stand in sharp contrast to the counsel given to me quite often around this place-counsel to the effect that what we need in Parliament is rational and reasoned debate. In particular, I recall one of my colleagues saying between clenched teeth in a very fierce voice and hitting the table at the same time, `What we need in this place is calm, rational debate'. Very often I see evidence of anything but calm, rational debate, particularly in regard to what passes for rational debate. If any honourable senator is in doubt of that, I refer them to Senator Lewis's speech on the sex discrimination legislation. If anything reached the dizzy heights of nonsense, his speech did. In particular, I refer to Senator Lewis's statement that sex discrimination legislation would cause all sorts of problems, particularly for those people who had to live in `compulsory, close cohabitation'. That seems also to be one of the problems of being a member of the Senate. One can hope that Senator Lewis will rest more easy in a larger place with more space between the cohabitants.

In particular, the nonsense and the foolishness of the contribution of the Opposition during the sex discrimination debate would seem to have meant that most of them were seeking prospective places as ghosts around here. I simply use this as one way of saying that one person who was never a ghost in her time here-I suspect that if she is to be remembered it is not because she is a ghost but because of her rational contribution-is former Senator Susan Ryan. I would like to place on record my high regard for that lady and her contribution to debate in this place and, in particular, the effects of that legislation passed for and on behalf of women. It would seem to me that the contribution of Opposition senators, if I can make the point, of sheer lunacy-let alone passion-in the name of rational debate will allow them to become ghosts. I would prefer to remember Susan Ryan in the very constructive, non-ghost like way in which she has contributed to the achievements of women.

I too would particularly like to place on record my thanks to you, Mr President. You have sat and ruled on so much of the lunacy in this place as people I presume were qualifying to become ghosts. I also thank those other people who have been listed so well and extensively by others.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 17 December:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister aware of the report `France: the Nuclear Renegade' by Senator Norm Sanders and Richard Bolt.
(2) Is it a fact that the Chaufferie Avancee Prototype (C.A.P.) research reactor in France has been used to develop nuclear reactors for civilian purposes and for nuclear-armed submarines.

(3) Is it a fact that the Pierrelatte uranium enrichment plant has produced uranium for the Phenix reactor, originally a civilian power plant, in addition to weapons-grade uranium for the French nuclear weapons program.

(4) Is it a fact that the Tricastin uranium enrichment plant is mainly for the production of fuel for civilian power plants, and also does low- and medium-level enrichment for the Pierrelatte plant, which then further enriches the uranium to weapons-grade.

(5) Is it a fact that the Atelier de Realisation d'Assembleages Combustibles, a fuel element fabrication plant, has done military work with highly enriched uranium as well as producing fuel assemblies for civilian nuclear reactors.
(6) Is it a fact that the Celestin 1 and 2 heavy water reactors are used to produce lithium and plutonium for nuclear weapons, and are also used for medical and industrial purposes.
(7) Were the now-closed G1, G2 and G3 reactors at Marcoule used to produce weapons-grade plutonium as well as being connected to the French electric power grid.

(8) Is it a fact the the Chinon 1, 2 and 3 gas-graphite reactors were built to generate electricity, but were also equipped with fast-loading and -unloading devices to enable them to produce plutonium for nuclear weapons.

(9) Is it a fact that the Phenix fast breeder reactor was built as a civilian pilot plant for the Superphenix faster breeder, and has also been used for the production of weapons-grade plutonium for military purposes.
(10) Is it a fact that the Phenix reactor is not subject to international safeguards because of its military role.
(11) Is it a fact that the UP1 and UP2 reprocessing plants reprocess spent fuel from both military and civilian reactors, for both military and civilian purposes.
(12) Is it a fact that the SAP-TOP reprocessing plant (soon to be reopened as TOR) has reprocessed fuel for civilian purposes, and spent fuel from the Phenix reactor for military purposes.

(13) Given that the current French plans to build at least 950 nuclear weapons over the next 10 years will require at least 5 tonnes of plutonium, in addition to the 1.5 tonnes of plutonium used in the nuclear weapons program so far, and given that military reactors (G1, G2, G3, Celestin 1 and 2) have produced only 2.5 tonnes of plutonium, is it a fact that the civilian plants Chinon 1, 2 and 3, Saint Laurant 1 and 2, Bugey 1, Vandellos (Spain) and Phenix must supply the remaining 4 tonnes required for the nuclear weapons program.

(14) If a decision to mass produce the neutron bomb is taken by France, is it a fact that France will not have enough plutonium available for mass production unless it uses weapons grade plutonium produced in the breeder mantles of the Superphenix faster breeder reactor.

(15) Are the French decisions to engage in a major nuclear buildup, to possibly build neutron bombs, to begin a joint cruise missile project with Britain to compensate for the elimination of United States (U.S.) ground-launched cruise missiles under the Intermediate Range Nuclear forces (I.N.F.) Treaty, and to examine the placement of French tactical nuclear weapons in West Germany under joint control, likely to undermine the I.N.F. Treaty and jeopardise future disarmament agreements, particularly reductions in strategic nuclear weapons and conventional and nuclear disarmament in Europe.
(16) Is it a fact the France has not stated whether its share of the plutonium to be produced in Superphenix will be used for military purposes.

(17) Is the Minister aware of a statement by Mr R. J. S. Harry of the Netherlands Energy Research Foundation in the `Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists' in March 1985 that `Australia . . . (has) . . . agreed to a complicated pro-rata rule which separates breeding zone and core and which in fact does not rule out possible military use of plutonium from Superphenix's breeder zone'.
(18) What are the precise details of that agreed rule.

(19) Given that large scale reprocessing of fast breeder fuel elements is neither economic not technically developed and that the large-scale building of fast breeders is not envisaged anywhere in the world, does this mean that fast breeders will play no major role in increasing the life of uranium reserves.

(20) Is this conclusion borne out by a 3 year study presented to the 13th Congress of the World Energy Conference by an Electricite de France employee, which found that the rapid introduction of fast breeders would only prolong the exhaustion of world uranium reserves by 17 years from 2073 to 2090.
(21) Does this mean that the major reason France has for continuing with the Superphenix is to ensure it has a sufficient supply of weapons-grade plutonium in coming years.
(22) Is it a fact that France does not accept that Euratom safeguards arrangements prevent the military use of plutonium produced in Superphenix.
(23) Is the uranium imported by France from Namibia and Niger and the uranium mined within France unsafeguarded.

(24) Is the quantity of uranium received from those sources sufficient to fuel France's nuclear weapons program and are Australian safeguards arrangements therefore unable to curtail France's nuclear weapons program.
(25) What action has the Australian Government taken in response to the illegal mining of uranium in Namibia.
(26) What action has the Australian Government taken in response to the following actions by France:

(a) its provision of the Dimona research reactor, the Machon-2 reprocessing plant, and nuclear weapons design information to Israel, as revealed by Professor Frances Perrin, former French High Commissioner for Atomic Energy in 1986;
(b) its involvement in building the unsafeguarded Vandilaba uranium enrichment plant, the Koeberg 1 and 2 power reactors for South Africa;
(c) its offer to build a 900 megawatt nuclear reactor at Chashma in Pakistan, which no other country was prepared to do;
(d) its construction of the unsafeguarded heavy water reactors at Baroda and Tuticorin, and a fast breeder reactor at Kalpakkam in India;
(e) its offer to rebuild the Osirak reactor in Iraq, and its provision of 12.5 kg of highly-enriched uranium to that country;
(f) its agreement to build 2 reactors and to supply reprocessing technology to South Korea; and
(g) its agreement to supply uranium to Taiwan.

(27) Given that Israel, South Africa, Pakistan, India, Iraq, South Korea and Taiwan are acknowledged nuclear weapons proliferation risks, what danger does the Australian Government see in the export by France of each item of nuclear technology specified above.

(28) Is it the case that the only means by which the export of Australian uranium can be guaranteed not to contribute to the development and production of nuclear weapons is by the Australian Government only allowing exports to countries which:
(a) are not testing nuclear weapons, and actively support the signing of a Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty;

(b) are not producing any weapons-grade nuclear materials, do not reprocess any nuclear wastes, and have placed all existing stocks of weapons-grade nuclear material under effective international control;

(c) have signed the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty (N.P.T.) and have given a legally binding commitment not to export nuclear materials and technology to countries which are not N.P.T. signatories and do not have full-scope safeguards on their nuclear facilities.
(29) Is it the case that, under these conditions, uranium exports to France, the United Kingdom and the United States would be banned.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.
(2) Yes. Nuclear propulsion is a different matter from nuclear weapons.

(3) Publications of the French Atomic Energy Commission (CEA) indicate that the Pierrelatte enrichment facility was established to meet French needs for enriched uranium for military and for several civil application requirements. It is possible that the enriched uranium used in the initial fuel load for Phenix was produced at Pierrelatte.

(4) The Eurodif plant at Tricastin is a commercial enrichment facility established by a French, Belgian, Italian and Spanish consortium to produce low enriched uranium suitable for use in civilian nuclear power plants. France has separate facilities and processes-including those at Pierrelatte-for the production from low enriched uranium of highly enriched uranium for military purposes, and for making nuclear weapons themselves. For operational reasons including that of nuclear criticality, it is not possible to produce highly enriched uranium in the Eurodif plant at Tricastin. Since the supplementary answer given, on advice from the Australian Safeguards Office, in the Senate on 22 August 1986 by the then Minister for Resources and Energy (Hansard p. 358) it has been learned by the Australian Safeguards Office that the Eurodif plant at Tricastin, in producing low-enriched uranium, does process both obligated nuclear material, which remains in civil use, and unobligated material, which can-after further enrichment at another facility-be used for military purposes. The Australian obligated nuclear material which passes through the facility at Tricastin, however, remains confined to exclusively peaceful non-explosive use; that is, there is a quantity of low-enriched uranium and depleted tails, equivalent to the Australian obligated nuclear material which entered the plant, which is designated Australian obligated nuclear material and which may only be used for peaceful, non-explosive purposes. Thus the presence of unobligated as well as obligated nuclear material at the Tricastin facility does not in any way diminish the effectiveness of the safeguards regime under which Australian uranium is exported.
(5) The Government has no information to verify the statement about this facility.
(6) Celestin 1 and 2 produce tritium (not lithium) and probably plutonium for nuclear weapons. We do not know if they are also used for medical or industrial purposes.
(7) Yes.
(8) Chinon 1, 2 and 3 were dual-purpose reactors. Therefore they could have been fuelled and defuelled at rates commensurate with weapons grade plutonium production.
(9) Phenix was built as pilot plant to test the concepts and feasibility of commercial fast breeder reactors.

A fast breeder reactor could be operated over a period of time to produce more than enough plutonium to refuel its own core or fuel another similar fast breeder reactor. If no peaceful use obligations were attached to this plutonium it would be available for military use by France.

(10) The list of facilities which France has declared as eligible for application of IAEA safeguards is confidential to France and the IAEA. Phenix is not amongst those facilities at which Australian obligated nuclear material could be used, processed or stored.

(12) TOR is a small, experimental facility for reprocessing of fast reactor fuels. If Phenix spent fuel reprocessed at TOR carried no peaceful use obligations the material recovered would be available for military use by France.

(13) to (14) The Australian Government is aware of speculation on these lines but details of France's nuclear weapon plans and bomb designs are not released to foreign governments. Accordingly, we cannot comment authoritatively on the amount of plutonium France might need to implement those plans. Regarding the Vandellos (Spain) facility, Spain has recently acceded to the NPT. Therefore all nuclear material in Spain including any nuclear material recovered from spent fuel from the Vandellos facility will be subject to IAEA NPT fullscope safeguards.

(15) French and British nuclear forces were not included in the scope of the INF Treaty signed by President Reagan and General-Secretary Gorbachev in December 1987. Both the French and United Kingdom Governments have argued that their forces are under independent national control and thus outside the scope of the U.S./Soviet Treaty. They have argued further that, in relation to the size of the U.S. and Soviet strategic forces, their nuclear forces are minimal and that any consideration of reductions in those forces should await the achievement of deep cuts in the strategic arsenals of the two major powers.

The Government is obviously aware of increasing defence cooperation between France and the Federal Republic of Germany, but has no knowledge of any intention to deploy French nuclear forces in the Federal Republic of Germany. In an interview in December 1987, President Mitterrand stated that reinforcement of France-German defence relations would not go so far as to involve the German Government in a decision to use French nuclear forces.

Both the United States and the Soviet Union would have been aware of discussion of possible developments in French defence policy at the time they negotiated and later signed the INF Treaty in December 1987. The INF Treaty was ratified at the Moscow Summit in May 1988.
The Soviet Union and the NATO allies have declared their intention to work towards further disarmament agreements in Europe.
(16) The Government is not aware of any official French Government statement on France's plans for use of its share of the plutonium produced in Superphenix.

(18) The details of operation of the proportionality principle in respect of fast breeder reactors are contained in the Administrative Arrangements to the Australia/France and Australia/Euratom nuclear safeguards agreements. These Administrative Arrangements are confidential to the Parties to those Agreements. However the broad thrust of the first part of Mr Harry's statement which mentions a pro-rata rule which separates breeding zone and core is correct.

The Administrative Arrangements exist to give effect to the obligations contained in Australia's bilateral nuclear safeguards agreements. Article IV of both Agreements includes the obligation that Australian origin nuclear material subject to the Agreement shall not be used for any military purpose.

(19) No. Fast breeder reactors can play a major role in increasing the life of uranium reserves. This could occur early in the next century if the economics of fast breeder systems then favourably compare with light water reactors. The technical feasibility of fast breeder reactor fuel recycle has been demonstrated in the United Kingdom and France. Plants have been designed in both countries for large-scale economic reprocessing of fast breeder reactor fuel.

(20) No. If the study referred to was that subsequently published as a book entitled ``Energy Abundance-Myth or Reality'' by Jean-Romain Frisch, then the data in the question only relates to one of several arbitrary scenarios considered in terms of the exhaustion of world uranium reserves and the introduction of fast breeder reactors. The study concluded that ``the advantage to be gained from breeder reactors (in terms of extending uranium reserves) is very clear''.

(21) No. Superphenix is a commercial fast breeder reactor operated by an international commercial consortium (NERSA) of electricity producers. Its purpose is to determine the commercial viability of fast breeder reactors for nuclear electricity generation. NERSA is 51% owned by the French electricity utility EdF, 33% by the Italian electricity utility ENEL and the remaining 16% shared by a consortium of Belgian, Dutch, FRG and British electricity companies.
(22) The Government is not aware of any official French Government statements on France's interpretation of the safeguards provisions of the treaty establishing Euratom as they relate to Superphenix.

(23) Niger and South Africa (the power which illegally occupies Namibia in defiance of U.N. resolutions) are not members of the NPT and therefore not subject to NPT obligations in respect of their uranium exports. Uranium mined in France would be subject to Euratom safeguards until declared by France for military purposes.

(24) The Australian Government is not in a position to comment authoritatively on the amount of uranium needed for France's nuclear weapons program because details of that program are not released to foreign governments. In respect of the amount of uranium required for France's nuclear weapons program the 1984 ASTEC Report on Australia's Role in the Nuclear Fuel Cycle noted that ``France has indigenous reserves that are more than sufficient to provide for its military needs''. (ASTEC Report, page 95).
The safeguards obligations Australia attaches to Australian uranium imported by France are designed to ensure that Australian obligated nuclear material is used only for peaceful non-explosive use.

(25) Pending the adoption of comprehensive mandatory sanctions by the international community as a whole Australia has implemented the full range of selective sanctions measures against South Africa adopted at Nassau and London by Commonwealth leaders. These also apply to Namibia. Australia supports the implementation of Decree number 1 of the United Nations Council for Namibia and would condemn any action in contravention of that Decree.

(26) to (27) Without commenting on the veracity of the allegations contained in these questions and noting that France has adhered to the nuclear supply controls contained in IAEA document INFCIRC 254 I would point out that Australia has long urged universal adherence to the NPT and has long urged all nuclear supplier countries to require the application of full-scope IAEA safeguards as a minimum condition for nuclear supply to non-nuclear weapon states. Australia is concerned at the export of sensitive nuclear material, equipment and technology to countries which have not adhered to the NPT or adopted full-scope IAEA safeguards.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 16 February 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has Mr F. L. Weaver of Unit 10, 63 Harris Road, Five Dock, N.S.W. 2046, who established and currently operates the Japan-Australia Pen Friends Association, lodged postal inquiry forms with Australia Post concerning the non-delivery of hundreds of letters from Japan since September 1985; if so, what investigations have been conducted into the matter.

(2) What is the extent of investigations into the allegations made by Mr Weaver about the conduct of various Australia Post employees in respect of the alleged theft of Mr Weaver's incoming mail, from both the Five Dock and Concord West post offices.

(3) Has Mr Weaver lodged forms officially requesting Australia Post to redirect his mail without charge as a person in receipt of a pension from the Department of Veterans' Affairs from his former address to Five Dock Post Office since September 1986; if so, what action has been taken in the matter; if no action has been taken, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question, based on information from Australia Post, is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. Australia Post has advised me that it has received more than 200 Postal Item Enquiry forms lodged by Mr Weaver concerning the alleged non-delivery of mail. These enquiry forms were lodged at numerous post offices over an extended period of time, and many of them were duplicates of forms which had already been lodged and were already being investigated by Australia Post.

Australia Post has advised me that detailed and thorough investigations, involving Australia Post security officers and including inquiries with the Japanese postal administration, were conducted in those instances where the sender confirmed posting of mail to Mr Weaver.

Australia Post's investigations found that the inquiry forms related to only a handful of alleged missing articles, each of which purportedly contained quantities of letters from Japanese students seeking Australian pen friends. Australia Post has advised me that its investigations failed to trace any of the alleged missing articles.

(2) Australia Post has advised me that thorough investigations, again involving Australia Post security officers, were conducted into allegations by Mr Weaver concerning the conduct of various postal officers. The allegations were found by Australia Post to be unsubstantiated, and this finding was endorsed by Australia Post's acting Managing Director.

(3) Yes. Mr Weaver has been informed by Australia Post that he is entitled to free redirection of mail only for the first month of the redirection period. Where continuity of the redirection service is required beyond one month, a monthly fee is payable.

As Mr Weaver has apparently not been prepared to pay the appropriate fee for redirection of his mail, any mail addressed to him at his former addresses would be delivered as addressed. This is in accordance with Australia Post's normal procedure in such circumstances.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Telecom Business Office, Bunbury, Western Australia

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 16 February 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What were the reasons for the proposed closure of the Telecom Business Office (T.B.O.) in Bunbury, Western Australia.
(2) To what extent did Telecom consider its proposal to close the Bunbury T.B.O.
(3) Were any alternatives considered in respect of the Bunbury closure; if so, what were these alternatives and the reasons for not adopting them.

(4) In relation to the general issue of T.B.O. closures Australia-wide: (a) what consultations were undertaken by Telecom with the employees and/or the unions concerned; and (b) are there expected to be any redundancies as a result.
(5) What, if any, is the nature of the retraining and skills upgrade courses offered by Telecom in the event that some T.B.O. employees are required to be relocated to different function areas.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question, based on advice from Telecom Australia, is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Telecom Australia has been rationalising its network of T.B.O.s for approximately twelve months now. This rationalisation has been predicated on the basis that Telecom's retail outlets, including Bunbury, were unprofitable. Also, Telecom has found the use of Business Sales Representatives a far more effective way of selling its products. Consequently, T.B.O.s are being progressively closed, or relocated with the District Office when this can be justified. Bunbury T.B.O. is part of this campaign.
(2) Bunbury T.B.O., along with all other T.B.O.s that have either been closed or relocated, was considered on its financial viability.

(3) No. It was necessary to close the Bunbury T.B.O. because of its operating loss of some $76,600 annually. However, a Customer Reception Area, where customers may deal with Telecom staff in person, has been established with the District Office in Edward Court, Bunbury.
(4) (a) Telecom Australia has consulted with all Associations and staff relevant to T.B.O.s and has an agreed process for the closures.
(b) Redundancies are not expected as the staff are being redeployed to other areas in the Customer Services Sections of Telecom.

(5) Most of the employees in T.B.O.s would require little re-training as they are part of the overall Customer Services Section structure. Where, however, there is a necessity for re-training, relevant and timely training is provided having regard to the particular circumstances of each case.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 17 May 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: What progress has been made, in view of recent debacles in the award of Government tenders, towards the development of streamlined tendering procedures for Commonwealth departments.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: A review of Commonwealth purchasing was initiated in mid 1987 under the auspices of the Financial Management Improvement Program. Its aim was to discover opportunities for greater efficiency, effectiveness and economy in Government purchasing.

The review was not a response to problems with specific tenders but rather was prompted by a recognition of potential for improvement and savings in this very important Commonwealth activity. The role and form of tendering have been examined in the review. A lack of flexibility, and an emphasis on process in the current system, have been identified as problem areas. The review is recommending changes to introduce greater flexibility in purchasing procedures to enhance professionalism in procurement within a framework where open and effective competition is established as the norm, and the traditional values of probity, equity and fair dealing are protected.

Consultation has been taking place with industry groups and within the public service on proposed reforms which include changes to the public tender system. If I agree with the detailed proposals put to me, I will be conferring with the Minister for Finance with a view to bringing them forward for decision by Government. A major consideration will be the maintenance of probity.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 24 May 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: Is the Minister considering changing the Government's purchasing policy, a result of which would be that much less of its purchasing would be done by public tender in the future; if so, will this change prejudice businesses seeking contracts and also increase Commonwealth purchasing costs because of reduced competition?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: An inter-departmental review of Commonwealth purchasing was initiated in mid 1987 under the auspices of the Financial Management Improvement Program. Investigations have included an examination of the regulatory framework of Commonwealth purchasing, including the requirement for public tendering as the norm above a threshold of $20,000. The review has completed its first phase, and recommendations have been prepared.
I am advised that the proposals are based on a principle that Commonwealth purchasing should be conducted on the basis of open and effective competition.

This principle is aimed at enhancing the opportunity for industry to compete for Commonwealth business through either tendering, or through alternative processes which would involve lower administrative costs for both the Commonwealth and industry. Other proposals involve encouragement of early public notice of requirements.

The proposals aim to maintain or improve the quality of competition in Commonwealth purchasing. They have been exposed to a wide cross section of Australian industry in recent months and have received favourable responses.

I expect these proposals to be put to me formally and in detail in the near future. If I agree, and am satisfied that probity will be protected, I will bring them forward for consideration by Government.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Royal Australian Navy Facilities at Jervis Bay

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 19 December 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) With regard to the proposed relocation of Royal Australian Navy (R.A.N.) facilities to Jervis Bay: (a) exactly what R.A.N. facilities will be moved out of Sydney; (b) to where will they be moved; (c) what will be the loss of jobs in the Sydney metropolitan area due to these moves; (d) what facilities will be left in Sydney; (e) will they include the Naval logistics and storage depot at Zetland (on Botany Road), the naval dockyard at Garden Island together and the fleet base and command facilities at Woolloomooloo; (f) what have been the costs over the years 1979 to 1988 for the modernisation of the dockyard at Garden Island, and the provision of the multi-storey carpark and fleet base facilities at Woolloomooloo; (g) what other planned modernisation programs does the R.A.N. have for other existing facilities in Sydney Harbour.

(2) In view of the fact that half the R.A.N. fleet is being moved to H.M.A.S. Stirling in Western Australia, does this make more room for the remaining R.A.N. fleet, leading to a more cost-effective use of the existing facilities at Garden Island, H.M.A.S. Platypus and H.M.A.S. Waterhen; if so, is the proposed move to Jervis Bay unnecessary.

(3) Has any detailed assessment been made of the R.A.N.'s ammunition transport, storage and loading requirements in the light of the trend to ``smart'' weapons containing small amounts of explosives compared to older style armaments.
(4) Is it a fact that a fixed, shoreside ammunition storage and loading facility may not be needed at the east coast R.A.N fleet base.
(5) Have ports with under used existing facilities like Port Kembla and Newcastle been evaluated as potential naval installations instead of Jervis Bay; if not, why not.
(6) If existing facilities have been evaluated, what were the reasons for rejecting them.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) The R.A.N. Armament Depot at Newington in to be relocated. A proposal to relocate the Fleet Base at Garden Island/Woolloomooloo and H.M.A.S. Platypus at Neutral Bay is being developed; (b) The proposed location is Jervis Bay; (c) This will be addressed in the Environmental Impact Statement; (d) There are no current plans to move Garden Island Dockyard, H.M.A.S. Kuttabul, H.M.A.S Nirimba; H.M.A.S Watson, H.M.A.S Waterhen, the Maritime HQ (under construction) and various supporting facilities including the Navy Supply Centre at Zetland; (e) Yes; (f) Expenditure to 1988: Garden Island Dockyard $77m; Woolloomooloo car park $20m, Fleet Base facilities at Garden Island/Woolloomooloo $15m; (g) H.M.A.S Waterhen will be modernised as a base for mine countermeasures vessels. Redeployment of patrol boats hitherto based at H.M.A.S Waterhen will strengthen patrol forces in the north based at Cairns and Darwin. One patrol boat will continue to be based at H.M.A.S. Waterhen, to support the R.A.N Reserve. Upgrading or augmentation of facilities at other establishments is planned but does not amount to modernisation. Rationalisation of some relatively minor naval facilities within the Sydney metroplitan area is also under consideration.

(2) While moving half the Fleet to H.M.A.S Stirling will relieve some of the problems in Sydney for the medium term, the future growth of Sydney will impose increasing constraints on the Navy's operations there. The Government is not prepared to wait until the situation becomes unacceptable before acting on the matter.
(3) Yes. However, `smart' weapons do not necessarily contain smaller amounts of explosives than earlier weapons.
(4) An armament depot and an associated explosives wharf are required on the east coast. For safety reasons these facilities would not form part of a fleet base.
(5) Yes.

(6) The procedures under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974-75 require the Department of Defence to justify the basis for the relocation proposal and address alternatives. Those procedures, which will be fully complied with, ensure that interested organisations and individuals will have an opportunity to comment on the Department of Defence's conclusions.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Aborigines: Access to Traditional Hunting and Fishing Grounds

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, upon notice, on 15 March 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Federal Government accepted the principles for Aboriginal access to traditional hunting and fishing grounds listed by the Australian Law Reform Commission in the January 1988 edition of ``Reform'' (page 31); if so, which ones.
(2) Are there areas around Australia where access to traditional hunting and fishing grounds has been granted; if so, where, under State or Federal law and on what conditions.

(3) Does the Government have any claims for access to traditional hunting and fishing grounds before it; if so, by whom are they made, to which areas do they relate and on what conditions are the rights sought.

(4) Have rights been granted or are claims pending for grounds within national parks; if so, are there any constraints on the activities which may be carried on under the rights granted and what efforts are made to ensure that the activity conducted is not detrimental to the environment of the national parkland.
(5) When referring to rights granted or claims pending, would the Minister indicate whether they relate to Crown land, leasehold, freehold or other interests.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) These principles have been the subject of discussion between officers of the Commonwealth and are under consideration by the Government. It has not been possible, given the complexity of the issues and their application to innumerable and different local situations, to yet adopt a position in relation to them before discussions are held with the States and the Northern Territory.

(2) There is a range of Federal and State legislation relevant to the recognition of traditional hunting and fishing rights. State legislation is by far the most important and takes a number of forms. A useful summary of the operation of existing legislation is to be found in Chapter 35 of the Australian Law Reform Commission's Report on The Recognition of Aboriginal Customary Laws.
(3) I am not aware of any such claims.

(4) The National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975 (Cth), provides for the recognition of traditional hunting and gathering rights within national parks and reserves administered by the Commonwealth in the Northern Territory. These processes of that Act, as well as park management plans, generally restrict such rights so as to ensure the protection of such areas and preserve a balance between the interests of all users. Again, Chapter 35 of the abovementioned Report details the operation of individual Acts and management plans.

(5) In the case of rights relevant to National Parks administered under the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975 in the Northern Territory, the land is held by the Director of National Parks and Wildlife Service under leasehold or freehold conditions.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on a 13 April 1988:

(2) Are these appointments made on the basis that the persons concerned will serve as independent individuals rather than as formal representatives of AFCO.

(3) Does a document entitled, ``Rules for AFCO Representatives'', prepared by AFCO, rule 1 state: ``Appointees are regarded by AFCO as accountable to the Federation and obliged to act in the interest of advancing its policies''.
(4) Does the Minister agree that this AFCO rule is in conflict with the Government's requirements for appointees.
(5) What steps will the Government take to resolve this conflict of interest on the part of AFCO appointees to Government bodies.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) There are no formal Government policies in place, which have overall application, in respect of the basis on which persons are appointed to such Government bodies. In some cases the terms of appointment for appointees may require service in an individual capacity but in other cases it may be recognized that appointees represent particular organisations or interests. This will vary from body to body according to the wishes of the Minister making the appointment and, in some instances, legislative provisions pertaining to the particular body.
(3) Yes. However, I am advised by AFCO that the notes are in draft form and have been circulated to AFCO members for comment.

(4) As noted above in (2), there are no Government requirements which have universal application with which the draft rules conflict. However, the draft rules do appear to have the potential to result in some conflict in particular situations.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 18 May 1988 (Hansard, page 2399) Senator Chaney asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations, a question without notice regarding the recent number of industry claims being lodged by the trade union movement and the consistency of this approach with the wage fixation principles. In particular he asked whether the union approach was in breach of the no extra claims commitment and what the Government was doing to counter that strategy. He also asked whether the union strategy was an attempt to pre-empt the May review of the principles and present the Commission with concluded agreements and whether that could be achieved without imposing any distortion on the principles to be considered and determined in the May Review. In my reply, I undertook to refer the matter to the Minister for Industrial Relations. The Minister has provided the following response:

ANSWER.PARA: The Government is aware that the ACTU has put in a claim for a new wages system and has supported claims being progressed on an industry basis.

It is open for the ACTU to discuss or progress these claims at an industry level. This process is not precluded by the present principles nor by the May Review. The Government has, however, made it clear that discussions at the industry level should not pre-empt the outcome of the Review which is properly the responsibility of the Arbitration Commisison to determine.

The Government has also emphasised that any discussions at industry level should be conducted responsibly without recourse to industrial action. The Government is continuing its dialogue with the parties to the May Review to ensure that his occurs.

The Government would encourage the parties to discuss at industry level the means by which productivity and industry performance can be enhanced at industry and enterprise level, including better training and skills formation in the context of award restructuring.

As the President of the Commission pointed out after a preliminary conference of the Wage Review on 12 May, the current principles continue to apply during the Review of the system. The next conference commences on 7 June.
